They also criticised the central government for spending so much on US president Donald Trump’s visit while people are struggling to find a living. Sarvari will be returning to Shaheen Bagh to join the protest, while Bilkis will be travelling to Kolkata to participate in another CAA protest.

On the second day of the protest, Congress leader K Muraleedharan MP and CMP leader C P John also spoke. The Welfare Party protest in which hundreds of people lay siege to Raj Bhavan for 30 hours concluded on Wednesday evening.

Title: Hyderabad: One dead, one critical in oil plant blast in Kukatpally
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: One person died while another is in critical condition as a result of an explosion at Gulf Oil Corporation Limited’s premises on Kukatpally ’s IDL Road. A case of negligence was registered against the management.

The deceased was identified as 62-year-old Eleshwara Vasudeva Sharma, a resident of Uppal, and an employee at the company. “It was a manufacturing unit for detonators. The decased was working with the manufacturing process,” said Kukatpally inspector B Laxminarayana Reddy.

Police are yet to ascertain the cause behind the explosion. “An expert has to inspect the spot. Raju, who was standing close to the victim, is in a critical condition,” the inspector said. Three others who also sustained injuries are out of danger.

Title: Jagan to inspect progress of Polavaram project tomorrow
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Amaravati: With the works going on at full pace, Polavaram project site has got a new life with nearly 5,000 labourers working day and night.

Top officials from the irrigation department camped at the site and are monitoring the progress of the project as chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy is expected to inspect the works on Friday.

Megha Engineering and Infrastructure Limited (MEIL), the new contractor for the project, has deputed experts and senior engineers as the government is keen to complete the project ahead of the August, 2021 deadline.

The company is using advanced technology to complete 3.07 lakh cubic meters of concrete work in eight months.

The Polavaram project was launched in 2004 but then then chief minister Y S Rajasekhara Reddy’s death in 2009 slowed down the work.

Continuous movement of vehicles has set the apprehensions about the completion of the project aside. “We intended to complete the work related to the main reservoir including the spillway, earth-cum-rockfill dam by 2021 kharif season. If all goes well, we would be able to complete the works by June 2021,” said A Satish Babu, general manager, MEIL.

He said the work related to 51 blocks of spillway are critical and the company has placed sophisticated technology to overcome the hurdles. He said they have deployed enough engineers to complete the task.

Though works were re-initiated in November last year, they could not gain momentum with floods in the Godavari, resulting in the accumulation of nearly 4 tmc water at the construction site.

“Roads on the project site were damaged as the whole was submerged. It took three months for MEIL to de-water the area and rebuild the roads. Works had taken a new pace since February,” said Satish Babu.

Title: Kolkata: Conduct business but do not encroach, mayor Firhad Hakim urges hawkers
Content:
Addressing close to 2,500 hawkers at Raja Subodh Mullick Square on the golden jubilee of the National Hawker F... Read More

KOLKATA: Mayor Firhad Hakim on Wednesday pleaded with hawkers not to encroach on the pavements and urged them to discontinue using plastic sheets so as to prevent fire hazards. He also requested them to keep their stalls and the vicinity clean and not throw the waste in the open.Addressing close to 2,500 hawkers at Raja Subodh Mullick Square on the golden jubilee of the National Hawker Federation on Wednesday, Hakim assured them that he will not remove a single hawker, but make them “state-of-the-art”.“You do your business, but please do not encroach. Stay hawkers but do not become encroachers. Please do not use plastic, which not only looks ugly but is a huge fire hazard. There are so many safe options available. Use them,” Hakim said.A blaze in Bagree Market in September 2018, which had raged for over 82 hours, had started in a hawker’s stall on the pavement along Canning Street. In January last year, a fire in a stall in Gariahat had spread rapidly to a nearby building due to the plastic sheets used by the hawkers. The KMC had made a few model stalls for the hawkers after that, but they did not find many takers.“If you do not like the make and colour of the stalls we have made, give us your inputs. We will work on them. But follow the safety norms. Also, keep the area clean because we get our livelihood from there,” the mayor added.Citizens have often complained about the lack of space on the pavements which forces them to walk on the carriageway. But Hakim assured the crowd on Wednesday that nobody would remove hawkers from the streets of the city. “You have the right to do your business there. We will bring people from abroad to showcase our street food vendors,” he said.Hakim also hailed the green e-commerce platform Hawker Bazar, which was launched on Wednesday evening. It will enable consumers to order food from their favourite vendor in the vicinity through an app available on Google Play Store. The green e-commerce platform using Borlaug blockchain will also enable the hawkers to source provisions directly from the producers. Speaking of the app, Hakim said it will also aid in freeing up pavements since many of the regulars will be able to just order the food online instead of taking up space to eat at the specific stalls.“This will create a level playing field for our street food vendors who suffer due to lack of resources and knowhow. It will also benefit lakhs of office goers who can have fresh and economically priced food in their offices,” said Hakim.

Title: Ahmedabad: She team gets man-handled, 1 held
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A She team of Naorda police station patrolling at night in plain clothes were in for a shock as they were assaulted and pelted with stones by a mob near Chiloda Ring Road on Tuesday, according to the FIR filed by them.

The trouble started when the She team, comprisingly mainly of women cops, quizzed a man, Nishant Barot, of Bapunagar, who was standing under suspected circumstances near a car. Barot, according to the FIR, was defiant and asked in turn pointing at his purse, “I have money. Wll you come with me to Pritam Hotel?” Taken aback with the obscene behaviour, the members of the She team flashed their identity cards at him. When Barot realized he had invited trouble, he attempted to turn the tables on the cops yelling ‘fake police’. This attracted locals who rushed to his rescue.

The FIR named one Ashok Patel, his wife Shweta Patel, Jhanvi Patel and about 100-150 people who gheraoed the cops. All persons mentioned have been booked for assault. The She team claims they were shoved and jostled by the crowd and assaulted. Head constable of the team, Harita Rajeshbhai, called up the police station and asked for help. “Other teams arrived and dispersed the crowd by use of force,” the FIR stated. ACP G division, A M Desai said, “We have arrested Nishant Barot and are searching for the rest.” In the FIR, complainant Harita Rajeshbhai has claimed that in front of the She team members the five accused tore her dress. They also manhandled with her and her colleagues.

Title: Amaravati Protest News: Wedding pandal is latest venue for Amaravati protests
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

venue shift: A newly-wed couple holds placards against the shifting of capital from Amaravati, in Guntur distr... Read More

AMARAVATI: The locals’ bond with capital city Amaravati is such that they are not hesitating to raise their voice for one capital city even during weddings.

The people of the capital city area, who have been relentlessly participating in agitations for Amaravati, took protests to the next level on Wednesday when a newly-wed couple and their family members sported placards in favour of Amaravati. The bridegroom Jammula Sudheer, native of Guntur, is working as an accounts executive at a private firm. He tied knot with girl from Thullur village on Wednesday. An activist of Telugu Desam Party (TDP), Sudheer decided to make his wedding a memorable by making family members and friends raise their voice for Amaravati.

J Malleswara Rao, Sudheer’s father, said that it was not proper for the state government to undermine the sacrifice of the capital city farmers. He said that people from all districts were extending support to the cause of Amaravati as it was the peoples’ capital city. The friends and family members of the wedding couple have also shouted slogans demanding that the state government retain Amaravati as single capital city of the state.

Meanwhile, former minister Somireddy Chandramohan Reddy, who participated in the farmers dharna in Mandadam village, said that Amaravati would surely tighten the noose around the YSRC government. He said that BJP leaders were insulting the Prime Minister Narendra Modi by backing Jagan on the issue of three capital cities as Modi had laid the foundation stone for Amaravati. He said that they would bring the capital city back to Amaravati even if Jagan shifted it. He said that the firms which entered into agreements with CRDA, state government and Centre would drag the present government to court and retain the capital city in Amaravati. “YSRC leaders compared Amaravati with burial ground. How could they distribute house sites to the poor in Amaravati? Do they want the poor to live in the burial ground?” Somireddy asked.

Former minister Nakka Anand Babu warned the police not to take the law into their hands as they would surely land in trouble in future. He said that police were deliberately implicating the commoners in the false cases just for opposing the government’s decisions.

Title: It took colours to bring back hope to his parents
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Seeing their son Himal paint, at a time when even holding a fork seemed like an impossible task, Harish Bikmal and his wife realised their son was on a path of inspiration. Himal was diagnosed with severe non-verbal autism at the age of two but his art has inspired his father Harish, a native of Hyderabad now settled in Virginia to co-found Zenaviv. The initiative provides a platform that promotes and empowers people with autism to showcase their artistic talents.

As parents of a child diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), Harish and his wife Sandhya had to face a lot of difficulties with Himal constantly falling sick due to a compromised immune system. With the recurring health problems, the couple was worried about their son’s future. On two instances, Himal had run away from home. He was unable to communicate, resorting to crying and shouting to express his discomfort. These incidents only made the distress of his parents mount further. They were running out of hope.

However one fine day, while Himal’s mother was painting, he snatched her paintbrush away. But what he did next surprised his parents. He started painting. At this time, Himal was around ten-years-old and even holding cutlery was a challenge for him. While he went to work on the canvas, his parents realised that this expression of his was their ray of hope. Since that day, they decided to nurture their son’s talent and even found an art teacher to help him pursue his passion.

“A few years back, there was no insurance to cover children with autism. With medical bills mounting, we decided to organise a fundraiser showcasing Himal’s artwork. His paintings were converted into around 1,500 postcards and within two hours, they were all sold out. As many as 130 of his paintings were sold in a span of six hours,” Harish Bikmal told TOI. “Himal could not understand what was going on but his face would light up every time someone came up and paid him a compliment. This is what inspired me to establish Zenaviv,” Himal’s father added.

“The love for painting empowered Himal. He would smile when he would paint and would even insist we clicked a picture of him with his painting. We thought that if painting can transform the life of our child, we can help parents of other children with a similar condition to find their passion and purpose. Our goal is to improve the self-esteem of children with special needs by helping them showcase their talents to the world and change the perception of parents,” Harish said.

Now all of 18 years, Himal is undergoing training for table tennis, taekwondo and fitness. It requires patience to try out different things and recognise the potential of a child with special needs and Harish asserts that there is always a possibility for things to get better. “Not every child will have an interest in painting. Some may be talented in playing instruments and some could be good at swimming,” Harish says adding that the visual memory in children is very strong and it is essential to focus on the strengths of one’s child.

Title: ‘My mother’s family completely wiped out’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Jaipur: “My mother’s family has been completely wiped out,” said a tearful Ramdev Dhobi, whose elder brother too died in the tragic accident in Bundi on Wednesday morning. Ramdev’s maternal family was going to attend a wedding and he himself was supposed to join them in Sawai Madhopur.

Ramdev’s brother Ramesh was one of the passengers killed in the mishap and talking to TOI, the bereaved said, “My uncles, aunts, cousins, real brother and other relatives were going to Sawai Madhopur to attend a wedding function but this tragedy occurred. I was supposed to join them at the wedding. My brother had gone earlier to travel with the relatives.”

Ramdev further claimed that 27 of his family members died in the accident, though officials have said that 24 persons, including the driver, were killed. “There were 34 of my relatives in the bus out of which 27 have died,” said Ramdev while choking on his tears.

Ramdev further added that the shock is unbearable for the rest of the family, who are unable to believe that what was supposed to be a happy occasion has turned into such a tragedy. “I really don’t know what to say anymore. My ‘nanihal’ (relatives from maternal family) is completely gone just like that and it is the most difficult time for us,” he added.

Title: God is great, says retired IPS DG Vanzara after promotion
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

DG Vanzara

AHMEDABAD: After he got a clean chit in both Sohrabuddin Shaikh-Tulsiram Prajapati and Ishrat encounter cases , former IPS officer DG Vanzara was given the long awaited promotion of Inspector General of Police ( IGP) with effect from September 29, 2007. He will get arrears from the deemed date of promotion.

Vanzara tweeted about his post retirement promotion also tagging the order from the government on Tuesday. “God is great. I had done nothing wrong but only protected Gujarat from terrorism,” Vanzara told TOI on Wednesday.

Vanzara, 66, who retired in May 2014 while he was in Sabarmati Central jail in connection with the Ishrat encounter case, said he is hopeful that he will soon get his ‘due’ promotion for the rank of ADGP. Vanzara, in his tweet, thanked both central and state government for the promotion.

Vanzara’s son Prithviraj Vanzara also tweeted and expressed his pleasure that his father got what he deserved. He also expressed immense pleasure and gratitude towards the governments.

Vanzara, who had joined the police service as a deputy superintendent of police (DySP) in 1980, was promoted as an IPS officer in 1987. He served as deputy commissioner of police of Ahmedabad crime branch and was later promoted as DIG of anti terrorism squad (ATS) in Ahmedabad. At the time of his arrest on April 24, 2007, he was posted as the Border Range of Kutch and Banaskantha.

Sohrabuddin Sheikh was killed in November 2005 and Tulsiram Prajapati was shot dead in December 2006. Vanzara was arrested in both these cases by the state CID (crime). Later, these cases were handed over to CBI for further probe and merged together. While in prison, Vanzara was arrested again by CBI in another encounter case in which Mumbai-based 19-year-old girl Ishrat Jahan, Javed Shaikh alias Pranesh Pillai, Amjad Ali Rana and Zishan Johar were killed in June 2004.

Title: Spandan: Students regale with spell-binding moves
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Varanasi: The fourth day of the inter-faculty youth cultural festival Spandan-2020 commenced with beautifully coordinated, rhythmic moves of participants at the creative dance competition held at the Amphitheatre stage on Wednesday.

As many as 23 participants presented their innovative performances based on several prevalent social issues. A classical solo dance competition was also held at Pandit Omkarnath Thakur Auditorium. Students from over 23 faculties gave performances in classical dance forms including Odissi, Kuchipudi, Bharatnatyam and Kathak.

A quiz competition was also held at the department of Journalism and Mass Communication in which six groups, each having three members, competed.

A sketch competition was held at the faculty of visual arts in which 23 participants took part while a poetry recitation was held at the Institute of Medical Science and a collage competition was held at the Exhibition Hall, department of visual arts. Eleven teams took part in short play competition at Swatantrata Bhawan. Other events held on the day included mimicry, classical vocal solo and western group song competition.

Title: Foundation laid for 100-bed ESI hospital
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Minister of state for labour and employment Santosh Kumar Gangwar laid the foundation stone for a 100-bed ESI hospital, which will be constructed with Rs 110 crore, in Kakinada on Wednesday.

Speaking on the occasion, Gangwar said with the objective of workers’ welfare, 154 hospitals, 1,500 dispensaries, 815 branch offices, 65 regional and sub-regional offices are working under ESI.

He said the 100-bed hospital will be built in 7.26 acres and benefit 63,000 workers and 2.45 lakh family members in Kakinada and Yanam region. He assured that the Centre will extend every possible support to ESI hospitals in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

He said, the Centre is giving utmost priority to the three and half crore workers and their 12 crore family members who are dependent on them. The expenditure is borne by the workers through their contribution from their wages even though the Centre has sanctioned 100-bed hospital in Kakinada.

Her appreciated the fact that the maintenance of ESI hospitals in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana states are the best in the country and added that Hyderabad hospital is the best in the country.

He said workers and managements are contributing 1.25% and 4.25%, respectively. With the total of six percent and informed that this total has been reduced to four per cent.

Title: When skilled workers graduate
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Chennai: It’s no longer just word of mouth that will endorse the work of 40-year-old S Devaraji, a construction labourer for a little more than two decades, he now has a certificate to validate his skills as a mason.

Under the programme by the Tamil Nadu Skill Development Corporation ( TNSDC ) of the labour ministry, unorganised sector workers like Devaraji can now receive national and international validated certificates. The government’s grassroots initiative ensures better employability of youth in the country and abroad and keeps a ready trained resource pool that it can select from when projects come up. For the workers it means being trained for free in workshops that help them pick up tips, gives them recognition and an avenue to ask for better pay depending on their expertise.

"I have been working for more than 20 years and learned the nuances of the vocation, but no document to prove my expertise. Now, I am happy I have a certificate, and that too from the government," said Devaraj from Kalandra village in Tirupattur district.

Devaraji, along with 20 others, underwent a three-day training programme organised by TNSDC. "We learned to measure the exact ratio of preparing the concrete mixture and the amount of moisture that should be used to ensure crack free walls and what should be done before erecting wooden frames to keep away termites," said Devaraji.

A few hundred miles away, G Babu of Colachel in Kanyakumari district is a proud owner of a certificate that describes him as a decorative painter. "This document will allow small-time workers like me to avail loans and take up contract work," he said.

The programme is aimed at creating a registry of skilled workforce in the unorganised sector, enhance their skills and improve their earning capacity. So far, 58,776 people have received such certificates, majority of them construction labourers, painters and fishermen. "The Union government had signed several memorandums of understanding with various foreign countries to consider the validation certificates of the workforce from India. Hence, it will be an advantage for the workers who aspire to go abroad," said V Vishnu, managing director of TNSDC.

Nearly 2,000 fishermen from Chennai and neighbouring coastal districts have enrolled in the programme and trained in marine aquaculture. They were trained in repairing boats, deep sea fishing and other nuances of fishing to improve their inherent skills. "Experts have sailed with the fishermen to assess their skills. Similarly, experts of each trade visit the worksite of the workers and assess their knowledge before certifying them. The certification will add value to avail government welfare schemes and subsidies under various schemes," said Vishnu.

Apart from the traditional sectors, the Ramnad district administration has been training youngsters to be guides under the programme. "Tourism is a thriving industry in the district as it receives 1 crore pilgrims and tourists every year," said collector K Veera Raghava Rao.

The TNSDC has also envisaged sharing the registry with the Overseas Manpower Corporation (OMC), a government agency, to help certified workers find jobs abroad. The agency has inked a pact with the Indian Trade and Exhibition Centre at Sharjah, Health Education England and a few other industries in foreign countries to generate employment for the youth of TN. Authorities in OMC have stated a minimum of 500 nurses would be placed in health sector in the UK for the next three years. Apart from this, they would also employ a minimum of 1,000 people every year in different trades and industries in the UAE and its neighbouring countries.

Title: City sweet makers to meet FSSAI over ‘best-before’ rule
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Kolkata: The recent order from the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI), asking all sweet manufacturers to print the manufacturing date of their sweets and “best before” declarations, has put city sweet manufacturers in a fix. They will now be going to meet the FSSAI bosses in Delhi on March 4 and 5 to look for a solution to the problem. It is likely that the state will support the Paschim Banga Mistanna Byabasayee Samiti in this and send a representative to attend the meeting.

Most of the big sweet makers in Kolkata, however, said they understand the intent of the FSSAI and support the move because this will stop “smaller” manufacturers from trying to sell stale sweets, which are often “covered in thick sugar syrup to hide their staleness”. The declaration of manufacturing and best-before dates will definitely put a stop to this, they felt. However, they agreed there were some logistical issues that need to be sorted out as well.

The meeting will be part of Ahara, a national food festival, to which city sweet manufacturers have been invited. “It is known that Bengal sweets are made of chhana, unlike mawa that is used by sweet makers of other provinces. Chhana as a raw material is extremely fragile and decays after 24 hours so we do not sell sweets that are beyond a day old. We are already writing “to be consumed within 24 hours” on our products,” said Dhiman Das, spokesperson for K C Das.

Most bigger brands said some sweets and their manufacturing processes are so delicate that they spoil within hours. In peak summer, rosomalai and rosogolla, if left unrefrigerated, can spoil in eight hours. “We mentally keep tabs on this. Now we will have to declare it. However, writing them on shelves and on boxes are two different ball games and involve additional hassles,” said Subhojit Ghosh of Banchharam. He insisted that because of the short shelf life of Bengal sweets, it is still considered a cottage industry that needs all the support it can get to survive.

Most sweet manufacturers said the inclusion of Bengal sweets within the GST net has already affected the industry because of the huge cost involved in upgrading accounts. But if the FSSAI declaration involves a complicated process, it will further affect business.

“We want the process to be uncomplicated. At the time of manufacture, we keep back-end records of each batch and we know when to stop selling which tray. We don’t mind declaring it, but we are a bit confused about the process,” Ghosh added.

A spokesperson for the 200-year-old brand Nalin Chandra Das echoed the thought. “We have received the circular to give these declarations by June 1. We don’t mind and we agree that customers have a right to know how healthy the sweet is. However, if we are once again channelled into complications, we will suffer,” said proprietor Tapan Kumar Das.

Title: No more bumpy ride in Secunderabad: 15 gravel stretches to turn into cement concrete roads
Content:
Commuters and activists emphasised on the need to restore such stretches as they pose a threat to motorists

SECUNDERABAD: As many as 15 gravel stretches are slated for conversion into cement concrete roads in Musheerabad , Secunderabad , Malkajgiri and Amberpet circles .“The 15 stretches in Secunderabad run up to almost four kilometres and are being laid at a cost of Rs 2.89 crore,” said a Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) official.Speaking to TOI, resident welfare associations, commuters and activists emphasised on the need to restore such stretches as they pose a threat to motorists. “Chances of vehicles skidding on such roads is more. The friction is unstable and should a motorist apply brakes in an emergency, he may end up hurting himself,” said BT Srinivasan of the United Federation of Resident Welfare Associations (UFERWAS). “I urge authorities to convert the existing gravel stretches near Sitaramnagar Colony in Malkajgiri to CC roads too,” he added.Another resident from Alwal urged authorities to inspect the by-lanes in residential areas and take appropriate measures where needed. “Gravel stretches haunt commuters who frequent the by-lanes of Alwal, Secunderabad and Malkajgiri. I request GHMC to take inputs from resident welfare associations and carry out restoration on these stretches,” said PM Sai Prasad, an activist from Alwal. “The visibility is also poor due to the dust that rises from these gravel stretches,” said another activist, Harish Daga.Restoration work on gravel stretches is being carried out across the twin cities. “A total of 580 stretches covering a little over 291 kilometres are being restored at a cost of Rs 170.7 crore. To speed up work, a special budget requirement is to be obtained from GHMC zonal commissioners,” read a statement by the civic body.

Title: Savarkar a role model, an ideology in himself: JP Nadda
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

File photo of BJP president JP Nadda

NEW DELHI: BJP president JP Nadda on Wednesday hailed Veer Damodar Savarkar as one of the greatest freedom fighters, saying he fought bravely against the British regime all his life and sacrificed each moment in service of the motherland.

“Savarkar was a visionary, a great hero of the freedom movement and I feel blessed to take part in an event in his memory,” Nadda said addressing a gathering through video-conferencing on the 54th death anniversary of the saffron ideologue at Ambedker Research Centre. Nadda was the chief guest for the event but could not come due to family engagements.

The NJP chief said Savarkar was a role model, a revolutionary and an ideology in himself and his dedication for the motherland was inspirational. “He (Savarkar) was one of the pioneers of a meaningful thinking. He shook the British by his flawless review of history. He was unique among revolutionaries,” he said.

Speaking on the occasion, actor-director Srirang Godbole said the government must name a nuclear submarine after Savarkar. “Why not INS Savarkar, INS Munje and INS Subhash?” he said.

The two-day conference commemorated Savarkar’s social, political, religious and ideological works with speakers being unanimously saying that he was castigated despite his contribution to the country.

Union culture and tourism minister Prahlad Singh Patel said, “If evaluation of work and role has to be done, it should be done for all. Savarkar did not get his due but it is our duty that we must strive to get him his due.”

Former Gujarat and Madhya Pradesh governor O P Kohli said Savarkar was the person who had first recognised 1857 movement as the “First War of Independence” and made Hinduism synonymous with nationalism.

Rajya Sabha MP Swapan Dasgupta said besides many other qualities of Savarkar, his being a political Hindu caused annoyance among many, especially Congress and other political outfits.

Title: Government chief whip lashes out at N Chandrababu Naidu
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu

VIJAYAWADA: Government chief whip G Srikanth Reddy and Mangalagiri MLA Alla Ramakrishna Reddy lashed out at TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu on Wednesday for his remarks on assigned lands. Naidu has been targeting the YSRC government for acquiring assigned lands for giving house sites to the poor.

Talking to reporters, they said Naidu, who is now crying foul over assigned lands, himself had issued a GO mandating that such lands can be sold, while former chief minister YS Rajasekhara Reddy had brought in a legislation that lands given to weaker sections can neither be purchased nor sold.

“Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has declared Amaravati capital region as ‘people’s capital’ and ‘bahujana capital’ to bring in the concept of inclusiveness and give a sense of pride to those living in the area cutting across caste, creed, and religion. While the government is going ahead with the unique exercise of distributing house site pattas to the poor, Naidu has turned green with jealously and is instigating people to file a 1,500-page PIL, which shows his character and intent,” they alleged.

Title: Bus operators protest, dividers at Talapady tollgate removed
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Private city bus operators stage a flash protest over installation of dividers at Talapady toll gate on Wednes... Read More

Mangaluru: Chaos prevailed at Talapady tollgate on Wednesday after private city bus operators staged a flash protest over installation of dividers at the tollgate.

The dividers hindered the movement of city buses, which take a U-turn before the Talapady tollgate, to avoid toll. However, the dividers were removed after the police intervened. The tussle between toll booth operators and city private bus owners has been going on from sometime now, ever since implementation of FASTag .

Due to the fee issue, city buses on the Mangaluru-Talapady route have been cutting short their trips, the last 100 metres, to avoid the tollgate at Talapady, after implementation of FASTag.

Dilraj Alva, president of the Dakshina Kannada Bus Operators’ Association said on Wednesday that all of a sudden toll booth operators have installed dividers across toll booths, making it difficult to take a turn from the Talapady tollgate. “Irked with this sudden development, which was done to harass city buses, we staged a protest, and after the police interveded, the same was removed,” he said, adding that the MP and DC asked toll operators to maintain the status quo, till a final decision is taken on the toll fee.

Dilraj explained that about 28 city buses ply to Talapady every day. Before the implementation of FASTag, all the vehicles were passing by the toll gate for free. The distance between Talapady toll gate to the last stop is about a km. “Now tollbooth operators are demanding a fee of Rs 30,000 per month for each bus but we are negotiating to pay Rs 4,500. A bus operator cannot pay such a huge amount as toll fee each month and sustain business,” he said.

Jurisdictional police said that a meeting between bus operators and toll booth contractors is scheduled on Saturday to decide about the toll fee.

‘Shift Surathkal tollgate’

Karanam Uma Maheshwar Rao, director, National Institute of Technology Karnataka Surathkal on Tuesday requested Union minister of human resources development (HRD) Ramesh Pokhriyal to shift the toll gate in front of the 60-year-old technical institution.

He said that the toll gate is causing inconvenience to NITK Surathkal staff and students. It is important to shift the Surathkal toll gate due to safety concerns, especially for girl students. NITK Surathkal was the first institution to protest against the toll booth, citing security and safety of the students as well as children, who study at the school on campus. However, the authorities never gave paid heed to their plea. The tollgate is 12m away from the technical institution, which has around 5,500 students. Also, nearly 1,200 children from LKG to high school study in Kannada and English medium schools situated in the same campus.

The campus is spread on both sides of the road. Since 2011, NITK authorities have written more than six letters to the district administration and chief secretary of the state government.

Title: Cabinet gives nod to eco-sensitive zone in Rajaji National Park
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Dehradun: The Uttarakhand cabinet , chaired by chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat, approved a separate eco-sensitive zone (ESZ) inside the Rajaji National Park on Wednesday.

According to government sources, around 296 of 819 square kilometres of Rajaji National Park would come under the eco-sensitive zone. Also, 22 out of a total of 825 villages situated in the national park area would be part of the eco-sensitive zone.

The cabinet also gave its nod to the introduction of self-assessment tax system for house tax in municipalities and nagar panchayats in the state. The amended Act for change in self-assessment tax system would be introduced in the assembly during the upcoming budget session. The new system would be applicable in 41 municipalities and nagar panchayats in the state. Till now, the self-assessment tax in property or house tax was only enforced in municipal corporations in the state.

The decision to introduce the system was brought with an aim to improve the financial conditions of municipalities and nagar panchayats.

The cabinet also decided to provide incentives to private insemination centres for artificial insemination of animals in all 13 districts of the state. According to government sources, an incentive of Rs 50 would be provided in the hills and Rs 40 in plains.

The cabinet also approved the bill that gives power to the state government to close down slaughter houses in the districts.

Meanwhile, the Van Gujjar community in Haridwar, which lives near Rajaji, welcomed the cabinet’s decision on the eco-sensitive zone and said that it would help the community to sort out their long-pending rehabilitation problem.

The state cabinet had around two weeks back, approved a 377 sqkm area for the proposed eco-sensitive zone for the Corbett Tiger Reserve (CTR) as well. No village was included in the ESZ, for which the maximum area was defined as 7.96 km. The creation of ESZ in Corbett has been a prickly issue, with villagers living near the reserve often protesting against the inclusion of their respective villages in the ESZ fearing loss of livelihood due to the restrictions imposed by the creation of such a zone. To recall, the Uttarakhand high court had earlier directed that a 10km-area around CTR as well as other sanctuaries in Uttarakhand be declared as ESZ.

Title: Library board’s 2020-21 budget gets official nod
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: GVMC commissioner G Srijana conducted a meeting with various committees of the district library board in the capacity of person-in-charge of the board here at the GVMC office on Wednesday.

Speaking on the occasion, Srijana asked the library committees to seek quotations from the local marketplace before purchasing any stationery, furniture and other items and compare them with the government e-marketplace. “The committees can choose a marketplace based on the pricing,” said Srijana.

Srijana suggested the committees to buy more books related to personality development, competitive exams and those useful to the society.

She directed them to take measures to collect the cess due from various government organisations by sending letters to them. The committee approved the 2020-21 budget for the maintenance of district libraries with proposed receipts of Rs 20.6 crore and expenditure receipts of Rs 15.6 crore.

The committee unanimously approved the revised budget of 2019-20 with receipts of Rs 14.15 crore and expenditure of Rs 9.22 crore.

Title: Vasco’s polar research centre inks MoU with Canadian facility for summer collaboration
Content: PANAJI: In what could be considered the beginning of a long and productive collaboration between India and Canada for research on polar science, the Vasco-based National Centre for Polar and Ocean Research (NCPOR) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Polar Knowledge Canada (POLAR).NCPOR director, Dr M Ravichandran has welcomed the Canadian institute’s scientists to India’s Arctic stations and in return, POLAR would be hosting Indian researchers in the Canadian Arctic.“Our next step would be to tap the concrete areas of research that Indian scientists would like to undertake in Canada’s Arctic. Simultaneously, to get the Canadian Antarctic research community thinking about what kind of collaborative opportunities to undertake with the Indian Antarctic programme and the two stations that currently operate in the Antarctic,” said POLAR president and CEO, David Scott who is currently in Goa.Over the coming months POLAR will be working with the NCPOR and its researchers to identify specific opportunities to work with in the Canadian Arctic.“Our peak season is between June and August. I would anticipate hosting quite a number of Indian scientists in the Canadian Arctic this northern summer,” Scott said. He said that since Canada has approximately one quarter of the arctic territory of the world, they’re looking forward to collaborate with NCPOR to undertake research in the Canadian Arctic wherein the scientists will work in and around the community of Cambridge bay where POLAR’s research facility is based.“We can have small day trips that will take us 10-15 km away from the station and in future we anticipate going even further away into more remote locations and set up a temporary camp and do various investigations, particularly in places which have the right characteristics for scientists to make observations,” he said.“Canada is very happy to be working in collaboration with India. Our countries worked together on several levels but as we get more detailed for Polar Knowledge Canada, it’s a real privilege to be creating a partnership with the NCPOR. The high-quality scientists on this research campus are well-equipped with the latest analytical machinery and experts,” he said.“India really is a polar nation that has been studying the Antarctic for years and is becoming increasingly active in the Arctic ,” he added.

Title: Goa:‘Stand like a rock behind the govt’, says BJP’s spokesperson Sambit Patra
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Sambit Patra

PANAJI: Condemning the “atmosphere created by CAA protesters during US President Donald Trump’s visit”, BJP’s national spokesperson Sambit Patra said that the protesters, who were until now conspiring against Prime Minister Narendra Modi, may start conspiring against the country.

“The BJP wants peace,” said Patra, who was in the state capital for an interaction with Goa’s legislators, businessmen and other prominent citizens on Wednesday.

He said that the protesters were trying to blackmail the government to backtrack on CAA, just as Rajiv Gandhi’s government was blackmailed during the Shah Bano case.

“No one wanted to touch the CAA issue or the abrogation of article 370, with a barge-pole. When a government finally takes decisions on such big issues, some are bound to find it difficult to digest it. They will try to bring instability, not just in the government, but in the country. You have to stand like a rock behind the government,” said Patra.

He said that between 1989 and 2019, 48,000 people had died due to terrorism sponsored by Pakistan.

He said since Pakistan’s creation, the number of its minorities had dropped from 23% to just 1.5% today, while the minority population in India has risen from 9% to 16% since its independence.

“This is an indication of how well India has treated its minorities,” Patra said.

In the case of Goa, infrastructure gets a huge boost only when the BJP is in power in the state, he said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Traffic cops book two for ‘hurting police’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 32-year-old man and his elder brother were booked for “hurting cops” when they allegedly got into a scuffle in which two buttons of a traffic cop’s uniform were torn. Ironically, they were booked for ‘causing hurt’ at the traffic police station where the cops are deployed, even though traffic police are not supposed to register such case but send them to local police station.

Late on Tuesday evening, a garment trader from the Jamalpur area, Rizwan Pathan was travelling on his scooter near Raykhad. He crossed the stop-line when signal was closed. A traffic cop came to him and told him to take his scooter behind the stop-line, said an official of Gaekwad Haveli police.

Rizwan alleged that the traffic cop abused him while directing him to take his scooter behind the stop-line. This irked Rizvan who got into a quarrel with the cop. The traffic cop began abusing Rizwan and told him to park his vehicle on roadside to file a legal case against him.

Meanwhile, Rizwan called up his elder brother Sarfaraz who reached there in around 10 minutes and tried to negotiate with the cops. Rizwan began shooting a video of the traffic cop and other three policemen who were arguing aggressively with Sarfaraz.

One of the four cops spotted Rizwan and he along with others held him and began beating him. Sarfaraz was forced to sit inside an autorickshaw. But as he insisted to take his brother along, he too was beaten by the cops, said a police official.

The FIR filed with Gakwad Haveli police mentions that Rizwan and Sarfaraz were attacked by four cops in which Rizwan suffered wounds. But as he went to Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel hospital in the Ellisbridge area, a medico legal case was registered and later city police filed an FIR against four cops. As Rizwan’s FIR was registered with Gaekwad Haveli police, one of the four cops – Jagdishsinh Mohabbatsinh filed a complaint of causing hurt with E Traffic police where he has been deployed.

The FIR filed by traffic police also accused their own TRB (Traffic Regulation Brigade) jawan, Danish Naseer of abetment as the TRB jawan was repeatedly telling other cops that the duo live in his neighbourhood Jagdishsinh maintained in the FIR that the two tore off his uniform’s buttons and they had suffered injury accidentally as they fell on a table.

Title: Rs 500-crore GST racket busted, 2 held in Kolkata
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The city zonal unit of the Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGI) on Tuesday unearthed a GST fraud of Rs 500 crore over multiple transactions. This was the fifth major case unearthed by the unit. Two persons were arrested in the case.

The accused is believed to be the brain behind the money laundering operation. They were produced at Sealdah court that remanded them to judicial custody till March 6. DGGI has also recovered Rs 5.8 crore from two firms. The total GST credit involved in the cobweb of transactions was Rs 96 crore.

According to DGGI, on scrutiny of the returns and documents, it prepared to carry out simultaneous search operations at 10 locations. These were, however, found to be non-existent. The companies existed only on paper and they were involved in the passage of fake invoices without supply of goods and services. “Hence, a huge amount of fake input tax credit was passed on to recipient companies across India who availed this fake credit of GST to meet their tax obligations, thus depriving the government of revenue,” a DGGI spokesperson said.

The money was paid through RTGS, to make the transactions appear regular, which was subsequently recircu-lated through a complex web of entities keeping the commission amount.

Title: Major Andhra Pradesh cities likely to get whitetopped roads
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The white-topping of road is widely accepted as the solution to preventing formation of potholes and making th... Read More

VISAKHAPATNAM: The government is planning to introduce whitetopping of roads in major cities, including Visakhapatnam .

Whitetopping of roads have already been introduced in cities such as Hyderabad, Bengaluru, Chennai and Delhi. The government has planned to adopt the new model on a pilot basis at select cities wherein the rate of damage to roads and vehicular traffic is high.

Speaking to TOI, state roads and buildings minister Dharmana Krishna Das said the whitetopping of roads is currently at the planning stage and there was no official proposal for the project so far. However, the government would study existing whitetopped roads in Hyderabad, Telangana and take a decision on it.

“We will discuss the viability of white-topping the roads with the officials concerned soon,” Krishna Das told TOI.

Jose Kurian, from Indian Concrete Institute (ICI), a national organisation of engineering professionals employed in concrete construction, said white-topping is the best alternative to check common problems in asphalt roads like potholes, especially, during monsoons.

Kurian said white-topping road is the covering of asphalt surface with a layer (approximately 100mm to 150mm) of concrete.

“The white-topping of road is widely accepted as the solution to preventing formation of potholes and making them durable. Not only will it reduce the number of accidents and causalities caused by potholes but also significantly enhance the driving comfort and save fuel,” Kurian added.

Speaking to TOI, Kurian said the cost of white-topping of roads would be nearly 25% more than laying asphalt roads, but the durability is guaranteed for nearly 25 years.

“We are ready to extend any technological support to any constructor, including the government, in white-topping project,” Kurian said while adding that the Kerala government would be converting nearly 1,400kms of asphalt roads into white-topped roads.

Title: Kolkata: College goes plastic-free, sets up vertical garden
Content:
Colleges across the city have banned plastic and combined eco-friendly measures with education to promote sust... Read More

KOLKATA: J D Birla Institute on Lower Rawdon Street has made its campus plastic-free and set up vertical gardens, creating horticulture spaces with rainwater harvesting facilities. The Nature Club of the college conducts regular workshops to tackle plastic menace. Also, segregation of waste on the campus is strictly followed.“We have provided our students with bags made of eco-friendly material. They can use these instead of polythene bags. We conduct workshops and awareness sessions on how to eliminate plastic. Even the Saraswati Puja on the campus is organized using eco-friendly materials. We have vertical gardens in the campus made with plastic bottles contributed by our students. If any plastic waste is generated it is handed over to a specialized outfit, which earns us green credits,” JD Birla Institute principal Deepali Singhee said.In fact, several colleges across the city have banned plastic and combined eco-friendly measures with education to promote sustainable environmental practices.At Presidency University, use of plastic carry bags has been discontinued. But authorities admit they need to introduce more environment-friendly measures. Authorities at Ballygunge Science College, University of Calcutta, use paper bags and eco-friendly material at official functions and plastic bags are not used in the canteens. “We use paper bags and envelopes at functions. Material like styrofoam are prohibited,” said Samprikta Bose, an environmental science post-graduation student at Ballygunge Science College.In August last year, the University Grants Commission had directed colleges and universities to discontinue use of plastic on the campus and introduce eco-friendly measures to promote sustainable environmental practices.Bhawanipur Education Society authorities have replaced plastic bags with jute ones. At Heritage Institute of Technology, there are separate bins across the campus to segregate waste. The campus also has a 100kW solar power plant, which caters to a substantial part of the power requirement at the institute, cutting its electricity cost.“We discourage the use of plastic on the campus. There is a robust recycling facility. We also have rainwater harvesting facilities. We adhere to all the norms of the green building standards. We also hold frequent awareness sessions,” said Pradip Agarwal, CEO, Heritage Institute of Technology.Rajabazar Science College, too, has started using eco-friendly material instead of plastic.At Presidency University and Jadavpur University the authorities are formulating guidelines pertaining to the use of plastic and other non-biodegradable materials.

Title: Defence pension adalat tomorrow
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The office of the defence pension disbursement office (DPDO), Visakhapatnam, under the controller of defence accounts, Chennai, will be holding a defence pension adalat in the premises of DPDO, Area Account Office (Navy) compound, Vinod Nagar on February 28.

Defence pensioners, defence family pensioners, including commissioned officers, defence civilians, coast guard, GREF/ DAD personnel residing in Andhra Pradesh may attend the pension adalat for settlement of pension-related grievances.

Pensioners residing in Visakhapatnam and surrounding areas need to submit their pension related complaints in English (in duplicate) on February 28 between 10 am to 5 pm or send in advance through speed post in the name of G Changalrao, mini pension adalat officer, DPDO, AAO (Navy) Visakhapatnam. For more details, one may contact telephone number 0891-2702790 or submit their grievances in advance through email on ID: dpdovisakhapatnam@gmail.com.

Pensioners should quote their name, rank, group, regimental number, PPO (pension payment order) number, details of bank/ treasury, unit/ name and address of record office/head office, specific grievance, date of discharge and their address with telephone numbers. tnn

Title: Chandrababu Naidu: TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu in Port City today
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

N Chandrababu Naidu

VISAKHAPATNAM: TDP president Nara Chandrababu Naidu is set to visit the Port City on February 27 and 28.

Naidu will first visit Pentavani Cheruvu at Pinagadi village and interact with the farmers living in areas where land is being pooled. Later, he will visit Vizianagaram district where he will address the public at various places and return to Visakhapatnam . He would attend the wedding of former minister Ayyannapatrudu’s younger son on February 28 and leave for Hyderabad.

YSRC leaders are preparing to hold a protest at the airport on Thursday to question him on why he is against setting up the executive capital in Visakhapatnam.

Meanwhile, TDP Greater Visakha president Vasupalli Ganesh Kumar has alleged that welfare schemes introduced in TDP’s government were stalled in the nine-month rule of YSRC. Ganesh, who is also an MLA, said that around 43,000 people were identified as beneficiaries for the housing scheme and were given pattas or required documents during the TDP government through the then GVMC commissioner M Harinarayan But now the number of beneficiaries have been reduced to 24,000, he alleged. The YSRC government has been forcibly pooling land for the construction of housing for the poor, he accused. “Is there any meaning in it, taking land of the poor and distributing or construction of houses for the poor,” he criticized.

Title: NU postpones MCom third semester exams
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: RTM Nagpur University (NU) has decided to postpone the M.Com third semester exam to March 21 as the late results of previous semester left very little time on students’ hands.

Earlier, NU had scheduled the exams to start from March 4. Chetankumar Masram , principal of a Tumsar college and NU senate member, said, “A group of students approached me on Monday and expressed concern over the lack of time to do any paperwork. Results were declared on February 22 and the next exams were beginning within two weeks. This was unfair to students who failed by hardly two or three marks. There was no way they would be able to apply for revaluation and get the result before the exams started.”

Masram then met with NU officials on Tuesday and was promised prompt action. “NU’s vice chancellor SP Kane said they had already planned for this after realizing the problems that students would face. Hence it resulted in smooth and fruitful discussions which is ultimately beneficial for students,” said Masram.

Title: 125 applicants in race for plum AU VC post
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

change of guard

Allahabad: As many as 125 academics from across the country are in the running for the coveted post of Allahabad University ( AU ) vice-chancellor, which fell vacant after professor RL Hangloo resigned on January 1.

The list of applicants includes nine professors of AU and a principal of one of the varsity’s constituent colleges. All eyes are now set on the formation of a three-member search committee for which AU is yet to convene a meeting of its executive council.

While two members will be nominated to the committee at the aforesaid meeting, the third will be nominated by the President in his capacity as the Visitor of the central university. The search panel will screen all applications and proceed further with interviewing short-listed candidates.

According to reports, of the nine AU professors who have thrown their hat in the ring, two already serve as vice-chancellor of state universities and one is a former VC. The list of aspirants also includes a professor of the arts faculty who in the past has vied for the post of VC in top state universities, including Allahabad-based Uttar Pradesh Rajarshi Tandon Open University (UPRTOU).

Other senior faculty members of AU who have applied include professors of English, botany, law and electronics and communication. If AU teachers are to be believed, the principal of AU’s constituent colleges is known for his close links with the RSS.

Rules say AU must select the new VC within 90 days of publishing the advertisement for the post. Since the varsity had published the ad on January 21, seeking applications within a month, it must find a new VC by April 19.

After scrutinising applications and interviewing applicants, the search committee is expected to forward names of three or five applicants to the Visitor. The final decision obviously rests with the President.

Title: ZP election nominations begin today
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Panaji: The State Election Commission (SEC) will begin accepting nominations from candidates seeking to contest the zilla panchayat elections on Thursday.

The last date for submitting nomination papers is March 5. The elections will be held in 50 constituencies across the state on March 22.

Meanwhile, of the nine political parties invited to a meeting convened by the SEC on Wednesday morning, representatives of only four BJP, INC, NCP and MGP attended. The broad outline of the schedule and arrangements for the elections were discussed with regard to enforcement and compliance of the model code of conduct.

When GPCC president Girish Chodankar complained about the party not being provided electoral rolls by the SEC, the commission agreed to issue clarifications and instructions to all returning officers and assistant returning officers.

Congress also protested the flagging off 44 new police vehicles by chief minister Pramod Sawant on Wednesday.

Title: Boy missing, family alleges police apathy
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Allahabad: Tension gripped Kadipur and adjoining villages on Wednesday under Aspurdevsara police station of Pratapgarh following the mysterious disappearance of a 12-year-old boy .

The missing boy is identified as Adarsh Kumar Tiwari, nephew of the current village head Kadipur Rajesh Tiwari and son of Ramesh Tiwari. He is a student of class VIIIth at Navodaya Vidhya Mandir.

The incident, as per police, took place around 8:15 am on Wednesday when Adarsh left the house to purchase stationery from a nearby shop. When he did not turn up for more than an hour, the family members informed the police station concerned, suspecting abduction.

Gram Pradhan Rajesh Tiwari alleged that the family members had dialled 112 but the local police reached the spot around three hours after they were informed. He said that he also spoke to the senior police officials on call but even that didn’t escalate the police response.

Following the incident, a large number of villagers assembled at the house of the victim, demanding police authorities to find the child.

The villagers also alleged that the local police was too lax to recover the child.

Family members told police that an unidentified man on a bike had arrived at their house about three days back and was asking Adarsh for the ATM card of his father Ramesh. The boy had refused to entertain him who then had threatened him of dire consequences.

Meanwhile, deputy SP (Patti) said, “Thorough investigations are being made into the incident.”

Title: KMC’s ‘demolition man’ faces uphill task in razing crumbling bldg on busy Lenin Sarani
Content:
According to a KMC buildings department official, the demolition of the structure was given top priority as it... Read More

KOLKATA: Workers of an engineering firm expert in demolition of the city’s insecure buildings are up against their toughest challenge yet. Bijay Shaw, the owner of the firm — who is known as the ‘demolition man’ in the Kolkata Municipal Corporation circles — was assigned to demolish a five-storied building on Lenin Sarani (beside Jyoti cinema) three weeks ago. Considering the building’s vulnerable nature and the threat it poses, municipal commissioner Khalil Ahmed issued a special express order for its demolition. The KMC building department asked Shaw to wrap up the job in a month’s time.Shaw, who boasts of pulling down several insecure buildings across the city, including some dangerous ones in Burrabazar-Posta area, however, is struggling with this project. In fact, the pace of the demolition work suffered a setback last week when concrete chunks fell on rows of shops on Nilmoni Halder Lane behind the century-old building.According to a KMC buildings department official, the demolition of the structure was given top priority as it posed a threat to not only pedestrians, but also the traffic on the busy thoroughfare. The building was first declared insecure over 10 years ago. The building was gutted in a fire in 2014. In 2016, a large concrete chunk fell on a tree, which in turn, got uprooted and fell on a running auto on Lenin Sarani, killing three passengers on the spot.Mayor Firhad Hakim finally ordered its demolition after he visited the area and took note of the locals’ complaints. However, demolition proved to be a Herculean task since the workers trained in demolition needed to pull down four load-bearing walls with little space left for the team to accommodate personnel or machines as the stairs of the building no longer exist.The building’s location between a busy Lenin Sarani and a densely populated Nilmoni Halder Lane increased the challenge. A chunk of concrete could do enough damage to lives and properties (shops). Mohammed Parvez, owner of a shop on Nilmoni Halder Lane, said he had a narrow escape after a large chunk of concrete fell on his shop on Thursday, damaging it badly. “I had gone out of the shop to have a cup of tea. But there is no guarantee that such freak accidents won’t happen during demolition of the building,” Parvez said.A KMC official conceded that there was real risk in pulling down the structure and, hence, they would rather wait for two more months to complete the demolition work. “We have tried using machines to wrap up the project, but failed as not enough space is available for operating them. On the contrary, use of machines led to the crumbling chunks. Now, we want to pull down the 25-foot walls manually to avoid a disaster,” he said.

Title: Delhi violence: Mob carried away young IB official, dumped his body in drain
Content:
Family members of Ankit Sharma alleged that a local politician was responsible for the murder

NEW DELHI: For the family of Ankit Sharma, 26-year-old Intelligence Bureau official whose body was recovered on Wednesday, it’s a nightmare that will never end. He had “gone missing” around 5pm after he ventured out of his home in Chand Bagh, which has seen some of the worst rioting in northeast Delhi, to “take stock of the situation outside.”“There was a mob outside the house and they were burning everything,” recalled his mother, Sudha Sharma, sobbing. “He had seen them while on his way back home. He came here, put down his things and did not take even a drop of water before going out with a few neighbours to check what was wrong. He didn’t return.”The mother’s long wait ended around 12pm on Wednesday with the tragic news of her son’s death. A group of men had spotted a body in a drain in the neighbourhood around noon and dived in to fish it out. They recognised Ankit and informed his father. The body was then taken to Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital. He had been badly assaulted.As family and friends began to pour into the young official’s home, their anger and sense of betrayal was evident. They alleged that a local politician was responsible for the murder and added that police did not pay any heed when they told them that a mob had dragged Ankit away. It didn’t matter that his father, Ravinder Kumar, is in Delhi Police.“The mob consisted of at least 500 people. They had come prepared and there were petrol bombs stocked up in the politician’s house. Before we could even react, they overpowered him and dragged him away. We could not do anything,” said a neighbour, who claimed to have accompanied Ankit to the main road where the violence was taking place. TOI tried to speak to the politician but he did not respond.His father, Kumar, said they began to get worried when Ankit did not return at night. “We then went out to search for him at a Kashmere Gate trauma centre and AIIMS but couldn’t find him. So, we went to file a complaint at Khajuri Khas police station. We were sent back by them,” he said.Even as the issue became politicised and neighbours gathered outside the house and raised controversial slogans, the family continued to talk about the compassionate young man who balanced his duty and family perfectly. Sudha spoke of the last time she stepped out of her house. On Monday, Ankit had “forcefully” taken her to an ophthalmologist. Her vision was getting blurry and he insisted on taking her to the nearby clinic.“I have an elder son but Ankit was the caring one in the family...He made sure that I saw the doctor before he left for work two days ago. That was the last time I spent some time with him,” she said. Inconsolable, the mother kept asking for “justice for her son.”“A case of murder has been registered. All allegations are being probed,” said DCP northeast Ved Prakash Surya.Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal expressed his condolences. "Such a tragic loss of life. The culprits must not be spared. 20 people have already lost their lives. So painful to watch people of Delhi suffering. Praying that we recover from this tragedy soon n work together to undo damage done to people n communities,” Kejriwal wrote on Twitter.

Title: Water board team in Delhi for NRCD meet
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hyderabad: A team of Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) travelled to Delhi on Wednesday to meet the officials of National River Conservation Directorate (NRCD) and get aid for the newly proposed Sewage Treatment Plant (STP).

“Water Board has conducted preliminary discussions with the NRCD about the STPs, that are a part of the ‘Sewerage Master Plan’ (SMP), as per the ‘Detailed Project Report’ (DPR),” a senior HMWSSB official apprised of the talks told TOI.

According to DPR, the water board has proposed four new STPs on North Musi and three on South Musi. Eight STPs are planned to be built on Kukatpally Nala, five STPs on Jeedimetla and another eight on Nakkavagu with a capacity of 1,399 million liters per day (MLD).

The water board had recently submitted designs, along with DPR, for the STPs to NRCD. The civic body needs nearly Rs 2,000 crore to Rs 5,000 crore central funds to execute the proposed plan. According to water board officials, the STPs will be constructed in a couple of years if all goes well.

Regarding land acquisition for the proposed STPs, an official said, “Water board has acquired the necessary land by coordinating with GHMC and other government agencies. Most of the STPs will come up on water board’s land.” The land is free from litigations, added the official.

Title: Task force will be set up to implement Goa 2035 roadmap, says Goa CM
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

CM Pramod Sawant met with Dr Raghunath Mashelkar (extreme right) and Vibrant Goa Foundation to discuss the way... Read More

PANAJI: Following up on his promise to implement the Goa 2035: vision and roadmap report, chief minister Pramod Sawant met with Padma Vibhushan Dr Raghunath Mashelkar and the Vibrant Goa Foundation to discuss the implementation of the report’s recommendations.

Sawant said that a taskforce will be constituted to review the vision document and provide inputs for a phase-wise implementation of the report in the state.

“I have taken a decision to form a task force. The task force will prepare a roadmap for the implementation of the Vision 2035 report,” said Sawant. “We discussed about various aspects of the Goa-Vision 2035 report and way to implement the suggestions in a phased manner.”

Mashelkar is the former Director General of the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research .

On the 59th Liberation Day, on December 19, 2019, Sawant announced that the recommendations would be implemented, and appealed to all stakeholders for support to make Goa golden.

The Goa 2035: vision and roadmap report was prepared by a high-level council and submitted to then chief minister Manohar Parrikar in July 2012 but the report was never implemented.

The ‘Goa Golden Jubilee Development Council’ (GGJDC), constituted on July 26, 2010 by the then Congress-led government was headed by Dr Mashelkar. Then Congress chief minister Digambar Kamat had tasked the council to conduct an in-depth analysis of education, environment and sustainable development, art and culture, trade and industry and make recommendations for the state government to implement.

Chairman of Vibrant Goa Foundation Nitin Kunkolienker said that the report’s broad outlines remain relevant but the finer points would require a few changes to account for the rapid strides made in technology and the global economy.

“The first thing that we have decided is to review the Goa-Vision 2035 report. Goa does not require multiple visions,” said Kunkolienker.

Title: Goa: Court acquits accused in 2014 rape-murder case
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative Image

COLVA: Additional sessions court judge Dvijpla Patkar on Wednesday acquitted Ram Bharosh Manji, a native of Bihar, in the alleged rape and murder case of a woman at Canacona.

On January 31, 2014, Canacona police registered an offence for rape and murder upon the complaint of Shashikant Yesso Pagi, that an unidentified person raped and murdered his 54-year-old wife Vijaya S Pagi, while she was returning home.

The autopsy report indicated that the death of the deceased was due to manual strangulation and smothering, and and there was also evidence of head injuries and sexual assault.

The accused then stole her mobile phone and cash of Rs 500. The prosecution examined 46 witnesses in support of the case. Advocate Peter Fernandes appeared for the accused under the free legal aid scheme.

The rape and murder had caused a sensation in Canacona, with villagers protesting outside the police station for two days demanding that the case be transferred to the crime branch. The police had announced a reward of Rs 50,000 for anyone who could provide information about the assailant.

The government had transferred the case to the crime branch who charge-sheeted the case against Ram. The second accused Vikas Kumar Sao was charged with dishonestly receiving stolen property, and is currently absconding.

The proceedings against him are to continue under Section 299 CrPC. Ram had admitted to the police that he had sold the mobile phone to Vikas.

Title: Remembering the evergreen voice of Madurai Somu
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Chennai: He was one of the rare Carnatic vocalists who was a musician of the masses. So it comes as no surprise that Madurai S Somasundaram’s birth centenary celebrations are continuing for more than a year, with Sangita Kalanidhi Madurai Seshagopalan paying tributes to the master at Ragasudha Hall in Mylapore this weekend.

But if his parents had their way, rasikas may not have had the pleasure of knowing his mesmerizing voice. Somu, as he was popularly known, was the tenth child, who was initiated into music as a ‘shruti-petti’ accompanist. As a child he showed keen interest in vocal music, but those at home didn’t seem to approve. Belonging to the family of nagaswaram vidwan Srinivasa Pillai, he was expected to take up this instrument. But the headstrong boy, captivated by singing, joined the theatre group "Boys Company" on his own.

Bowing to his preference, his parents took him to veteran vocalists Abhirami Sasthriar and Sesham Bhagavathar. Later in 1930, he began taking lessons from Chitoor Subramaniam Pillai in the gurukulam style for 14 years, at the end of which he debuted on the stage at a concert in Tiruchendur in 1945.

A faithful to the grammar prescribed by music pundits, he never allowed this to imprison his creativity. One could equate the popularity of Somu with that of Madurai Mani Iyer. Somu’s music, his abilities in all domains of Carnatic music — the ‘alapana’, rendering of the ‘kriti’ and ‘swaraprastharam’ — was engrossing. He would explore known ragas to unknown depths.

His concert-framework had special time for Ragam Tanam Pallavi. His pallavis used to be tough on the accompanists who used to dread these. He always demanded the full-bench when it came to supporting (pakka vadhyam) laya artists. The picture of Somu at the centre, as if on a pivot swirling around, encouraging these performers is etched in the memory of those who frequented his concerts. His concerts would follow the pattern of temple nagaswaram concerts, commencing in the evening and extending into the small hours of the day with unflinching vitality. He tried to mimic the nagaswaram and it is well-established that his raga phrases were imitative of the nagaswaram ‘bhani’ (pattern).

During his concerts there was the less heavy phase where he used to sing self-composed Tamil pieces as ‘ragamalika’(in a string of ragas). His evergreen songs are "Enna Kavi Padinalum", "Ullak Kovilil" and "Madumeikkum Kanna". Listeners would not let him go without singing these. After he had made his conspicuous entry into cinema with ‘Deivam’ as a playback singer, requests included the number "Maruthamalai Mamaniye", a song that made him popular instantly among the masses.

In spite of being a star, Somu was easily accessible, amiable and an endearing personality. And probably his goodness of heart also reflected in his voice too. People used to say his voice would improve qualitatively, get stimulated, mellow and attain sweetness as the concert progressed — an eternal experience of rasikas.

Title: Four held for illegally transporting 62 cows
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Barwani: Sendhwa rural police have arrested four persons from Agra-Bombay National Highway for illegally transporting 62 cows by a truck in Barwani on Wednesday afternoon.

Sendhwa rural police station town inspector Vishwadeep Singh Parihar said that police seized a truck carrying the bovines, four km from Sendhwa.

Empty cartons and mattresses were kept over the cows so as to hide them. The cattle were being taken from Mandsaur district to slaughterhouses in Maharashtra.

Police arrested Mohammad Hussain, Shakeel, Rahim, all residents of Botal Ganj in Mandsaur and Jafar Khan of Multanpur, Mandsaur.

As the cows were being transported in a brutal condition, four of them died, he said.

Title: Coast Guard officer reviews opposition in Goa
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

PANAJI: The Indian Coast Guard ’s regional commander for Western region, inspector general Anand Prakash Badola was in Goa on a two-day official visit. During his inspection visit, the flag officer reviewed the operational preparedness, coastal security mechanism and administrative set-up of the Coast Guard , said Commandant Akshay Jain.

This is Badola’s maiden visit to Goa since he took over the reins of the Coast Guard Region (West) in December. During the visit, the flag officer witnessed various Coast Guard operations at sea, including air operations.

The flag officer has had an illustrious career in the Indian Coast Guard, spanning over three decades. Badola, a specialist in navigation and direction, and alumni of US staff college, has served in various capacities both ashore and afloat.

Title: Elgar case: 9 activists moved to Mumbai jails
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Pune: The nine activists arrested in the Elgar Parishad case were shifted to Arthur Road and Byculla jails in Mumbai on Wednesday from the Yerawada central prison, days after Pune police handed over the investigation to the National Investigation Agency.

The prisons department shifted seven activists— Surendra Gadling, Rona Wilson, Sudhir Dhawale, P Varavara Rao, Vernon Gonsalves, Arun Ferreira and Mahesh Raut—to Arthur Road jail for undertrial prisoners. Sudha Bharadwaj and Shoma Sen are in Byculla women’s jail. Special UAPA court, Pune, had passed an order to produce them before NIA court in Mumbai on February 28.tnn

Title: Stop meaningless opposition: Botcha Satyanarayana
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Botcha Satyanarayana

VISAKHAPATNAM: Minister for Muncipal and urban administration, Botcha Satyanarayana has urged people of Visakhapatnam to question Naidu as to why he is opposing the setting up of the executive capital in Visakhapatnam.

Speaking to the media here on Wednesday, the minister lashed out at the TDP chief for allegedly claiming that land was being grabbed from people on the pretext of land pooling. The minister alleged that the people of Visakhapatnam district remember the manner in which names were changed in records and land was grabbed from farmers during the previous regime.

He clarified that land pooling was being taken up in the state for the construction of homes for the poor and added that the YSRC chief and chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy has insisted that people must be paid extra if their land was being pooled and not be cheated in any way. Regarding Visakhapatnam as executive capital, the minister pointed out that the government aims to develop Visakhapatnam on the lines of Benguluru and Mumbai. “The opposition parties must put an end to its meaningless opposition to the idea of a decentralised capital and stop opposing everything the government does,” Botsa Satyanarayana said.

When asked why the chief minister was not invited to the official dinner hosted at Rashtrapathi Bhavan for the US President, Donald Trump, Satyanarayana replied, “ Chief ministers like Naveen Patnaik and Mamta Banerjee were also not invited.”

Title: Many Keralites living under fear: Pinarayi Vijayan
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM/KOZHIKODE: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan called for urgent intervention by the Centre to bring back normalcy in Delhi. Among the people in Delhi, there are thousands of Keralites who are living under fear. Hence, the centre should intervene immediately to put an end to the violence, he said in a statement issued here.

“There are reports that rumours are being spread to create communal hatred in Delhi. The death toll is increasing and even the media are not being spared. The BJP leader who gave hate speech is still creating trouble. He has not been arrested till now. The law and order has been completely deteriorated,” said the chief minister adding that the home ministry should not hesitate in taking action against the perpetrators of violence. “Police should be effectively deployed to prevent spread of violence. The government has the responsibility to check communal hatred being spread in the society.”

“The anti-CAA agitation is to protect the secular credentials of the country. However, the Sangh Parivar’s agenda is to take this agitation to the streets. This has resulted in the violence in Delhi. All the secular forces should come together to bring peace in the national capital,” said the chief minister.

Meanwhile, a delegation of the Indian Union Muslim League ( IUML ) is planning to visit riot-hit areas in Delhi on Thursday and also meet senior leaders including AICC president Sonia Gandhi.
