The working committee of the party met here on Wednesday and expressed concern over the gruesome violence in Delhi. The meeting chaired by party president Panakkad Syed Hyder Ali Shihab Thangal said the central government failed to ensure safety and security of life and property.

Leaders also said even the police, instead of stopping the violence, stood as mute spectators to the rampage unleashed by the Sangh Parivar.

The meeting demanded the resignation of home minister Amit Shah for failing to protect lives. IUML also asked the police to arrest BJP leader Kapil Mishra for sedition.

An IUML delegation comprising national general secretary P K Kunhalikutty, organizing secretary E T Muhammad Basheer, treasurer P V Abdul Wahab, state general secretary K P A Majeed, assembly party leader M K Muneer and Lok Sabha party whip Navas Ghani would meet Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, AICC president Sonia Gandhi and home minister Amit Shah to discuss the prevailing situation.

The meeting also expressed concern over the LDF government’s move to sabotage anti-CAA agitations. The Kerala police have been registering cases against those who have been staging peaceful anti-CAA protest. IUML also criticized chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan for insulting Justice Kemal Pasha who has taken a strong stand against the CAA .

The party will organize get-togethers at panchayat and ward levels on March 10, which is the party's founding day.

Title: ‘Amazed & anguished’ police didn’t file FIRs for hate speeches: Delhi high court
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The court directed the Delhi CP to view all the clips received in this connection and take a “conscious decisi... Read More

NEW DELHI: The alleged hate speeches by BJP functionaries Kapil Mishra , Anurag Thakur and Parvesh Verma came under the scrutiny of Delhi high court on Wednesday, which said it was “amazed” and “anguished” that police hadn’t lodged FIRs against them.

Playing in the courtroom video clips of each controversial speech made by the three BJP members in connection with the CAA-related violence, a bench of Justices S Muralidhar and Talwant Singh said they “ex facie appear to be answering the description of the crime of hate speech in terms of IPC Section 153A proviso (a) and (b), both of which are cognisable and non-bailable.”

The court directed the Delhi Police commissioner to view all the clips and any other that police may have received in this connection and take a “conscious decision” by Thursday.

“What is an appropriate stage? When the whole city has burnt down? How many more lives are to be lost before action is taken? Unless you don’t take action now, how will a conducive situation arise?” the bench demanded from Solicitor General Tushar Mehta when he maintained that police were in possession of the clips, but were waiting for a conducive time since the atmosphere was charged now.

Disagreeing with Mehta’s stand, the bench was quick to point out the “consequences” of police inaction against hate speech. “Has the police commissioner seen these videos? If you don’t have an FIR, how are you going to proceed? Three speeches have given way to more speeches. You acted with alacrity in cases of loot and arson. Why was no similar action shown in the case of these speeches?” the bench wondered, referring to BJP MLA Abhay Verma’s alleged speech in Laxmi Nagar.

The bench asked special commissioner Praveer Ranjan to convey the “anguish of a constitutional court” to the commissioner and recorded that the senior officer had assured he would sit with the police commissioner, view all video clips, take a decision of lodging FIRs and convey it to the court on Thursday.

“We want peace to prevail. We do not want the city to witness another 1984 riots. This city has seen enough violence and anguish,” the bench said, questioning the police’s reluctance when it had lodged 11 cases in incidents including arson, looting and stone-pelting in the past week.

The order was issued while hearing a petition by human rights activist Harsh Mander and activist Farah Naqvi. Appearing for the petitioners, senior advocate Colin Gonsalves said not just FIR, the BJP members should be arrested and jailed.

The hearing, held in a jampacked courtroom, saw Mehta and Delhi Police standing counsel Rahul Mehra differ on registration of FIRs. While Mehta argued that the court should wait for police to file its response and not pass any interim orders, Mehra contended an FIR should be registered if a cognisable offence had been committed and, later, if enough evidence is not found, a cancellation report could be filed.

Mehta also objected to why the “public spirit” of the petitioners, including Mander, woke up “in the case of three individuals when there were 50 such clips from all sides.” He argued that any step at this stage by the court would aggravate the situation. However, the court countered, “The situation out there is so unpleasant. We have all watched videos of some leaders making hate speeches openly. There are videos that hundreds of people have watched. Do you still think it’s not an urgent matter?”

While watching Mishra’s video, the bench also asked the name of the police officer seen standing next to the BJP functionary and was informed by Gonsalves that it was DCP (Northeast) Ved Prakash Surya.

Title: Hyderabad: At Alamgir mosque students can plan & prepare for their careers
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A mosque in Shantinagar area of AC Guards will open its doors for hundreds of students, and help them prepare for various competitive exams including national eligibility cum entrance test (NEET) for medical courses, and civil services.

Experts drawn from various fields will train students on how to plan, prepare and appear for competitive examinations at national and state level. Classes will be held at the expert coaching centre daily from March 2 for students planning to take entrance tests for various professional courses beginning next academic year. Separate classes will be held those appearing for public service exams.

The first floor of Alamgir mosque near Mahavir Hospital has been allotted for the coaching-cum-study centre. The coaching programme called “connect with mosque”, will be held during nights and students can use the mosque premises to prepare for competitive exams. Apart from experts, there will be trained teachers to guide students. This is the first time in Hyderabad that a mosque will double up as a coaching centre for academic and career enhancement.

Syed Ata Hussain Anjum, president of Alamgir Masjid committee, told TOI that they had taken up an educational-cum-job coaching campaign, “Excel 2020 plus”, to keep students abreast of latest developments in all fields and to enable them to crack tough competitive examinations.

“Many students cannot afford tuition fee to take coaching at leading coaching centres,” he said.

“Also, many families do not have enough space at home for students to study in a serene atmosphere. We provide motivational programmes and coaching by teachers to hone the competitive skills of poor students.”

Mosque committee secretary, Basha Mohiuddin: “We will ensure students get at least two hours of expert attention daily. Classes will be held for students of classes VIII to X, intermediate and degree courses. There will be separate sessions for those appearing for competitive exams in medicine, law, engineering.”

Salar Jung Museum board member and educationist, Syed Zakir Hussain, said the mosque committee had decided to extend the scope of a masjid beyond prayers. “Classes will start after Isha prayers (about 8pm). Students can study in the mosque till the Fajr prayers (around 5am). Mobile phones will not be allowed, and students need to deposit them at an exclusive counter before entering the mosque,” Zakir said.

Title: 50% quota for women must be implemented: Committee
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Tirupati: Chairperson and members of the subordinate legislation committee (SLC) reviewed the progress of various work and the implementation of government orders with the officials of Chittoor district administration led by collector Narayana Bharat Gupta at Sri Padmavathi guest house at Tirupati on Wednesday.

Chairperson of SLC, P Samanthakamani, directed the officials to ensure that GO 74 and 75, passed in September last year, is implemented strictly. The district administration should also see to it that 50% reservation for women be implemented even with regard to sanction of engineering work, besides in the appointments of permanent or contract workers.

Gupta briefed the committee on the status of various development work, and implementation of government welfare schemes in the district. He assured that GO 74 and 75 are being strictly implemented but that there was a shortage of women contractors. Gupta, however, added that the district administration was carrying out awareness programmes to encourage women to take up contracts. tnn

Title: Delhi riots: How outsiders were kept at bay in this ‘island of peace’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Muslim residents guarding a temple against marauding mobs

NEW DELHI: While northeast Delhi was caught in a communal frenzy, Indira Vihar, a locality in Shiv Vihar, proved gallantly different. There are 3,200 houses in the area, and a mere eight of them belong to Hindu families. To save them from the mob, the residents even changed the nameplate on a pickle maker’s shop and guarded a temple. “Whether it is Diwali or a cremation, we have always been at each other’s side, so why not today?” reasoned Wasim.

Delhi violence: Live updates

On Wednesday, three Muslim men stood guard outside the temple in Indira Vihar. One of them told TOI, “We have always lived in peace together. A place of worship should not be damaged.” Nearby a house had a slip of paper with “Parwaiz Ansari” pasted on the blue door. While a cloth covered the wall ledge, underneath it idols of Saraswati, Hanuman and other gods could be espied. The house belongs to a Hindu pickle maker, and the subterfuge saved the man, his wife and two children from harm.

Nandlal, locally addressed as mathri-maker Panditji’s son, said with much relief, “We are safe because of the people living in the two lanes. No one has allowed an outsider to venture there, and even if someone does come into the area, they are prevented from coming anywhere near our house. We might not know everyone by name, but do recognise most people by face.”

Tasleem Ansari has been a neighbour and best friend to the Sainis living opposite his house. Ansari said, “Shiv Vihar is burning because of outsiders, not because of its residents.” He said that there is social interaction among all the people and they visit each other’s houses. Ansari said the elderly Sainiji, head of the family, had died recently, but his son Pankaj and his wife lived here. Neeraj, the other son, lived in Maujpur. When two Saini women married, the entire neighbourhood joined in to help, and the Hindu family has always reciprocated by visiting their neighbours’ homes on Eid. “The two brothers hadn’t been able to meet because of the violence, so Pankaj has gone to Neeraj’s house only today,” Ansari said.

Tara Dev, one of the Hindu residents, said “In our three decades living here, we have never had any issue with our neighbours. They are our brothers and sisters. Today, many of them are on vigil outside our house and we know we are safe.”

At Chand Bagh too, Praveen Kumar was all praise for his Muslim neighbours. “They saved our temple from destruction and went out of their way to ensure harmony even in this deadly situation.”

A reciprocal story unfolded in Brijpuria Puliya. Akhtar Raza, a member of BJP’s minority cell, was at the Faruqia mosque where anti-CAA protests were taking place. When a mob attacked them, Raza, by his own testimony, stated that he and his family wouldn’t be alive if not for his Hindu neighbours.

Raza said the rioters went around identifying Muslim homes and attacking the panicky people. Six such houses were burnt down. “Our Hindu neighbours helped us escape and many of us have moved in with our relatives,” said Raza.

Title: Paddler Jaiswal’s FB account hacked
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hyderabad: International paddler Naina Jaiswal has approached Hyderabad Cyber Crime police and lodged a complaint stating that her Facebook account was hacked.

Assistant commissioner of police (Cyber Crime) KVM Prasad said Naina approached police on Tuesday and a case was registered against the hacker under the Information Technology Act.

Naina, who has a Facebook account ‘Iamnainajaiswal’, saw late on Monday night that someone had taken control of the account. The hacker had been uploading videos, posters and other content at regular intervals.

Police have contacted Facebook to share with them the required information for investigation. The ACP claimed that they have not received any response from Facebook yet. Naina has over two lakh followers.

“I use this account for official purposes. I am unable to access it since February 24. The hacker is posting a new video, a creative work, every hour,” Naina stated.

Title: Gyanvapi row: HC bars civil court from resuming hearing
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

A file photograph of Gyanvapi mosque in Varanasi

Allahabad: The Allahabad high court on Wednesday stayed a lower court’s order to proceed with the hearing of a case related to Kashi Vishwanath Temple-Gyanvapi Masjid dispute in Varanasi.

On February 4, 2020, the Varanasi lower court had held that since in writ petition related to the dispute pending before the Allahabad high court no interim order was extended in the past six months, the stay is deemed to be vacated as per the ruling of the Supreme Court in 'Asian Resurfacing of Road Agencies case' and it can resume hearing of the case.

One of the parties, Anjuman Intazamia Masjid of Varanasi challenged the decision of the Varanasi civil court. Hearing the petition, Justice Ajay Bhanot fixed March 17, 2020 as the next date of hearing of this case. The petitioner's contention was that it had earlier filed a petition related to the dispute and court had granted a stay order in the case directing civil court not to proceed in the case pending before it. However, the civil court wrongly interpreted the order of the Supreme Court and held that since the said order was not extended by the high court in the past six months, the stay is deemed to be vacated and now, it can resume hearing of the case, the petition said.

In the orginial petition filed before the Varansi civil court in 1991, KV Mandir Trust had contended that the kashi Vishwanath temple was built by Maharaja Vikramaditya about 2050 years ago. According to the Trust's petition, Mughal emperor Aurangzeb destroyed the temple in 1664 and used the remains of the temple to construct a mosque on a portion of the land, which is known as Gyanvapi masjid.

The Trust requested the lower court to issue directives for the removal of the mosque on the temple land and give back the possession of the land to the temple trust. The trust had contended in the original suit that the Places of Worship (Special Provisions) Act was not applicable on its suit as the mosque was constructed over a partly demolished temple and even today many parts of the temple exist.

In 1998, Anjuman Intazamia Masjid, Varanasi, moved the high court with contention that the mandir-masjid dispute could not be adjudicated by a civil court as it was barred by the law.

The high court then had stayed the proceedings at the lower court which continued for the past 22 years. In February this year, the trust approached the lower court again with a plea to resume the hearing as the HC had not extended the stay in the past six months.

Title: Telugu Ganga water for Chandragiri villages
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Tirupati: The state government passed a government order on Wednesday allocating 130 million cubic feet of water from the Telugu Ganga project to Chandragiri assembly constituency.

The move is aimed to mitigate the drinking water problems faced by several villages in the perennially drought-hit district of Chittoor.

Following a representation from Chandragiri MLA Chevireddy Bhaskar Reddy, who is also the chairman of Tirupati Urban Development Authority (TUDA), the government passed the order to release the water from the Telugu Ganga project to meet the drinking water needs of Settipalli, Padmavathipuram, Sai Nagar, Avilala, Vedantapuram, Peruru, Tiruchanoor and Tummalagunta gram panchayats.

Bhaskar Reddy, who is also the government whip in the assembly, expressed his thanks to chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy for providing a permanent solution to the drinking water woes faced by the people of Chandragiri constituency which continues to reel under extreme drought conditions year after year.

He also took a dig at TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu for not trying to alleviate the drinking water problems of the area during his 14-year-long stint as chief minister of the state.

“Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy understands the sufferings of people and takes prompt decisions to mitigate their problems. People of Chandragiri have staged several protests for more than three decades to address their drinking water problems, but successive governments didn’t pay any heed to their appeals. Now they will receive 368 crore litres of assured water supply from the Telugu Ganga project every year,” he said.

Title: AU panel to vet student body’s future today
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Allahabad: Allahabad University’s (AU) academic council will decide about the fate of Students Council and whether the varsity should continue awarding degrees to Ewing Christian College during its meeting on Thursday.

The decision on the body is a much-awaited one in the wake of the frequent protests which were reported after the varsity replaced the AU Students’ Union with a Students Council in 2019.

In June 2019, AU replaced the students union with a student council and the move was endorsed by the varsity’s Executive Council too.

The Students Council elections were held on the campus and also in other constituent colleges in October 2019. However, all 23 students who had filed nomination for various posts of the body withdrew their names at the last minute. Without any candidates to contest the election, the Students Council elections were subsequently cancelled.

“AU’s Academic Council will discuss the future of the students representative body. It will decide if the Students Council would continue to exist or if the students union will be reinstated,” said one of the head of departments at AU, who would be attending Thursday’s meeting.

The council would also discuss if the varsity should continue awarding AU degrees to Ewing Christian College (ECC) students.

Last month, AU’s examination committee had decided to discontinue with the practice as the constituent college conducts its own admission process, sets question papers itself and even evaluates the answer sheets independently.

“The meeting would be convened at 11am in the North Hall and several important issues would be discussed, ” said AU public relations officer Shailendra Mishra.

Title: Air in Indore cleaner than a year ago as pollutants down by 5%
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Indore: Improved waste management and a lid on open burning has made Indore’s air much cleaner than a year ago with particulate matters falling by over 5 per cent in a year.

Waste minimization and management coupled with regular cleaning of roads through mechanised sweeping has made a difference to city’s air, that may improve further with the use of upgraded fuel Bharat Stage 6, said experts.

In the study conducted by the Regional Pollution Control Board, Vijay Nagar area recorded the lowest pollution.

Chief chemist and lab head at the board Dr DK Wagela, said, “Implementation of air pollution control action-plan worked well in the city and yielded good results. Effective waste management played a very crucial role besides last year had more rainy days that also helped in keeping the air clean.”

Particulate Matter 10 (PM10) and Particulate Matter 2.5 (PM2.5) have dropped by 8.33 per cent and 5 per cent respectively in 2019 as against a year ago, claimed the board.

The board studied the data on particulate matters from three manual stations- Sanwer Road, Kothari market and Vijay Nagar - in city.

Experts said, non-stop cleanliness drive in the city to retain the crown of cleanest city of the country and innovative waste management mechanism are helping in keeping it dust-free.

According to the board, the average level of PM 2.5 in 2019 stood at around 37 as against 39 a year ago, while PM 10 was recorded at 77 as against 84.

Environment expert Gunwant Joshi said, “Dust has reduced in the air because roads are clean. Night cleaning helps a lot as it keeps road clear the next day. Vehicular emission has not improved much as this is a time taking process but once that happens, air quality will improve further.”

Title: Delhi Riots News: 14 more confirmed deaths take toll to 27; gunshot wounds killed at least 12
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

A grieving family member of Rahul Thakur

NEW DELHI: The death toll in the riots in northeast Delhi touched 27 on Wednesday, with 14 more deaths being confirmed by Guru Tegh Bahadur (GTB) and Lok Nayak hospitals where most injured are being rushed.

Director of GTB hospital told TOI that 25 persons have been declared dead at their hospital in last three days, of which 22 were brought dead. “The other three died during treatment,” Dr Sunil Kumar, the hospital director, said. At Lok Nayak hospital, the authorities confirmed death of two persons, who suffered from gunshot injuries during the riots. “Mahroof Ali (32) was brought dead, while Aman (17) died during treatment,” said an official.

Of the 27 declared dead, at least 12 have died due to gunshot wound.

As per the list of the deceased at GTB hospital, Ishak Khan (24), Mudassar (30), Vir Bhan (50), Md Mubarak Hussain (28), Shan Mohd (35), Pravesh (48), Asfak (22), Rahul Solanki (26) and Shahid (25), who were brought dead, had gunshot injuries. Deepak (34), Zakir (24) and one unknown person, who was brought dead, had stabbing injuries. At least six others, including Mohd Furkan (30), Rahul Thakur (23), Ratan Lal (42), Ankit Sharma (26) and two unknown youths, succumbed to assault injuries. One person, Dilbar, died due to burn injuries.

Several of these deceased had multiple types of injuries, including assault and burn and stab and gunshot, the hospital data mentions. The number of deaths is likely to increase further, sources said, adding that many of the injured were battling for their lives in hospitals.

GTB hospital has 183 persons admitted in various wards of the hospital, who came with gunshot, stabbing and blunt injuries caused by stone pelting during the riots. “Among the injured, 22 required surgeries, 10 persons had head injuries and four to five persons had fractures for which they were referred to the orthopaedics department. Some of the injured have also suffered from injury to the eye, which may affect their eyesight,” said a source.

At Lok Nayak hospital, the doctors confirmed around 48 persons with different injuries have been rushed over the past three days, including security personnel, who suffered from acid burns.

“Most people had minor injuries and they were discharged after primary aid. However, there are at least seven persons who are admitted in neurosurgery, ENT and burns departments for treatment,” they said.

Eleven policemen are admitted at Max Hospital in Patparganj. This includes DCP Amit Sharma who suffered serious head injuries while controlling the mob. He underwent an emergency surgery and is currently recuperating in the Intensive Care Unit.

Title: CAA not against Indian Muslims: Muralidhar Rao
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

BJP national general secretary Muralidhar Rao

GUNTUR: Defending the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), BJP national general secretary Muralidhar Rao said the Centre has brought in the legislation to protect India from intruders.

He said there was nothing in CAA that harmed the interests of Muslims. He said it was unfortunate that opposition have been spreading false information to create apprehensions in society.

Addressing a meeting organized to create awareness among the SCs and STs here on Wednesday, Rao said BJP would not enact laws for political gains. “I demand anyone to show one single sentence or clause in CAA that goes against the interests of the India-born Muslims. We are ready to quit active politics,” said Rao. He said it was unfortunate that some intellectuals were creating unneeded confusion and trouble in the country.

He said BJP is committed for the uplift of Dalits and tribals. He said interests of the nation were paramount for them rather than partisan political benefits.

He explained various features of the CAA at the meeting and how it would benefit those migrated to India after being persecuted in neighbouring Muslim-dominant nations like Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan.

Rao said that Prime Minister Narendra Modi had included a Dalit in the Ayodhya Ram Mandir Trust as he believes that nation would not progress without the presence of dalits.

BJP state president Kanna Lakshminarayana said opposition were resorting to smear campaign as they could not take on Modi. Party senior functionaries Ravela Kishore Babu, Sunil Deodhar, Satish Ji, Paturi Nagabhushanam were also present during the occasion.

Speaking to media later in the day, Rao said BJP was not against reservations to the SCs, STs.

Title: Cheque bounce case: HC to hear plea against acquittal
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Allahabad: The Allahabad High Court has held that in offences pertaining to cheque bounce, the appeal against acquittal of accused by the subordinate court can be moved before the high court under provisions of criminal procedure code. Hence, no such appeal would lie before the sessions judge of the district court.

The court further held that against the same judgment and acquittal order in a complaint case, where the victim and complainant are different persons, the appeal by the victim can be made only before the high court.

Section 138 of Negotiable Instrument Act provides for circumstances under which a complaint case can be filed in the case of dishonour (bounce) of cheques.

These two key questions were referred to court in the case of Anil Kumar Agarwal and others versus State of Uttar Pradesh. A division bench comprising Justice Shashi Kant Gupta and Justice Saurabh Shyam Shamshery directed the Registrar General of high court to ensure circulation of this order among all judicial officers in the state for their guidance.

The court further directed that a copy of this order be sent to the chief secretary, principal secretary (law) and legal remembrance and stamp reporter of high court for taking follow-up action.

A criminal offence is made out under Section 138 Negotiable Instrument Act, where cheques bounce due to inadequate funds in the account of the person who issues it or due to any other reason.

The question referred before the division bench of high court was whether against acquittal order in a criminal complaint case filed under Section 138 Negotiable Instrument Act, the victim, who is a complainant also may prefer appeal before the sessions judge at district court or the appeal can be made before high court under section 372 of CrPC.

Another question referred was if the victim and complainant both are different persons, the victim may file appeal before sessions judge or high court.

Title: Ayurveda clinic owner loses Rs2.5L saved for income tax
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Indore: Owner of an ayurveda clinic at Kachi Moholla in MG Road area had the biggest shock of his life on Wednesday morning when he opened it. Thieves had made away with his hard-earned money -Rs 2.5lakh - saved to deposit income tax the next day.

The owner - Chandi Prasad Trivedi - lodged a complaint at MG Road police station that the thieves gained entry in his clinic late on Tuesday by breaking the main gate. They took away Rs 2.5 lakh cash, which he had kept in the drawer. The cash was in the denomination of Rs 10 notes.

MG Road police station in charge Rajendra Chaturvedi said that a case has been registered and further investigation was on. “We are looking at the CCTV footages of nearby areas to ascertain identity of the accused,” he said.

Two more areas in the city were targeted by the burgalars. They broke into a house in Ambedkar Nagar and made away with Rs 38,000 cash. Complainant Harsh Jain told police that he had gone away with his family when the incident took place.

Another theft occurred at a godown in Lasudia Mori. Unidentified persons stole valuables worth Rs 2 lakh from the spot. On the complaint of one Sonu Mandloi a case was registered.

Title: Gold, US dollars seized at airport, man arrested
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Mangaluru: Customs at Mangaluru International Airport , late on Tuesday, arrested Moideen Arzan , 23, a passenger from Uppala in Kasaragod, on charges of attempting to smuggle gold .

Arzan, who had arrived from Dubai by Air India flight IX814, was attempting to smuggle gold in paste form, which was concealed within rubber capsules inside his rectum .

Joannes George, joint commissioner of customs, said the gold on purification resulted in the recovery of 619g of yellow metal of 24 karat purity valued at Rs 26.3lakh.

Customs produced Arzan before the CJM court in Mangaluru, George said.

Foreign currency seized

Late on Monday night, customs at MIA seized $16,400 from Atiqurahiman, 32, from Bhatkal, when he attempted to smuggle the foreign currency to Dubai on board a SpiceJet flight.

Foreign currency notes equivalent to Rs 11.6 lakh was concealed in biscuit packets kept in his check-in baggage, George added.

Title: Agra Univ notice to 228 BEd colleges over inadequate teachers, infra
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Agra: Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University administration has issued a final notice to 228 self-financed colleges offering Bachelor of Education (BEd) course, asking them fulfill standard teaching-learning norms by March 15 or else their affiliation will not be renewed for the next academic session. A majority of these colleges don't have qualified teachers.

The notice by the varsity registrar to 228 colleges mentions that, during inspection, it was found that teachers in these colleges were appointed without following the standard procedure and norms. A majority of teachers on duty in these colleges were not approved by the university administration. Some of the approved teachers are associated also with several colleges.

The notice also mentions that these colleges do not have adequate fire safety measures, drinking water facilities, washrooms and electricity supply. Laboratories are not present and libraries lack adequate books. Also, required furniture is also lacking.

University registrar Rajeev Kumar said, “228 colleges have been asked to fulfill the standard teaching-learning norms by March 15. In this regard, final notices have been issued to them. The temporary affiliation to these colleges will end on June 20. If these colleges fail to fulfill the norms, their affiliation will not be extended. These colleges will not be allowed to take fresh admissions.”

Title: Tiranga rally in Kurnool appeals for peace in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Tirupati: Kurnool MLA Hafeez Khan appealed for peace during the massive ‘Tiranga Rally’ held in the city on Wednesday.

The rally, organised by the students’ Joint Action Committee in Kurnool city, was held in response to the ongoing violence at the national capital of New Delhi.

The people who participated in the rally observed a moment of silence and expressed their solidarity with the people who have lost their lives in the protests.

Speaking at the event, Khan said there is no place for hatred in the country and added that peace must prevail. He said there is a lack of trust in the people and it is the central government’s responsibility to create trust in the people.

Moreover, he asserted that Muslims from all classes and specially backward classes in the state would not be harmed by the “black laws” and added that chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy would take care of his citizens without discriminating on religious lines.

Khan said he has complete faith in the chief minister that he will make sure that all the rights of the citizens in the state are safeguarded. He pointed out that the chief minister has already assured that NRC and NPR in its current format will not be allowed to be implemented in the state.

Title: 23-year-old kills self in Hyderabad, police suspect dowry harassment
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 23-year-old housewife hanged herself inside the bathroom of her house in Vanasthalipuram on Wednesday. Her husband also attempted to commit suicide but was rescued. The deceased, S Soumya and her husband Raghavendra were living with his parents. “It was found that Soumya was mentally and physically harassed by her husband and family for dowry. The victim’s family alleged that she killed herself due to harassment. No suicide note was found,” said Vanasthalipuram inspector, A Venkataiah.

On Wednesday, Raghavendra found his wife hanging. He informed his family and then attempted to hang himsel. He was rescued by neighbours. Police have registered a case under Section 304-B (Dowry death) of IPC against the husband and his family and is yet to arrest them.

Title: ‘Gaddar’ does not refer to one section: Delhi cops to court
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The police said Verma had only stated his position on the ongoing protest at Shaheen Bagh

NEW DELHI: “Gaddar,” which means traitor, does not signify any particular section of society, said Delhi Police stressing that no cognisable offence was found for lodging an FIR against BJP minister Anurag Thakur and MP Parvesh Verma over the “inflammatory” speeches made during Delhi assembly elections.

CPM leaders Brinda Karat and K M Tewari had sought an FIR against Thakur for allegedly leading a chant "desh ke gaddaron ko, goli maaro saalon ko" in reference to persons who participated in "peaceful protests against the CAA". Verma allegedly threatened protesters of Shaheen Bagh.

“Connotation of the word—gaddar is traitor. It does not point to any particular section of the society. Surmises and conjectures cannot be the basis of initiating any legal action,” stated Delhi Police’s status report following a magesterial court’s direction for an action taken report.

The police said Verma had only stated his position on the ongoing protest at Shaheen Bagh. “He has nowhere given any threat of any unlawful action and has just stated that protesters will be removed after BJP comes to power,” stated the report.

During his interview, the Delhi police said that he was pointing at a group of protesters and not any particular community. “He is not provoking the crowd to start any riot or take any retaliatory action against the protesters,” police’s report said.

Kapil Baisla, who was arrested after a firing incident at Shaheen Bagh, seems to have not attributed his act to the speeches of either Thakur or Verma, according to the police. Another incident that took place on February 1 relating to a minor, who shot at unarmed protesters outside Jamia Millia, was stated to be under investigation with the crime branch. He too, it was stated, hadn’t attributed his role to either of the speeches.

Delhi Police has dealt with another allegation of a video posted on January 31, 2020, on the party’s official Instagram handle over CAA protesters. It said, "The speaker has only stated his own view regarding the ongoing protest in Shaheen Bagh. Call for removal of protesters does not construe to causing any unlawful action."

The police called these “independent acts,” which didn’t have connection with the speeches. "However, legal opinion is being sought on the complaint. In view of it, some more time may kindly be granted to submit a final ATR on the complaint," it added.

The court will pass its order on the issue on March 2.

The applicants have sought a direction to the Parliament Street police station to register an FIR against the BJP leaders for promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc; imputations, assertions prejudicial to national-integration; deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs; uttering, words, etc, with deliberate intent to wound the religious feelings of any person; intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace; public mischief and criminal intimidation.

Title: Technopark stretch hot favourite for day-night zone
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The city corporation made a tentative list of five stretches for day and night live vending zones; the project which was approved by state cabinet last week.

Kazhakootam–Technopark, Karamana–Killipaalam, Kowdiar–Kuravankonam, Poojapura–Kunchalumoodu and Vellayambalam–Sasthamangalam stretches are being considered for the vending zones.

A meeting was held in corporation main office on Wednesday and a steering committee meeting was also convened by city corporation. The shortlist prepared by the meeting will be presented in the council meeting scheduled to be held in the first week of March.

An inter-departmental meeting comprising various officials was also held recently. The local self-government department (LSGD) issued a directive to city corporation on Thursday to select the suitable spots for day and night live vending zones within 10 days.

The corporation will also have to allot zones for food trucks and vendors with FSSA license to function from 10pm to 5am on Friday and Saturday.

While the civic body has made an initial list, it has to weigh a few factors which should align with the criteria laid down by LSGD.

LSGD in its order has said that proposed zones should have sufficient parking facilities, facilities like footpath and cycle path. Special focus will be on implementation of green protocol and sanitation.

The police and security staff will oversee the security arrangements in live vending zones.

LED streetlights and free WiFi will be other requirements at live vending zones. While corporation plans to co-ordinate with police regarding parking and security arrangements, the other aspects like path for cycling, facilities like free WiFi will have to be considered by city corporation.

The initial list has been prepared mainly considering stretches which are already abuzz with some activity late into the night. The Kazhakkoottam–Technopark stretch is high on the list, as many of the shops especially eateries are open during late hours at night along this stretch.

The ongoing flyover works and resultant traffic regulations in place at Kazhakkoottam is also being taken into account by corporation while finalizing the stretch from Technopark to Kazhakootam for day and night live vending zone.

The project conceived by the state government aims at a live commercial zone in addition to eateries.

The state government is planning to launch the pilot scheme in the capital by March 31 and LSGD, which is co-ordinating the project, is keen on getting the live vending zones functional in the city even before March 31 so that it could be emulated in other cities in the state.

The government aims to implement the project with various objectives; the primary one being promotion of tourism. The government has assessed that it is important to have live and secure streets and vending zones for the promotion of tourism in the state. Besides, it is expected to create new employment opportunities not just for hoteliers but for entertainment sector and small-scale traders.

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has the other day emphasized the need to encourage part-time jobs among students and has mooted change in working hours in educational institutions.

Title: Anti-CAA protest: SIT to probe Sunday's violence in Aligarh
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Agra: A Special Investigation Team (SIT) was constituted on Wednesday to probe all cases registered after the violent clashes between anti CAA protesters and police in Aligarh on Sunday. Senior police officials, accompanied by religious leaders, also took out a peace march in the city to restore confidence among the public. Police, meanwhile, booked 250 persons, including six AMU students, for violating prohibitory orders by blocking a road and unlawful assembly at Quarsi bypass road in Jeevangarh area.

Mobile Internet services remained suspended in Aligarh for the third consecutive day on Wednesday and will continue to be off till further orders, said DM CB Singh.

Aligarh SSP Muniraj G said all the 12 FIRs, registered at various police stations in Aligarh after Sunday’s violence will be probed by a SIT, headed by SP (crime) Arvind Kumar. The SSP said the situation in the city was under control but protests are being held at three different places across the city, including in Shahjamal area, the road opposite the old change gate of AMU and in Quarsi bypass-Anoop Shahar road.

Talking to TOI, SP (crime) Arvind Kumar said a peace march was taken out in the city in presence of ADG (Agra zone) Ajay Anand, SSP Muniraj G and religious leaders of various communities to spread the message of brotherhood and restore confidence among the residents. Around 1,000 people participated in the peace march.

Circle officer Anil Samaniya told TOI that all the 250 persons, including five women students of AMU and the varsity's students leader, were booked in the latest FIR under IPC sections 149 (unlawful assembly), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 291 (public nuisance), 150 (hiring or conniving at hiring of persons to join unlawful assembly) and 341 (wrongful restraint) along with section 83 of the Juvenile Justice (Care And Protection of Children) Act of 2015 for allegedly ‘using’ children during anti-CAA protest at quasi police station.

One of the student leaders, booked by police, told TOI that he had gone to address an anti-CAA protest demonstration and the allegation levelled against him by police that he shouted slogans in support of a former research scholar-turned-Hizbul terrorist, Mannan Wani, is baseless. He claimed that he was being victimized for being a Kashmiri.

According to a senior police officer, the situation in the area continues to be tense, specially after the Delhi riots, and there are reports that some residents have collected stones on their terrace. The officer said this came to the notice of the authorities during monitoring of the areas with drones. House owners who have collected stones will be issued notices soon, he said.

Title: Judgment in Behmai massacre case adjourned for fifth time
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Kanpur: The much-awaited judgment in the Behmai massacre case was adjourned for the fifth time on Wednesday on the ground that the original case diary is not in the court file.

The specially constituted court has now fixed March 18 as the next date for further orders. It has directed the office to write a letter to DGP and inform him that the original case diary is missing from the court file.

Earlier, the court had adjourned its verdict on January 18, 24, 30 and February 12 respectively on the same ground.

According to DGC (criminal), Rajiv Porwal, the court had issued the letter to SP Kanpur Dehat Anurag Vats about missing of the case diary. The SP on Wednesday informed the court that the original case diary was not with the police.

When asked what is the use of the case diary when the trial has concluded and the court is to pronounce the verdict, the DGC said the case diary is a document in which an investigation officer mentions about the investigation conducted in a case and records statements in writing. It is submitted in the court at the time of filing of a chargesheet, he added.

The court, he said, provides copy of the chargesheet to the accused before commencement of trial.

The defence, at the time of prosecution evidence, uses copy of the case diary to match the statements recorded under section 161 of CrPC during investigation and point out any addition in the statements or facts. “This phase was already over. As per practice, now the case diary has no use except to keep it in record”, the DGC said.

Abhimanyu Kumar Sachan, a senior advocate, talking to TOI said, “The apex court had held that case diary is a part of the case file and judicial official can take its help at the time of judgment”. If original case diary is missing and its photo copy is on the record, then judgment can be delivered, he added.

The DGC said the court munsarim (head clerk) had mentioned in his report that the photocopy of the case diary was on the file.

The Behmai carnage case was filed against over 36 dacoits, including Phoolan Devi on February 14, 1981 but at present it is being heard against four dacoits--Posa, Bheekha, Vishwanath alias Krishna Kumar alias Putani and Shyam Sundar, four dacoits are absconding and the remaining, including Phoolan Devi, had either died or killed in police encounters.

Behmai massacre had shaken the entire country as this was the first case in which the dacoits had killed over 20 villagers.

Title: AMU student leaders demand resignation of Shah, Delhi police chief
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Agra: Student leaders of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) have demanded the resignations of Union home minister and Delhi Police chief for failing to save the lives and properties of the people in Delhi.

Condemning the violence in Delhi wherein at least 25 people have been killed and properties worth millions have been damaged in the past three days. The student leaders slam the opposition political parties for being silent on the ongoing violence.

“The violence must stop immediately and the government should behave in a lawful manner,” former students’ union president Salman Imtiaz said.

He added, “We call upon all peace loving people to come out and safeguard the lives and properties of people in Delhi.”

Another students’ leader and former president of AMUSU Faizul Hassan said, “Police acted in an unprofessional manner and showed thorough incompetence in upholding law and order in Delhi.”

Meanwhile, AMU Teachers Association (AMUTA) also condemned the violence in Delhi. “It is shameful to see such unlawful acts carried out in front of the police,” secretary Prof Najmul Islam said.

Title: Parking fee row: Traders paste missing posters of MP, MLA
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Missing posters of Agra MP SP Singh Baghel and Agra North MLA Purshottam Khandelwal

AGRA: On the 44th day of their indefinite strike on Wednesday, traders of Sanjay Place put up ‘missing’ posters of Agra MP SP Singh Baghel and Agra North MLA Purshottam Khandelwal in the market and on cars to mark protest against the imposition of parking fee by the Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC).

President of Sanjay Place Market association KN Agnihorti said, “We have been protesting since past 44 days. Even after much delay, both MP and MLA have not taken cognizance of our genuine demands. As a mark of protest, we have placed their missing posters. We regret voting for them.”

Since January 14, traders of Sanjay Place have been sitting on an indefinite dharna against imposition of parking fee at 38 places in the market premises by AMC. They claimed it violates norms as they had already paid a one-time parking fee at the time of purchasing the property.

The dispute over parking fee between Sanjay Place traders and AMC is sub judice. Traders want AMC to cancel the parking contracts till the court delivers its final orders in the matter.

Title: Coast Guard holds interaction with fishermen at Bunder
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Mangaluru: Coast Guard Karnataka conducted a community interaction programme with fishermen in south wharf, Bunder fishing village, on Wednesday, to sensitise the local fishing populace about safety and security at sea, as well as providing impetus to the Centre’s flagship programme Swachh Sagar abhiyan. A total 50 fishermen, personnel from the fisheries department, coastal security police and customs attended the programme.

During the interaction, fishermen were sensitised about the present security scenario and important role they play as eyes and ears of the nation out at sea. They were asked to share any untoward or suspicious activities at sea with the Indian Coast Guard on toll-free number 1554. The fishing populace was also briefed about various safety precautions to be adhered to while operating at sea, including the use of safety equipment and gear.

Fishermen were advised to carry all life-saving equipment and boat registration papers, including biometric id cards and Aadhaar cards during their fishing expeditions, and operate in groups or buddy systems so that they can help each other during emergencies.

Assistant commandant Apoorva Sharma sensitised the gathering about heeding to weather warnings, and the importance of collecting weather updates prior to proceeding to sea.

Intelligence meet held

The second intelligence sharing meeting was organised by Coast Guard district headquarters 3 at DHQ 3, Panambur, on Wednesday. ICG is nominated as lead intelligence agency (LIA) for sea borders by the group of ministers (GOM), government of India, through ministry of home affairs, coastal security section.

ICG Karnataka has been proactive on intelligence sharing in the area of responsibility of Karnataka with the help of other central state government intelligence agencies, to safeguard its 320 km coastline.

DIG S B Venkatesh, commander, Coast Guard Karnataka, chaired the meeting. Delegates from various agencies exchanged intelligence inputs and provided feedback on inputs that were shared during the last meeting held in January. A healthy discussion and sharing of input were effected, which highlighted the increased use of Chinese made automatic identification system (AIS) on board fishing boats.

Title: Kerala: Soaring mercury, hidden pollution
Content:
PCB’s latest data showed that maximum pollution in Kochi was recorded between November and February.

Kerala’s most-polluted cities are Kochi and Thiruvananthapuram and air pollution is increasing steadily in the state with the average PM 10 (particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter) levels touching the permissible limit of 60 microns on most days a month. This was evident in the data compiled by the pollution control board (PCB).Track the pollution level in your cityExperts said that with pollution levels increasing over the decade, the climate risk factor (when a certain temperature threshold is crossed, there will be a change in weather) has also risen in the form of high temperatures. Also, PM 2.5 levels (particulate matter 2.5 micrometers or less in diameter) levels are only monitored by real-time monitoring systems at two spots in Kochi and it too showed that PM 2.5 level has gone up.CT Aravindakumar who teaches at MG University’s school of environment sciences, explained the scenario. “Though we are a coastal state and sea winds play a role in cleansing the air, dust and pollution due to constructions, burning of plastic and vehicular emission is beginning to reflect in rising temperatures,” he said.He said that nobody talks about the pollution due to the dust generated by non-stop road repairs. “While Kochi Metro construction does lead to pollution, their method of construction is much better as they do it in phases. But, in case of road work, they do it simultaneously at many places and it generates a lot of pollution,” he said.Aravindakumar said studies had recorded heat islands in Thrissur and high levels of industrial pollution in Kanjikode. “Kerala belongs to a different climate zone than Delhi. Kochi’s average pollution is nearing the permissible limit and showing indicators of climate risk,” said Centre for Science and Environment’s executive director Anumita Roy Chowdhury.She said climate risk will be visible in the form of rising temperatures, increased premature births, deaths and respiratory disorders. Climate risk for coastal areas is indicated by a temperature of 30-32 degrees and Kerala is recording higher temperatures.“We cannot completely link it to just pollution. There are several factors including sea surface temperatures and other parameters. But, we need to take a note of it on land,” said Aravindakumar.PCB’s latest data showed that maximum pollution in Kochi was recorded between November and February. Since Kerala enjoys monsoon between June and November, the air is comparatively clean in those months.Pulmonologists said the impact of rising air pollution is visible in the cases they treated in the past few years.“Rubble and dust from construction site, road works affect people in the neighbourhood. We are seeing more cases of upper respiratory infections in city and its outskirts. The chances of contracting infections are high and for persons with respiratory disorders or pre-asthmatic condition, hospital visits will double in a year.,” said pulmonologist Dr Ramesh Nair.

Title: Kerala: Soaring mercury, hidden pollution
Content:
PCB’s latest data showed that maximum pollution in Kochi was recorded between November and February.

Kerala’s most-polluted cities are Kochi and Thiruvananthapuram and air pollution is increasing steadily in the state with the average PM 10 (particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter) levels touching the permissible limit of 60 microns on most days a month. This was evident in the data compiled by the pollution control board (PCB).Track the pollution level in your cityExperts said that with pollution levels increasing over the decade, the climate risk factor (when a certain temperature threshold is crossed, there will be a change in weather) has also risen in the form of high temperatures. Also, PM 2.5 levels (particulate matter 2.5 micrometers or less in diameter) levels are only monitored by real-time monitoring systems at two spots in Kochi and it too showed that PM 2.5 level has gone up.CT Aravindakumar who teaches at MG University’s school of environment sciences, explained the scenario. “Though we are a coastal state and sea winds play a role in cleansing the air, dust and pollution due to constructions, burning of plastic and vehicular emission is beginning to reflect in rising temperatures,” he said.He said that nobody talks about the pollution due to the dust generated by non-stop road repairs. “While Kochi Metro construction does lead to pollution, their method of construction is much better as they do it in phases. But, in case of road work, they do it simultaneously at many places and it generates a lot of pollution,” he said.Aravindakumar said studies had recorded heat islands in Thrissur and high levels of industrial pollution in Kanjikode. “Kerala belongs to a different climate zone than Delhi. Kochi’s average pollution is nearing the permissible limit and showing indicators of climate risk,” said Centre for Science and Environment’s executive director Anumita Roy Chowdhury.She said climate risk will be visible in the form of rising temperatures, increased premature births, deaths and respiratory disorders. Climate risk for coastal areas is indicated by a temperature of 30-32 degrees and Kerala is recording higher temperatures.“We cannot completely link it to just pollution. There are several factors including sea surface temperatures and other parameters. But, we need to take a note of it on land,” said Aravindakumar.PCB’s latest data showed that maximum pollution in Kochi was recorded between November and February. Since Kerala enjoys monsoon between June and November, the air is comparatively clean in those months.Pulmonologists said the impact of rising air pollution is visible in the cases they treated in the past few years.“Rubble and dust from construction site, road works affect people in the neighbourhood. We are seeing more cases of upper respiratory infections in city and its outskirts. The chances of contracting infections are high and for persons with respiratory disorders or pre-asthmatic condition, hospital visits will double in a year.,” said pulmonologist Dr Ramesh Nair.

Title: Christians ‘ashed’ their sins as Lent opens with Ash Wednesday
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Indore: Churches in city were crowded with hundreds of devotees for the holy Eucharistic mass of Ash Wednesday , which opens Lent , the 40-day period of abstinence and deprivation for Christians before Easter.

Considered as a time for introspection and sacrifice, during Ash Wednesday Christians confessed their sins and professed their devotion to God . Priests at the churches placed ashes in the shape of a cross on foreheads of the devotees to remind them that they are made of dust and will return to dust. The ash put up on the forehead is made of the palm leaves used previous year for the Palm Sunday.

The 40-day period of repentance also leads to Palm Sunday, Maundy Thursday and Good Friday. Bearing in mind the message of Pope Francis for Lent Dr Chacko Thottumarickal also encouraged devotees to pray continually since prayer is more than an obligation and it always precedes and sustains people.

Besides praying, most of the christians believe in refraining from doing anything or any habit that they find extremely difficult to stay away from or think is unpleasant in the sight of God. Mostly people fast by doing so, devotees try to imitate Christ's fasting for 40 days in the desert.

During Lent season, ‘Way of the Cross’, a prayer which represent different stages of Jesus Christ’s journey on the cross that finally ended with his crucifixion is prayed on every Wednesday and Friday.

All the catholic churches of Indore conducted holy Eucharistic mass twice- in morning and evening- for the devotees.

“Attending the holy mass on Ash Wednesday is a tradition. Families consider it mandatory. But due to hectic work schedule in morning, people mostly come for it in the evening,” a devotee Emily D’souza told TOI.

“Every year, I don’t eat non-vegetarian meals for 40 days and also refrain from becoming angry,” she added.

Title: General, OBC state employees protest against reservation in promotion
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Dehradun: Protesting against reservation in promotion, hundreds of state government employees from OBC and general categories took out a mashaal (torch) rally in the city. The agitating employees also burnt the effigy of Union minister Ram Vilas Paswan who recently hailed reservation system and stated that the job reservation will stay put till caste system exists in the country.

Deepak Joshi, president of General-OBC Workers’ Organisation of Uttarakhand, told TOI, “Over eight thousand employees have been awaiting their promotion since several years. These employees work in departments ranging from education, health, transport, and others. Now that the Supreme Court order on promotion in reservation has come, the state government must not delay our promotions any further. If our demands are not met by the month end, the employees will sit on strike.”

Joshi further said that more than two lakh members of the General-OBC organisation across the hill state have joined the protests in various districts. “The Supreme Court has already ruled in our favour. We believe that there should be no reservations in promotions and it is unfair to subvert the directions of the Supreme Court. We will not suffer injustice anymore,” added Joshi.

Meanwhile, the state government employees from Scheduled Caste (SC) and Scheduled Tribe (ST) communities have threatened to launch mass protest in the state if they aren’t given reservation in promotion. The state government has already formed a sub-committee with three ministers to handle this matter.

Hundreds of unemployed youths also launched protests in the state on Tuesday over the recent instance of cheating in the forest guard recruitment exam and alleged failure of state government to provide jobs. The agitators continued their protest outside secretariat on Wednesday. The police detained some of the protesters who tried to break police barricades but they were later released in the evening. The protesters were claiming that they will not leave the spot until the chief minister meets them.

Title: Now, a library for the neo-literates
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Kerala State Literacy Mission Authority has set up a library and study centre at ‘Aksharam’, the headquarters of Literacy Mission at Pettah .

It is the first library set up by the Literacy Mission for candidates registered in its equivalency programme and their instructors.

Education minister C Raveendranath officially inaugurated the library on Wednesday. It functions on the first floor of the main building of the office.

“The library is another achievement for the Literacy Mission, which has received accolades from across the world for its initiatives,” said Raveendranath.

As many as 9,525 books were collected for the library. Novels, children’s books, and works on alternative education, science, mathematics etc. have been arranged at the library.

Literacy Mission director P S Sreekala said that more books will be bought for the library in coming days.

The library is also open for other students and general public.

A reading space has been arranged at the library and books cannot be taken home.

“An amount of Rs 2 lakh was reserved to buy books for the library. We are planning to buy books based on demand from students,” said a Literacy Mission staff.

The minister presented a prize to Kozhikode project coordinator Abdul Rasheed, for collecting highest number of books for the library. Also, 14 ‘preraks’ who collected large number of books for the library received prizes.

The minister also felicitated assistant director K Ayyapan Nair and Kozhikode assistant district project coordinator Radhakrishnan at the function, who are retiring from service.

Title: GMR gets Rs 5,248 cr from Groupe ADP
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hyderabad: Less than a week after GMR Group entered into a pact with Groupe ADP of France for selling 49% stake in its airports business, it has received Rs 5,248 crore towards the first tranche of payment from the French airports player. The transaction is pegged at Rs 10,780 crore, including Rs 9,780 crore towards secondary sale of shares by GMR group and Rs 1,000 crore equity infusion in GAL.

GMR Group, which runs the Indira Gandhi International Airport at Delhi and the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport in Hyderabad, said on Wednesday that the funds received will primarily be used for corporate debt reduction.

It also said that with this deal it has provided an exit to the existing private equity investors in GMR Airports Ltd.

It was only last week that GMR announced its intent to sell 49% stake in its airports arm GAL and 100% stake in GMR Infra Services Ltd (GISL), an operating and holding company whose primary business is to hold shares in GAL. The deal was, a day later, approved by competition watchdog Competition Commission of India (CCI) under the green channel route.

Title: Mira Road woman on way home from coronavirus-hit ship
Content:
Sonali Thakkar on a bus to Tokyo’s Haneda airport after disembarking from Diamond Princess ship

MUMBAI: Mira Road resident Sonali Thakkar’s 24-day ordeal is close to being over as she was evacuated from the coronavirus-hit Diamond Princess ship along with over 120 Indians on Wednesday. Sixteen of 138 Indians, including 132 crew members and six passengers, onboard the ship docked at Japan’s Yokohama port since February 3, have tested positive for the infection so far and taken to hospitals there.Sonali (24), who works as a security officer on the cruise liner, had been sending desperate pleas for evacuation as more passengers and crew members contracted the infection with every passing day. On Wednesday, her father Dinesh said Sonali sent them a picture showing she had boarded a bus and was headed to the Haneda airport from where an Air India plane was to fly them to Delhi. The Indians were ferried from the Yokohama port to Haneda—a 20km journey— in four buses, he said.More than 700 of the 3,700-odd Diamond Princess passengers have tested positive for Covid-19 since it docked at Yokohama. At least four have reportedly died. The isolation of passengers on board the ship by Japanese authorities has met with criticism as it proved ineffective to contain the infection.Thakkar’s family is relieved. “My daughter was in jail for 24 days. She is finally free,” said father Dinesh.In Maharashtra, 91 symptomatic travellers have been isolated. As on Wednesday, two from Mumbai and one from Pune were in isolation.

Title: Kerala: Soaring mercury, hidden pollution
Content:
PCB’s latest data showed that maximum pollution in Kochi was recorded between November and February.

Kerala’s most-polluted cities are Kochi and Thiruvananthapuram and air pollution is increasing steadily in the state with the average PM 10 (particulate matter 10 micrometers or less in diameter) levels touching the permissible limit of 60 microns on most days a month.
