Title: Cop booked for taking Rs 50k bribe
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Vadodara: The anti-corruption bureau’s (ACB) Vadodara unit booked a head constable of Dahej marine police station on Tuesday for demanding and accepting Rs 50,000 as hush-up money in a prohibition case. Cops have also arrested a man from Karjan in this connection.

The complainant was going to Bharuch for a wedding when his father’s friend asked him to take his gift along. On reaching Madhuli circle at Bharuch, a car stopped the complainant and a man who identified himself as a cop, checked the gift box and found Indian-made foreign liquor bottles from it. ACB said the cop was accused head constable Manish Mistry.

Mistry demanded Rs 2 lakh to avoid prohibition case and after negotiations, settle for Rs 1.25 lakh and took Rs 50,000 cash on the spot.

It was agreed that the complainant will pay him Rs 75,000 in cash later and was asked to pay Rs 50,000 to the middleman Dharmesh Rawal. As he did not wish to pay the money, he informed the ACB and a trap was planned. The complainant contacted Rawal and the duo agreed to meet under the flyover bridge at Narmada chowkdi in Bharuch where he was caught.

Title: Goa: Turbid water trickles from taps in Keri
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Villagers have been receiving turbid water (R) since the past 10 days

By: Afaq Khan

VALPOI: With water levels in the Anjunem dam dipping, the villagers of Keri, Sattari , have been grappling with a severe water shortage for the past 10 days. And when they do get supply from the Keri water treatment plant (WTP), the water is turbid and yellow— unfit to drink, they say.

Assistant engineer for PWD’s water supply division, Valpoi, Prashant Gaude told TOI that the water resources department(WRD) had recently opened the lower gate of the Anjunem dam, resulting in the supply of yellowish water with high iron content. “Usually the WRD officials open the upper gates of the dam, but since there was not enough water at the upper level, they were forced to open the lower gate,” Gaude said.

Gaude further said that a large team of PWD officials had been deployed at the site and were working hard to resolve the issue. “We are taking every precaution to subject the water to more intensive treatments to make it safe to use, we are testing water samples on a daily basis,” he said.

When health minister Vishwajit Rane was informed of the issue, he called a meeting of the PWD and WRD officials on Monday and instructed them to take more precautions while supplying water to the villagers. However, supply is still poor as the Keri WTP has the capacity to treat only 8 MLD of water per day, which is less than half of the daily water consumption of the area.

Speaking to TOI, the sarpanch of Keri village panchayat, Govind Gawas, said that panic gripped Keri village when the yellowish water trickled from their taps, after several days of poor supply. “A few parts of Keri, like Ghoteli, Kewada, Dhangar wada and Shiroli, are located at a height, and the water cannot reach these areas due to low pressure, so tankers have been arranged,” Gawas said, adding that water was now being treated to remove the iron contamination.

Lab technician Dharma Shetyekar said that officials are allowed to release water with iron content less than 0.3 mg/l, which is the permissible limit. “In Keri, we have measured iron content of 1.37 mg per litre of water, which is too high,” Shetyakar said. The villagers may have to cope with water shortage for a few more days as it is taking longer than usual to treat the water, and as a result, only 8MLD of water is released, he said.

Keri-Sattari resident Devendra Gawas said that 90% of the houses at Keri are still facing the water shortage. Some houses get low pressure supply, but only for few hours— not even long enough for their tanks to fill, he complained. "Officials say that they provide tankers to the houses where there is water scarcity, but there are many homes in Keri where the tankers cannot reach due to the terrain of the areas, or lack of roads for the tankers to navigate. How will these people get water?” he asked.

Title: Delhi: Chief Justice’s bench to now hear hate speech case
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

File photo of Delhi high court

NEW DELHI: The petition seeking prosecution of BJP members Kapil Mishra and others for alleged hate speech will now be heard by Chief Justice’s bench on Thursday.

The bench of justices S Muralidhar and Talwant Singh took Delhi Police to task on Wednesday, for their failure to book Mishra, BJP MP and minister Anurag Thakur, MP Parvesh Verma and MLA Abhay Verma. It gave time till Thursday 2.30pm for police to inform what action it plans to take against these functionaries.

However, the cause list for Thursday reflects the matter now stands transferred to the court of Chief Justice D N Patel, who is back at the helm, after being out of station on Monday and Tuesday.

Since even the second senior-most judge, justice G S Sistani was not available on Tuesday, the next in line of seniority — Muralidhar — then heard the petitions and conducted a midnight hearing to issue a series of directions to police and AAP government and help violence affected persons.

As per the high court roster, only the chief justice’s bench or justice Sistani’s court can hear PIL matters, writ petitions challenging the constitutional validity of any law or invoking constitutional provisions. Rules specify that in absence of the chief justice, urgent mentioning of a case or petitions highlighting public interest causes that need immediate intervention, can be heard by the second senior-most judge.

Title: Gujarat budget: Tur dal chosen to ration out strength
Content:
State finance minister Nitin Patel announced in the budget that under the new scheme, 12 kg Tur Dal will be di... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Gujarat does not have enviable statistics of malnutrition, especially among children. A recent Comprehensive Nutrition Survey (2016-18) of the government of India stated that 39 per cent of children in Gujarat below the age of four are stunted. In what appears to be a corrective measure by the state government, Tur dal, a source of protein in a largely vegeterain state, has for the first time been included in the list of groceries that are sold through the public distribution system (PDS).“We have been consistently demanding for universalisation of public distribution system in the country. Introduction of Tur Dal in the PDS is an important step in ensuring people get a protein rich diet. I hope they start introducing protein-rich diet in anganwadis of the state as well,” said Neeta Hardikar, director, Anna Suraksha Adhikar Abhiyan. She added that the Gujarat government should follow states like Madhya Pradesh and Chhatisgarh and introduce eggs in mid-day meal scheme.State finance minister Nitin Patel announced in the budget that under the new scheme, 12 kg Tur Dal will be distributed to each beneficiary at concessional rates from PDS outlets. There are 66 lakh beneficiaries under the PDS in the state. The state has made a provision of Rs 287 for this addition to list of groceries under the PDS.The government announced a number of new schemes in 2020 state budget to address burning issues. A scheme called the `Madre Vatan Yojana’ was also announced during the budget. Under the scheme, the state government will contribute an equal amount of donation that an individual gives to develop facilities like school, kindergarten, dispensary or other public amenities in villages. A provision of Rs 200 crore has been made under the scheme.In its bid to curb pollution and make state plastic free, the state government has announced a scheme to purchase plastic and dry waste from rag pickers in cities. A provision of Rs 56 crore has been made for this scheme, finance minister Patel said.The state government has also extended the `Smart Cities’ scheme to towns. For the first time, a sum of Rs 100 crore has been allocated for five municipalities (Rs 20 crore for each) who have done commendable work in developing people-oriented facilities.

Title: Kolkata: 12 fall prey to KYC cons in 72 hours, cops issue warning
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The detective department’s crackdown seems to have had little effect on e-wallet frauds in the city, with 12 cases being reported from Kolkata, Bidhannagar, and Barrackpore police areas over the past 72 hours. TOI accessed at least six FIRs, the most prominent ones being reported from Girish Park, Netaji Nagar, Patuli, Salt Lake and Garfa. The total loss has been estimated at Rs 5 lakh.With around 50 complaints being lodged over the past two months, joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma again issued an warning, asking people, especially senior citizens, not to fall in the trap of the fraudsters.One such victim was 65-year-old Sonali Biswas, a resident of Madan Chatterjee Street at Girish Park, who received a message last Sunday evening, stating her e-wallet would be blocked if KYC formalities were not completed. Panicking, she responded to the message, and following “instructions” given out, she downloaded a an app, TeamViewer QuickSupport, on her mobile and shared an OTP. The app allowed the accused to gain control over her mobile. Shortly, she received five messages from her bank, alerting her that Rs 90,299 had been debited from her account in five transactions. At Netaji Nagar, Amiya Basu of Baikuntha Apartment alleged she was coaxed into disclosing her ATM card details and share OTP on the pretext of filling up a KYC form on Sunday. A total of Rs 73,347 was siphoned off from her account, police said.According to police, the accused targeted customer by asking them to download an application on their mobiles or computers to facilitate the KYC process. These applications include Anydesk and TeamViewer Quicksupport, said police sources, adding the accused gained access to the victims’ gadgets and siphoned off money from their accounts by using their bank details.Another victim was Narendra Kumar Das (46), a resident of Patuli Township, lodged a complaint that around 5:30pm on Sunday, he received a text and a call from an unknown number, asking him to upgrade the KYC for his e-wallet. After he shared his bank details and OTP, Rs 65,461 was withdrawn from his account, “causing wrongful loss to the complainant”. Salt Lake’s Ashmi Bhattacharya, who lives in FE Block, reportedly lost Rs 21,000 after she was also asked to download TeamViewer QuickSupport.Paytm founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma had taken to social media in November last year to plead with customers to maintain caution and not fall for scam messages and emails from fraudsters, pretending to be company officials. “Pls (please) don’t trust any SMS sent on blocking your Paytm account or suggestion to do a KYC. These are fraudsters…” Sharma had tweeted.

Title: Activist Piyush Manush held for assaulting landlord, 53
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Salem: Social activist Piyush Manush,40, was arrested on Wednesday for allegedly attacking his house owner, a widow, when she asked him to vacate the rental house.

In her complaint, 53-year-old Asha Kumari, of Kondappanaickenpatty area at the foothills of Yercaud, said she had rented out her house to Piyush Manush in 2015.

Pointing out that she had been residing in Bengaluru with her husband S N Singh, Kumari said she had decided to shift to her own house in Kondappanaickenpatty area after the demise of her husband in April 2017. “I requested Piyush to vacate the house, but he refused. I subsequently didn’t renew the rental agreement in 2018. After that too, he not only refused to vacate the house but also stopped paying me the rent.”

On Monday, Asha Kumari had approached the activist with a request to vacate the house. This time, Piyush allegedly assaulted her, and she lodged a complaint with city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar. The case was transferred to the Kannankurichi police.

She had also met chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami in Salem the same day and petitioned him to take action against her tenant.

On Wednesday, police inspector V Thangavel held an inquiry with Piyush Manush for nearly three hours. “We subsequently registered four cases against him under Sections 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty), 294 (b) (sings, recites or utters any obscene song, ballad or words, in or near any public place), 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt) and 506 (1) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and arrested him,” the officer said.

The activist was produced before the judicial magistrate of Salem district court and lodged in the Vellore Central Prison under judicial custody in the evening.

Talking to reporters, Piyush’s wife Monika said they had spent Rs 4 lakh to renovate the house before they moved into it in 2015. “Moreover, our children are studying in a nearby school and we can’t vacate the house until their exams are over.” She said there was political pressure on police to arrest her husband as he had opposed central and state government projects that were against farmers and public.

Title: Telangana: Constable kicks dead girl’s father
Content:
Screenshot of cop kicking the suicide victim’s father

HYDERABAD: A video of a constable kicking an ex-serviceman, who made a vain bid to stall the men in khaki from shifting the body of his daughter to Patancheru government hospital, went viral on Wednesday. Later in the day, Sangareddy superintendent of police Chandana Deepti transferred and attached the constable, Sridhar, to district headquarters.Patancheru police said 16-year-old Sandhya, who was pursuing Intermediate at Narayana Junior College, committed suicide by hanging in the bathroom of her hostel with a rope from the geyser on Tuesday. After the suicide, her parents were informed and her body was shifted to a local government hospital for post-mortem examination (PME). She did not leave a suicide note, but was reportedly unwell. Based on a complaint lodged by her father, a negligence case was registered against the college.As Sandhya’s PME was to be performed, her body was kept in a freezer box. On Wednesday morning, members of students organisation SFI reached the hospital and staged a protest demanding that action be taken against the private college, accusing them of negligence.SFI members barged into the hospital and forcibly pulled out the freezer box from the mortuary in the presence of police personnel, who were monitoring the protest by 30-40 students.“The students brought the freezer box on to the road and they wanted to stage a protest at the college with the body. The PME was not performed by then. Police had to intervene and when they were bringing the body back to the mortuary, her father suddenly fell in front of the freezer to stop them from wheeling it back,’’ Patancheru police told TOI.At that time, a constable kicked the girl’s father and forcibly removed him. However, the entire action was caught on camera and it went viral on social media.“We are conducting an inquiry into the incident, and the erring constable has been attached to the district headquarters,” Deepti told TOI.Meanwhile, police registered a case against the protesters for illegal assembly, obstructing doctors from performing duty, vandalism and other charges.In Video: Policeman kicks father of deceased girl who committed suicide in Telangana

Title: MSU report says girls beat boys in cheating in exams
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Vadodara: “Number of girl students caught adopting unfair means while appearing in the exams have gone up,” said Prof M N Parmar, convenor of MSU’s unfair means committee, which disclosed a report on “copy cats” found during the first half exams conducted at the university campus.

The report alarmingly revealed that as many as 67 girl students were caught adopting unfair means during the examination, while only 59 boys were found cheating.

However, Parmar further said that exam reforms introduced by the university along with awareness programmes have resulted in lesser number of copycats.

“Overall the number of such cases have reduced significantly. Earlier, we would find more than 200 cases, which came down to 170 last time and this time we have 130 such cases,” he said.

Explaining why cases of cheating have gone down over time, Parmar said that many students now know that if they fail in a particular subject in the month of June, they can appear again in the month of October. “This is much better instead of wasting an entire term if they are caught cheating,” he added.

While most of them were found to be using traditional methods of using chits, writing answers on clip boards and body parts, some were novel methods were revelations even for the hawk-eyed faculty.

Title: CCTV cameras to prevent copying during SSC, intermediate exams
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: State minister for education minister Adimulapu Suresh on Wednesday said CCTV cameras will be deployed at examination centers to prevent copying during SSC and intermediate examinations to be held in March.

Addressing a press meet, the minister said Andhra Pradesh School Education Department and Board of Intermediate Education would use advanced technology to conduct the examinations in a fair and transparent way.

Suresh said the government was focused on bringing in reforms to create a stress-free environment for students . “We have made elaborate arrangements for the public examinations this year.

“Co-ordination committees with officials of education, revenue, electricity and APSRTC have been formed to provide amenities for students at examination centers. District collectors are playing a key role in coordination works. Safe drinking water, electricity, city bus facility will be provided at all examination centers across the state,” said the minister.

“We have directed authorities to arrange benches and furniture to students so that no one sits on the floor to write exams. We are verifying possibilities of utilising the services of village volunteers as invigilators for intermediate exams,” he said.

“There is no internal assessment and bit paper for SSC students from this academic year. We have directed the officials to conduct awareness programmes for students about the revised pattern. Motivation and counseling on stress management will be conducted at government schools to help students,” said the minister.

Title: Goa: Government submissive to casinos, says Curtorim MLA
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco

MARGAO: Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco has expressed his disapproval over the permission granted by the state government for the ninth onshore casino to be opened at a starred hotel on Kadamba plateau.

Accusing the government of having become “submissive to casinos”, Lourenco said it would never act against them “as it is solely dependent on this gambling industry to finance its BJP party, both locally and nationally”.

“How desperate the BJP state government is towards casino money can be gauged by the fact that the nod for the ninth casino was given just before the code of conduct was enforced for the zilla panchayat elections,” Lourenco said in a press note.

He further pointed out that since March 2012, when BJP assumed power in Goa, it kept giving false promises on establishing a gaming commission, shifting offshore casinos out of the Mandovi river and banning entry to Goans.

“The state government should take a leaf from the neighbouring Karnataka, which has ruled casinos out. Very recently, Karnataka tourism minister C T Ravi said there were no plans to open casinos to boost tourism in the state,” Lourenco added. He further urged the government to try and open environmentally friendly industries.

Title: Olympiad calls homeopathy ‘pseudoscience’, angers doctors
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Homeopathy doctors are furious over a question in the Indian National Junior Science Olympiad test terming the stream of medicine as “pseudoscience”. They have demanded disciplinary action against concerned people and an apology.

The INJSO 2020 test conducted by the Homi Bhabha Centre for Science Education (HBCSE) took place earlier this month. Question 31 carrying seven marks was found to be objectionable by doctors who said it “mocked” homeopathy as a pseudoscience . Indian National Junior Science Olympiad (INJSO) is a competitive exam open to secondary school students. “I got a rude shock when I came to know that the INJSO–2020 exam Question 31 makes a mockery of homoeopathy,” said Dr Praful Barvalia.

When TOI contacted Aniket Sule, a reader at HBCSE, he said the question was printed after “proper consideration... There are hardly any countries in the world that consider homeopathy as a medical science. Our question is about calculating scientifically if there is any meaning in the claims made by homeopathy.”

Homeopaths say the stream has lakhs of subscribers in India and is recognized by AYUSH, a part of the ministry of health.

Sule said, “There are government programmes which fund research to find the medicinal effect of cow urine. That does not mean medicinal effect of cow urine is a factual science. Or, say, there are universities which have graduation programmes in astrology. That does not mean it is meaningful science.”

A doctor said, “INJSO comes under the government of India. AYUSH is also a part of the government. Homoeopathy is an integral part of AYUSH. How can one part of the government do this?”

Title: Goa: Carnival floats snap cables, government offices lose connectivity
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The RTO office at Mapusa wore a deserted look on Wednesday

PANAJI/SALIGAO: Citizens queuing up at the regional transport office (RTO) in Mapusa on Tuesday and Wednesday were in for a rude shock to learn systems were paralysed, and the internet connectivity could not be restored. All operations pertaining to licensing, registration of vehicles and that of high security registration plates (HSRP) were suspended on both days.

A notice has been placed outside the office stating that there is a network connectivity issue since Tuesday and the “inconvenience caused is highly regretted”. Internet connectivity comes under the purview of the Goa Broadband Network (GBBN). Sources from GBBN said that there was a fibre cut in the town’s aerial cabling which occurred during Tuesday’s carnival float parade.

Other government offices in Mapusa like the PWD, police station, electricity department were also affected due to the cut cable, sources said.

A majority of the transport transactions are now online, owing to which various tasks could not be completed by RTO staff. Sources said citizens waiting in line to complete their works had to be sent back on Tuesday. The situation prevailed through a major part of Wednesday as well. “The RTO in Mapusa has been vacant since Tuesday as the systems are not working due to the cable cut. I had been there on both days, but the problem was not resolved,” a Mapusa resident told TOI.

RTO officials said that a lot of licensing and registration work is pending due to this. Assistant director of transport Madan S Fatarpekar told TOI that the entire office is facing problems due to the connectivity issue. “We have informed the internet service provider about the bad connectivity and we expect the problem to be resolved as soon as possible,” he said. The HSRP operations counter at the RTO’s officer was also affected. “The connection was restored later in the day. But by that time, most citizens had stopped coming in,” an RTO official said.

GBBN confirmed that the lines were restored by Wednesday afternoon.

Title: Hearing posted to March 3rd week
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Vijayawada: The high court on Wednesday heard the petition related to the shifting of the capital from Amaravati. The court divided the petitions into three parts.

Petitions related to the shifting of the high court to Kurnool and those seeking development in Amaravati were heard as one set and the court posted the matter to March 17 for hearing.

Meanwhile, petitions challenging Andhra Pradesh Decentralisation and Inclusive Development of All Regions Bill and APCRDA Repeal Bill 2020 were considered as the second set. The court posted these petitions to March 30 for hearing.

Ashok Bhan, counsel for the petitioners, argued that the CRDA Repeal Bill and decentralization of capital Bills were unconstitutional. He cited the example of the combined high court orders on stalling the Telangana government’s proposal of shifting the secretariat to Gachibowli, Hyderabad. tnn

Title: Capital farmers challenge GO-107 in HC
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Vijayawada: The state government’s decision to allocate some of Amaravati capital lands for the construction of affordable houses for families below the poverty line sparked a major controversy in the state. Farmers opposed GO no 107 given by the state government on Tuesday allocating 1251.5 acres land in villages in the capital region to build affordable houses for the poor.

The Andhra Pradesh government, which is gearing up to give house sites for around 25 lakh poor by Ugadi on March 25, is undertaking a huge exercise in identifying land. Around 1,500 acres of land is required to allocate house sites for the poor residing in Vijayawada, Tadepalli, Mangalagiri, and Duggirala.

The state government had decided to give land to around 54,307 beneficiaries.

Amaravati farmers challenged the GO in the high court. The counsel representing the capital farmers requested the Andhra Pradesh high court, on Wednesday, to cancel the GO as capital lands were meant for development activities. They argued that the government is trying to create slums in Amaravati. The court posted the case to Thursday for further hearing.

Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan said that the government is deliberately trying to create a rift among the people. “The government issued orders allocating the lands acquired for the capital city for the purpose of house sites for the poor as it will lead to disputes. No one will find fault in allocating house sites to the poor people. If the government has real commitment, it should give dispute free lands. The poor people will suffer with further legal complications,” Pawan said.

Title: Dharmapuri lad gets into TNPL T20 squad
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Dharmapuri: For the first time, the Tamil Nadu Cricket Club (TNCC) has selected a player from the district for the Tamil Nadu Premier League (TNPL) T20 cricket tournament.

In a meeting convened to select new and young faces for the TNPL T20 in Chennai on Wednesday, TNCC selected S Vijayakumar, of A Mallapuram village near Palacode here to represent the ‘Chepauk Super Gillies’ team.

“I am the first person to be selected for TNPL T20 from Dharmapuri district,” Vijayakumar, a MSc graduate, said.

Vijayakumar’s father Sakthivel is a farmer.

A right-handed spin bowler, Vijayakumar had represented school, college and university level cricket tournaments between 2005 and 2016. “I had also participated in national level cricket tournaments that were held across the country,” he said.

“A total of 633 cricketers were listed and my name was selected for Chepauk Super Gillies team,” Vijayakumar said.

He thanked Dharmapuri district cricket club for recommending his name for TNCC.

Title: Gujarat: 18 political, religious leaders booked for Khambhat riots
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The riots started last Sunday in Akbarpura area

VADODARA/ ANAND: Khambhat police has booked 18 political and religious leaders, including members of right-wing Hindu Jagran Manch, were booked for illegally organizing a public gathering and delivering inciting speeches after the town was singed by communal riots for two days.

The 18 persons have been booked for violation of public notification issued by Anand district magistrate which prohibits gathering of four or more persons in a public place. They had organized a gathering attended by hundreds of people at Khambhat’s main Tower Bazaar area on Tuesday.

Khambhat police sub inspector M J Chaudhary has registered the offence against former BJP MLA Sanjay Patel, Khambhat BJP’s city unit president Pinakin Brahmbhatt, Yogesh Shah alias Saadi, Nanka Patel, Jayveer Jayraj Joshi, Nandkishore Brahmbhatt, Vishwanand Swami of Chhatardiwala Ashram, Hansa Shrigol from Hindu Jagran Manch (HJM), Nadiad unit president of HJM Ketan Patel, Vadodara unit president of HJM Niraj Jain, Dharmendrasinh Rathod, Kalpesh Pandit, Ashok Khalasi.

Councillor Raju Rana, former councillor Mangoo Shah, Rita Rana, a resident of Gandhrak Wado Balram Pandit and a resident of Gavara area Parthiv Patel have also been booked for the offence.

Meanwhile, situation was slowly returning to normal in the town and no fresh violence was reported on Wednesday.

According to the complaint registered at Khambhat city police station, after the communal riots on Sunday, no public rally, public gathering or programme was granted permission in the town.

The complaint states that the leaders had called for bandh on Tuesday and a crowd of around 6,000 man and women had gathered at the Gavara tower area to attend the public gathering. FIR states that the leaders gave inciting speeches at the gathering. The cops had later stopped the leaders from delivering their speeches and asked the crowd to disperse, the complaint states.

In another FIR, three accused including one Viral Patel, Jignesh Chunara and Ishwar Macchi have been booked along with a mob of around 500 others for targeting houses in Mochiwad area of Khambhat on Tuesday afternoon. The town which has remained on the edge since Sunday’s flare up had witnessed a violence when a mob had set a house and a shop ablaze in Mochiwad.

The riots on Sunday had started from Akbarpura area when members of Muslim and Chunara community had resorted to heavy stone pelting. Later, the clash had spread to other areas of the town leaving as many as 13 persons injured while around 30 houses and shops were set ablaze by rioters who had also damaged over a dozen vehicles.

Title: Godhra top bosses cough up taxes for their govt offices
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

District collector Amit Arora paying the taxes

Vadodara: A flurry of activity was witnessed at the Godhra municipality headquarters on Wednesday when almost all top officials of the district administration and police converging on the premises in the morning hours.

The officials including Panchmahal district collector Amit Arora, district development officer A J Shah, superintendent of police Leena Patil and other senior officials had turned up together to pay property taxes for the buildings of their respective departments, responding to a move by the district collector to motivate others in the town to pay their taxes.

A municipality official said that Rs 33.22 lakh was deposited by government offices to the civic body on Wednesday.

The cash-strapped Godhra municipality is suffering default in tax collection of Rs 17.5 crore. These include Rs 9.6 crore for the current year and Rs 7.9 crore due from the previous years.

In the past, the civic body has struggled to pay salaries, electricity bills and other dues due to shortage of cash.

Arora who took the lead in the initiative said that the officials took the lead to ensure that the recovery of tax got a boost.

“We wanted to promote a culture of people paying their dues to the municipality,” he said.

The officials even appealed to the elected representatives to join the initiative.

Arora said that large business houses and citizens in general also joined the initiative taking the total collection in Godhra to Rs 48.9 lakh.

He added that across the district similar initiatives were taken up and the total collection from all four municipalities in Panchmahal on Wednesday stood at Rs 60lakh.

Title: Rajini’s brother blames oppn parties for riots over CAA
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Krishnagiri: Actor Rajinikanth’s brother Sathyanarayana Rao Gaekwad on Wednesday held the opposition parties responsible for the riot over the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) issue in New Delhi. “I am supporting the move as CAA is good for the country. The opposition parties are instigating people to revolt against CAA. Prime minister Narendra Modi will settle the issue at the earliest,” he said.

He also strongly condemned the riots that unsettled the capital city when US president Donald Trump was touring the country. “Such riots will tarnish the country’s image overseas.”

Gaekwad was in Burgur to attend a marriage reception. While speaking to the media outside the marriage hall, he said Rajinikanth would make an announcement on his political party this year itself. “He will name the party and also allies. He will come to his native village Nachikuppam before making any major announcement.”

Title: Gehlot supports Sonia’s demand for resignation of Shah
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Jaipur: Chief Minister Ashok Gehlot on Wednesday justified Congress president Sonia Gandhi’s demand for the resignation of Union home minister Amit Shah , saying he had failed to curb the violence in Delhi.

Gehlot said, Shah should resign on moral grounds as he did “nothing to save lives and restore normalcy” in the national capital.

Earlier in the day, the Congress chief alleged that there was a “well-planned” conspiracy behind the violence, that also led to injuries to more than 200 people over the past three days.

The Centre, the home minister and the Delhi government are responsible for the situation in the national capital, Sonia Gandhi alleged.

Supporting her demand for Shah’s resignation, Gehlot tweeted, “Congress president Sonia Gandhi has rightly demanded that the Home Minister should resign, given his ‘inaction’ during incidents of violence and arson in Delhi and his inability to control the situation. Delhi has been burning and we see no action from Home Minister.”

The chief minister added, “What we are witnessing in Delhi is a result of inflammatory speeches and provocative statements given by BJP leaders. They have purposely created a vicious environment of hatred and fear. Worst is the authorities remained a mute spectator and did nothing to control the situation.”

Title: Bengaluru: Jilted man who fired at lover critical after suicide bid
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Accused Amarendra Pattanaik

BENGALURU: The case of a miscreant opening fire at a 25-year-old woman in Whitefield on Tuesday evening has taken an interesting turn. The man, who is suspected to be the woman’s jilted lover, was found lying unconscious near Marathahalli bridge in the early hours of Wednesday.

Amarendra Pattanaik, a native of Odisha, works as a software engineer with a firm in Hyderabad. Police identified him on the basis of a 17-page handwritten note in English with him. While the woman, Subhashree Priyadarshini, is out of danger now, Pattanaik is battling for life.

On Tuesday evening, Pattanaik opened fire on Priyadarshini outside her paying guest accommodation in Manjunath Layout, Munnekolala. Another PG occupant had rushed her to a hospital. Police had recovered a country-made pistol and a mobile phone from the spot.

Priyadarshini and Pattanaik worked for a software firm in Hyderabad. In 2018, Priyadarshini moved to Bengaluru and joined Nimhans as a software developer. According to her colleagues, Pattanaik would come to Bengaluru to meet her.

Around 2.30am on Wednesday, passersby saw Pattanaik lying unconscious near Marathahalli bridge and alerted police.

“Initially, we thought it was an accident. After reading the 17-page note, we realised he was the man who shot Priyadarshini. He had slit his throat and wrist. After he fell on the road, a vehicle knocked him down,” an investigating officer said.

Another officer said the last page of the note explained how movable properties of Pattanaik should be dispersed after his death. “The other pages talk about his relationship with Priyadarshini and how frustrated he was after she moved to Bengaluru. But we need to confirm his claims,” he added.

Disowned by family?

Police said Pattanaik’s family has so far refused to come down from Odisha to attend to him. “Both his younger brother and father said they had severed ties with him,” an officer said.

Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Krishnagiri: Two people were killed after the bike they were travelling in hit a truck that was parked on the roadside near Hosur here in the early hours of Wednesday.

The Soolagiri police identified the deceased as V Ajith Kumar, 20, of Arunapuram village in Villupuram district and his friend Tirumurthy, 27, of Sathyadhiri layout area in Bengaluru. Both were carpenters.

An investigation officer said the incident took place while the two were returning to Bengaluru from Krishnagiri, where they had come for work. “Tirumurthy was driving the bike, while Kumar was on the pillion. When they neared Chinnaru on Krishnagiri-Bengaluru national highway around 6.30am, Tirunurthy lost control over the vehicle, which crashed into the stationed truck from behind. Title: 10 tourists stranded in snow rescued
Content: Pithoragarh: At least 25 people, including 10 tourists , were rescued by police from Kalamuni area on Tuesday night as they were stranded due to heavy snowfall.The rescue operation took around six hours, a distance which usually takes around 20 minutes by road.Munsyari station house officer MC Joshi said that snowfall on the stretch between Kalamuni and Pathal Thaud started around 5pm and 25 people were trapped in around half-foot snow. Though some people tried to cover the 16km distance on foot, they later alerted police who sent a team. The SHO said that all of them were rescued by 11pm.

Title: Ajit Doval: NSA Ajit Doval visits riot-hit areas again, assures people of ‘full protection’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Doval assured people of adequate security and told the media that police is on the ground and doing its job

NEW DELHI: Residents of riot-hit northeast Delhi had an unexpected visitor late on Tuesday night and Wednesday afternoon with National Security Advisor Ajit Doval knocking on the doors for real and speaking to them as he walked around extensively, meeting and assuring people to not worry or feel scared.

“Ab sab theek hai.. koi darne ki baat nahi hai.. We are here as per orders of HM and PM... Inshallah yahan par bilkul aman hoga...,” he said. Doval visited several areas like Brahmpuri, Ghonda, Jafrabad, Maujpur, Seelampur, Gamdi and Chauhan Bangar and met people at their doorsteps and intersections.

Doval had reached the office of DCP (north-east) in Seelampur around 11.45pm on Tuesday and chalked out a plan of action with special CP S N Shrivastava and other senior officers before venturing out on the streets. He returned at 4pm on Wednesday and visited different areas in North-East Delhi after reviewing the situation.

In Brahampuri, he walked a couple of kilometres, meeting people and asking how they were. Many residents got emotional while recalling the riots. At one point, a woman came up to him and said how she almost had a ‘heart attack’ seeing the rioters go on rampage but was feeling assured after seeing him there. Doval wittily replied: “No no.. keep your heart strong.. don’t feel weak so easily.. all is good now.. just stay united.”

At another place, he addressed a group of men at an intersection saying: “Prem ki bhaavna bana kar rakhiye. Hamara ek desh hai, hum sab ko milkar rehna hai. Desh ko mil kar aage badhana hai.”

“People have a sense of unity among them, there is no enmity. A few criminals do things like this (spread violence), people are trying to isolate them. Police is here & doing its work...,” he said while holding residents by the arm and patting their back. Later, he told reporters, “Situation is totally under control. People are satisfied. I have confidence in law enforcement agencies. Police is doing its work... My message is that those who love their country.. also love their society, their neighbour. Everyone should live with love and harmony with others. People should try to resolve each other's problems and not increase them.”

The NSA’s intervention came soon after US President Donald Trump’s state visit ended and followed heightened deployment of police forces on Tuesday night which seemed to have resulted in a reduction in violence.

In his interactions, Doval assured people of adequate security and told the media that police is on the ground and doing its job.

Earlier, Doval, who has been tasked with checking violence, held a meeting with the Delhi Police brass at the office of the deputy commissioner of police (Northeast) in Seelampur. Newly-appointed special CP S N Shrivastava, additional commissioner of police (Crime) Mandeep Singh Randhawa, Special CP (Law and Order) Satisha Golcha and DCP northeast Ved Prakash Arya were among those present.

Title: Prepared a strong case in SC: Goa CM

Chief Minister of Goa, Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The opposition should support the government instead of constantly criticising efforts made by authorities to protect Goa’s interests in the Mhadei water sharing dispute, said chief minister Pramod Sawant on Wednesday. Sawant added that he saw no reason to provide a white paper on the Mhadei dispute as demanded by the opposition.

“Unanimously, the opposition should have supported the government because this is an issue of the state, not of Pramod Sawant. It was vital for them to support the government but instead they are indulging in politics,” he told reporters on the sidelines of a function in Panaji.

Sawant said the state had roped in senior Supreme Court lawyer Mukul Rohatgi to argue on Goa’s behalf and to seek a stay on the notification of the Mahdei Water Disputes Tribunal award. “The way we have prepared a strong case in Supreme Court and prepared evidence, we will win the case,” said Sawant.

Title: Kolkata: Woman dials 100, gets molester on bus arrested
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: A 21-year-old college student travelling on a bus stood up to her molester , dialled 100 and got him arrested.

The incident took place at Jodhpur Park on Tuesday evening, when the young woman from Darjeeling was returning from a nearby popular mall to her Kolkata accommodation at Taltala. The accused has been identified as Rohan Kumar Jaiswal (30), a resident of Howrah.

“The woman boarded a bus on Route 240. Soon after she got a seat, the accused sat next to her. He began touching her inappropriately. She protested and even drew the attention of the conductor but still, the accused continued to harass her. It was then that she placed a call to the Lalbazar Control Room by dialling 100. As the bus headed for Dhakuria, the control room relayed the complaint to Jadavpur police station , Lake police station and the Jadavpur traffic guard. Cops from the Lake police station responded, stopped the bus and caught the accused from the spot,” said an officer.

A case pertaining to molestation and outraging the modesty of a woman has been registered at the Lake police station. Cops said that after the accused was hauled away, the victim was safely dropped off to her residence. “We will record the woman’s statement before a magistrate and might ask for a test identification parade. A charge sheet will follow shortly. We will record the statements of the conductor and some passengers,” said a senior officer.

Police pointed out this was a perfect example of how to react to such situations. “We are always ready to listen and respond to any distress call,” said a Lalbazar officer. Cops said there had been multiple arrests following calls to Dial 100 ever since model Ushoshi Sengupta was chased by helmetless bikers and the brass introduced a new SOP that spoke of coordination between the central control room and the various police stations.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: 3 dead, 1 injured as car falls into gorge
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: Three persons died and another was injured when the car in which they were travelling fell into a gorge in Amritpur village of Bhimtal early on Wednesday.

On information, police rushed to the spot and shifted the injured to a hospital in Haldwani.

Circle officer Anusha Badola said, “The car was around 7km from Amritpur village on Kailash Marg when the driver lost control of the vehicle and it fell into a 200-metre-deep gorge.”

Police said that all the four car passengers were from Kotabagh and were returning home after attending a wedding reception.

“The victims left the ceremony in Bhimtal around midnight and were travelling home. However, their car fell into a gorge. While three of them died on the spot, the driver sustained injuries and has been admitted to a hospital in Haldwani,” they added.

The deceased were identified as Harish Chand (27), Hemchand (25) and Dev Tiwari (30). The injured, Neeraj Semwal, was driving the car when the accident occurred.

Badola said that the families of the victims were informed and the bodies sent for postmortem.

Title: Campus strikes: HC orders strict police action
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Kochi: Reiterating that student organizations do not have the right to compel students to participate in strikes nor do they have the right to conduct strikes on school or college campuses , the high court on Wednesday ordered heads of all educational institutions to promptly report such disturbances to police and asked the state police chief to direct police officers to take prompt action.

Justice PB Suresh Kumar issued the order after considering a total of 26 petitions filed by schools and colleges, with the lead case being a plea by Raju Kuruvilla, manager of MS Higher Secondary School at Ranni in Pathanamthitta, through advocate Jacob P Alex.

In the judgment, the court referred to a 2017 decision (Antony Thomas vs Muhammed Rafique) in which it was held that it is the obligation of police to ensure that academic atmosphere in educational institutions are not disturbed and that educational institutions cannot be hijacked or converted into a political battle field. The court also cited a 2003 decision (Vijayakumar V vs State of Kerala), which held that police can enter campuses to prevent or take action against students engaging in criminal activities.

The court, in its judgment, said: “…organizations of students do not have the right to disrupt or disturb the academic and other activities of students who do not want to partake in their strikes and agitations, or any right to compel such students to forego the aforesaid activities in their campuses. Similarly, it is also declared that organizations of students do not have any right to convene any meetings and resort to the modes of agitations like strike, dharna, gherao, processions, etc in the school or college campuses… It is also declared that it is the obligation of the police to ensure that the fundamental rights of the students to pursue their academics in the campuses are not thwarted by anyone...”

However, the judgment does not mean that students cannot voice their opinions on political issues and redress their grievances by recourse to various forums allowed by statutes and executive orders.

Further, the court said educational institutions are forced to approach the high court for police protection despite several judicial pronouncements regarding the rights of students. The position of government and quasi-government institutions is that students have to forego studies until disturbances and disruptions settle down naturally, the court said. It is the students themselves who become victims of student unrest in campuses, the court pointed out.

Noticing that judicial pronouncements alone won’t suffice, the court ordered, “…I deem it appropriate to direct the director of collegiate education, director of higher secondary education, director of public instruction and also the registrars of the various universities in the state to bring this judgment to the notice of the heads of the educational institutions under them, and direct them to bring the external and internal disturbances affecting the conduct of the classes forthwith to the notice of the police... There will also be a direction to the director general of police to bring this judgment to the notice of the police officers...”

Title: MP contractor cheated of Rs 25 lakh in city
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Vadodara: A civil contractor from Dhar district in Madhya Pradesh was duped of Rs 25 lakh by an alleged iron trader living at Sama and his three aides on Tuesday.

Civil contractor Aslam Multani had come to buy iron rods for his construction project as these cost less in Vadodara than in Madhya Pradesh.

In his complaint lodged at Sama police station, Multani stated that a real estate broker from Indore – Yogesh Agrawal – knew accused iron trader, Rahul Patel. Agrawal told Multani that he can help him get the iron rod at Rs 35 per kg instead of the prevailing price of Rs 44 in Madhya Pradesh. After Multani and his partner managed to arrange Rs 35 lakh, Multani, his friend Rashid Khan and Agrawal came to Vadodara on Tuesday.

On reaching Golden Chowkdi on national highway-48, Patel asked them to wait as he had sent his men to receive them. An hour later three persons reached in an SUV and asked Multani and Agrawal to sit in their car so that they can take them to Patel’s home in Sama. Khan, meanwhile, waited at Golden Chowkdi. When Multani and Agrawal got down on reaching Sama, the three others fled away in their car. Agrawal called up Patel, who asked them to reach Halol.

The duo was picked up from Sama by Khan and drove to Halol. When they reached Halol, Patel asked them to Kalol and later asked to come to Godhra. On reaching Godhra, when Multani called Patel, the latter asked them to come to Dahod. It was then that Multani realized that Patel was only fooling him and he had lost his money.

The trio came back to Vadodara to inform police. Multani registered a complaint of cheating against Patel and his three unidentified men at Sama police station. “We are trying to track down the accused based on the phone number given by the complainant,” said a police official.

Title: Eye on panchayat polls, Gujarat government goes all out to woo farmers
Content:
Finance minister Nitin Patel allocated an impressive Rs 7,423 crore for various schemes being implemented by t... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Facing crucial panchayat polls later this year, the state government has gone all out to placate farmers, who have been badly hit by extended monsoon, cyclones and locust attack.Finance minister Nitin Patel allocated an impressive Rs 7,423 crore for various schemes being implemented by the agriculture, farmer welfare and co-operation department. Last year, the budgetary allocation for agriculture was Rs 7,111 crore.Earlier this month, ceding to a demand by farmers, the government of India had made crop insurance voluntary for farmers and the state government has made a provision of Rs 1,190 crore to pay interest for farmers availing crop insurance.In addition, Patel also announced a new scheme named ‘Dinkar Yojna’ with a inital provision of Rs 500 crore to provide water during the day time for irrigation purposes. Farmers in districts of Saurashtra have been demanding irrigation water during the day time after a series of leopard attacks during the night recently.“The government will strengthen transmission network and install new sub-stations in three years at a cost of Rs 3,500 crore,” Patel said.Besides crop failure due to nature’s fury, farmers are seething over delayed and inadequate compensation for their losses.A sizeable budgetary allocation has been made agriculture, farmer welfare and co-operation department has been earmarked for paying interest on loans taken by farmers and paying premium of farmers who opt for crop insurance scheme.

Title: Trump hurt country's reputation by not mentioning Mahatma in message: Gehlot
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Times News Network

Jaipur: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot accused US President Donald Trump of hurting the country's reputation by not mentioning Mahatma Gandhi in the visitor’s book at Sabarmati Ashram.

Gehlot said a person who does not have any regard for Mahatma Gandhi and whose ideology does not match with that of Gandhi was taken to Sabarmati Ashram in Ahmedabad.

“Mahatma Gandhi's name was not mentioned in the comments; Narendra Modi's name was written. I think that it has hurt the reputation of the country,” the chief minister told reporters here on Wednesday.

Trump visited Sabarmati Ashram on Monday. In his message in the visitor’s book, he wrote: “To my great friend Prime Minister Modi - Thank you for this wonderful visit.”

The next day, during his visit to the Rajghat in Delhi, the US president paid homage to Mahatma Gandhi. “The American people stand strongly with a sovereign and wonderful India -The vision of the great Mahatma — This is a tremendous honour!" Trump wrote in the visitors’ book at Rajghat.

Expressing concern over the violence in Delhi, Gehlot said it was the result of polarisation which was done during the Delhi Assembly elections.

“A campaign was run in Delhi elections for polarisation. They could not succeed that time because the public taught them a lesson, but it is the result of the campaign which the entire world is seeing now,” he said, targeting the BJP.

Gehlot said that US president’s programme remained intact despite the dharnas and demonstrations being held across the country and in the national capital.

Title: NSD wants Thommi in mundu
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

A scene from Suveeran’s play, based on Paul Zacharia’s novella

THRISSUR: Onstage nudity is still too hot to handle. The National School of Drama (NSD) has now asked director Suveeran , to clarify the portrayal of nudity in his play.

NSD asked for clarification on the play, ‘Bhaskara Pattelarum Thommiyude Jeevithavum’, staged in Puducherry on February 12, 2020.

The play, based on Paul Zacharia ’s novella, ‘ Bhaskara Pattelarum Ente Jeevithavum ’, had received wide acclaim at the recently-concluded International Theatre Festival of Kerala .

NSD had given a contract to Suveeran to stage the play at the Bharat Rang Mahotsavam (BRM) International Theatre Festival of India 2020.

The school’s letter said: “As per the law, nudity and obscenity are banned in public performances. It was also verified from the DVD submitted by you that while applying for the participation in BRM, there is no scene of nudity in the said play.’’

Suveeran, an NSD alumnus, replied that it was absurd to argue that rules of “public places” were applicable to work of art. “If nudity can enhance the total feel of the play, it can be used even for public staging. This is what I feel as a director. Incidentally, the play was staged at Puducherry in a closed place, before an invited audience,’’ he said. Suveeran also dismissed the NSD argument that the DVD submitted did not contain nude scenes.

“…the DVD submitted is for quality analysis. A play is not a mechanical imitation of the video documentation of its first performance. The organic nature of the play gives the director freedom to intervene and improve the performance in each ensuing stage,’’ he argued.

Suveeran said the play’s protagonist, a servile character, had almost always been naked. “He is clad in a torn dhoti. The cloth often slips, exposing nudity. This culminates in the final scene in which he runs away naked,” he said.

The director said it was a pity to explain such nuances to an institution like NSD, “which had a rich legacy of promoting experimental plays as part of its academic endeavours.”

Suveeran recalled that as a student, he was given highest marks for a play in which an actor was presented nude.

Title: West Bengal: IIT Kharagpur boy falls off hostel balcony, cops suspect suicide bid
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

IIT Kharagpur

KHARAGPUR: A third-year mathematics student at IIT Kharagpur , Ayush Kumar Mondal, on Wednesday fell from the second-floor balcony of Lal Bahadur Sasthri Hall on the campus. Mondal is critical but stable.

On hearing a loud thud around 7.45am, Ayush’s friends and hostel staffers rushed out to find him him lying on the ground, bleeding. IIT-Kgp’s security staff and cops from the Hijli police outpost rushed to spot and carried Ayush to the campus hospital. From there, he was referred to West Bank Hospital in Howrah. Confirming the fall, Kharagpur ASP Quazi Shamsuddin Ahmed said, “Our preliminary investigation shows it was a suicide bid. But we are probing whether there was any other cause.”

IIT-Kgp’s registrar B N Singh said, “We are yet to ascertain how he fell. He has been sent to Kolkata for treatment. He lived with his mother in an accommodation on the campus. We are trying to find out why he went to Lal Bahadur Sasthri Hall.”

Mondal, a resident of Bhilai, took admission in 2017-18. He was allotted a room at LBS Hall and later, at Nehru Hall. After his family reported he was undergoing mental treatment , IIT authorities allotted him a one-bedroom accommodation on the campus so that he could stay with his mother. On Wednesday morning, his mother had gone to the Technology market, when Ayush went to LBS hall. “At times, he would stay in his Nehru Hall room, which was right next to the warden’s office so that he could be under 24-hour supervision,” a source said.

After initial treatment at BC Roy Technology Hospital, Ayush’s mother, classmate, a hostel staffer and a doctor accompanied him to the Howrah hospital. Though he was referred to Medica, it was decided to send him to West Bank, which was nearer. “It appears he had landed on his feet. There are multiple fractures on his legs for which he will undergo a surgery on Thursday. His father arrived in Kolkata on Wednesday evening,” a source said.

Title: ‘Trump visit gave global impression and showed personal relations of India with Us’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Ajmer: BJP president JP Nadda on Wednesday said the visit of Donald Trump gave a boost to India-US relations. He said Trump’s visit will also help spread the message that India is an emerging country.

Nadda said the visit of Trump will tighten the ties of both countries. He said the world was looking towards India for the development push it got from Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Nadda, however, refused to answer queries on Delhi riots.

Senior BJP leaders like former CM Vasundhara Raje, national vice-president Om Mathur, general secretary Bhupender Vadav, state BJP president Satish Poonia and others also met Nadda and discussed the work of party in Rajasthan.

Sources said there was also discussion over Rajya Sabha elections in Rajasthan.

Nadda was in Pushkar for three days for the marriage of his son. On Wednesday, he came to offer prayers at Brahma Temple and Pushkar Sarovar with his family and the newlywed couple.

Anil Deshmukh

MUMBAI: Home minister Anil Deshmukh on Wednesday promised strict action will be taken against former BJP MLA Narendra Mehta for allegedly harassing a woman corporator from Mira-Bhayandar Municipal Corporation.

MLCs Vidya Chavan of NCP and Manisha Kayande of Shiv Sena raised the issue in the upper house and demanded action against him.

Title: BCA fetes U-19 nat’l champ team with Rs 15L reward
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The Baroda team was felicitated on Wednesday

Vadodara: Last season, Baroda boys faced intense criticism after they lost 18 matches on the trot including games they played in the Under-19 Cooch Behar Trophy.

On Wednesday, the same team was beaming while it picked up the champions cup of Cooch Behar Trophy in presence of Baroda Cricket Association (BCA) management.

The Baroda team that won the national championship 10 days ago was felicitated on Wednesday by the BCA that also announced a cash prize of Rs 15 lakh for all the team members. It is for the first time that such prize has been given by the BCA to the U-19 team for winning the Cooch Behar Trophy after 2007. “We are thankful to the BCA for providing us facilities and motivating the players to perform better. We focussed on our fielding and fitness this season and that helped the team in outplaying our rivals,” said Ajit Bhoite, coach of the team.

It was a team performance as batsman, Parikshit Patidar amassed 752 runs including three centuries and as many fifties, Kush Marathe scored 700 runs consisting of two tons and three fifties while Atharva Karulkar gathered 466 runs including three fifties. In bowling department, Archan Kothari took 46 wickets, Malhar Ghevaria picked 45 wickets and scored 276 runs, Mahesh Pithiya got 44 scalps and 223 runs and Jaypal Chad bagged 11 wickets.

Shashwat Rawat, who joined the team in the finals, scored a crucial 105 runs to help his team win. BCA president Pranav Amin handed over the cheque of Rs 15 lakh to the team. “Coming back into the game after last year’s debacle was like film ‘Chak De’. The team showed perseverance, determination and character and we all need to learn from them,” Amin said.

In a noble gesture, the winning team decided to give Rs 1 lakh to the BCA’s ground staff.

Title: Locks of hope: MBA students donate hair for cancer patients
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

This is the third year that PSG institute of management has organised a hair donation drive.

COIMBATORE: First-year MBA student Kavya S Menon, from PSG Institute of Management , grew up watching her grandmother suffer from cancer. She also noticed that one of the issues that caused her most pain, was losing her thick hair, which she was proud of. On Wednesday, when her college organized a hair donation drive to make free wigs for cancer patients, she was one of the first ones to sign up. At least 70 students also joined Kavya in donating a lock of hair each.

While wigs are available for cancer patients, who lose hair as part of the chemotherapy, good quality ones are usually extremely expensive, making it unaffordable for many people. Good wigs made of natural hair is also rare because it often requires more than six sets of people’s entire hair to make one wig.

Kavya said growing up in a family, where they had several cancer patients including her grandmother, she could always relate to the various issues they face, besides the treatment. “Knowing the heart ache my grandmother bore, giving up a lock of hair is just a small change I have made to make a cancer patient feel better,” she said.

This is the third year that PSG institute of management has organized a hair donation drive. “We tied up with Green Trends salon which cuts and takes the locks of hair, makes it into wigs and distributes it among hospitals. We expect PSG Hospitals to receive a few wigs,” said Vijaya P, director, PSGIM.

“For women, hair makes a big part of their appearance. To give away a part of it feels like giving a small portion of yourself, but we encourage our students to be socially sensitive,” she said.

Along with the students, nearly 15 faculty members too joined in contributing a lock of hair. “ The salon suggested collecting just one lock of hair from the middle portion, so that it does not make any difference in appearance. This in turn will prompt more girls to come forward,” said K Kokilambal, who contributed a 10-inch long lock of her thick hair. “ I think this is the least we can do to help a cancer fighter feel better.”

Title: Corona scare: Airlines ‘rationalize’ services to reduce mounting losses
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Kolkata: The sharp decline in overseas travel following the novel coronavirus outbreak continues to haunt flights to South East Asia with airlines rationalising services or stopping flights altogether to reduce mounting losses.

After China Eastern Airlines stopped flights to Kunming and IndiGo suspended flights to Hong Kong and Guangzhou, Thai Airways sister carrier Thai Smile has prematurely withdrawn services between Bangkok and Kolkata. Sources in the aviation industry said the airline, which was planning to discontinue flights from March 28, advanced the suspension of services to mid-February to reduce operational losses.

IndiGo and SpiceJet, too, are slashing flights to Bangkok, the most well-connected overseas destination with Kolkata. While IndiGo, which has twice-daily flights, will suspend one flight between February 29 and March 2, SpiceJet has decided to drop the daily flight 10 days in March.

Cathey Pacific has also announced the suspension of sister carrier Cathay Dragon ’s flights between Hong Kong and Kolkata from March 9 to March 20. In India, the airline has already reduced the number of flights from 49 a week to 26. “All airlines are rationalising flights in view of poor traffic. If the Covid-19 virus scare persists, it will drive the airline industry to its knees ,” feared an aviation industry expert.

Title: Students to be roped in for spreading health msg
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Edited

Jaipur: Spreading awareness on Nirogi Rajasthan campaign, the state government has decided to rope in schoolchildren. The health department is planning to include a chapter on diseases and its prevention in school textbooks under Nirogi Rajasthan campaign which was launched in December 2019.

A programme was organised at Sawai Man Singh medical college’s sports ground on Wednesday in which chief minister Ashok Gehlot and students of 11 schools were present on Nirogi Rajasthan. The schoolchildren took pledge to take the message of Nirogi Rajasthan-Swasthya Rajasthan to each and every home.

Nirogi Rajasthan is a programme which was launched in the state to create awareness on the diseases focussing on preventive aspect. Accredited social health activist (ASHA) workers, anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANM) will play a key role in implementation of Nirogi Rajasthan.

On the occasion, health minister Raghu Sharma said that they will encourage people to take proper precaution to ward off the risk of diseases.

Moreover, organ donation will also be promoted under Nirogi Rajasthan.

Gehlot released the posters of organ donation, Nirogi Rajasthan and posters related to create awareness on rare disease.

Apart from ASHA workers, ANM and anganwadi workers, the health department will create a fleet of swasthya Mitra in each and every village of the state. In every village, two swasthya mitra will be deployed to promote health schemes and to make people aware about the diseases and their prevention.

SMS Medical College principal Dr Sudhir Bhandari said children will be brand ambassadors of Nirogi Rajasthan who will take the message home and spread it to others.

Title: Two get six months jail, fine for theft bid
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: A local court on Wednesday sentenced two persons to six months of imprisonment and Rs 200 fine each in two separate case of attempt to commit theft . The cases were registered in Malkajgiri police limits in 2019.

In the first case, Pallapu Janaki (22), a resident of SP Nagar, Moula-Ali, worked as a domestic helper at the complainant’s house in Secunderabad. She had attempted to commit theft of valuables, said police.

In another case, the accused, Kandula Shashi (32), a labourer from Malkajgiri, had entered the complainant's house in Venkateshwara Apartments , in Secunderabad and attempted to commit theft. Police nabbed him the same day while trying to escape. Both the accused were booked and convicted under 380 (Theft) of the IPC.

Title: Gujarat budget: Dairy farmers to get cheaper cattlefeed
Content:
The state government also made a budgetary provision of Rs 81 crore for providing subvention to livestock owne... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Dairy farmers battling rising costs of cattle feed have been given a relief by finance minister Nitin Patel.In the budget, Patel announced Mukhya Mantri Pashudhan Sahay Yojana aimed at providing cattle feed at concessional rate to farmers for their cattle and progeny. A provision of Rs 200 crore was made to provide healthy and nutritious feed to milch animals.“Nearly 150kg cattle feed will be provided at 50% concessional rate for one month to farmers when their cow or buffalo give birth to a calf. The scheme will benefit nearly 15 lakh livestock owner who are members of the village milk cooperatives,” said Patel.R S Sodhi, managing director of GCMMF, said, “ This will go a long way as it would reduce the cost dairy farmers incur towards maintaining their cattle. The saving will translate in more income in their hand.”"Gujarat counts for 7 to 8 % of country's cattle population. New veterinary college was need of the day," he added.A veterinary college has been proposed at Rajpur Nava, Himmatnagar, a centre for post-graduate study in fisheries, veterinary institutes and construction of intensive livestock conservation offices. A new centre for excellence for horticulture was also proposed in Jamnagar districtThe state government also made a budgetary provision of Rs 81 crore for providing subvention to livestock owners dairy farm, animal units and goat units, among other schemes.The government has also announced another scheme to provide subvention to small and traditional fishermen for procuring engines. “50% subsidy of the unit cost of Rs 1.2 lakh will be provided for purchase of marine fishing boat, two-stroke and four-stroke, TBM and OBM engines. Funds worth Rs 9 crore have been earmarked for this,” he said.A provision of Rs 289 crore was also been made to provide VAT exemption on diesel used in mechanised fishing boats, subsidy for procuring safety gears for rescue operation to help fishermen combat disasters and providing modern equipment to fisherman for making inland and marine fisheries lucrative and safe.The minister also one-time subvention to upgrade panjra pol (cattle pound) to make facilities for cow sheds, godowns for fodder storage, tubewells, solar rooftop installation, micro irrigation in the fodder plot and sprinklers, among others.

Title: Hospital development panel inspects CMCH
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Coimbatore: A four-member team of hospital development committee on Wednesday inspected the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH), interacted with the staff and patients.

The committee evaluated the staff, space and infrastructure that the hospital requires to improve its functioning. The team is expected to submit a report to the state government on the same.

The team comprised former CMCH dean Dr Vimala, Dr Theranirajan, Dr Sathya, who is a pediatrician at Vellore Medical College, and Dr Gandhimathi Nathan, who is known for transforming the tuberculosis sanitorium at Kapalur in Madurai.

Confirming the inspection, CMCH dean Dr B Ashokan said the committee was set up mainly to study government hospitals and assess and recommend what was required to improve their infrastructure to the government.

According to him, the hospital, which used to get around 400 outpatients, now gets around 7,000. “The team inspected different parts of the hospital. They are likely to evaluate if the hospital’s infrastructure has increased accordingly or whether it requires more facilities, space, staff or outsourced staff. They will observe cleanliness and the care given to patients,” he said.

After the inspection, the team asked all the departments to submit a list of infrastructure requirements that they needed. “They also made a few recommendations like adding seats for the attenders and treating pediatric trauma patients in the Tamil Nadu accident and emergency care initiative ward. They were impressed with our orthopedic and obstetrics wards and that there wasn’t any patient on the floor anymore,” said a doctor.

The committee members were unavailable for any commet.

Title: MPs meet farmers, voice concern over HT power lines
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Tirupur: Coimbatore MP P R Natarajan, along with his counterparts in Tirupur and Karur, visited a village here on Wednesday and interacted with farmers, who have long been opposing erection of high-tension (HT) transmission towers on their farmlands.

Natarajan, Karur MP S Jothimani and Tirupur MP K Subbarayan said they visited Anupatti village for taking stock of the situation and to express solidarity with the farmers, who have been fighting the Power Grid Corporation of India’s move to erect transmission towers on their farm lands as part of the Raigarh-Pugalur high-voltage direct transmission line project.

Natarajan said the high-tension power lines would have an adverse effect on farming as well as the health of public and sought the state government to scrap the project.

Criticizing the state government for allowing the project without taking into account the health of public, Natarajan urged the government to heed the demands of the farmers.

Jothimani said, “The government claims to be farmer friendly. However, granting permission to erect high-tension lines through farmlands proves that the government is not keen on the welfare of farmers. When the farmers protest for their livelihood and health, they are being portrayed as anti-development.’’

Title: IIT-Roorkee and NIH-Roorkee hold three-day conclave on water management
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee ((IIT-R) and National Institute of Hydrology, Roorkee (NIH-R) jointly ... Read More

ROORKEE: Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee ((IIT-R) and National Institute of Hydrology, Roorkee (NIH-R) jointly launched a three-day long conclave on water management on Wednesday. Around 400 participants from the country and abroad have come to attend the event, whose theme is “hydrological aspects of climate change”.

Speaking during the event, RK Jain, chief guest of the inaugural session, said "India has about 4% of world’s freshwater resources. But due to high population, our water resources are under stress… We need to formulate new mechanisms to address the challenge that lie ahead in wake of global warming.”

Several topics such as management of floods & drought, modelling and assessment of water resources under changing climate, policy framework and climate change adaption strategy, river dynamics, and others would be discussed during the event.

On its first day, the event was attented by several dignitaries, including G Ashok Kumar, National Water Mission official; AK Chaturvedi, IIT-R director; Sharad K Jain, NIH-R director; and others.

A total of 42 technical papers will presented during the event and 11 keynote lectures will be held on the water.

Title: Child marriage: Advocate, aide arrested for threatening minor bride’s parents in Coimbatore
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative Image

COIMBATORE: An advocate and his friend were arrested for threatening the parents of a minor girl not to testify against his client, who had married their daughter, before court in Ramanathapuram here on Tuesday.

According to a police officer, 32-year-old lawyer D Seenivasan’s client Benny had married the minor girl against the wishes of her parents in October last year. “Her parents subsequently lodged a complaint against Benny, who was arrested and sent to the Coimbatore Central Prison .”

The officer said Benny’s elder brother Joshua was also arrested for marrying a minor girl and that he was also undergoing jail term for the offence.

“On Tuesday, the advocate, along with his friend, entered the minor girl’s house and threatened her parents not to appear before court and testify against his client (Benny). They also abused them and threatened to kill them,” the officer said.

The girl’s parents lodged a complaint with the Ramanathapuram police, who registered a case under Section 75(i)(c) of the Tamil Nadu Police Act , Section 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) of Indian Penal Code and Section 4 of the Tamil Nadu Prohibition of Harassment of Women Act and arrested D Seenivasan and his friend T Valakai alias Senthil, both residents of Puliyakulam.

The two were produced before the judicial magistrate, who remanded them in judicial custody, on Tuesday itself. They were later lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

This story is from February 27, 2020

Title: Savitribai Phule Pune University plans to reduce exam days by half, eyes innovative methods
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

to boost productivity

PUNE: The Savitribai Phule Pune University ’s (SPPU) exam department plans to reduce the examination period from over 100 days to 45-55 days in each of the two sessions in an academic year.

The newly appointed controller of examination, Mahesh Kakade, said the pressure of the extended exam was directly felt by the department, which resulted in low productivity. He said efforts were being taken to reduce the examination days and also introduce innovative methods , such as “exam on demand”.

Kakade said he would have to study the ground situation with availability of infrastructure, manpower, student count, facilities and provisions for online examinations to implement all the changes.

“I have recently taken charge of the department and am in the process of studying the ground situation. However, some of these changes will be implemented immediately and we will reduce the exam period at SPPU step-by-step,” he said.

For the upcoming summer exam, some changes would be made on a pilot-basis at one of the university departments to see how the system would work before scaling it up at the college-level, he said.

Kakade said the changes would not impact the time students got for preparation. The department would ensure enough gaps between two papers. “The decision will speed up the evaluation process and help in declaration of results on time,” he said. Kakade said when he was with Shivaji Vidyapeeth, Kolhapur, he had undertaken similar measures.

At Shivaji Vidyapeeth, he said, the summer exam session was reduced to 57 from 90 days. Similarly, the winter session was reduced to 22 days from 42. Kakade said the science faculty examinations took the maximum time and stretched to 42 days. Examinations for the other faculties were finished within 18-20 days.

“As per the exam on demand method four unique question papers would be set for a particular subject. Students can choose one of the four dates to give the exam. This will reduce the man-hour and the exam will be conducted online in computer labs,” Kakade said.

He said if a paper had 80 marks, there could be a policy of conducting 40 marks online and 40 as theory. This would enable the department to conduct more exams on a single day. He added that the multiple faculty exams, such as arts and science, could be conducted simultaneously with the right combination of subjects,
