Besides, all Saturdays during the exam period would be made working days and exams of non-credit subjects, such as environmental science, could be conducted on Sundays.

Title: Coimbatore: Drunk auto driver jailed for abusing policemen on duty
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative Image

COIMBATORE: A 32-year-old auto driverwas arrested for verbally abusing a special sub inspector (SSI) and his team while they were on duty near Bazaar Street in the city on Tuesday night.

Police said M Ranjith alias Ganesh, a resident of Edayar Street, was stopped by R Nagarajan, an SSI attached to Bazaar police station, and team during a vehicle check as the autorickshaw didn’t have registration plates.

“The team realized that the driver was under the influence of alcohol and they made him to take a breath test. When the result came positive, they issued a penalty notice and asked him not to drive the vehicle.

“The driver suddenly started to verbally abuse us. He threatened to kill the SSI and sped away in his auto,” a police officer said.

Based on a complaint lodged by the SSI, the Bazaar police booked the driver under Sections 294 (b), 353 and 506 (i) of the Indian Penal Code and arrested him. He was produced before a judicial magistrate and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison .

Title: Pune police invoke MPID provisions against MLC Anil Bhosale, 3 others
Content:
MLC Anil Bhosale (centre) outside the court on Wednesday

PUNE: The city police have invoked provisions of the MPID Act against NCP MLC Anil Bhosale and three others in the alleged Rs 71.78 crore fraud at the Shivajirao Bhosale Cooperative Bank.The police told a special MPID court on Wednesday that 1,187 investors had so far approached them with complaints that the bank had misappropriated investments totally worth Rs 52.92 crore.Investigating officer (IO) Murlidhar Karpe told the court, “The number of affected investors and the quantum of embezzled amount is likely to grow further as more investors are approaching the police. Hence, the provisions of the Maharashtra Protection of Interest of Depositors (MPID) Act have been invoked.”In a related development, deputy commissioner of police (economic offences) Sambhaji Kadam said a separate case related to misappropriation of Rs1.5 crore would soon be filed against MLC Bhosale and others with the Deccan Gymkhana police. “We are expecting the amount to increase further,” he said.“A letter has been sent to the state home department for hiring a forensic auditor to establish the money trail in the case registered with the Shivajinagar police that resulted in Tuesday night’s four arrests,” he added.Defence lawyers S K Jain, Harshad Nimbalkar, Rushikesh Ganu and Bipin Patole complained that the MPID Act and the Indian Penal Code (IPC) had been invoked to bypass the remedy under the Maharashtra Cooperatives Societies (MCS) Act, a special enactment.Karpe and his team produced the four arrested persons before special MPID judge S S Gosavi. Additional public prosecutor Vilas Patare moved a remand report, arguing that the investigators had collected sufficient evidence to establish that the allegations against the arrested persons were well-founded and a 14-day custodial remand was needed for recovery of cash. The court ordered such remand till March 6.“No special treatment for any accused,” judge Gosavi said in a stern voice after Bhosale’s lawyer Harshad Nimbalkar orally mentioned that his client suffered from a heavy diabetic condition and needed food as well as medical attention.The judge told the IO to ensure that Bhosale was not sent to a private hospital without a prior report to the court and its permission. He, however, allowed access to food and medicine “as per provisions of law”.Earlier, lawyers Jain and Nimbalkar, both representing Bhosale, argued that custodial interrogation was not required as the case was based on documents in possession of the investigating machinery.“Recovery of cash need not require custody of the accused,” said Jain.Nimbalkar submitted, “As the chairman of the bank, Bhosale was responsible for strategic decisions and had no direct role in running day-to-day affairs of the bank. Hence, his remand was not required.”Lawyer Ganu, representing Jadhav, submitted that prior permission under Section 148 of the MCS Act was required and there was no need to apply the IPC sections as the cooperatives registrar has powers to inquire into the matter.

Title: School reforms scheme; Rs 31,955 crore for education in Gujarat budget
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat government seems to have taken a leaf out of Arvind Kejriwal’s successful Delhi model as it announced new scheme that aims to develop 500 state-run schools as ‘Schools of Excellence’ by the end of March next year. The scheme is part of the state government’s massive budget outlay of Rs 31,955 crore for the education sector.“Our government has implemented a number of schemes to brighten the future of India taking shape in the classrooms. I announce, ‘Schools of Excellence Scheme’ to ensure quality education in government schools,” Gujarat deputy chief minister Nitin Patel, who also holds the finance portfolio, announced on Wednesday while unveiling the state budget for 2020-21.Talented teachers from taluka level will be identified to impart global standard education in these schools, the minister said.The Aam Aadmi Party, which won again in the Delhi state elections, had made quality education in government schools one of its major poll planks.A provision of Rs 250 crore has been made for the scheme which includes providing modern infrastructural facilities, smart classrooms, computer labs, STEM labs and sports facilities, according to the budget document.“In the pilot phase, about 500 schools will be developed as schools of excellence during 2020-21,” said Vinod Rao, secretary, primary and secondary education.Separate sub-head has also been provided in the budget for ‘External Assistance Funding for Schools of Excellence’ so that it could be scaled up in the next 5 years.The broader vision is to convert about 15,000 primary schools (with more than 150 students) and about 5,000 secondary and higher secondary schools into schools of excellence in the next 5 years, Rao said.The state government’s share of funds will be dovetailed with that received from the Centre, external funding agencies, NABARD and other sources to realize the mission for Schools of Excellence, Rao said.The mission will also focus on intensive training and capacity building of teachers by strengthening of GCERT and DIETs.All this will help in improving ‘grade appropriate learning outcomes’ and ‘higher order thinking skills’ across all schools so that Gujarat can participate in Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) in 2024, Rao added.The budget has also made provision to the tune of Rs 650 crore for school infrastructure; Rs 188 crore to Gujarat Institute of Educational Technology for setting up command and control centre, computer labs and education-technology interventions, and Rs 125 crore for smart classrooms across schools during 2020-21.

Title: Grant received for medicinal plant centre
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Pune: The Savitribai Phule Pune University has received a grant of Rs1.67 crore from the Ayush ministry of the Union government for setting up the western regional centre and information hub for medicinal plants.

The centre at the university would promote, plant, expand and conserve medicinal plants in Goa, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Daman and Diu, and Dadra-Nagar Haveli. A statement issued by the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) said the ministry had developed seven such centres across India.

Digamber Mokat, associate professor at the botany department of the SPPU, would head the western regional centre for medicinal plants at the varsity. TNN

Title: Coimbatore: Government schoolteachers trained to improve learning outcome
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Teachers being trained in the city on Monday

COIMBATORE: The National Achievement Survey (NAS), conducted by the National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT) last year, which aims to assess the competency of school students , had ranked the state ‘significantly below the national average’ in reading comprehension, mathematics, science and social science.

Following this, the state has been conducting a ‘Post-NAS training’ for government schoolteachers who handle classes IX and X. Based on the results of the survey, the State Council of Educational Research and Training (SCERT) has trained resource persons, who have been training the teachers from Monday. The session would conclude on Saturday.

In Coimbatore, a total of 1,899 teachers are being trained by 48 resource persons in centres across the district. Officials of Samagra Shiksha, which has been conducting the sessions, said the sessions were being conducted at a budget of Rs6lakh. “The sessions aim at training teachers to improve the outcome in students,” said the official.

“It has been found that our students were lagging in answering questions which require them to apply their conceptual understanding. If a question is twisted, they find it difficult to answer,” he said. “The training would inform teachers how to make students understand the concepts and apply them,” he added.

This would help students not only to tackle competitive and assessment exams such as the NAS, but also their board exams, as under the new syllabus, much of the questions required them to apply their understanding, said resource persons.

K Ravichandran, a mathematics resource person, said while the pass percentage in exams was being given more prominence, the idea of the training session was to increase the students’ competency. “While the training we give teachers, would help students tackle competitive exams better, eventually it aims to enhance the regular classroom teaching as well,” he said.

Ananthi, a resource person for English, said they train teachers to improve the listening, reading, writing, vocabulary and grammar competencies of students. Around 30% of the questions under the new syllabus was based on the thinking ability of the students, she said. “The focus is to manifest an outcome-based education in schools,” she said.

Title: Budget to fix aggravating traffic with new roads & more flyovers in Pune
Content:
Standing committee chairman Hemant Rasne (in white) presenting the civic budget to mayor Murlidhar Mohol on We... Read More

Core Area Vision

Road Along The River

Smaller Buses

PUNE: The city’s chaotic traffic jams with blaring horns, exhaust fumes and rising tempers that dampen the quality of life, drew the attention of the standing committee of the Pune Municipal Corporation .Its chairman Hemant Rasne on Wednesday tabled a Rs 7,390 crore civic budget for 2020-21, nearly Rs 1,000 crore more than municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad’s draft budget of Rs 6,229 crore. It focused heavily on measures to streamline traffic.Last year, former standing committee chairman Yogesh Mulik had presented a Rs 6,765 crore budget about Rs 680 crore more than former municipal commissioner Saurabh Rao’s.“Daily commute for citizens has become tiresome and we need to take steps now before the situation worsens,” Rasne said.Funds were set aside for the construction of 18 flyovers, bridges and grade separators proposed in the last few years in many parts of the city, Rasne said.Starting with Rs 230 crore for ongoing infrastructure projects, Rasne proposed the development of new road links, construction of more bridges and flyovers.A grade separator at Lal Mahal chowk on Shivaji Road at a cost of Rs 4 crore was proposed to reduce traffic congestion in the core areas. “We will ask experts and urban planners to advise us on how it can be executed with minimum hardship to citizens,” Rasne said.Activists said the project has not been given proper thought. “Shivaji Road is a congested area and digging up a single lane will lead to huge traffic jams,” Vivek Velankar of Sajag Nagrik Manch said.“WiIl a grade separator solve the traffic problem in an area which has illegal hawkers and shops? When the feasibility fizzles out, the allocations will be diverted to other projects,” Velankar added.The construction of a road from Bund Garden junction to Mundhwa bridge along the Mula-Mutha river and a new bridge in place of the Sadhu Vaswani bridge were proposed.Rasne said the development plan road will reduce the traffic burden on North Main Road. Velankar said the area is heavily encroached upon.Rasne also proposed midi-buses in the central areas with an allocation of Rs 25 crore to strengthen public transport and reduce the use of private vehicles.“We have proposed 32-seater buses with a Rs 10 ticket for the entire day. Buses will ply Deccan to Pulgate, Swargate to Pune station and Swargate to Shivajinagar routes. Bus trips will be introduced on a circular Swargate-Tilak Road-Khajinavihir-Appa Balwant Chowk-Pune station-Pulgate-Swargate route,” Rasne said.A coordinating officer at the zonal office level to oversee various works like concreting, digging up of roads for cabling, painting and markings on roads and work on footpaths was proposed.

Title: Rape and murder: Dad moves court for relief
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has issued notice to the state government on a plea by a man who sought Rs 1 crore compensation for his minor daughter who was raped and murdered in 2011, citing that police officials and other agencies were not able to crack the case.

In the petition, K Kalaikumar, a resident of Pudukottai district, stated that his daughter, a Class X student was raped and brutally murdered by some unidentified people when he and his wife who were working as headmaster and teacher respectively at government schools had gone to work on March 9, 2011. His daughter was found hanging from the fan with stab injuries on her head and stomach.

He said that his five-year-old son who was in the house at the time of the incident told him that some unidentified people had entered the house and attacked the girl and stole 25 sovereign gold jewellery from the house.

Initially, the case was registered with the Ganesh Nagar police and later transferred to the CB-CID and subsequently to the CBI. Kalaikumar stated that the investigation in the case was not conducted in a proper manner since the beginning and the perpetrators in this case have not been found yet.

On October 10, 2019, the CBI had submitted a closure report citing their inability to collect prima facie evidence to link the suspect accused to the case before the Trichy chief judicial magistrate court and the court had accepted the same.

Since the authorities whose primary duty is to prevent, detect, register and investigate crime and prosecute criminals have failed to crack the case and find the perpetrators in this case, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking compensation from the state government.

When the case was taken up for hearing on Wednesday, justice A D Jagadish Chandira issued notice to the state and adjourned the case to a further hearing.

Title: Number of polling stations in corporation limit up by 29
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Coimbatore: The number of polling stations in the corporation limit has been increased by 29 to 1,245 from 1,216, according to the draft list of polling stations released by corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar in the city on Wednesday.

Since the district collector had released the voters list two weeks ago, as per the directions of the state election commission, the corporation has been working on to prepare the polling station list based on the newly released voters list.

Following special camps conducted to add or remove voters at the polling stations in the district for about a month, the new list added 36,000 voters, totaling 14.85 lakh voters – 7.44 lakh men, 7.4 lakh women and 203 under the other category.

Each polling station will have a maximum of up to 1,400 voters. The stations will be equipped with basic amenities, including drinking water, sanitation, ramps and lights, the commissioner said.

The new list reflects some changes suggested by the public, he said, adding that a meeting would be held at the district collectorate on Monday with representatives from political parties to elicit their suggestions on the new list.

Title: ‘Man of many talents, local at heart’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

‘singing bishop’: Late Bishop Valerian D’Souza during a church service in Germany

PUNE: Like a cut gem, there were many facets to Rt Rev Valerian D’Souza — avid sportsman in his youth, multilinguist, powerful orator, singer, guitarist, champion of the poor and, above all, a spiritual leader.

“Indeed, Bishop D’Souza was a man of many talents. He was also a local at heart, a complete Pune man,” recalls Bishop of Pune Thomas Dabre, who stepped into Bishop D’Souza’s shoes after the latter’s retirement in 2009.

Bishop D’Souza passed away of multi-organ failure at a city hospital on Tuesday night. He was 86. He had served as Bishop of Pune for nearly 32 years from 1977. After retirement, he held the title of Emeritus Bishop.

Bishop D’Souza studied at St Vincent’s high school and Nowrosjee Wadia, excelling in both academics and sports. He captained his college football and hockey teams and represented the Pune university too in those games. He trained for priesthood at Papal Seminary and later in Germany.

“Fluent in English, Bishop D’Souza was comfortable with speaking Marathi and Hindi too. During his four-year priesthood training in Germany, he picked up German, which he spoke very well. His sermons in that language were popular,” Bishop Dabre told TOI. He also remembers the late Bishop’s singing and guitar skills, for which he was known as the “Singing Bishop”.

Fr Malcolm Sequeira, vicar-general of the Pune diocese, recalls Bishop D’Souza’s special concern for the poor. “He would often hand over money to me which well-wishers had given him. ‘Help some poor family with this money. God gives me and I must share what I get,’ he would say. He firmly believed that one gets more when one gives to the poor.”

Fr Sequeira commended the late Bishop’s knowledge of sports. “He would avidly watch cricket, soccer and tennis on TV and give us all the updates at the dinner table. He would observe such fine points of the game that we were left wondering how a busy man like him paid such attention to sports,” he said..

Cardinal Oswald Gracias, the Archbishop of Bombay, will conduct Bishop’s D’Souza’s funeral mass at the St Patrick’s Cathedral at 11.30am on Thursday, followed by the burial at the City Church cemetery at Nana Peth. The body will be kept for public viewing at the cathedral from 9am.

Title: Anti-CAA stir: Lawyer wants FIR quashed
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has directed the police not to file a final report (charge-sheet) in a case registered against an advocate for participating in an anti-CAA public meeting organised at Madurai. In his petition, T Lajapathi Roy, an advocate based at Madurai, stated that the case of the prosecution is that he along with 25 people participated in the anti-CAA public meet attended by around 1,200 people in Goripalayam on February 8.

He stated that a suo motu complaint was lodged by the Tallakulam police stating that they did not obtain proper permission for organising the meeting from the assistant commissioner of police as per Police Act. Roy said that he was invited to deliver a speech during the meeting and as a lawyer he delivered a speech about the legality of CAA. Stating that it was his fundamental right to participate in the meeting, the advocate moved the court seeking to quash the FIR registered against him. The court passed an interim order directing police not to file a final report in this case and adjourned the case . TNN

Title: With eye on local body polls, urban infrastructure gets a boost in Gujarat budget
Content:
The urban development department has made a provision of Rs 4,544 crore to boost basic infrastructure in citi... Read More

AHMEDABAD: With a clear focus on local body polls scheduled in November this year the state government has made a number of budget provisions for improving quality of life in towns and cities. After smart cities, for instance, the state government is now encouraging the concept of ‘smart towns’, which are mainly nagarpalikas.The government has announced a new competition for encouraging such towns with a provision of Rs 100 crore. Five winning towns will be provided Rs 20 crore each.Besides this, there has been no new announcements this year for urban areas. The urban development department has made a provision of Rs 4,544 crore to boost basic infrastructure in cities and nagarpalikas under the Swarnim Jayanti Mukhya Mantri Shaheri Vikas Yojana.A big portion of this budget, Rs 1,169 crore will be spent to spruce up underground civic facilities — drainage, storm water drains — while Rs 500 crore has been allocated for municipal water networks. To improve traffic management in cities, Rs 200 crore has been provisioned for de-congesting railway crossings, and another Rs 500 crore for bridges and flyovers.

Title: On Sinhagad Road, many hope for a flood-free year
Content:
The road was shut after the floods

The sight of broken pipes laid to create a makeshift culvert near Prayeja city — off Sinhagad Road — sparked fears of future flooding among residents this week. Their worries are not unfounded. Last year, this area was one of the worst hit by floods during heavy rains in September.Locals have now urged the PMC to finish the clean-up at the site as soon as possible. They said the civic body should ensure the nullah is channelised properly. Officials, while responding to a TOI query, sought to assuage fears saying the pipes (pictured), are only part of temporary measures and that they will be removed once a new culvert is built at the spot.Neighbourhoods in Katraj, Sahakarnagar, Satara road, Katraj-Kondhwa road, Indiranagar, Bibvewadi and Sinhagad Road suffered massive damage during the flooding that occurred on the night of September 25, 2019. The flood swept away the walls of a crematorium on Sinhagad Road and wiped out two culverts, including this one at Prajeya City. “We only want the PMC to ensure sewage flowing through the nullah is channeled correctly. The area was severely hit by flooding last year. The disaster hit not just residents, but also commuters who used the culvert,” said Dnyanesh Deolalikar, a local resident.Parikshit Karve, a resident of Sinhagad Road, said: “The road adjacent to the nullah is important as it connects the Sinhagad road area with the Pune-Bengaluru highway. Many people going to Wakad and Hinjewadi use this road. It will be a big worry if there are flash floods here again.”Others said there have been severe traffic jams in the area since the floods last year.“The road was shut after the floods. Commuters along Sun City Road and main Sinhagad Road felt the impact. A bridge has now been proposed here to resolve the problem,” said resident Deepak Nagpure. The PMC’s decision to pull down the flood-damaged bridge near Prayeja city had indeed impacted the movement of traffic from Anandnagar, Wadgaon, Dhayari, Narhe and other localities near Sinhagad Road. But the civic body said a new structure is in the works.“The tender for the bridge has been approved. Construction will start in March,” said Vitthal Ingawale, a senior PMC official who is working on the project.Ingawale said the broken pipes have been laid at the site as a temporary diversion measure. “They will be removed once the bridge is completed,” he added.Many amenities such as gardens, a water pumping station, cultural halls and schools were damaged in the floods. Officials with the PMC said the civic body has set in place a number of measures to ensure a repeat of 2019 doesn’t happen.They include a protective mesh along nullahs; reconstruction of culverts and roads along the nullahs; action against illegal constructions and encroachments; and a survey of properties along drains. The new bridge near Prayeja city is a part of this project.

Title: Nagpur-bound flight faces 5-hour delay, flyers fume
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: An IndiGo flight to Nagpur was delayed on Wednesday by almost five hours, much to the flyers’ inconvenience.

The flight (6E-134) took off from Pune at 4.05pm, five hours after its scheduled departure at 11.05am. The delay had a cascading effect, as the same aircraft (Airbus A320 Neo) was supposed to fly to Delhi at 1pm. It departed at 5.43pm.

Several Nagpur-bound flyers took to the social media to express their grievances.

“Still no information about my flight and sitting at the airport since. The airline should have informed about such delay. Will it fly today or cancelled? Please revert,” Hemang Parikh, a passenger, posted on Twitter.

When the airline replied that the flight had been delayed due to operational reasons, Parikh reposted, “When will you inform? From last 5 hours have been in the airport without any clarity. Will this flight leave from Nagpur today? Atleast tell this. Really very sad state of affairs,” he said.

Prasanna Patil, another passenger, tweeted about how flyers were made to undergo security check all over again and given fresh boarding passes at the last minute.

IndiGo was sent a detailed mail in the evening, but an answer was awaited till the time of going to the press. A source said, “There was a delay of four hours and 45 minutes to be exact. There was a technical issue but nothing related to the engine of the aircraft.”

The airline, while replying to queries by passengers, said on Twitter that the flight had been delayed because of operational reasons.

Title: Coimbatore: TMMK, SDPI members stage protests condemning violence in New Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Members of TMKK tried to enter the station, when there was a hustle between policemen and protestors.

COIMBATORE: Around 100 members of the Tamil Nadu Muslim Munnetra Kazhagam ( TMMK ) were detained on Wednesday for staging a protest in front of the Coimbatore Junction railway station . Around 100 members of the Tamil Nadu Muslim Munnetra Kazhagam (TMMK) were detained on Wednesday for staging a protest in front of the Coimbatore Junction railway station. The members tried to enter the station, when there was a hustle between policemen and protestors.

More than 100 members of TMMK staged the protest on Wednesday afternoon condemning the violence against Muslims and anti-CAA protesters in New Delhi and the Delhi police who did not stop the violence.

The protesters raised slogans against the CAA and right-wing forces which have unleashed violence against protesters and Muslims in the country’s capital. They said around 20 people have been killed in the riots, but the Delhi police did nothing to stop it.

Meanwhile, public and members of the Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI) staged a protest at Karumbukkadai in the city condemning the violence against protesters and Muslims in New Delhi. Representative of the outfit, A Abdul Kadar, alleged that the RSS with the help of the Delhi police, had unleashed violence on the protesters there. In Madurai, various Muslim organisations demanded resignation of home minister Amit Shah and arrest of BJP leader H Raja for making provocative statements. T Velmurugan, former MLA and founder of Tamizhaga Vazhvurimai Katchi (TVK), addressed the protesters at Nelpettai and offered his support.

In Trichy also members of SDPI and other parties staged protest marches. SDPI members staged a protest near Ramakrishna bridge near Palakkarai. More than 350 people, including 50 women, participated in the agitation. They raised slogans against the central government for the violence on the anti-CAA protesters in New Delhi. The protestors condemned BJP MLA Kapil Misra for his remarks against the anti-CAA protesters.

Title: Seven ways to boost civic body’s income, property tax untouched
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Standing committee chairman Hemant Rasne, who said concrete measures are needed to increase the Pune Municipal Corporation’s finances, has backed efforts to explore additional revenue sources and boosting tax collection.

He presented a Rs 7,390 crore municipal budget, Rs 1,161 crore more than municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad’s draft budget of Rs 6,229 crore.

Rasne put forth seven broad ideas to boost revenue and increase tax collection. He did not announce any hike in property tax .

“We observed a gap between the targeted revenue and actual collection after reviewing the budget performances of the last ten years. We will minimize this gap and boost revenue,” Rasne said.

An amnesty scheme in two steps is expected to fetch Rs 1,000 crore revenue. “A plan will be chalked out to recover tax arrears from cellphone companies. A way to curb lapses in collection of property tax and recover arrears which have increased to Rs 4,200 crore will be announced,” Rasne said.

A three-step payment system for builders on development charges will be rolled out. “At present, developers pay at one go. We will allow these payments in three steps to boost projects,” Rasne said.

New schemes that increase the revenue from advertisements will be announced. There is a plan to rent out spaces on foot overbridges and gantries at 200 locations for advertisements.

Spaces on bridges, flyovers and gardens will also be sourced for revenue generation from advertisements.

A scheme will be introduced to collect arrears of taxes from rented spaces of Pune Municipal Corporation-owned buildings and a retired judge would be appointed to clear pending revenue related cases.

The standing committee also proposed to widen and redevelop six-metre wide roads in the city and in the 34 merged villages to boost construction activities in the fringe areas.

Title: Maharashtra: Man dupes restaurateur by posing as army officer
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A caller posing as an army colonel duped a restaurant owner of Rs 72,000 on the pretext of ordering food for 40 of his men and then acquiring the details of the restaurateur’s debit card, including one-time password, to pay for the order online on Sunday.

“The caller sought the OTP under the garb of security code that, he claimed, was required for an army software to make online payments,” inspector Ashok Shelke of the Haveli police said.

Restaurant owner Manish Tukaram Kadu (30) of Gorhe village on Sinhagad-Panshet Road lodged a complaint with the Haveli police on Monday. According to the FIR, Kadu’s father was at the restaurant when he received a call from an unknownnumber on Sunday morning.

The caller, who introduced himself as an army colonel, told Kadu’s father that there was an army camp in Panshet and he required 40 ‘vegetarian meals’ for his men in the evening.

In the evening, Kadu’s father received another call from the same person, who promised to pay for the order online. He then asked Kadu’s father to share his son’s phone number with him, the police said.

Later, the conman called Kadu to seek his bank account and debit card details. Kadu shared his debit card details, including the CVV number. “The caller then told him that he would receive a security code on his cellphone. However, Kadu received an OTP, which he shared with the conman,” the officer said.

Soon after Kadu shared the OTP, the suspect transferred Rs72,000 from his bank account. “The preliminary investigation has traced the phone numbers and the account to Jamtara in Jharkhand,” Shelke said,

Title: Need Sonia as Congress chief for ‘foreseeable future’: Manish Tewari
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Congress MP and spokesman Manish Tewari said Sonia Gandhi should continue as the party president for “foreseea... Read More

NEW DELHI: Joining the debate on the issue of leadership crisis, Congress MP and spokesman Manish Tewari said Sonia Gandhi should continue as the party president for “foreseeable future”, calling it the overwhelming opinion of the Congress rank and file.

At the same time, senior member Anil Shastri demanded that Priyanka Gandhi Vadra should be appointed the Congress president as he rejected the possibility of a non-Gandhi leading the party. He was reacting to calls for election for the post of Congress chief as demanded by Congress MP Shashi Tharoor.

Amid views that it was time for Congress to move beyond Sonia Gandhi who became an interim chief after Rahul Gandhi ’s resignation last May, Tewari said, “Overwhelming consensus in Congress is that we need Sonia as president for foreseeable future. It is the view of leaders across the parliamentary group as well as of those in other positions in the organisation and those whom I have known since my days in the NSUI four decades ago.”

Tewari added that Congress should stick to Sonia Gandhi till the party sorts out its ideological conundrum which requires immediate attention. He stressed that the party should hold a “Panchmarhi type” brainstorming conclave.

“The hunt for new president can take months or even a year or two,” he said.

The comments from the Lok Sabha MP from Punjab add to the growing voices in the party over the leadership issue which started after Rahul Gandhi resigned as president following the Lok Sabha defeat in May 2019. The Congress Working Committee appointed Sonia Gandhi as “interim president” in August.

Tewari noted that Rahul Gandhi was emphatic in his resignation and even turned down pleas from party leaders to take back his decision.

In contrast, Anil Shastri appeared to weigh against the call for election to the top organisational post. “There’s no question of a non-Gandhi taking over as Congress president. Priyanka Gandhi should be elected to lead the party.”

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: Coronavirus hurts currency trade in B’luru
Content:
A man, who recently travelled from China, waits to get checked for the coronavirus at RGICD in Bengaluru

3.3 lakh passengers screened at KIA

BENGALURU: The coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak has found an unlikely victim in Bengaluru: the foreign exchange (forex) market.A few forex traders, who are facing a severe shortage of customers and queries, have now stopped accepting Chinese yuan, Singapore dollar, Malaysian ringgit and Thai baht.The number of people travelling to coronavirus-affected countries — mainly China, Singapore, Thailand and Malaysia — has fallen drastically, rendering trading of these currencies unviable, say forex traders."The combined impact of a sluggish economy and the Corona Virus situation, has resulted in slowing demand for our travel segments and hence cascading impact to our retail forex business too- more so as this coincides with the peak booking season for summer vacations,” said Mahesh Iyer, executive director & chief executive officer, Thomas Cook (India) Limited, which has six counters at Kempegowda International Airport.Forex counters at KIA have also been struggling with multiple flights getting cancelled and falling passenger footfall to/from these affected countries.“Indians have stopped travelling to many of the affected countries and the list of nations included in the travel advisory only continues to grow. International visitors have also stopped coming. Our business has taken a hit,” said Sagar Reddy, director in-charge of Tei Forex on Brigade Road.“We are no longer taking yuan, Singapore dollar, Thai baht and Malaysian ringgit. There is no demand for them. Neither are there individual queries, nor corporate ones,” said Syed, who manages a forex shop in the city’s central business district.Traders pointed out that even Hong Kong dollar and Japanese yen aren’t being accepted in a few places.“Both individual and corporate queries have dropped drastically. While individuals are postponing their trips, corporate trips and meets are getting cancelled,” said a currency trader from in Jayanagar.As of February 25, China continues to be the worst hit nation, with more than 78,000 confirmed cases, followed by South Korea (1,261). Italy (374) and Iran (139) too have seen a jump in the number of cases reported.On Wednesday, the ministry of health and family welfare issued a travel advisory instructing Indians to refrain from travelling to South Korea, Italy and Iran as well.Since January 20, some 3.3 lakh passengers have been screened at KIA. Of them, 352 travellers, who came to Bengaluru from COVID-hit countries, have been identified. Of them, 258 were under home isolation and surveillance. All 198 samples tested for the infection from Karnataka have been found to be negative.

Title: Madras high court restrains collection of toll at Vandiyur plaza from today
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The court produced the order talking cognizance of the fact that there is no separate lane for ambulances

MADURAI: The Madras high court on Wednesday restrained toll collection at Vandiyur toll plaza from 9am on February 27, taking cognizance of the fact that there is no separate lane for ambulances and other exempted vehicles.

A division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran passed the interim order while hearing a batch of petitions against collection of toll at three new toll plazas on the Madurai ring road.

The counsels appearing for the petitioners submitted that the toll was being collected at Vandiyur toll plaza without providing a lane for ambulance.

A senior counsel appearing for the Sri Balaji Tollways (Madurai) Private Limited, which is collecting the toll at the toll plazas, submitted that steps were being taken to expand the road at Vandiyur toll plaza. He further submitted that they would not collect toll from the Vandiyur toll plaza till the work was completed.

The judges also directed them not indirectly collect the toll for Vandiyur toll plaza at the other two toll plazas, located at Chintamani and Valayankulam. The case was adjourned to March 26 for further hearing.

It maybe recalled that these batch of petitions were filed challenging collection of toll fee at three new toll plazas set up at Vandiyur, Chintamani and Valayankulam, which are located on the 27km stretch in Madurai. The petitioners stated that several vehicles ply on the road every day as several educational institutions, hospitals and Madurai Airport are situated on the stretch. Due to this, functioning of these toll plazas have also resulted in traffic congestion at the stretch.

Title: Beneficiaries for Tamil Nadu’s capital subsidy scheme down in 3 years
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative Image

Coimbatore: The number of beneficiaries from the district who have got capital subsidy through the state’s ‘New Entrepreneur Cum Enterprise Development Scheme’ (NEEDS) has come down in the past three years, according to data from the District Industries Centre (DIC).

Correspondingly, the total subsidy amount given also has come down.

In 2017-18, the total subsidy given under the scheme was Rs1,199.23lakh, which came down to Rs752lakh in 2019-2020 (as on February 19).

Under the scheme, up till now, educated youth who are first generation entrepreneurs would be given a capital loan subsidy of 25% of the cost of starting a new enterprise, up to a ceiling of Rs30lakh. State finance minister O Panneerselvam, in his budget speech earlier this month announced that the subsidy would be increased from Rs30lakh to Rs50lakh. He also announced a fund of Rs100crore for the scheme in the budget estimate of 2020-21.

While this is expected to give a shot in the arm for the scheme and is expected to increase the number of potential beneficiaries applying for and receiving the subsidy under it, the trend in the past three years show that the annual subsidy amount and the total number of beneficiaries in the district have come down.

Officials of the DIC said this could be due to selection process of the scheme involving an interview and a training programme, which could be reasons for the fall in numbers. “It could also be because aspiring entrepreneurs from the service sector, who form the core of the beneficiaries, have not been coming up for the scheme. We would analyse the reasons for the fall in numbers and come up with interventions,” said B Karthigaivasan, general manager of DIC Coimbatore.

Industrialists, on the other hand, said the overall reason could be the apprehension among aspiring entrepreneurs due to the prevailing unfavourable economic situation. The slowdown and its effects might have made aspiring entrepreneurs apprehensive as to whether they could find proper business activity to repay the loan they avail through the scheme.

There must be good cash flow in the industry for new entrepreneurs to boldly start industries, said J James, district president of Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Micro Enterprises (TACT).

“The NEEDS is a very helpful one for new entrepreneurs. But, due to the current economic situation, many aspiring entrepreneurs could have backed up from starting new businesses and so the fall in numbers under the scheme,” he said.

Beneficiaries of the NEEDS said the scheme had provided them with much needed support at the time of starting a business. They too echoed the same idea that the current economic situation could have caused the fall in numbers.

M Azmathullah, whose wife M T Kurushith had availed a loan subsidy through the NEEDS scheme in 2014, said the loan subsidy amount of around Rs20lakh came as a solid support for them to start a footwear jobwork unit in Malumichampatti near the city. “I have also suggested other aspiring entrepreneurs to apply for the scheme,” he said. “But right from the demonetization move, the situation for industries has not been great. That, and the slowdown, could have kept off many from starting new businesses, and availing loans through such schemes,” he said.

Title: Nine arrested in Elgar Parishad case shifted to Mumbai prisons
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The nine activists arrested in the Elgar Parishad case were on Wednesday shifted to Arthur Road and Byculla jails in Mumbai from the Yerawada central prison, days after the Pune police handed over the investigations to the National Investigation Agency.The Maharashtra prisons department shifted seven activists — Surendra Gadling, Rona Wilson, Sudhir Dhawale, P Varavara Rao, Vernon Gonsalves, Arun Ferreira and Mahesh Raut — to the Arthur Road jail, meant for undertrial prisoners. Sudha Bharadwaj and Shoma Sena have been lodged at the Byculla women’s jail.The special UAPA court, Pune, on February 14 passed an order to produce the activists before the special National Investigation Agency (NIA) court in Mumbai on February 28.Additional director-general of police (prisons) Sunil Ramanand told TOI, “We have transferred the activists to the Mumbai jails as per the order of the NIA court for commencing trial against them in the Elgar case.”U T Pawar, the superintendent of Yerawada central prison, said, “We handed over the custody of the activists to the Pune police at 11.30am following directions from the NIA court. The police have handed over them to the respective jails.”A senior officer from the Pune police said, “The NIA investigation officer had obtained permission from the special court in Mumbai for transferring the activists to the jails concerned for the convenience of investigations after we handed over the case papers to the agency. We held a meeting with the officials from the NIA and the prisons department, and an elaborate security plan was drawn. The activists were transported and handed over to the jails’ authorities concerned.”“The nine activists are in judicial custody after their arrest. The Mumbai police will produce them before the NIA court on the next day of hearing,” the officer said.The state government on January 23 had reviewed the investigations done by the Pune police in the Elgar case after the NCP chief, Sharad Pawar, demanded a special investigation team (SIT) probe into the role of the police. On the next day, the central government issued a notification transferring the case to the NIA.The Maha Vikas Aghadi government had initially opposed the transfer of investigations because the Pune police had filed two chargesheets and submitted the draft charges against the activists. The state home department, after seeking legal opinion, handed over the case to the NIA.The Pune police claimed that the Elgar Parishad held in the city on December 31, 2017, was supported and funded by the banned CPI (Maoist) organisation as a part of a larger conspiracy to create social unrest and overthrow the government. Alleged inflammatory speeches at the Parishad contributed to the January 2, 2018, caste clashes at Koregaon Bhima , the police claimed.

Title: 1L books from 272 libraries at readers’ fingertips
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bengaluru: The government launched a digital library on Wednesday, which will provide access to books available at 272 state public libraries, except those with copyrights.

Launching e-Sarvajanika Granthalaya, primary and secondary education Suresh Kumar said it is a matter of pride that the country’s IT capital is also taking the lead in digital education by digitising books on such a large scale.

“Citizens can read their favourite books and magazines from the comfort of their homes. We are sure this will improve reading habit of youngsters and others. This application aims to increase readership among citizens,” the minister said.

The project to digitise over 1 lakh titles was taken up by the department of public libraries to modernise libraries with technology and digital infrastructure to bridge the gap in access to information.

The library will have e-books and journals, covering more than 10 subjects like arts and humanities, science and technology, classics and literature, in seven languages.

The project is considered to be a first in the country, where a state-level initiative has been taken up to digitise and provide access to learning in such a large scale. This project covers city central libraries (26), district central libraries (30)and taluk libraries (216) across Karnataka.

Calling it a cultural shift, Kumar said 95,000 English books are available on the platform. “It is time authors and publishers welcomed this change,” he said, assuring that digitisation won’t affect publishers.

Title: Pune: Winter’s parting shot, 4ºC slide in day and night temperature
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The receding winter this year gave the city its final cold spell of the season on Wednesday when, for the first time in a fortnight, the minimum temperature plunged to 12.2ºC in Shivajinagar. The day temperature also dropped significantly to 30.8ºC.The sudden drop in the day and night temperatures was almost a four-degree decrease from the mercury levels recorded in the city barely two days ago. On Monday, the day temperatures in Shivajinagar and Lohegaon were 34.9ºC and 36.2ºC, respectively. The minimum temperatures in Shivajinagar and Lohegaon were 16ºC and 19ºC on the day.On Wednesday, the day temperatures in Shivajinagar and Lohegaon dropped to 30.8ºC and 31ºC, respectively. The minimum temperature in Lohegaon was 15.9ºC.This was the first time in the past 17 days that the minimum temperature dropped to the “below normal” level in Shivajinagar, giving the city its coldest morning after February 8 this year, when the mercury had gone down to 12.1ºC. Since then, the night-time mercury has been consistently rising.Anupam Kashyapi, head of the weather, India Meteorological Department (IMD), Pune, told TOI that Wednesday’s drop in the minimum temperature was “the last temperature dip of this winter”. Winter starts in January and ends by February-end, after which the pre-monsoon season begins.Pune has witnessed a temperature contrast this February with above-normal night and day temperatures recently, with the mercury levels going down to the below-normal levels on Wednesday. The city has suddenly become cooler than some coastal locations, such as Ratnagiri where day temperature has been marching towards the 40ºC-mark.Kashyapi said, “We had predicted a significant drop in the minimum temperature. But we had not expected it to come down to 12.2ºC. Since the last couple of days (Tuesday and Wednesday), northerly winds in the lower atmospheric level have been exclusively affecting northern parts of the state, especially north and central Madhya Maharashtra, including Pune.”He said had it been the start of the winter season, the kind of northerly flow that the city has been recently witnessing would have dragged the minimum temperature further down to 10ºC, or even below. “But since it is almost the end of winter season, the dip was till 12.2ºC,” he said.Northerly winds began penetrating parts of the state after the passage of the western disturbance over north India. “Once a western disturbance passes, it generally causes a drop in temperature if there is no hindrance in the northerly wind flow,” he said.The drop in temperature may be short-lived, as both the day and night temperatures should start rising from Thursday. “Night temperatures may rise due to the partly cloudy conditions from Thursday caused by a line of discontinuity over Konkan and Madhya Maharashtra areas during the next few days. The day temperatures will also rise, as the easterly wind flow may replace the northerly wind flow,” Kashyapi said.

Title: State GSDP grows 9.2% in 2018-19
Content: Ahmedabad: The gross state domestic product (GSDP) at constant-price in the year 2018-19 grew by 9.2% against the year 2017-18. The GSDP was estimated to be 11,90,121 crores in 2018-19 as against 10,89,811 crore in 2017-18.The socio-economic review for the year 2019-2020 states that the GSDP at current prices in year 2018-19 increased by 13.1% at Rs 15,01,944 crore as against 13,28,068 crores in year 2017-18.The review points that the per capita income at current prices has been estimated at Rs 1,97,447 in the year 2018-19 as against revised per capita income estimated of Rs 1,73,079 in the year 2017-18. The socio-economic review states that the per capita income of Gujarat is about 56.06% higher than the country’s per capita income of Rs 1,26,521.The socio-economic review stated that according to the second advance estimates, production of food grains during the year 2019-20 is estimated to be 80.7 lakh tonnes compared to 68 lakh tonnes during the year 2018-19. The production of oil seeds is pegged at 54.2 lakh tonnes in 2019-2020 as against 37.3 lakh tonnes in 2018-19.The production of groundnut is estimated at 32,61,000 tonnes during the year 2019-20 against 22,03,000 tonnes in 2018-19. Also, during the year 2019-20 the production of cotton bales (each of 170kg) is estimated at 87.1 lakh bales against production of 62.8 lakh bales during the year 2018-19.The socio-economic review states that the during the year 2019-20 the state’s export stands at 20.8% with the state ranked second-highest contributor in India’s total exports. According to the Director General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) Gujarat’s exports were of US $38.14 billion in the year 2019-20 (April-October) as against US $ 67.41 billion in year 2018-19.Also, the review stated that the number of factories increased by 2.39% from 25,966 in the year 2016-17 to 26,586 in the year 2017-18.

Title: VBA calls for anti-CAA protest in Delhi on March 4
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

As per the announced schedule, the data collection exercise for NPR is set to begin in the country, except on ... Read More

AURANGABAD: Prakash Ambedkar-led Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi ( VBA ) has called for a mega protest at Delhi’s Jantar Mantar on March 4 against the implementation of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

As per the announced schedule, the data collection exercise for NPR is set to begin in the country, except on Assam , from April.

Ambedkar on Wednesday released a video appealing to citizens to join him in the protest. “What we feared is becoming a reality. NPR is the beginning. The rights that the country earned through the work of Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar will be lost. Citizens have to fight to retain their rights,” he said.

Activists privy to the preparation of the agitation said their biggest concern is that poor, backward communities will suffer the most.

“People, who have not understood this issue, are the ones supporting it. They will end up regretting it,” said Nayab Ansari , a close confidante of Ambedkar.

An official with the administration said the NPR is a register of usual residents of the country prepared at the local, tehsil, district, state and nation levels under the provisions of Citizenship Act 1955 and Citizenship (Registration of Citizens and issue of National Identity Cards) Rules, 2003.

Title: Students give paediatric ward of Coimbatore hospital a colourful makeover
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

COIMBATORE: Around 60 students of Krishna Adithya College of Arts and Science spent the day painting the walls of the pediatric ward at Coimbatore Medical College Hospital on Wednesday. They decorated the walls with illustrations of children driving cars, playing with football and toys, gardening etc. CMCH authorities welcomed the initiative stating that colourful walls go a long way in cheering up sick children and helping them recover faster.

The college students who volunteer for Chandran’s Yuva Foundation had also recently painted the walls of the Ukkadam Bus stand. The initiative titled ‘Vanam 2.0’ edition, was organized by the foundation and the college. Volunteers of the foundation had first drawn illustrations on the walls, following which students began filling the drawings with colourful paints.

“Through our paintings, we wanted to create awareness on avoiding plastics and promote greenery by planting saplings,” chairperson of the foundation Shasikala Sathiyamurthy. “We chose this initiative to help beautify the ward,” she said.

Hospital dean Dr B Ashokan painted a few strokes along with the students. He said this initiative is expected to help the patients feel positive. “This ward has only children admitted and when they are sick, we believe these colourful walls will cheer them up. Their mental wellness is of utmost importance alongside their physically recovery,” he said.

Title: Sector magistrates to monitor law & order in Bareilly zone
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bareilly: In the backdrop of violent clashes over CAA in Delhi, sector scheme has been enforced across Bareilly zone for better maintenance of law and order, said deputy inspector general (DIG) Rajesh Kumar Pandey on Wednesday. The DIG said instructions to this effect were issued by the government on Wednesday morning.

The DIG said, “During the Supreme Court's Ayodhya verdict last year, the district was divided into sectors where sector magistrates were deployed to keep a tab on their respective areas as a precautionary measure. Following orders by the government in the wake of the ongoing law and order situation in Delhi, we have tightened our belts to avert any untoward situation. Our first challenge is to peacefully carry out Friday prayer on February 28. We have also started preparation for a peaceful Holi.”

In the evening, DIG and divisional commissioner Ranveer Prasad presided over a meeting of senior police and administrative officials at the Police Lines' auditorium to review the law and order preparedness following the ongoing violence in the national capital, as well as keeping in mind the upcoming festival of Holi.

Meanwhile, additional director general of Bareilly zone, Avinash Chandra, arrived in Moradabad on Wednesday to take of the situation near the Eidgah, where protesters have been staging a sit-in since January 29.

Title: Man injured in accidental firing
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Rajkot: A man was injured in an accidental firing at Mansarovar Apartment on Royal Park main road in Rajkot on Wednesday.

Police said the victim, Rahul Haran (27), was holding a revolver belonging to his employer Arvind Raninga, while sitting in Raninga’s car. Haran is Raninga’s driver. It was when he was holding the revolver, it went off accidentally, injuring his hand and feet.

“We have booked both Haran and Raninga. While Haran has been booked for firing, Raninga has been booked for allowing Haran to hold his licensed revolver,” said K A Vala, inspector with Gandhigram-2 police station.

Title: Man abducts woman, warns her to drop earlier charges in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

Title: Azam Khan News: Azam Khan family's new address;Barrack number 1 at Rampur jail
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

SP leader Azam Khan surrenders with his son Abdullah

RAMPUR: Senior Samajwadi Party (SP) leader and Rampur MP Azam Khan , his wife Tanzeen Fatimah and son Abdullah Azam were sent to judicial custody of six days by additional district and sessions judge Dhirendra Kumar Kamboj on Wednesday after the trio surrendered before the court in Rampur in a case involving the alleged forging of Abdullah’s birth certificate. The former UP cabinet minister along with his wife and son have been sent to the district jail and the next date of hearing is March 2.

The court while rejecting the anticipatory bail pleas of the three SP leaders had earlier declared them “absconders”. A local court on Tuesday had ordered “confiscation of their moveable and immovable properties” in connection with the forgery case.

The family had been ignoring court summons and were chargesheeted under various sections of the IPC for allegedly helping Abdullah obtain two fake birth certificates. Abdullah had allegedly gave an incorrect date of birth while filing his nomination papers for the assembly election. Following a high court order, he had lost his membership of the state assembly last December after he was found guilty of forgery. Azam and his kin have been booked in as many as 47 cases, ranging from "book theft" to land grab. The father-son duo were allegedly also involved in 11 criminal cases.

Dismissing the charges as “politically motivated”, Azam said he is “not just a foot soldier, but a warrior”. Several SP workers from Moradabad, Sambhal and Rampur had assembled outside the court room which had a heavy police presence.

Raising Azam’s health concerns before the court, counsel Khalilullah Khan said his client is a patient with blood pressure issues and is in need of regular medical attention. To this, the court said Azam and his wife "will be provided with all the facilities which an MP and MLA should get in custody”.

Rampur district magistrate Aunjaneya Kumar Singh told TOI, “Azam Khan, his wife Tanzeen Fatimah and son Abdullah Azam will get adequate security inside the jail as per the manual and they will be kept in the general barracks along with other prisoners.” Sources further said they would be kept in “barrack number 1”.

SP’s Sambhal unit president Feroz Khan said, “Our leader has been booked under several cases, which are all fake.” Police reportedly detained an agitated local SP worker outside the court premises.

Title: Shopkeepers, religious places, get relief in electricity duty
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Ahmedabad: Reeling under slowdown, shopkeepers received a breather on Wednesday when the state government proposed reduction in their electricity duty. The budget also cut electricity duty for religious places , dharamshalas and cold storages. The reductions will cost the state exchequer by approximately Rs 320 crore per year. For shopowners, traders, artisans and professionals, the budget proposed to reduce electricity duty from 25% to 20%. The reduction is for shopkeepers engaged in the trades like grocery, cloth, ready-made clothes, medical store, hardware, colour, provisional store, cutlery, bakery, stationary, mobile shops, garages etc.

Besides these, lawyers, chartered accountants, travel agencies, offices of transporters, coaching classes, photo studio, beauty parlour, saloon which are providing services will also benefit from the reduction.

In what could benefit 10,500 religious places within the state, the budget has proposed to reduce electricity duty for religious place like temples, mosques, churches, gurudwaras, derasars, and agiaris.

Title: Min: Senior cop to probe killing of tractor driver
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Jaipur: Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal on Wednesday assured the assembly that additional director general of police (Civil Rights) will investigate the case of killing of a tractor driver on May 29, 2019 under Deoli-Uniara assembly seat.

Dhariwal was giving his reply to the calling attention motion by MLA Harish Chand Meena during Zero Hour. He clarified that the incident took place on May 29, 2019 but no report came till June 3, 2019. He said that Dinesh and Kamlesh, the brothers-in-law of the deceased, arrived at the police station on the night of June 3, 2019, after which a report was registered in the morning on June 4.

He informed that Harbhajan Meena was brought to the Nagarfort Hospital with serious injuries on May 29 by Uniara police station SHO Manish Charan and other police personnel by 108 ambulance. Doctors declared him dead. The relative accused the police of murder. They filed a written complaint in this regard on June 3.

Jyoti Swaroop Sharma, additional superintendent of police, CID (CB) range cell Ajmer was appointed as investigating officer in the case. After his transfer, further investigation was done by newly appointed additional superintendent of police Preeti Chaudhary.

Title: Madurai-Delhi AI Express to fly daily
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Madurai: Air connectivity between Madurai and New Delhi by Air India Express is set to increase from March as the airline, which is operating its flight for four days per week at present, would be operating it daily, said Madurai MP Su Venkatesan.

Speaking to reporters in Madurai on Wednesday, Venkatesan said the decision was taken during the meeting of the Madurai Airport Consultative Committee. Chairman of the committee, Manickam Tagore presided over the meeting during which developmental activities in connection with the Madurai airport were discussed.

Among other issues discussed were the delay in provision of compensation to the people whose land was acquired for the expansion work. They had taken it up with the district administration after assuming charge in May last year and the process had been expedited with Rs 54.25 crore having been disbursed till date.

Steps are also being taken to stress upon the central government to sign the bilateral treaties needed for launching air services between Madurai and international destinations.

Venkatesan said that the director of the Madurai airport had assured to revamp the airport runway to enhance night landing facility, and work on this would be taken up in June and completed by December.

Steps are also being taken to improve bus connectivity by the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) from the airport to various parts of the city. Air-conditioned buses are like;y to be operated between the airport to various destinations from April onwards. Thiruparankundram MLA Dr P Saravanan was also present. TNN

Title: Cancer hospital doctor ends life days before her wedding in Aurangabad
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A 28-year-old medical officer with the government cancer hospital was found dead at her residence late on Tuesday night in the city.

The deceased has been identified as Shadab Shireen, who was going to get married on March 13. The police said she had been to the cancer hospital on Tuesday morning. After returning home, she also indulged in some marriage preparations.

Investigation officer and assistant inspector Sainath Gite said she had committed suicide by hanging herself using a scarf and tying it to the iron rod of a window. “Exact cause of the suicide is not known. We have registered a case of accidental death and are investigation the matter,” he said.

An officer privy to the probe said that the police were checking if there was any work-related stress that forced her to take the extreme step. “There must have been a serious trigger that forced a highly qualified professional to take an extreme step. We have not found any suicide note so far and are exploring all angles,” said senior inspector Vyankatesh Kendre of Jinsi police station.

A family friend told TOI that the doctor had been to the market along with family members for carrying out marriage related shopping. While the shopping was underway, she left midway and returned home. Later, when her siblings and mother called her, she did not respond. They broke the door down and found her unconscious.

Title: Govt mulls using M-sand for construction
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The state government in its reply to a question said since sand mining on riverbed is banned by the Supreme Court, it will form guidelines to use manufactured sand (M-sand) for constructions undertaken by its departments/agencies.

Title: Pune: Youth held for kidnapping, molesting minor girl
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

Title: ‘Social entrepreneurs’ show the way in doing sustainable biz
Content: Dehradun: Social entrepreneurs — who are running businesses in a sustainable manner, taking care of the needs of local communities as well as environmental concerns — are on the rise in the Doon valley. These entrepreneurs say that sustainability in a business is vital as it means generating profit while improving societal and environmental conditions, and that it is “the ethical responsibility of a business as well as its owner to be aware of the social and environmental issues prevailing and try to find out ways to improve the situation.”Nupur Agarwal and Abhinav Ahluwalia, founders of Evolve Foundation, a social enterprise that manufactures ‘plantable stationery’ and aims to contribute towards sustainable villages in Uttarakhand, say that women entrepreneurs especially are suitable for social enterprises as they have “sensitivity towards the environment and society.” “In our organisation, we help a rural family by buying seeds from the farmer, provide employment to local women who produce the products and conduct education workshops for their children,” says Agarwal, adding, “Every young person should aspire to start something that matters and should volunteer for at least a few hours in any area they would like, as it will not only lead to a better society but also help them learn more about themselves.”A few entrepreneurs are looking at reuse and recycle options in their businesses to make sure that they make the least demands on the environment. Like Joshua Hishey and Richa Ghansiyal, who run the Alaya Design Studio in Old Rajpur — which is in the custom design furniture business and also trains locals in the art of woodworking. “We consciously make an effort to integrate and explore design solutions based on restoration and renewable resources, recycling in our personal and professional assignments,” says Ghansiyal. She adds that “earlier, needs were few and addressed locally, while today we have created a world of desires.” “Consumption has become an activity that is creating more and more waste. For instance, in our fast-moving lives, meals have changed. From freshly made food, we have moved to packaged foods, where inevitably the packaging is something that needs to be disposed of, after one-time use. Any talk of sustainability cannot remain as a responsibility in the sphere of governance, environmental or otherwise, but has to be inculcated at each micro-task level. Therefore it is essential to teach sustainability within one’s immediate environment, natural or human-made.”For Ghayur and Patricia Alam, engaging with the local community is an integral part of their work. The couple runs Himalayan Weavers that produces shawls, stoles, rugs and scarves using only natural dyes. Wool is collected from villages in Gangotri and Himachal, and the work of dyeing and hand spinning is given to village women, thereby providing them employment. “Our greatest reward is the satisfaction of customers and the smiles on the faces of the women who work with us,” says the couple who operates out of Masrana, a small village near Mussoorie.A similar vision — of empowering locals — drives two friends, Tanya Kotnala, a fashion designer and Tanya Singh, a nutrition consultant. With an aim to create products that are “sustainable and ethnic”, the duo set up ‘Bhuli’(which means ‘little sister’ in Garhwali) in 2017 with the aim of promoting Uttarakhand’s unique art and craft culture. “Cultural preservation of every kind is important for society because it makes it more dynamic. I believe that it is also essential for supporting local artisans and businesses,” says Kotnala.

Title: Madurai: Burial urns found in Konthagai near Keeladi
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Burial urns have been found in Konthagai village near Keeladi, which is being excavated in the sixth phase of ... Read More

MADURAI: Burial urns have been found in Konthagai village near Keeladi , which is being excavated in the sixth phase of excavation by the Tamil Nadu state archaeology department.

The sixth phase of excavation at Keeladi in Thirupuvanam taluk in Sivaganga district was inaugurated on February 19 by chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami through video conferencing. Apart from Keeladi, three more villages - Konthagai, Manalur and Aharam - have also been taken up for excavation in this sixth phase.

On Wednesday, workers at Konthagai found the top portion of two burial urns. Konthagai is already said to be the burial site of the civilization that had thrived on the banks of river Vaigai over 2,600 years ago. Sources at the department of archaeology said that while burial urns have been found in many places in the state, brick structures were being revealed in Keeladi, and hence importance was given to Keeladi.

It will take a few days for the workers to work on the site and find out if the urns are intact or damaged. But, there are chances of finding many more urns in Konthagai, said sources.

Meanwhile, visitors have already started coming to Keeladi to witness the excavation process. It may be recalled that thousands of people thronged Keeladi after the report of the fourth phase of excavation was published by the archaeology department in August last year.

The temporary exhibition at the Tamil Sangam building in Madurai is drawing hundreds of people on a daily basis. Now, people have started thronging Keeladi already, though it has been just five days since the work began. In order to ensure that the public are not disappointed, he department has put up a photo exhibition at the site.

Title: Telangana: Villagers block highway to protest couple’s death
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Villagers protest on the Warangal-Khammam highway on Wednesday

WARDHANNAPET: Tension prevailed on Warangal – Khammam highway on Wednesday as villagers staged a protest following the death of a couple in a road accident on Tuesday.

The couple, Bommakanti Raju and Bommakanti Rani, died on the spot and another person was grievously injured after the official vehicle of Palakurthi Circle Inspector knocked down the bike the latter was riding at Thirumalayapally village.

Villagers and family members of the deceased staged a rasta roko demanding compensation and action against the CI, forcing vehicular traffic to come to a standstill for 5 km on the highway for more than five hours. Parents of the deceased, who staged the protest with the bodies of the deceased, refused to perform their last rites and alleged that the police was trying to mislead them.

On coming to know about the incident, police rushed to the spot and resorted to mild lathi-charge to disperse the protesters and clear the blockade. Around 200 police personnel from Mamnoor, Wardhannapet and Kazipet were deployed at the protest site. The protesters moved to the villages and continued their protest after assurances from the police that the matter would be thoroughly probed and that they would be provided all help to meet the funeral expenses.

Title: 245 hosps in Haridwar do not have facility to dispose bio-medical waste, reveals RTI
Content: Haridwar: The menace of dumping bio-medical waste in the open continues unabated in Haridwar. An RTI reply from the health department has revealed that out of the total 306 private and government medical facilities in the city, only 61 have proper arrangements for disposing bio-medical waste scientifically. Among these 61 facilities, 42 are government-run centres.The rest 245 medical facilities openly dump bio-medical wastes in the residential areas which could trigger a spread of several diseases. The RTI was filed by Shiv Sena district president Charanjeet Pawha.Locals claim that hospitals and clinics do no not abide by the rules and dump their waste in public dustbins, due to which bio-medical waste gets mixed with domestic waste.Social activist Vishal Garg told TOI, “Sanitation facilities are in a bad shape in Haridwar and bio-medical waste is being dumped in the open and is getting mixed with domestic waste. This could lead to a spread of infections in the city but local officials are not taking concrete steps to address this issue.”When queried on the issue, Haridwar’s chief medical officer Saroj Naithani told TOI, “A total of 306 hospital, clinics, and pathology labs are registered under the Clinical Establishment (Registration and Regulation) Act in the city. We ask them to follow guidelines in regards to disposal of bio-medical waste. We will set up an inquiry into the matter and strict action will be taken against those who violate rules.”Notably, Haridwar generates around 250 metric tonnes of garbage (on an average) daily and Roorkee Municipal Corporation collects around 125 metric tonnes of it. During festival and religious fairs, the garbage quantity increases by 25%. “All this waste isn’t treated. In fact, Haridwar Municipal Corporation collects garbage from the city and dumps it in Sarai village. This continued dumping has triggered a health scare among the people who live there,” a local said.Meanwhile, Haridwar Municipal Corporation commissioner Narendra Singh Bhandari told TOI, “We do not collect bio-medical waste from hospitals or nursing homes. We have directed our sanitation workers to not collect waste from hospitals. We will take action if they are found dumping bio-medical waste in public dustbins.”

Title: Ancient burial urns found at Peraiyur
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Madurai: About 30 ancient burial urns have been found near Peraiyur in Madurai district on Wednesday.

T Muneeswaran, head of the department of history at the Saraswathy Narayanan College, and founder of Pandinadu Cultural Centre along with few others had gone on a field visit to Koppaisamy temple, located in the foothills in Peraiyur, where they found these burial urns.

Muneeswaran said that this site, which was expected to be about 3,000 years old, may have existed since the neolithic period till the Sangam era. He said that like Keeladi and its neighbouring villages, this habitation also seemed to have a habitation site, Kalmedu, an industrial area and burial site.

They spotted the top portion of about 30 urns, which were buried in the ground. The urns seem to have been made from black-red pottery on the inner side. An urn with a diameter of about 84 cm, with about two inches thickness and a smaller one of 60 cm diameter and one inch thickness, which is more damaged were found there.

Title: BJP walks out of assembly over Appropriation Bill
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Jaipur: The opposition BJP legislators on Wednesday staged a walkout from the assembly demanding division of votes on the state Appropriation Bill, 2020. The bill was passed through voice vote.

As chairperson Rajendra Pareek proceeded to pass the bill by voice vote, Opposition members created an uproar claiming that the government was not having majority and members of the ruling Congress were not present on their seats. Deputy leader of Opposition Rajendra Rathore said the government was in minority and it could fall. “The finance bill is being passed in the House. The government is in minority. Get the lobby cleared. They have made it a mockery,” he said. Amid uproar, BJP legislators started shouting slogans and entered the well demanding division of votes.

The chair appealed to the members to go back to their seats, but they did not pay heed.

Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal asked to get the members counted. He said 56 members of ruling Congress were present against 28 of the Opposition.

Title: Madurai: Encroachments removed from temple land
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Over 100 acres of land had been retrieved in Madurai and the neighbouring districts in the last two years.

MADURAI: Encroachments, including 10 shops and 10 houses, were evicted by the administration of the Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple in Madurai’s Chokkalingam Nagar with the help of police on Wednesday.

Joint commissioner of the Sri Meenakshi temple, N Natarajan, said that they were taking stringent action to retrieve temple land, which were earlier leased and now misused by people. Over 100 acres of land had been retrieved in Madurai and the neighbouring districts in the last two years.

Recently, they evicted people, who had encroached upon the temple land near the ancient Kasi Viswanathar temple. On Wednesday, they went to Chokkalingam Nagar near the Bypass Road with police and the buildings that were encroaching on about 20 cents of land were razed to the ground. Tension prevailed in the area due to the eviction drive.

The Natarajan said that attempts had been made by the encroachers to sell this land, which then was brought to their notice. After a legal battle, the temple was given permission to evict the encroachers.

Title: Standing panel hikes draft budget by Rs 200 crore
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The draft budget was declared by the municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game

NASHIK: The standing committee of Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) on Wednesday increased the draft budget for the financial year 2020-21 by Rs 200 crore — from 2,161.79 to Rs 2,361.79.

The committee suggested that Rs 150 crore should be raised through bonds while remaining Rs 50 crore to be raised through making the marginal hike in property tax collection targets through the property, water, and other taxes. The draft budget was declared by the municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game.
