Title: Turtles caught in fishing net at Arichal Munai rescued
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The turtles were rescued and released into sea by police officials

MADURAI: Police personnel from the Marine police and Q Branch in Ramanathapuram district rescued two turtles caught in a fishing net on Wednesday evening. The five-member team comprising Q branch sub-inspector Mustafa and Marine police inspector S Kanagaraj were on duty at Arichal Munai near Dhanushkodi when they spotted the turtles and rescued them as the fishermen were reluctant in freeing them.

The stretch from Rameswaram to Dhanushkodi is a turtle nesting zone where the forest department collects thousands of eggs during the nesting season.

“As it is the annual nesting season now, turtles frequent the stretch and at times get caught in fishing nets,” the inspector said. Since turtle hunting is banned under The Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 , the species is mostly released.

Interestingly, this is also the season when fishermen engaged in shore fishing get a good catch, due to which they catch fish two to three times a day, against the usual practice of once a day. In this fishing model the net is spread for 1.5 to 2km stretch and a group of fishermen draw the net from either side from the shore.

On Wednesday evening, the police personnel spotted two turtles caught in the net each weighing about 25kg and 20kg.

As fishermen were reluctant in rescuing them, the police personnel made them release the turtles. While one returned to the sea, the other was injured due to mishandling by a fisherman.

The turtle that was motionless after the hard landing was comforted by the police personnel and it started moving its limbs after 10 minutes.

It was released in the sea. Marine police personnel said that earlier this month they released five turtles caught in a fishing net at Dhanushkodi.

They appealed to the fishermen to ensure that turtles are neither caught nor injured when they are fishing.

Title: When rainwater quenched thirst
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Jaipur: When there were no pipelines, rainwater harvesting helped quench heritage city’s thirst.

At Nahargarh and Jaigarh forts, rainwater harvesting structures dates back to the 18th century.

An elaborate network of channels and aquaducts were built by Sawai Jai Singh, the founder of of modern Jaipur.

The gradient of the hill was used to channel the flow of water through ducts to a portion of the hill that was carved out to form a tank. As the water entered the tank, an elaborate swirling mechanism ensured that the gush of water could be regulated and that the structure did not suffer damage in case the flow was excessive.

At Nahargarh, water harvesting structures preceded the construction of the fort in 1734.

Neeraj Doshi, an organiser of the heritage water walks, while giving details about the old water structures of the city said, “The technology used then was to preserve as much water possible and prevent it from flowing down the hills. There are three tanks at Nahargahr and five at Jaigarh. The Nahargarh tanks could store around 6 crore litres of water. At Jaigarh, the only open tank stores around 2.5 crore litres of water. The structures are still working except a few damages on the route.”

The water collected at the forts was utilised over there, but there are ruins of a tunnel coming down the hill of Nahargarh fort to Talkatora pond. It is presumed that this tunnel was used to transfer water to Talkatora in case of overflow, which gushed into Mansagar Lake. Talkatora was filled by water received through a canal passing through the city from Dravyawati river which also flows to Mansagar lake.

“The system of Jaipur was advanced enough to provide water to royals and the residents. Choti Chaupar and Badi Chaupar used to have water tanks from where water was taken by the common people. The idea was to make water available at the centre of the city. With change of time, taps were introduced by Samuel Swinton Jacob, an English engineer, after 1880. He installed taps on many intersections of the Walled City to reach out to common people,” explained Neeraj.

The structures built at Nahargarh still store water, but it is not used. At Jaigarh though, water is utilised by the people living within the fort except for bathing and drinking.

Title: Madurai: UK, US tourists swim across Palk Bay
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

MADURAI: Two tourists from the United Kingdom and the US took out a swimming expedition across the Palk Bay from Talaimannar in Sri Lanka to Arichal Munai near Dhanushkodi in Ramanathapuram district on Wednesday. The swimmers were escorted by the Indian Coast Guard (ICG) from the International Maritime Boundary Line (IMBL) and stopped at the first island near Arichal Munai.

Adam A G Moss from the UK and Eddie Al-Ming Hu from the US got clearance from the ministry of external affairs on Monday, following which information on the same was shared with the ICG at Mandapam in Ramanathapuram district. “They were supposed to take up the expedition on Tuesday but the plan was dropped as the sea was rough,” ICG Mandapam commandant G Mani Kumar said.

They set off from Talaimannar at 5am on Wednesday and crossed the IMBL that is 6 nautical miles (11km) from Arichal Munai and entered the Indian waters at 12.05pm. The duo was accompanied by a support team in a boat. ICG’s ship and two smaller vessels also accompanied them for search and rescue operations in case of emergency.

Police sources said the support boat from Sri Lanka that accompanied the tourists was stopped at 4 nautical miles (7.4km) off Arichal Munai. The swimmers were allowed to proceed up to the first island -- about 2km off Arichal Munai -- as they are not permitted to proceed further.

On reaching Arichal Munai at 4.15pm the swimmers and the support team was questioned and checked by the marine police and Q branch personnel to check if those who accompanied the tourists were not involved in any other activities. The tourists then started back by boat and were monitored by the ICG till the boat crossed the IMBL at 5.40pm and entered the Sri Lankan waters.

Title: Chandigarh: Truck on wrong side runs over 2 pedestrians
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The truck driver fled, leaving the vehicle behind on Wednesday

CHANDIGARH: A truck coming from wrong side mowed down two pedestrians and injured another near the railway underbridge at Industrial Area, Phase I, on Wednesday night.

The victims were yet to be identified. All three were walking home after completing their shift. They were trying to cross the road near Bhushan Steel factory when the speeding truck ran over them. As passersby gathered at the spot, the driver fled, leaving his vehicle behind.

Passersby informed police about the accident. A PCR vehicle took the three to Government Medical College and Hospital, Sector 32, where doctors declared two of them brought dead. The condition of the injured is serious. Police registered a case against the truck driver and started investigation.

Title: 13-year-old boy among two killed in separate cases of celebratory firing
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bareilly: A boy, who went to attend his cousin’s wedding in Budaun, was struck in the head by a bullet fired during the function. He died on the spot. In a separate incident, a groom’s 35-year-old maternal uncle died after being hit by a bullet in his abdomen at a village in Sambhal district. Both the incidents took place late on Tuesday.

Deputy inspector general (DIG) of Bareilly range Rajesh Kumar Pandey said that the accused was one of the close relatives and no complaint was lodged by the victim’s family. “I have instructed the superintendent of police in Budaun to ensure FIR is lodged. We are investigating the matter,” the DIG said.

Police said that Bunty, 13, had come to his maternal aunt’s place in Salempur village of Alapur area in the district to attend a wedding where he was struck by a bullet on his head in celebratory firing on Tuesday night.

“The incident took place around 11 pm on Tuesday. However, the victim’s family didn’t inform the police. We came to know about the incident on Wednesday morning following which a police team reached the spot and spoke to the family members. An FIR against unknown person has been registered,” the DIG said, claiming that it was the first such incident of death caused by celebratory firing in four districts of Bareilly range over the past year, since he was posted there.

In the other incident that occurred in Sambhal, Dinesh Singh was attending his nephew’s wedding at Allupur village under Hayatnagar police station limits where a few guests in an inebriated state started firing. Singh was struck in his stomach and he fell in a pool of blood. His family members rushed him to hospital where he was declared brought dead.

Police sent the body for postmortem and registered a case against unidentified accused.

Title: Cong report on Nagaur incident finds lapses on part of police
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Jaipur: A fact-finding committee constituted by deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot to look into the incident of two Dalit cousins being beaten up and humiliated in Nagaur on February 16, submitted its seal-packed report.

The report is confidential, but sources in the Congress claimed that the fact-finding team had found lapses on part of police in handling the case. “The fact-finding team was not satisfied with police action taken in the issue,” he said.

The police department has already sent station house officer (Panchaudi) Rajpal Singh to reserve police lines, Nagaur. Shambhu Dayal Meena has replaced him.

Pilot, while informing reporters that he had received the report from the committee, said the report will be sent to All India Congress Committee and in-charge general secretary of the state. “The incident is shameful. Action should be taken against those involved in it,” he said. On February 16, two Dalit cousins were beaten up and humiliated. The incident happened at a motorbike service centre, where the workers had alleged that the Dalit youths had stolen Rs 50,000. They thrashed them and also inserted a screwdriver laced with petrol in the private parts of one of the two Dalits.

A series of videos went viral and an FIR was filed on February 19. A team of Dalit activists, who visited Son Nagar village to meet the Dalit cousins, had also raised question on the role of police in the case. The fact-finding team of Dalit activists alleged that the incident happened on February 16. Despite the video going viral, police did not act on it, they claimed. The victims reached police station after three days of the incident, when they gathered some courage.

Title: Tamil Nadu: GRH new burns ward ready, yet to be opened
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The ward, as proposed, is set to be equipped with state-of-the-art equipment and facilities to provide special... Read More

MADURAI: A new state-of-the-art burns ward, which was proposed to be built at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) in Madurai at a cost of Rs 6 crore, is yet to be inaugurated.

According to sources, construction of the building is complete but it is yet to be equipped and opened for use.

Dean of the GRH, Dr Sangumani J asserted that the new ward would be fully ready within the next two weeks.

The proposal for the new ward had come in 2018 after the current 20-bedded burns ward was found to have flaws and was found insufficient to handle victims with burn injuries in the aftermath of the forest fire at Kurangini in Theni, which left 23 dead.

“The building is fully complete. However, the necessary equipment is yet to be acquired. Within two weeks, we are hoping to get it. Soon after it is done, we want to equip and open the ward as soon as possible,” said Sangumani, speaking to TOI.

However, hospital sources said the building was completed almost two months ago but was just kept locked up.

“We were expecting it to be equipped soon and opened but it did not happen. We suspected administrative delays,” said a source.

The building of the new burns ward is located close to the ophthalmology section and old nephrology department near the hospital’s compound wall.

The ward, as proposed, is set to be equipped with state-of-the-art equipment and facilities to provide specialized care for patients with burn injuries. The unit is set to have water beds and kept fully-sterile fitted with hepa filters.

The facility would be centrally air-conditioned and there would also be an upgraded laboratory to treat patients better.

In a similar case, a new separate clinic for transgender people has been built and kept ready but is yet to be officially inaugurated.

Title: Cash, belongings worth Rs 40 lakh looted from bank official’s flat
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: Unidentified miscreants decamped with gold jewellery, cash and other articles worth nearly Rs 40 lakh from a bank official’s flat located in the busy Raghunathpur area, when the residents were away in the early hours of Wednesday.

The 45-year-owner, Pushkar Thakur , said, “My parents have been staying in the Raghunathpur flat since seven years. But it was empty for the last few days as they were staying in my flat in Bhubaneswar itself (from February 21). On Wednesday morning, we received information about the loot in that flat.”

In his complaint with the Nandankanan police station, Thakur alleged that nearly 100gm of gold jewellery, Rs 1.5 lakh in cash, some Australian dollars and other articles were stolen from the house.

“We are in shock. The apartment has a private security guard and a well-protected surveillance system. However, I came to know on Wednesday that the CCTV cameras were not functioning,” Thakur said.

Acting on Thakur’s complaint, police questioned the security guard and the maid of the house.

“We strongly suspect the involvement of someone close to the victim who may have passed on information to the burglars. We could have gotten vital leads on the robbery had the CCTV cameras been working,” a police officer said.

The flat is located on the third floor of a four-storeyed apartment in the area. “We didn’t have the slightest clue of the loot next door. Though the robbers broke the steel lock of the flat, we could not hear a noise as it was raining heavily that night,” a neighbour residing on the same floor said.

The security guard and society members of the apartment were unavailable for a comment.

It must be mentioned that in February last year, a gang of around 10 masked men broke into a house in Kanan Vihar area, hold a baby at knife-point and looted items worth Rs 10 lakh.

Title: Narmada canal breathes life into sandy Sanchore
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Jodhpur: The sandy landscapes of Sanchore in Jalore district have witnessed an impressive change after water from Narmada canal gave the entire region a lush green look.

One is greeted with hundreds of green and poly-houses in the agriculture fields when entering the limits of Sanchore subdivision. The land here is now producing fruits and crops – something that the local farmers had never believed would be possible.

The farmers of Sanchore are now cultivating pomegranates, which are being supplied to almost entire country. Orchards of fruits like papaya, dates and other have become a common sight in the once-barren lands.

Talking about this transformation, Mahaveer Singh Dantiya, a farmer-turned-politican said that there was a time when even drinking water was a luxury. “However, arrival of Narmada water has changed the lives of people. Not only has the drinking water problem been resolved, but adequate water is now available for irrigation. This has changed the character of agriculture here,” said Dantiya.

He said now not only groundwater has risen remarkably, but the salinity of water has also disappeared.

Entire agriculture was dependent on rain here before 2008 and the farming average was very low. The area receives 370 mm rainfall on an average and traditionally, millet and gaur were the predominant crops.

“Now the farmers are harvesting three crops a year. Crops like cumin seed, fennel seeds, pearl millet and caster seeds are very common here,” said a progressive farmer of the region, Yogesh Joshi.

He said that nobody had ever dreamt of harvesting vegetables and fruits in the region but all types of agriculture is being practiced in the region with advanced farming technologies being adopted by the farmers.

According to agriculture observer Devendra Singh, the major crop now is jeera, which is sown in 30,000 hectares followed by isabgol. The production of jeera, which requires sweet water and was never grown in the region pre-canal era, grows about 10 quintals per hectare. Pomegranate is sown in 1,000 hectares.

The 74-km canal has nine major tributaries to carry the water of the main canal in different directions as far as upto Gudamalani in Barmer.

“There are 2,200 diggies built on these tributaries to hold the water of the canal for irrigation,” said Dantiya, adding that a huge network of sprinklers in the agriculture farms is in itself define the opulence of agriculture here.

According to the agriculture department, total area sown in the region was 60,383 hectares in 2008-09 and today, almost a decade after water reached Sanchore, it has risen to 1,63,000 hectares. It serves an area of 1,477 square kilometre and provides drinking water to 874 villages.

In recent years, the agricultural transformation has caught the fancy of investors from neighbouring Gujarat, who have set up processing and packaging plants in Sanchore, further improving the economy of the area and generating employment.

“You ride along the highways and will come across many packaging units engaged in packaging of fruits and vegetables,” said Devesh Vyas, an advocate, adding that hardly any affluent person in Sanchore can be found who does not own an orchard.

Title: Raj movie ‘Turtle’ is state GST free
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Rajasthani movie ‘Turtle’ was made state GST free by chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Wednesday. The movie spreads the message of water conservation in the state where it is scarce. The movie was awarded the best Rajasthani movie in the 66 National Awards. Earlier, Gehlot had even made Super-30 and women empowerment movie ‘Sand Ki Aankh’ state GST free.

Title: Chandigarh: PGI voices speech woes of tutors, party animals
Content:
File photo of PGI Chandigarh

CHANDIGARH: What do coaching classes tutors, frequent discotheque visitors and regular jagrata participants have in common? They are part of a new group of patients reporting to PGI with voice-related complaints, according to doctors. And, it is the background noise that is affecting voice in many cases.“When the background noise is above 90 decibels, one tends to raise voice. This causes trauma to the vocal cord. Consequently, one keeps on continuously talking loudly. Sometimes a single exposure can also cause damage,” said Dr Sanjay Munjal of department of ENT at PGI.“Long-term effect can make the voice turn hoarse. Usually, the effects are temporary and can be reversed with voice rest. If the voice is raised frequently, it can have permanent changes. For instance, in case of hoarse voice, the loudness of the voice can be reduced. Voice trauma can be treated with proper hydration, speaking for short duration and restricting voice usage,” said Dr Munjal. “Perhaps, tutors in coaching classes are teaching for a longer duration and larger groups. At discotheques, noise levels are already high,” he said.It was observed that doctors and other paramedical students who attended the annual festival of Association of Resident Doctors at PGI — Spring Festival — used to come back with hoarse voice. “So, we decided to conduct a study how loud noise in the background affects voice,” said Dr Anuradha Sharma, speech therapist faculty member at the ENT department in PGI.Both the noise levels in the background and voice changes in students owing to howling and shouting during the festival were measured. “We found that out of 25 students, 50% had hoarse voice, while three developed nodules, which if not treated, needs surgery for removal. The age group was from 18-25 years of age and all were women,” said Dr Sharma.These kinds of nodules are seen in those talking loudly during kirtans and jagratras. “Nodule formation can result in irritation in the voice and dryness of the throat. We get mostly teachers, untrained musicians and schoolchildren who shout in the playground or classrooms with nodules,” said Dr Sharma.The department now plans to include large group of students for its next study and follow them up after seven weeks until two months.

Title: Satpute tops ICSI from city centre
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Aurangabad: The Institute of the Company Secretaries of India (ICSI) on Tuesday declared the results, where several students from Aurangabad, Ahmednagar and Jalgaon excelled in the professional and executive programme exams.

In the first module of the professional programme for the old syllabus, eight students passed the examination from Aurangabad district, while another 11 and 10 cleared in the second and third modules, respectively. In the new syllabus, five students passed in the first module, whereas three and five students cracked the second and third modules, respectively, an official release said.

Among the most successful candidates, Mansi Satpute cleared all modules in the first attempt and secured top rank in the merit list from the Aurangabad centre.

In the executive programme of the new syllabus, 15 students cleared the examination in the first module and another six passed in the second module. In the old syllabus, 20 students passed in the first module, whereas another 26 students cleared the second module.

Title: Madurai: Over 1 lakh students to take public exam next month
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative Image

MADURAI: More than one lakh students of Madurai district from Class X, XI and XII will be sitting for the public board exam next month.

A total of 1,13,321 students are set to appear for the exams . Meanwhile, school counsellors and teachers have urged parents and students to seek help if needed to cope with exam stress. They said schools are better equipped at handling exam stress nowadays.

“There will always be fear and stress as long as exams exist. However, nowadays we are better equipped to handle exam stress since parents and students themselves are more aware about such stress,” said Vijayalakshmi C, a counsellor for school students. She also pointed out that parents and teachers must consciously monitor children especially before exams to watch out for signs of anxiety or panic attacks. “Even the brightest student can have a mental break down before exams. So, it is a must for parents and teachers to offer emotional support,” she added.

Some schools in the city are also holding yoga sessions, meditation and candle prayers to help students ease their fears. “Little things can give students the motivation and courage to face exams. We hold a special candle prayer for Class XII students and even ask them to take a small oath to work hard and do good for the society. Such little things give positive energy,” said Ambigai S, a Class XII teacher at a private school.

While the current syllabus for all three classes is voluminous, students also get leaves between exams to revise. “Of course, students who study last minute will suffer but if a student has been studying regularly, the time gap between exams is more than sufficient for good revision,” said Venkatesan V, a Class X teacher from a corporation school. Several teachers and parents also added that they try to not let their child get too caught up and skip meals before exams.

On March 2, a total of 36,293 students from Class XII will be starting their board exams in Madurai. On the other hand, in Madurai, while a total of 36,904 students from Class XI will be beginning their board exams on March 4, as many as 40,124 students from Class X will be writing their board exams from March 27.

Title: Anti-CAA protesters in Tamil Nadu condemn Delhi violence
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative Image

Madurai: Public protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in Madurai and Tirunelveli, on Wednesday, condemned the violence in Delhi. In Tirunelveli, they demanded the resignation of home minister Amit Shah.Various Muslim organizations have been continually protesting against the CAA, National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) at Melapalayam in Tirunelveli, and Mahaboopalayam and Nelpettai in Madurai. On Wednesday, protesters at Melapalayam demanded the resignation of Shah, handing over control of police forces to the Delhi government and arrest of TN BJP leader H Raja for making provocative statements

In Madurai, on Tuesday night, Social Democratic Party of India led a protest at Nelpettai condemning violence in Delhi, which has left at least 27 people dead. The protests at Mahaboopalayam entered its 13th day on Wednesday while protests at Nelpettai entered its 10th day. Over 1,500 women took part in demonstration at Nelpettai.tnn

Title: Rajasthan: Slain Delhi cop declared martyr, kin to get Rs 1 crore relief, government job
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Head constable Ratan Lal died during clashes over the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in northeast Delhi on Mo... Read More

JAIPUR: The family of Delhi Police head constable Ratan Lal , who died in CAA-related violence in the national capital on Monday, was consigned to flames only after Union minister of state for home G Krishna Reddy stated that the deceased policeman is a martyr .

“Consulted Satya Gopal, home secretary, Government of National Capital Territory of Delhi (GNCTD), head constable Ratal Lal, who was martyred while on duty is a martyr. His next of kin is now entitled for compensation amounting to nearly Rs 1 crore. The Centre may consider a suitable employment for his family member,” Reddy wrote in the message to Sikar MP Sumedhanand Saraswati, who showed it to the villagers of Tihawali.

Prior to that, Tihawali villagers staged a dharna at Sadinsar village. They decided not to take Lal’s body to the village until he had been declared a martyr. They protested for six hours in the morning at Sadinsar before Sumedhanand showed evidence of fulfilling their demand.

They blocked National Highway 11, due to which police had to divert traffic. Sumedhanand told villagers that he had been in touch with the home ministry and the demand of declaring Lal martyr will be fulfilled.

Despite his assurance, the villagers demanded it should be given written. Folowing that, Saraswati showed the message of Reddy mentioning that his kin will be given Rs 1 crore and employment to a family member.

“They were demanding it in writing. We made aware leaders in the Centre about the demand. A meeting was held on the issue and they informed me that Lal has been declared as a martyr,” said Saraswati, who added that so far not a single policeman of Delhi Police had been declared as martyr.

Talking to the newspersons, his daughter Varsha demanded that the accused involved in the killing of his father be given strict punishment. He died of bullet injury. Lal’s seven-year-old son Ram lit the funeral pyre.

People in large numbers, even from nearby villages, were present during the cremation.

Title: Three held for kidnapping of jewellery shop owner
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Accused in the custody of Rajkot police

RAJKOT: Three persons were arrested on Wednesday for allegedly kidnapping the owner of a jewellery showroom in Bhavnagar on January 29. Police said accused Rohit Kotar (30), Yashpalsinh Chudasma (28), his brother Shaktisinh Chudasma (27) and Kalpesh Kotar, had allegedly kidnapped Mukesh Jodhvani (43) from his residence in Prarabhda Residency at Bhangli Gate in Hill Drive locality of Bhavnagar.

Another accused, Kalpesh, is still at large, said cops.

“The accused had demanded Rs 50 lakh cash and jewellery worth Rs 50 lakh as ransom from the jeweller. After they received the ransom they released Jodhvani on January 31.

The accused accosted Jodhvani on his bike near his residence and threatened him with firearms and knives, before kidnapping him,” said N G Chaudhary, inspector with Neelambaug police station.

After paying the ransom for his release, Jodhvani was reluctant to lodge a police complaint out of fear. However later, when minister Vibhavari Dave, came to know about the crime, she convinced Jodhvani to lodge the complaint.

After the complaint was lodged, Bhavnagar deputy superintendent of police Manish Thakar formed four members team.

“We initiated investigation on basis of CCTV footages of the crime spot, mobile network and using our informers. We traced the accused and nabbed them on Wednesday,” said Thakar. The police recovered Rs 12.10 lakh cash, two cars and two cellphones from the accused. The police also found the involvement of one Kalpesh in the crime and launched a manhunt for him.

Title: CCB asks film unit to keep accident site as it is
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Chennai: The Central Crime Branch (CCB), which has taken over the investigation into the crane accident that killed three people during the shooting of ‘ Indian 2 ’ on February 19, has asked the production unit to keep the accident site in EVP Film City as it is. A CCB team visited the shooting spot on Wednesday.

The police team led by deputy commissioner of police G Nagajothi, along with forensic experts, gathered evidence from the spot.

Police have asked the production unit to not disturb the shooting set where the accident took place until the investigation officers give the go ahead.

The officials were at the shooting spot for three hours. EVP Film City has shut the studio set.

The other studio sets, however, continue to be busy with film shoots.

Earlier, the Nazarethpet police had arrested crane operator Rajan, who later got bail from a magistrate court.

After the case was transferred from Nazarethpet to CCB last Sunday as per the direction of police commissioner A K Viswanathan, DCP Nagajothi summoned six people who engaged the crane from Mumbai. Rajan was also questioned.

Title: Standing committee chairperson poll deferred
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has deferred the election to the post of the standing committee chairperson, which was scheduled on March 3, following the state government’s stay on the appointment of eight new standing committee members.

The state government’s urban development department had put a stay to the appointments of eight new members on Tuesday. The stay came after complaints by Shiv Sena group leader Vilas Shinde. The urban development department has also sent a letter to the municipal commissioner, asking him to submit his report on Shinde’s complaints.

Accordingly, the NMC administration has decided to defer the election to the standing committee chairperson’s post as well.

NMC town secretary Raju Kute sent a letter to divisional revenue commissioner Rajaram Mane, informing him about the postponement of the election.

On Monday, mayor Satish Kulkarni had declared the names of eight new members of the standing committee — four from the BJP, two from the Shiv Sena and one each from the Congress and the NCP — after the term of eight former standing committee members came to an end.

In the 16-member standing committee, the BJP has nine seats, while the Sena has four. The Congress, NCP and the MNS have one member each. The quota of the standing committee members to political parties is decided based on their strength in terms of corporators.

During the 2017 civic elections, the BJP had won 66 seats and the Shiv Sena got 34. Accordingly, the comparative strength of both BJP and Shiv Sena was 8.65 and 4.45, respectively. Therefore, the BJP had got a quota of nine members, while Sena got a quota of four members.

The total number of BJP corporators later reduced from 66 to 64 and Sena’s number increased to 35. Owing to this, the comparative strength of the BJP reduced from previous 8.65 to 8.39, while Sena’s increased from 4.45 to 4.59.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Women-friendly liquor shops set to lift spirits
Content:
Image used for representational purpose

BHOPAL: In a move that is bound to lift spirits of women tipplers in Madhya Pradesh , the state government will set up dedicated liquor shops for women that will facilitate safe and hassle-free buying of the tipsy drink. These outlets would dispense high-end foreign liquor.To start with, Kamal Nath government has decided to set up two exclusive shops each in Bhopal and Indore, and one each in Jabalpur and Gwalior. And these outlets would stock wine and whiskey brands that are popular among women.These exclusive shops would be on the lines of those in New Delhi, Mumbai or any other metropolitan city. More so, to ensure quality, government would allow sale of only foreign liquor, known as bottled in origin, through these shops. It means even the liquor brands not registered in state would be available for sale at these shops. Talking to TOI ,officials said no additional duty would be levied on these foreign liquor brands, as it is brought to the country after paying duty. These exclusive shops would open market for sale of expensive liquor in the state, he added.Additional chief secretary, commercial tax department, ICP Keshri said these shops would offer foreign brands that were not sold in the state, so far. These liquors shops would be opened in malls or upmarket places where women can comfortably buy liquor, he said. In a bid to generate revenue and make local brands popular, government will hold wine festivals in Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior and Jabalpur to market state-made wines. Officials said this has been a long-pending demand of local wine makers.Officials said the schedule and number of days the wine festivals would be held would be finalized in April. Besides, fifteen new wine shops would be opened in tourist places of the state to promote wine made of grapes in Ratlam and other pockets of the state.Liquor prices in MP are expected to go up by 15% from April 1- the day new excise policy comes into effect. It will cover all kinds of liquor sold in MP, including country-made and Indian made foreign liquor. State government aims to generate additional revenue worth Rs 2,000 crore from excise this year. The revenue for this year was Rs 11,500 thousand crore, which is expected to go up to Rs 13,500 crore. There are 2,544 country-made liquor shops and 1,061 Indian made foreign liquor shops in state. Earlier, the state cabinet had turned down the proposal to open sub-shops of country-made and foreign liquor in the state.Liquor prices in MP are the second highest in the country, next to Karnataka.

Title: Lyca: Safety measures were in place for ‘Indian 2’ shooting
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Chennai: Lyca Productions , which is producing ‘ Indian 2 ’, with actor Kamal Haasan in the lead and S Shankar directing it, on Wednesday said it had provided all safety measures for the film’s shooting. It sought to put the ball in the court of the veteran actor and the ace director for the mishap at EVP Film City near Poonamallee which left three people dead, as the unit was under their control.

“It is profoundly unfortunate that such a tragic accident took place during the filming of ‘Indian 2’, despite our firm commitment to the highest standards of health and safety as an international firm. As you are surely aware, incidents of this nature need to be dealt with in the spirit of collective responsibility and rectification,” Neelkant Narayanpur, director, Lyca Productions Private Limited, said in a letter to actor Kamal Haasan, adding that it had also taken a comprehensive insurance policy to cover the entire production, including personal accident policy for each member working on the set.

“Given the involvement of an eminent artist and technician of your calibre and experience, and a veteran director of Shankar’s stature being the captain of the ship, we were doubly confident that our own safety measures would have been amplified by your on-the-spot judgement,” Lyca said in its letter.

Lyca’s letter was in response to actor Kamal Haasan’s earlier letter to the company questioning the steps taken by the production team to ensure the safety of the artists, crew and other technicians involved in the film’s shoot and the insurance that the production team has taken.

Earlier, a day after the accident, Kamal Haasan had expressed regret that the industry, of which he is part for decades, is yet to ensure utmost safety measures for the workers involved in film shooting and stressed the need for ensuring the same.

Three people, including an assistant director, were killed and nine others were injured in the accident during the shooting of ‘Indian 2’ when a crane crashed on a small tent while lifting a load of lighting equipment on February 19.

The deceased were among a group of people sitting inside the tent coordinating the shoot.

Title: Visiting British historian decodes politics of the suit
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Christopher Breward spoke at CSMVS on the history of Western fashion in art

Christopher Breward is acutely aware that he is wearing a T-shirt, relaxed Italian pants and trainers when he says he hates the term “business casual”. But he can’t help it. Besides being an “oxymoron” of a phrase, this annoyingly ambiguous corporate dress code also represents a “loss of trust” for this British cultural historian who has written an entire book on the history and politics of the suit. Along with “dress down Fridays”, “business casual” trigger in him the memory of a photograph from the world’s last big economic crisis in which employees in uber-fashionable London can be seen walking out of their establishment with cardboard boxes and without corporate staples of blazers and ties.

Still, you could be excused for describing what Breward, director of collection and research at the National Galleries of Scotland, was wearing during his recent lecture at the Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya, as “business casual”. On more ostentatious days, the historian—who says he believes “people should wear what they like to express their identity”—tends to favour an understated, bespoke tuxedo, like the one designed by the revered late British fashion designer Alexander McQueen that Breward had received in barter for curating a British Council exhibition. “We needed a bespoke suit by McQueen, sadly no longer with us. He had done a line of suits for a tailor in Savile Row and a bespoke suit has to be made around a living body. So I said to the British Council, I can be the body around which the suit is made,” recalls the lithe 54-year-old, who was in the city to deliver a lecture on the history of Western fashion in art.

Back in the 1980s, casual eavesdropping at art galleries had shown Breward what art connoisseurs were really commenting on while looking at portraits: Clothes, hair and make-up. “I became interested in how fashion could unlock the secrets of meaning 300 years ago,” says Breward, adding now fashion houses have been funding research and exhibitions in recognition of its power to express the history of identity.

That’s how the timeless suit—which radiated patriarchy, masculinity, capitalism, power and even “subversion of authority” with immigrants in 1940s America wearing the high-waisted, tight-cuffed, wide-legged zoot suit to “own its power”—came to preoccupy Breward not too long ago. Contrary to what Indians like to believe, the suit may not have been a Western invention born in the European courts of Louis XIV or Charles II, Breward tells TOI. As a historian interested in the imports of colonialism, he tends to lean towards the theory that the attire may have had its origins in the 16th century Mughal courts of India.

Title: Save Merit activists meet CM Thackeray
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

SMSN delegation handing over the memorandum of demands to CM Uddhav Thackeray on Wednesday

Nagpur: A delegation of the Save Merit Save Nation (SMSN) forum, affiliated to the Save Merit Foundation in the city, met chief minister Uddhav Thackeray in his office in Mumbai on Wednesday.

State president of SMSN, Dr Sanjay Deshpande, claimed that the meeting was positive. “I think the CM will understand the seriousness of this issue and render justice to the open category and meritorious students,” he said.

“Our team drew the CM’s attention towards the alarming situation in Maharashtra due to the increase in the percentage of reservation, which has escalated from 74% to 85% with further lateral reservations. The chief minister gave us a patient hearing after which we were assured that all the concerned departments would be given instructions to review the announcements made by the previous government,” added Deshpande.

The CM also assured the delegation that he would call for a meeting with SMSN activists soon. Shiv Sena MLC Gopikishan Bajoria from Akola coordinated the meeting with the CM.

“When Devendra Fadnavis was CM, he had called SMSN members for a confidence building meeting in July 2019. After the meeting, the state government had issued five GRs, including fee reimbursement for open category students who were forced to take admission in private colleges. We want these decisions to be implemented this year as well. It will provide at least some relief to merit students of the unreserved class,” said executive president of the forum Shreekrishna Buty.

The main demand of the SMSN forum is that reservation in education should have a maximum limit of 50% as capped by the supreme court. SMSN state office-bearers Utpala Mulawkar, Sachin Poshettiwar, Abhijeet Ambhaikar, Mahesh Karwa, R B Heda, Aparna Randive and Ashutosh Pradhan were part of the delegation.

Title: CID may quiz Cyberabad cops in jeweller’s custodial suicide case
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Criminal Investigation Department (CID) has not ruled out the possibility of questioning the Cyberabad police team involved in the detention of the deceased city jeweller.

The Cyberabad police team had detained 47-year-old Vijay Birari for allegedly buying stolen jewellery from a Nashik burglar who had committed house break-ins in Telangana.

On Tuesday afternoon, the jeweller had jumped from the fourth floor of a government guest house to end his life. The bereaved family has accused the Cyberabad police team of excesses which drove him to suicide. The Cyberabad police team is still in Nashik.

“We will initially take the statements of the Cyberabad police team. We will be quizzing them if there are any discrepancies in their statements and the events that unfolded leading to the jeweller’s death,” sources in the state CID told TOI.

According to the CID sleuths, even the burglar — Santosh, alias Prakash Shinde — who is in the custody of Cyberabad police would be questioned on his claim that he had sold the stolen gold ornaments to Birari.

“Our probe will kick off immediately after we formally take over the case,” said the CID sources. They said they are waiting for the post mortem report to start the investigation.

Birari’s body was taken to the government medical college and hospital in the neighbouring Dhule district at 5 am on Wednesday for the post mortem.

Police officers said it is mandatory to carry out the autopsy of any person who dies in police custody at a government medical college decided by the state government. At present, Nashik does not have a government-managed medical college.

Birari’s family performed his last rites on Wednesday evening after his body was brought back from Dhule following the post mortem. Amol Tambe, the deputy commissioner of police, said the city police is unaware of the autopsy’s findings.

“In such cases, the post mortem report is opened in court and the findings are revealed there. The CID would take the copy of the report from the court concerned and begin its investigation,” he said.

At present, the Mumbai Naka police have registered a case of accidental death in connection with Birari’s suicide.

Title: Jewellers across Nashik district take to streets
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

In Nashik city, hundreds of aggrieved jewellers took part in a peaceful protest march from Saraf Bazar to the ... Read More

NASHIK: Over 7,000 jewellers across the district staged a peaceful protest on Wednesday following the death of Vijay Birari, a city-based jeweller. The protesters also kept their shops closed on the day.

In Nashik city, hundreds of aggrieved jewellers took part in a peaceful protest march from Saraf Bazar to the district collectorate. The march was organised by the Nashik Saraf Association (NSA).

Birari, who was detained by Cyberabad police of Telangana, jumped to death from the fourth floor of the government rest house in the city on Tuesday afternoon. The Cyberabad police had detained Birari for his alleged involvement in buying stolen gold from a burglar.

Birari was a resident of Panchavati area of the city and owned a jewellery shop in the Peth Road area.

A delegation of the association met the district administration authorities and handed over a memorandum of their demands on the matter.

Chetan Rajapurkar, president of the association, said there is a strong resentment among the jewellers fraternity not only against the Cyberabad police but also against a section of the city police authorities on the issue.

“Our association has demanded that a criminal case be lodged under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code both against the Cyberabad police team and the local police authorities,” added the association president.

Rajapurkar said that when Birari’s family and relatives came to know that he was summoned for investigation by Cyberabad police team, they went to the Panchavati police station seeking help of the police officials on the issue. “But the police declined to render any help,” alleged Rajapurkar.

According to the association, jewellers are soft targets of the police whenever any mischief monger claims of stolen jewellery sold in the market.

“Jewellers are invariably picked up by the police officers who never bother to verify whether their informer or suspect is misleading them or not. Such police action tarnishes the image of not only that particular jeweller but also of the entire fraternity,” remarked Keshav Sonar, a senior member of the association.

“Our counterparts from Kolhapur, Pune, Ahmednagar, Mumbai, etc. have expressed deep shock over the death of a member of the association and express solidarity with the fraternity,” Rajapurkar said.

Title: Pune: Burglars decamp with cash & ornaments worth over Rs 7 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Cash, ornaments and US dollars, collectively worth over Rs 7 lakh, were stolen in three burglaries in Hadapsar, Wanowrie and Yerawada between February 23 and 25.

In the first case, burglars stole Rs3.7 lakh from a private firm in Hadapsar between February 23 and 24, an officer from the Hadapsar police said. The suspects first broke the shutter’s locks with sharp weapons. They then broke the locks of an iron locker and stole the cash related to delivery of parcel goods, the officer said.

In the second incident, burglars stole cash, gold and silver ornaments from a flat in Kalepadal on Tuesday between 10.30am and 11.30am. An officer from the Wanowrie police said the flat owner had gone out when the burglars entered his residence by breaking the door’s locks with sharp weapons. The burglars then broke the cupboard’s locks and stole ornaments worth Rs1.4 lakh and around Rs15,000 cash.

In the third incident, the burglars broke the locks of a flat in a housing society in Wadgaon Sheri and stole gold ornaments and US dollars collectively, worth Rs2.04 lakh, on Tuesday between 9.30am and 4.30pm. They broke the door’s locks to enter the house and stole the valuables from a cupboard after breaking its locks as well, an officer from the Yerawada police said.

The three owners lodged three FIRs against the suspects under the relevant sections of the IPC with the Hadapsar, Wanowrie and Yerawada police stations. The crime branch is conducting parallel investigations.

Title: Madurai: Man, 40, held for sharing child porn
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative Image

MADURAI: A 40-year-old man was arrested in Madurai on Tuesday night for uploading and sharing child pornography videos and photos on social media sites.

The accused has been identified as N Kumar of Arapalayam. He was arrested based on information from the National Centre for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) Cyber Tripline Report. Police sources said that Kumar has been watching, uploading and sharing child pornographic videos and images using his mobile phone during the last one year.

They added that the accused had posted the content on two Facebook pages. Police identified the accused by tracing the IP address of his mobile phone.

The Madurai South all-woman police registered a case against him under sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act and the Information Technology Act.

This is the first time that a person has been arrested in Madurai district for sharing and uploading child porn content since the Tamil Nadu police recently began crackdown on people involved in distributing child pornography. Earlier, some men were arrested in districts like Chennai, Trichy and Coimbatore for sharing child pornography.

Title: MCCIA’s two-day international business summit from March 2
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Pune: State ministers Subhash Desai and Aditya Thackeray will inaugurate the two-day International Business Summit in the city on March 2, which will be organised by the Maharashtra Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Agriculture (MCCIA).

The summit will feature attendees from across the globe, including representation from the US, Germany, Gulf countries, France, Indonesia, South Africa, among others, MCCIA stated.

The sessions have been broadly themed on a new economic world order that has been emerging, and India’s role in it.TNN

Title: Swatantryaveer Savarkar remembered at his birth place
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Nashik: Swatantryaveer Vinayak Damodar Savarkar was on Wednesday remembered by the people across the city and the country, many of whom visited his birthplace at Bhagur about 9 km away from the Nashik Road Railway station.

Citizens, including political figures, students and artists visited the Savarkar Waada at Bhagur to worship Goddess Ashtabhuja, the family deity of Savarkars. It is believed that Savarkar had taken an oath before the deity to fight for India’s freedom.

The Bhartiya Janata Party (BJP) had organized a rally from Nashik Road to Savarkar’s house at Bhagur. The party members held placards with ‘Rashtrabhakti Tuzhe Naav Savarkar,’ ‘SavarkarJi Ke Sanman Mein’ and ‘BJP Maidan Mein’ as they flagged off the rally in the morning.

Mayor Satish Kulkarni, BJP corporators of the Nashik Municipal Corporation and senior party functionaries paid tributes to Savarkar at his house which is now being preserved by Archaeological department.

Title: Milling: Madras high court summons three top bureaucrats
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Milled Old Mahabalipuram Road near Indira Nagar MRTS last year

CHENNAI: Just adding another layer of tar without scraping or milling plays havoc with road height and buildings find themselves going below road level overnight. Turning its attention to this civic menace, the Madras high court on Wednesday flayed officials and summoned three top secretaries of the Tamil Nadu government to appear in court on February 28 and explain the disobedience.

“No contractor is milling/scraping the road before relaying the road. It would only go to show that the contractors are not properly monitored by the officials while the work was executed and sheer negligence on the part of the officials is the root-cause for this problem. Therefore, the officials should be identified and put to task whenever milling is not done while re-laying the road,” said a division bench of Justice N Kirubakaran and Justice P Velmurugan said.

Indiscriminate laying of road without milling/scraping the existing road makes the buildings go down and the roads go up, resulting in inundation during rainy season, flooding the residential houses and other properties and blocking the drainage also, the judges said.

Citing the example of War Memorial on Kamarajar Salai, the bench said, “The Memorial has a platform surrounding it. In the 1980s, the height of the platform was about 5 feet and it was very difficult to climb on it from the road. In due course, the road has been repaired and re-laid without milling and the present condition is that the height of the road has gone up and the platform has gone down. When that is the fate of an arterial road in Chennai, one can understand the position of roads in other areas.”

The bench made the observations while hearing a plea moved by Mayiladuthurai Chamber of Commerce seeking direction to the local administration to mill existing roads in the town before relaying them. When the plea came up for hearing, the bench pointed out an order passed by the first bench of the court dated March 9, 2018, in which the state authorities made an undertaking that roads would not be relayed without milling.

The court then directed the appearance of secretaries of municipal administration, rural development, and the state highway on February 28.

Title: Rajasthan: 24 of a wedding party killed as bus falls into Mej river in Bundi
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Rescue workers pulling out those trapped in the bus that fell into Mej river in Bundi on Wednesday

KOTA: In a tragic accident, as many as 24 people of a wedding party were killed and five critically injured after a private bus fell into Mej river near Papdi village on Kota-Dausa highway under Lakheri police station in Bundi on Wednesday morning.

While 13 people died on the spot, others succumbed to injuries on the way to hospital in Lakheri town. The deceased included 11 women and three children. The wedding party was on its way to Sawai Madhopur city to offer ‘bhaat’ (gifts).

“At least 29 persons, including the driver, were in the bus,” DSP Shyamsunder Vishoni said. The accident occurred after the bus lost control while crossing the river at around 9.30am. The vehicle fell from a height of about 20-25 feet.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot announced a relief of Rs 2 lakh each to kin of the deceased and Rs 40,000 to the injured.

Bundi district collector Antar Singh Nehara told TOI that three of the injured were in a state of trauma and have been sent to a hospital in Kota. Two of the injured were discharged after primary medical care, he added.

Mechanical failure is likely to have caused the accident, officials said. Two people, who escaped unhurt from the accident, said the bus lost control and fell into the river after a wheel detached from it, the district collector said.

The family of one of the survivors, Murli (55), son of Babulal Dhobi, a resident of Basant Vihar, Ganeshpal area of Kota city, was going to Sawai Madhopur along with his relatives to offer gifts for the wedding of his sister’s daughter when the accident occurred.

The four others injured have been identified as Deepak Sindhi (18) son of Narayan; Amit Dhobi (35); Kannu alias Teena (13), daughter of Suresh; and Manju (35), wife of Mahavir Dhobi, said sub-inspector Rajendra Kumar, Lakheri police station.

Deepak and Amit have been discharged while the three others are undergoing treatment, he said.

Police received information at around 9.45am and a 13-member squad from the Lakheri police station rushed to the spot.

Villagers nearby had started rescue operations after they heard the sound of the bus falling into the river. Amit Dhobi was the first survivor to come out of the bus trapped in deep waters, said SI Rajendra Kumar. He helped identify the spot where the bus fell.

“We found villagers pulling out people from the water with the help of ropes. We joined the rescue operation,” Kumar said.

The rescue effort lasted around 90 minutes and the bodies of all the deceased were retrieved from the bus. The vehicle was pulled out from the river bed in the afternoon.

The actual reason for the accident can be ascertained only after conducting a thorough investigation into the matter, the DSP said.

The post-mortem of the deceased was carried out at the Lakheri government hospital. The bodies were sent to Kota to be handed over to respective families.

Title: PICT organizes graduation ceremony and alumni meeting
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Pune Institute of Computer Technology ( PICT ) recently celebrated the graduation ceremony of the 2019 batch.

IT expert Deepak Shikarpur, who was the chief guest, honoured the students with their degrees in the presence of principal PT Kulkarni and other college officials.

Kulkarni spoke about the students’ active participation in national and international hackathons and achievements.

Shikarpur said only a degree was not enough and to shape their career and told them to improve their skills in their area of choice.

The grand silver jubilee alumni meet (1994 batch) and a get-together of the 1987 and 1993 batch were also held on the PICT campus. Alumni coordinator Sheetal Sonawane spoke about objectives of the alumni association. N Ramakrishna, former principal and former managing trustee of society for Computer Research and Education, also attended the event.

Title: Four yrs on, Bhopal smart city yet to translocate single tree
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bhopal: The first translocation of a tree under smart city project is still another few weeks away. Only 200 trees out of a possible 1,800 are now likely to be saved by translocation, given the delay in tendering process and unexpected disruptions in the ambitious urban transformation project.

“Two hundred trees have been identified which can be saved by translocation. Other measures to protect green cover are also being pursued,” said Bhopal Smart City Development Corporation Limited (BSCDCL) city engineer, OP Bhardwaj.

National Green Tribunal (NGT) on Tuesday ordered BSCDCL to maintain status quo in terms of green belt in the smart city coming up in Bhopal — which involves cutting of more than 6,000 trees in TT Nagar.

Since the smart city project began in 2015, about 500 trees have been cut for road expansion and other development in the core development area along TT Nagar. Last year, the state government announced ‘translocation of trees’ under the smart city project.

As per the new plan, BSCDCL called for a survey and translocation of the trees in TT Nagar and tenders were floated. On the third try, one agency has been shortlisted and has been entrusted to identity trees that can be saved. Initial markings indicate that 200 such trees can be saved.

Overall, the translocation would cost BSCDCL an estimated Rs 30 lakh. However, time is running out. Around 300 trees that were to be translocated to Kaliasot due to the smart road project have already been lost. More than 800 truckloads of soil from the Upper Lake area has been dumped along the smart road construction site to cover the loss of green cover. According to forest department estimates, there are around 5,700 trees, comprising 70 species in the smart city development area. Many have already been cut along core smart development site. Loss of green cover was one of the primary objections for smart city development in Shivaji Nagar. The site was later shifted to TT Nagar, which had more trees than Shivaji Nagar.

As per the smart city plan presented in 2017, BSCDCL had pledged to keep 80% of the green cover and take measures to increase the green cover in TT Nagar.

More than 1,000 trees were lost during the construction of BRTS in Bhopal around a decade ago. Experts are apprehensive as to whether translocation will work. It would cost about Rs 1.5 lakh to translocate one tree. However, the ecological impact of lesser green cover in the middle of Bhopal is yet to be assessed.

Title: VMRDA picks 7 mandals to develop 1-cent housing sites
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA) is racing against time to prepare one-cent layouts for distribution to the homeless in Vizag city starting this Ugadi. Even though the land pooling exercise is being carried out in 10 mandals in the district for nearly 6,100 acres, officials have identified about 2,867 acres in seven mandals out of the pooled land to develop the housing sites for 1.54 lakh beneficiaries.

About 58,861 beneficiaries will be given one-cent plots in Sabbavaram mandal alone, including Gollapalem village (15,108 plots), Nanginarapadu (11,936), Yerukunaidupalem (3,363), Pydiwada (9,953) and Gangavaram (18,501). Housing sites will be allocated to nearly 38,000 families in Thangudubilli, Gandigundam and Ramavaram villages in Anandapuram mandal.

About 20,187 plots will be provided to the homeless in Mudapaka mandal. Nearly 13,000 housing sites will be developed in various villages of Parawada mandal. Other layouts will come up in Gajuwaka, Anakapalli and Pedagantyada mandal.

Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority estimates that basic infrastructural development works, including jungle clearance, site levelling, total station survey and peg marking with stones for the one cent plots, would cost the exchequer about Rs 57 crore. VMRDA called for tenders for the same two days ago. Civil works at these layouts are expected to begin around March 10 after finalising bidders. Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao said VMRDA engineering officials will prepare a daily report on the ongoing works at various layouts.

“VMRDA officials were asked to work in a coordinated manner to complete the works within the stipulated deadline to facilitate distribution of the housing sites to the poor,” said Koteswara Rao. VMRDA will get nearly 900 acres as its share out of the pooled land in compensation for the development of these one-cent layouts. The farmers (assignees/encroachers) will also be provided developed plots. But the size of the plots will be based on the legitimacy of possession and tenure.

While the development of one-cent layouts is estimated to cost about Rs 2 lakh per acre, expenditure on the layout development towards farmers’ share as well as VMRDA’s share is likely to hover around Rs 50 lakh per acre.

Title: Students ‘beg’ for scholarship dues
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Students protest demanding that the government clear pending dues asap on Thursday

Visakhapatnam: Activists of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) staged a novel protest here in Visakhapatnam on Wednesday by begging for money and cleaning vehicles for the release of pending fee reimbursement and scholarship dues to the students.

ABVP city secretary L Rajayya faulted the YSRCP-led state government for not releasing the dues even after assuming office a year ago. “It is a shame on the part of the state government to make poor students wait for dues for years on end,” he said.

Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad district convener I Bhanumurthy alleged that that it is very unfortunate to see chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy watering down the welfare schemes introduced by his father and ex-Chief Minister YS Rajasekhara Reddy. “Youth and students played a key role in the landslide victory of Reddy in the recent elections. But after coming to power, the state government left the welfare of students to the air. We demand the government to immediately release pending dues. Otherwise, we will intensify our stir. We do not hesitate to storm the houses of ruling party MLAs, MPs, ministers and even the Assembly,” said Bhanumurthy.

Hundreds of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad student activists took part in the protest.

Title: Nashik farmers miffed at denial to hike compensation
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik district administration has turned down the demand of farmers affected by the Samruddhi highway to increase compensation for the land acquisition. The farmers have now decided to approach the Nashik divisional commissioner on the issue.

A delegation of the farmers from Shivade , Sonambe, Konambe villages of Sinnar taluka and others from Igatpuri taluka met the district administration and senior officers from Maharashtra State Road Development Corporation (MSRDC) demanding better remuneration, in lines with the one offered in Jalna district.

They claimed that the Jalna district administration has given a good rate for the crops and even the plants to the farmers who gave up their land for the project. The local authorities should have drawn the inspiration from the same and given us compensation on same grounds, they said.

The district administration said the farmers’ request for re-visiting the value of the crops and the plants was not tenable. “Since the property was brought through private negotiations, they cannot challenge it in the court of law,” the officer said.

Title: 11 nabbed for sale of fake lottery tickets
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Srikakulam: Police on Wednesday arrested 11 persons on the charge of selling fake lottery tickets.

Speaking to reporters here, Srikakulam Women Police Station sub divisional police officer (in-charge) DSRVSN Murthy said the people made lottery tickets in the name of Government of Bodoland and sold them locally.

The people had brought the tickets from Kolkata and were selling them in the district, he said. Jallu Narayana Rao, the kingpin of the gang, belongs to Palakonda.

The gang has been involved in the business for the last 25 years. On Wednesday, the accused were caught red-handed selling tickets at a pan shop of Tankala Kameswara Rao at Salman Khan Galli in the town.

Police personnel have so far recovered 11 cellphones, Rs 27,680 and 5,309 lottery tickets from their possession. A case has been registered under Section 7(3) of Lotteries Regulation Act 1998.

Title: Corporator raises voice against illegal offices on roads
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) corporator, Seema Savale , has sought the disqualification of opposition leader Vitthal alias Nana Kate and his wife Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) corporator Sheetal Kate for unauthorised construction of their office in Pimple Saudagar.

She sent a letter to Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) commissioner Shravan Hardikar.

Savale said the office at Shivangan society in Pimple Saudagar is on the side margins and built illegally, flouting the rules of MRTP Act 1966 and Maharashtra Municipal Corporation Act 1949.

She has demanded immediate disqualification of both.

Kate said that Savle was settling old scores.

“The sampark karyalaya (office) is not registered in my name. It is only meant for enabling local residents to contact me for their grievances and not for any business. Most corporators including a large majority of BJP corportoars have their ‘sampark karyalaya’ on the roadsides, in basements or in the margins of buildings. Action will have to be taken against all,” Kate said.

Title: Five government doctors, 1 driver injured in road accident
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: Five government doctors from Nashik and Palghar districts — who were on their way to a training programme in Niphad in a rented multi-utility vehicle — were injured following an accident near the Niphad chowkey on Tuesday.

Of the five doctors, two suffered serious injuries and are currently undergoing treatment at private hospitals. The driver of the vehicle also suffered serious injuries.

Additional civil surgeon Nikhil Saindane said the doctors were going to Niphad for a training programme on female sterilisation, and they had rented a MUV from the training centre for the doctors and other staff associated with the district health department.

In Niphad, the vehicle rammed into an MSRTC bus which had stopped at a pick-up shade near the Industrial Training Institute (ITI).

Among those injured are Amit Bari of the Durvesh primary health centre (PHC), Sanjay Lohar of Sakur PHC and Sanjeev Dube of Agardanda PHC — all in Palghar district. Two other doctors Manisha Gangurde of Jaidhar PHC in Nashik district and Tushar More of the rural hospital in Niphad also suffered injuries.

Medical officers said that Gangurde and Bari have suffered serious injuries and undergoing treatment at a private hospital.

Title: Central tribal varsity gets a special officer
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Prof H Lajipathi Rai was appointed as special officer of Central Tribal University (CTU) on Wednesday.

Andhra University vice-chancellor Prof PVGD Prasad Reddy handed over the appointment order to Rai, who earlier served as vice-chancellor of BR Ambedkar University in Srikakulam and rector and faculty of Sri Krishnadevaraya University in Anantapur. AU is the mentor institute of Central Tribal University.

Meanwhile, Dr R Nandagopan, director of National Science and Technological Laboratory in Visakhapatnam, visited the APSSDC centre of excellence in AU. Nandagopan enquired about the machinery and software available at the CoE and said he will send a high-level team from DRDO-NSTL to explore how best the labs and equipment of the CoE can be used for testing and design of various components in defence research. A regional workshop on Unnat Bharat Abhiyan (UBA) was also conducted in the zoology department of the varsity, which is the regional coordinating institute for the program. The participating institutions were told to work in tandem with village secretariats for effective implementation of the UBA programme at the ground level.

Title: Soon, free platform tickets for performing squats at Bhopal station
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

A ‘Fit India Squat Kiosk’ has been installed in Delhi’s Anand Vihar railway station on Friday

Bhopal: Soon , performing squats will help you earn a free platform ticket at Bhopal station. Witnessing the success of the squat machine installed at a station in New Delhi, the Bhopal railway division is planning to implement it at Bhopal station also. At the Anand Vihar Metro station in Delhi, doing squats 30 times in front of a machine can get you a free platform ticket and help you dodge lengthy queues.

Talking to TOI, DRM Bhopal, Uday Borwanker, said it is a good concept to encourage fitness among passengers. “We are examining it. Final decision is yet to be taken. However, it is a good concept to encourage people to understand the importance of fitness,” said Borwanker.

Incidentally, in order to promote the ‘Fit India’ campaign, a government programme that encourages Indians to adopt healthier lifestyles, a kiosk has been set up at the entrance of Anand Vihar, where a machine produces a free ticket once a passenger completes 30 squats in two minutes.

Borwanker added that there are things which need to be implemented. “I will disclose about it later. We have made several plans in this regard,” he added.

Interestingly, Vystavochnaya station, west of Moscow, introduced a similar concept in 2013 as part of promotions for the Winter Olympics in Sochi. If passengers could do at least 30 squats in two minutes, they got a free ticket.

Passengers from Bhopal who have used the machine at the Arvind Vihar station said the concept should be implemented at the earliest in Bhopal too. “This is an excellent idea. At least people would have started learning about fitness,” said Anuj Singh, a passenger.

“Railway station is the best place for installing such machines. It is a place where people from all sections come. Let people feel the need to be fit,” said Gitanjali Yadav, a passenger.

Title: Call on location of railway zone headquarters likely in April
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Discussions are on to finalise the location to house the headquarters of the South Coast Railway Zone (SCoR). As of now, two options are being discussed. The first option being considered is Wireless Colony, which is located around 500 metres from Vizag railway station, which already has a land parcel of 20 acres. The second option being weighed is Mudasarlova, which is around 14 kilometres from the station.

Railways has sufficient land in both locations. However, in case Mudasarlova gets the nod, it might have to wait for clearance of some files from the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation.

A senior railway official said railways has around 52.22 acres of land in Mudasarlova. “GVMC had given us the land in lieu of the land the railways had to forego for the widening of the city’s thoroughfares. An agreement for transfer of land was signed on January 12, 2016. However, the change in ownership in favour of railways is yet to reflect on the revenue records. The matter is being pursued,” said the official.

Of the 52.22 acres, a corner portion of nearly 13 acres is stuck in litigation, the official said, who added that the civic body is working on a resolution. He further said that the advantage of having the SCoR headquarters at Wireless Colony is that it is only 1km from the railway station. On the other hand, the advantage with Mudasarlova is that it is a lush green area with little pollution.

“If SCoR adopts the same principle as ECoR, which is located some 8 kilometres away from Bhubaneswar railway station, then Mudasarlova could be the ideal location for SCoR headquarters,” added the official. The only problem with having the headquarters in Mudasarlova is that it might be inconvenient for the staff to travel there from the city. A final call on the issue is likely to be taken in the first week of April.

Title: Woman found dead, kin suspect husband
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A woman from Amruthapuram village in Sabbavaram mandal was found dead early on Wednesday. The deceased, V Krishnaveni, was married to V Nagaraju of K Kotapadu for 11 years.

Nagaraju, who repairs punctured tyres for a living, called his in-laws over phone and told them that he was taking Krishnaveni to hospital as her stomach was aching. Minutes later, he rang them up again saying she had died.

According to sources, Nagaraju who married Krishnaveni eleven years ago, harassed her suspecting her fidelity.

The couple have two children — a 10-year-old girl and a one-year-old boy.

Krishnaveni’s relatives allege that her husband and mother-in-law were behind the murder . They accused Nagaraju of torturing his wife several times in the past questioning her fidelity.

“He claimed that he is taking her to hospital and later said she died. When we reached his house, Krishnaveni’s body was lying outside,” one of the relatives said.

Nagaraju claimed Krishnaveni committed suicide by hanging herself to a ceiling when her parents and relatives questioned him. A police complaint has been lodged and investigation is underway.

Title: CBSE Class 10 exams begin, students find English paper easy
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bhopal: The CBSE exams for class 10 began on Wednesday with the English paper. The students who appeared for the exam in the state capital said that they found the paper easy, but slightly lengthy.

Harshi Kaur of Delhi Public School, Neelbad, said: "The English paper was quite easy as the grammar section was very generic and the literature part was simple. I hope to score high."

Priyanshi Verma of Sagar Public School Saket Nagar said, "The literature part was very easy as the questions were direct. Most of my friends are happy with the question paper." Rachna Tripathi, English teacher at St Joseph Co-ed school, said: "The paper was very simple . Most of the questions were from the sample papers, hence the students solved them with ease.

Pankaj Sharma, principal of SPS, Saket Nagar, said: "The teachers are happy that the paper was simple, and the set 1 and 3 were the same. Only set 2 was different, but most of the questions were from the sample papers. We hope many students will score 100/100."

Title: Govt’s grand plan for Harappan site hits squatters’ wall
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Villagers walk past cow dung kept for drying in an ASI protected area where the construction of Rakhigarhi mus... Read More

RAKHIGARHI (HISAR): One of the five biggest townships of Harappan civilisation excavated till date, Rakhigarhi, lies shrouded under black plastic sheets and heaps of mud across nine interconnected mounds spread across 350 hectares of land in rural Haryana .

It remains, however, partly encroached, with some areas still under farming and others dotted with rural dwellings. So far, only 83.5 acres of the spread has been notified as “protected” by the Archaeological Survey of India.

But finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman designating Rakhigarhi as one of the five iconic sites where museums shall be built, has fuelled the pace of work on India’s antiquities. It has also galvanised work on the a 5.5 acre museum, said to be the largest one on Harappan civilisation, in the village of Rakhigarhi, less than 100 metres away from the site of excavation.

Efforts to clear the encroached land around the excavation site, however, have met with some resistance from local residents who have expressed unhappiness over the rehabilitation plans proposed by the local administration. Reactions have been largely negative to the government’s proposal to move the rural families into 160 new flats being constructed. “We are farming families and we raise cattle. We live in 500 yard homes and the houses being promised to us are less than half in size. Where will we keep our animals? Only those living in smaller houses will agree to this,” said Soorajbhan Singh, a resident of Rakhigarhi.

Hisar deputy commissioner Priyanka Soni, though, says the government is making efforts to rehabilitate families. Minister of state for tourism and culture, Prahlad Singh Patel , who visited the archaeological site on Sunday assured villagers that while protecting the site is priority, concerns of the villagers will also be addressed.

“Excavation on this site unearthed skeletons and the existence of an entire township. It points to the existence of an ancient people and a rich tradition. As a result, this is an important site. However, I am confident that the Haryana government will resolve the problems of the local people. It is our plan to develop this area as a big tourist hub,” Patel said.
