Even as they iron out locals’ concerns, the state government has begun work on a state-of-the-art museum replete with seven dimensional technologies, photography and conservation laboratories, access control and intrusion systems, and a wifi enabled campus that will give visitors an immersive experience into Rakhigarhi and the Harappan civilisation. The main attraction, architect Vishank Kapoor said, is the museum’s facade replicating the gates of the ancient town of Mohaenjodaro .

Title: Expedite 12-point plan, budget proposals by March: Kerala CM to secretaries
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The 12-point programmes and the budget declarations have to be completed in a time-bound manner with special care, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan instructed the department secretaries .

Speaking at the meeting of secretaries, the chief minister said that the secretaries should review the functioning of the departments and should give a report to the ministers concerned once in two weeks. The chief minister reviewed various ongoing programmes too.

The chief minister instructed that the programmes should begin from March. Some of the plans include providing ration cards for those living in poramboke land, planting one crore saplings, LED lights on roads, reconstruction of all roads in the state before December 2020, safe accommodation centres for women travelling alone, 12,000 pairs of toilets at major centres, job opportunities for five in every 1,000 citizens in each panchayat, municipality.

He said that new entrepreneurs creating job opportunities will be offered incentives. He said that entrepreneurs registering from April 1, 2020 till March 31, 2025 will be provided incentives. He asked the secretaries concerned to consider the demand for reducing width of mandatory road from 10 metres to eight metres for all buildings that have a floor area of 18,000 square metres and above. He asked the secretaries to dispose of files at the earliest with nones by the end of this fiscal.

The chief minister said that the government plans to remove the ban on women working in factories in night shifts, with the onus of their safety on the factory management. He said that entrepreneurs investing more than Rs 100 crore will receive all clearances through the facilitator in KSIDC.

The chief minister asked the secretaries to speed up all programmes launched in agriculture and animal husbandry sector and being implemented through local self-government bodies. He also asked them to give a special focus on floriculture, which has high export possibilities through the four airports in the state.

Title: MP’s Megha will try to scale Mount Kosciuszko on Mar 2
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bhopal: State mountaineer Megha Parmar, who has already scaled world’s highest peak, Mt Everest, will now attempt to climb Australia’s mainland highest mountain, Mount Kosciuszko. Her expedition will begin on March 2.

Earlier, Megha and fellow mountaineer Bhawna Dehariya had faced a setback while trying to scale Mt Aconcagua when they had to abort the expedition midway, die to bad weather. Megha has successfully completed the summit of three mountains-Everest, Kilimanjaro and Elbrus, while Bhawna has completed summits of Everest and Kilimanjaro so far. These two mountaineers have brought glory to the state, and with every new challenge, they are promoting the messages of ‘Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao’ and ‘Fit Rahega India, Tabhi To Badhega India’.

Mount Kosciuszko is at 2,228 m (7,310 ft) above sea level. It is located on the main range of the snowy mountains in Kosciuszko National Park, part of the Australian Alps national parks and reserves, in New South Wales, Australia.

Megha will leave Bhopal for the expedition today. “I will start the expedition from March 2 to complete it on March 7,” she said. She had managed to overcome immense odds and nagging pain from a broken back last year to conquer Mt Everest. Megha had even suffered snow blindness and high altitude sickness on the way down and had to spend several days in hospital before people back home realized that she had been on the top of the world.

Seven Summits are the highest mountains of each of the seven continents. Climbing all of them is regarded as a mountaineering challenge, first achieved on 30 April 1985 by Richard Bass.

Title: Programme on geriatric care commences in city
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A three-day orientation programme on geriatric care for functionaries of old age homes commenced in the city on Wednesday. Organised by Sneha Sandhya Age Care Foundation (ACF), Nightingales Medical Trust (NMT), Bengaluru in collaboration with Visakhapatnam District Senior Citizens Welfare Association (VDSCWA) at Pradhama Hospital, various stakeholders including lawyers, doctors, differently-abled department officials and social workers will participate.

Dr TVS Rao, president of VDSCWA during the inaugural of the orientation programme said, “The need of the hour is to exponentially increase interventions that improve the quality of life of the elderly.”

Participating as chief guest of the programme, K Venkateswara Rao, assistant director, department of differently-abled, transgender and senior citizen welfare, government of Andhra Pradesh said, “Ageing is inevitable and most aged people are left alone at home, confined to solitude with minimal care and support. So, there is great need for having fully-functional geriatric units in hospitals.”

Title: Students get a sneak peek into culture and heritage of Punjab
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Cultural team from Punjab performs at Mrs AVN College in the city

Visakhapatnam: After AP was paired with Punjab under the ‘Ek Bharat Shreshtha Bharat’ initiative, a cultural team from the north Indian state has been visiting several city colleges for cultural exchange in the spheres of language, literature, cuisine, festivals and tourism.

The Punjab team has already visited Mrs AVN college, BVK college, Krishna college and government women’s college in the city in the last one week. While the team, led by Jagjeet Singh, performed bhangra dance during its visit to AVN college recently, a Burrakatha party from Draksharamam in East Godavari district gave a peek into the popular oral storytelling technique of Andhra Pradesh to the Punjab team. The college students also took part in several cultural activities. N Srinivasa Mahesh, assistant director, regional outreach bureau, said a team from AP will soon visit Punjab. “The initiative will help showcase the rich heritage, culture, customs and traditions of the two states and help students and other segments of the society understand and appreciate the country’s diversity besides fostering a sense of common identity,” said Mahesh.

He added that an activity calendar was being prepared through mutual consultation for a yearlong process of mutual engagement.

Title: Soon, barter plastic for coffee at rhythu bazaars
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Around 12 plastic collection counters will be set up in rhythu bazaars and along the national highway within a month by India Youth for Society (IYFS) in association with the district administration.

The plastic parlour set up two months ago by IYFS on Beach road initially saw good collection, but now it has dwindled to just a few kg of plastic per day. Therefore, IYFS volunteers are setting up collection centres across the city to make the public aware of the adverse impact of plastic. Speaking about the plastic collection venture, Y Appala Reddy, president of IYFS and director of Plastic Free India Campaign said, “For the first 10 days, our plastic parlour on Beach Road got very good response. The residents of surrounding posh localities and morning walkers dropped in and we collected about 15-20 kg of plastic daily. But gradually the enthusiasm reduced and some days we did not get any plastic. On an average, we started getting about 1-2 kg thereafter. To encourage the public to bring waste, for every kg of plastic, we give one cup of coffee for free and for four kg of plastic, we offer a jute bag.”

“After a month, we decided to conduct plastic collection drive in rhythu bazars in MVP Colony and Madhurwada and collected around 40 kg of plastic in a single day. Therefore, we decided to set up counters across various rhythu bazaars, other busy centres and along national highway. We are working on obtaining permission from the district administration. The waste collected are carried by trucks, mostly supplied by GVMC, and sent to the recycling yard at Kappuluppada,” Reddy explained.

The rhythu bazaars where counters are being planned include Seethammadhara, Narasimhanagar, MVP Colony, Pedda Waltair, Gopalapatnam, Marripalem, Pedagantiyada, Gajuwaka, Steel Plant, Kancharlapalem, Madhurawada and Pendurthy. Those interested can deposit plastic waste with IYFS by calling 9703489797 or email to support@plasticfreeindia.org.

Further, to generate awareness about the damage caused by plastic pollution and to highlight the benefits of recycling, a deeksha programme and photo exhibition on plastic waste rules is being organised on March 14 from 9 am to 6 pm at Gandhi Statue.

Title: Tribal JAC wants Araku fest nixed
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The joint action committee (JAC) formed for the protection of tribal rights and the implementation of Acts has demanded that the government cancel Araku Utsav scheduled to be held on February 29 and MArch 1.

“If the government does not call off the festival, tribals will obstruct the event,” a member of the JAC said. If any untoward incident takes place, then tribal representatives MP G Madhavi, MLAs Bhagya Lakshmi of Paderu and S Phalguna of Araku should be held responsible, he added.

The JAC alleged the government was preparing to conduct Araku Utsav spending Rs 1 crore at a time when tribals were agitating for the implementation of Acts protecting their rights.

JAC district convenor Ramarao Dora and co-convenors M Rajababu and T Jagatrai alleged non-tribals were occupying their lands in violation of the 5th Schedule of the Constitution.

Non-tribal migration has increased with the introduction of tourist projects in Araku Valley, Anantagiri, Lammasingi and other areas in Visakha agency. These migrations have become a threat to the rights of tribals giving rise to anti-social activities including sale of sedative drugs and spreading of AIDs and other communicable diseases, locals alleged.

The committee alleged that tribals were losing their identity, traditions and values due to the imposition of non-tribal cultures. Presently, tribals in all 11 mandals in Visakha Agency have been agitating for their rights.

Title: Tale of two Samaritans
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Story 1:

Sudipta.Sengupta@timesgroup.com

Hyderabad: From much before 9am, the parking lot at Nizam’s Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS) starts filling up. Hundreds wait here for a particular autorickshaw — one that has been pulling up at the same spot for the past 1,212 days — carrying their daily plate of scrumptious breakfast.

On the menu: piping hot rawa upma made in desi ghee.

Serving the first person in a queue of more than 100 — it goes up to 400 on most days — Mohd Shujathullah says: “Today is my 1,213th day here… even on holidays and festivals I am here. I never miss a single day.” NIMS is the third stop for this 27-year-old from Musheerabad who begins the breakfast run from Koti Maternity Hospital at 8am every day. In between, at 8.30am, he serves about 400 at Niloufer Hospital too.

“On an average, 1,000 people eat every day. By end of the year, I hope the count reaches 5,000,” says the founder of Humanity First Foundation, a Doctor of Pharmacy by education. This journey, he recollects, started after he flunked his third year BPharm exam. “I had promised to feed 10 homeless people if I cleared it the next time. Little did I then know, it would become my life’s mission,” says Shujathullah describing that first experience as being almost spiritual.

While the drive was initially self-funded, with some support from family and friends, he now manages to raise donations to cover the monthly expenses of Rs1.5 lakh. But his biggest takeaway: the duas that people shower after every meal.

“He is doing a great deed. Allah will bless him,” says 50-year-old Zainab Begum, who travels to NIMS from Mallepally at least 15 days a month. Her husband is paralytic. “We leave home at 6.30am. This breakfast is the only food we have till we get home late in the afternoon,” she adds.

In fact, K Maruti’s 35-year-old daughter, admitted for a neurological disorder, looks forward to the upma every morning. “She loves it. It is better than any other food you get around here,” the doting father says as he packs an extra tiffin box for her. “Also, it saves us Rs100-150 every day,” he says.

Story 2:

Taking ownership of our natural resources

Uttara.Varma@timesgroup.com

For years, Sainikpuri residents have dealt with high E. coli content in their water. But that’s never surprised Deepa Shailendra. “I see people dump waste into the Kapra Lake all the time. What they don’t understand is that the water body recharges our aquifers. The water they pollute today, could be flowing through their taps tomorrow,” said the local who, in 2017, brought together 11 people to discuss the lake.

From then on, the ‘Kapra Lake revival’ group has only grown.

The group began with a campaign to promote clay Ganeshas and soon moved on to clean-ups at the lake and anti-plastic drives. “We cannot bequeath a cesspool to our children,” says Deepa. The movement has included people from all walks of life: children and even people in wheelchairs.

The group has gone all out to protect the lake even reaching out to minister KT Rama Rao. “I petitioned KTR and the government on the issue. Telugus believe in vaastu. The lake is in the north-east of the city and needs to be kept pure for prosperity,” says Deepa.

She says that while litigation has been crippling pace of work, she is hopeful that constant attention will hinder encroachers.

“The lake has been a great example of how every person can take ownership of a public asset.”

On the ground, the change is stark. Vast swathes of waste in the lake are no longer visible and residents can be seen taking stock of the situation daily. Those living in the neighbourhood sound out an alert to group members in case of people come to dump their garbage, and they are promptly counselled and sent back.

Deepa’s plans do not stop at the lake. “I have started a group that is working on organic gardening, another for caring for stray animals, and yet another to promote sustainable living,” she says. Deepa hopes to make Sainikpuri a model community that can be replicated in other places.

Title: BS Yediyurappa: Karnataka CM BS Yediyurappa turns 78, grand celebration planned at Palace Grounds
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: Some of the state’s tallest political functionaries will descend on Bengaluru’s Palace Ground on Thursday to celebrate chief minister BS Yediyurappa ’s 77th birthday.

BJP sources confirmed all who were invited, including five former chief ministers — SM Krishna, HD Kumaraswamy, Siddaramaiah, Jagadish Shettar and DV Sadananda Gowda — have agreed to attend. Defence minister Rajnath Singh will inaugurate the event, while BJP national general secretary (organisation) BL Santosh will also be present.

In a tweet on Wednesday, Yediyurappa requested well-wishers not to bring bouquets, flowers, shawls, sweets, turbans or souvenirs. “As I enter a new year of my life tomorrow, I am indebted for all the love and support I’ve received from all of you at every stage of my life. Whatever I have achieved today is a result of the blessings and faith that the people of my state have showered on me and that is all I seek from all of you,” he tweeted.

Some see the event as an attempt by Yediyurappa and his loyalists to send a message to the central leadership that he is still going strong. Under Narendra Modi and Amit Shah, the BJP has retired several members who crossed the age of 75. Yediyurappa has been an exception.

Moreover, a mysterious letter recently surfaced which questioned his health and style of functioning. The unsigned letter, believed to be the handiwork of disgruntled BJP leaders who were denied cabinet berths, said at the age of 77, Yediyurappa should retire from electoral politics and instead mentor youngsters in the party.

Sources said Yediyurappa’s family and supporters are now pulling out all stops to ensure a grand celebration on Thursday to counter critics. But a senior functionary rubbished the rumours, saying, “The event is only a birthday celebration. It's not a political event. It has nothing to do with Yediyurappa’s political career.”

Title: Delhi Highcourt on Violence: Can’t allow 1984 rerun; Delhi has seen enough anguish, violence, tragedy
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Delhi high court

NEW DELHI: Hours after conducting a midnight hearing to ensure that victims of violence in northeast Delhi got immediate medical help, including ambulances, Delhi high court on Wednesday said it won’t let another 1984 occur under its watch.

“We cannot let another 1984 scenario (when the anti-Sikh riots took place) occur again. We don’t want a repeat at all. The city has seen enough anguish, tragedy and violence. Not under the watch of this court,” the bench said after being told of the rising death toll, including the killing of an Intelligence Bureau (IB) officer in the violence.

The court stepped in a little after Tuesday midnight and conducted a special hearing at the residence of Justice S Muralidhar, the senior-most judge available in absence of the Chief Justice, who was out of station.

The judge noted in his early morning order that he received a call from a lawyer apprising him about riot victims stuck at Al-Hind Hospital in New Mustafabad. The lawyer explained that the victims couldn’t be moved from the small hospital to GTB Hospital in the absence of ambulances.

A bench of Justices S Muralidhar and Anup J Bhambhani directed Delhi Police to ensure safe passage for the victims to government hospitals and provide them emergency treatment.

The bench asked additional standing counsel Sanjoy Ghose to ensure the presence of the joint commissioner and DCP (Crime) at the judge’s residence and then spoke over the phone to Dr Anwar at Al-Hind Hospital. The doctor informed that two bodies and 22 injured people were at the hospital. He added that the hospital and the injured had been trying to seek police assistance since 4pm.

The judges made DCP Rajesh Deo speak with the doctor and also coordinate with the area DCP, who immediately reached the hospital to evacuate the injured to the nearest hospital.

Later in the morning, the bench lauded police for promptly evacuating the injured and suggested that the highest functionaries of Delhi reach out to the affected people and personally meet the victims and their families.

In the meanwhile, the court gave a slew of directions to augment the helpline for victims and directed that private ambulances be provided for their safe passage.

Stressing on the need to rebuild confidence, the court said this was the time to reach out to people and give them assurance. It ordered the AAP government to open shelters with basic facilities, including blankets, medicines, food and sanitation, on a war-footing and said that night shelters and community halls could be used for the same.

Advocate Zubeda Begum was appointed amicus curiae to coordinate between the victims and various agencies for providing medical assistance and safe passage.

The court was hearing two pleas, one seeking safe passage to government hospitals and emergency treatment for the injured and the other for lodging of FIRs and arresting those involved in the violence in which around 200 people were hurt.

Title: Curtains on high-octane Khajuraho festival
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

A CLASSIC EVENING

After mesmerising the audience with several magnificent classical performances, the weeklong Khajuraho dance festival came to an end on Wednesday.The spectators enjoyed the splendour of Indian classical dances in the backdrop of a spectacular view of Chitragupta temple, in Khajuraho, Chattarpur district, at this festival organised by Ustad Allauddin Khan Sangeet Evam Kala Academy, MP.

The finale started with the performance of Srividya Angara, performing ‘Mandodari Saptam’ to describe the marriage of Mandodari and Ravana in Kuchipudi dance style. The entire saga of Mandodari -who was said to be a frog, falling in love with mighty Ravana, her prayers to Lord Brahma, her subsequent transformation into a beautiful woman - was majestically presented by the dancer. Ravana falling for Parvati and his wanting to end his marriage were all explained through excellent synergy of bhava, abhinaya and nritya. “I'm privileged to offer my dance to the audience on such an auspicious stage,” an overwhelmed Angara later said.

A melange of two diverse dance forms - Odissi and Bharatanatyam - by Enakshi Sinha and Pavitra Bhat - respectively, was a sight for the sore eyes. Third presentation of the evening - ‘Shiv Panchakshra’ in Manipuri style performed by Sinam Basu and her group- was equally bewitching, bringing to fore the rich cultural traditions of India. The evening ended with the kathak presentation by Amita Khare.

During the fest, audience enjoyed some of stalwarts like Uma Sharma, Jatin Goswami, Meera Das, Shobana Pillai, Narthaki Nataraj etc. putting forth some memorable dance performances. Young Mohika Saxena's Bharatanatayam also enchanted the audience. Pursuing her bachelors in dental surgery at Bhopal, Mohika gave three performances and each one of them was appreciated a lot by everyone.

Over 22000 people attended the weeklong fest in Khajuraho; and it was also watched by over 40000 live audience each day as the event was webcast, said an official of the organising committee of the event.For those in the audience who attended each day, the end 'left a void.' A connoisseur and self-confessed lover of all forms of Indian art, 85-year-old Satish Mehta who had come from Mumbai, said, "I first attended Khajuraho festival in its inception year in 1975 and never missed a single edition post that. Every time I leave this place with a heavy heart because there is a quintessential spirituality attached with this particular event."

It was heartening to see a lot of youngsters at the finale, who witnessed the classical magnum opus in awe. All of 23, Aman Dixit, a student of financial engineering, had come from Sagar along with his family to attend the annual fest. "This event will remain etched forever in my mind," said he and added, "I wish such wonderful ethnic cultural fests are promoted well, just like pop, hip-hop, rock or Bollywood events. I'm sure many more youngsters will rediscover this genre once they get up close with it. I was exposed to classical festivals since childhood thanks to my parents, but there are so many people my age who need to know about the inherent beauty of classical forms."

Title: CM Nath lays foundation stone of micro lift irrigation project in Dhar
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Dhar: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Wednesday laid the foundation for a micro lift irrigation project in Dahi village and named it after freedom fighter Tantya Bheel. The project would irrigate around 47,000 hectares of agricultural area in about 106 villages of Dhar and Alirajpur districts.

While participating in the public programme, Nath inaugurated 40 projects worth Rs 1,218 crore.

Addressing the public, CM praised tribal people for their sincerity, simplicity and hard-working nature. Nath said that his government is committed to improve state’s deteriorated economy inherited by us. “We are making a policy that improves the condition of farmers. Efforts have been started to revive the purchasing power of the farmers, which crumpled over the last several years. He said that the state's condition will change with the comprehensive policies of the state government. Shri Kamal Nath said that 70% population of the state is based on agriculture. State government is making every effort to improve the condition of the farmers through schemes like 'Jai Kisan Fasal Wrin Maafi Yojana'.

He asked locals to remain alert from opposition leaders who he alleged were propogating falsehoods. “Unlike (former chief minister) Shivraj Singh Chouhan, I don’t believe in making announcements, but delivering goods,” said Nath.

He took a dig at Prime Minister Narendra Modi on his alleged failure in generating employment, doubling farmers’ income .

The gathering was addressed by cabinet ministers Dr Vijaylaxmi Sadho and Surendra Singh Baghel, who explained benefits of the micro lift irrigation project for the locals.

According to the officials concerned, the project using 58.47 MW electricity, three pump houses will draw Narmada water from a distance of 17.82 km through the pipeline and will supply at a pace of 16.06 cubic m/s. It will take 48 months in completion of the project.

Title: Char Dham mahapanchayat distances itself from priests’ comments of ‘natural calamity if shrine board runs temples’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Dehradun: A day after TOI reported that priests from the Char Dham shrines of Kedarnath, Badrinath, Gangotri and Yamunotri have warned pilgrims not to visit the shrine towns as they “might witness something worse than the 2013 tragedy if a shrine board runs their temples,” Suresh Semwal, convener of the Char Dham mahapanchayat , a body representing priests of the Char Dham shrines distanced the body from the remarks, saying, “The priests, who are asking people not to embark on the yatra, are doing so in their personal capacity.” He however added that if the government goes ahead with the shrine board, they will be “forced to launch a massive nation-wide protest that would bring down the BJP government.”

“We are the only people who know the rituals of the Char Dham temples. Without us, the government will neither be able to commence the yatra nor conduct puja properly. We hope that the government will not disturb us and let us continue the work that we have been doing since centuries. If they don’t, they should be ready to face the consequences,” Semwal said.

Harish Dimri, a priest from Badrinath, said that the government action of setting up a shrine board hasn’t sent a good message to pilgrims. “I won’t say anything beyond this as the matter is now in court,” he added.

Brijesh Sati, another priest from Badrinath said that “no priest in the revered shrine will boycott puja but instead, we will call for a bandh.”

“We will not boycott the rituals. People are welcome to the Char Dham shrines, but we will continue to show our resentment. For this, we will plan a bandh with local traders and shopkeepers but no ancient ritual will be disturbed,” he said adding that if some priests are boycotting the yatra, that is their personal decision.

Meanwhile, IAS officer Ravinath Raman, who was recently appointed as CEO of Uttarakhand Char Dham Devasthanam Board, sought to allay the priests’ concerns. “We are mulling to put in place the new arrangements which will be more professional. Having said that, no one is disturbing the worship and traditional things associated with the temples. Let me be clear that this Act is not taking away anyone’s rights,” he added.

Title: Kapalabetta row: No illegality in land allotment, finds report
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The district administration found that the government had followed due procedure while transferring the land t... Read More

BENGALURU: A report into the controversy surrounding the allotment of land to Harobele Kapalabetta Development Trust in Kanakapura taluk, Ramanagara district, has reportedly found no illegalities or violation of law. The trust had planned to erect a 114-ft statue of Jesus Christ on a portion of the land, a decision which members of the Sangh Parivar have taken exception to.

The report was submitted to the government by the Ramanagara district administration, but indications are that it will be put in cold storage for the time being. The Ramanagara administration was tasked with filing the report after the row over the statue erupted.

The report, which was submitted to the government on Monday, found that the 10 acres allotted to the trust was gomala land (land reserved for cattle grazing), but the previous coalition government led by HD Kumaraswamy had followed due procedure before allotting the land.

The issue hit the headlines after former minister and senior Congress functionary DK Shivakumar, who represents Kanakapura assembly segment, laid a foundation stone for the statue on December 25 last year.

BJP leaders had argued that the 10 acres sanctioned to the trust was gomala land and the construction of the statue, was therefore illegal. The Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), Vishva Hindu Parishad (VHP), Hindu Jagaran Vedike (HJV) and other right wing organisations had also taken out a protest march in Kanakapura against the installation of the statue and had stepped up pressure on the government to take back the land.

Following these developments, revenue minister R Ashoka had sought a report from the district administration and issued two notices to Harobele Kapalabetta Development Trust. District officials conducted a survey before preparing their report.

Now though, the report will be kept under wraps for obvious reasons. “The report was prepared based on facts ascertained during the survey. Our team just stuck to the terms reference given to us regarding land allotment. We did not look into the other aspects of the installation of the statue,” said MS Archana, Ramanagara deputy commissioner.

Asked if the land would be taken back and Gomala status restored, Archana remained noncommittal, saying: “That is up to the government.” Revenue department sources said the government may not make the report public, but would wait for an appropriate time to revive the issue.

Chinnaraju, member of Harobele Kapalabetta Development Trust, reiterated the trust was not in a hurry to resume work on the statue. “We would be happy if the government and people know the truth that we have not committed any illegality. But, we will wait before resuming work as we want to go about in an amicable manner,” said Chinnaraju.

Shivakumar also reiterated that he had no role to play anymore in the issue. “I played my role as representative of constituents and guided them in following rules before getting the land parcel granted. I have no further involvement in activities of the trust,” he said.

Title: VACB finds VS Sivakumar’s locker clean
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Vigilance and anti-corruption sleuths could not find any documents or articles from the bank locker of former minister V S Sivakumar which was examined as part of a probe into a disproportionate assets case against him.

Bank officials opened the locker in the presence of vigilance sleuths on Wednesday. Sivakumar had said he had lost the locker key of the bank. The vigilance sleuths had earlier conducted searches at the residences of Sivakumar and his close associates and had seized documents.

Sivakumar, on Wednesday, said that his innocence has been proved again. The Congress leader said that he had told the vigilance team during the search that the key was lost as the locker was not being used, and had shared the details of the locker with the sleuths. He said the documents that the vigilance had seized from his residence were some receipts of property tax, registration document of the house, receipts of remittance of power and water bills, loan documents of the house and car and life insurance policy documents. He alleged that he is being hunted on the basis of anonymous complaints, and suspect vested interests in maligning his reputation. Allegations against him were found baseless in the vigilance inquiry earlier, he said.

Even though the agency could not find any disproportionate assets after conducting a preliminary inquiry against Sivakumar, the agency sleuths had noticed that there is a disproportionate increase in the assets of his associates, thus inferring that they are the former minister’s benamis. However, the vigilance has been unable to find evidence to substantiate it.

Meanwhile, the vigilance seized 155 sovereigns from the bank locker of Harikumar, a close associate of Sivakumar. The vigilance seized the locker keyboard after making a record of it and the locker key will be submitted in the court. Vigilance suspects Harikumar to be Sivakumar’s benami. Vigilance sources said that if the investigation reveals that there are bank lockers for the other three, those will also be examined.

Title: Uttarakhand Congress launches lantern yatra against BJP’s ‘anti-people policies’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Congress leaders added that the state unit of the party is drafting a report card of the ruling BJP which will... Read More

DEHRADUN: To protest against what they termed the “anti-people policies” of the incumbent state government, Uttarakhand Congress launched a “lantern yatra” from Haldwani on Wednesday. The yatra was so named because the party was “trying to find out the development done under BJP rule using a lantern.”

Hundreds of Congress workers and residents participated in the yatra along with senior party leaders, including state president Pritam Singh, state-in-charge Anugrah Narayan Singh, leader of opposition Indira Hriyadesh, former CM Harish Rawat and others. Congress leaders urged workers to “go door-to-door to tell people about the anti-people policies of the BJP government in the state.”

“BJP government is promoting alcohol use by making it cheaper. There is no development but only scams all around. The ministers are always travelling here and there and the bureaucrats hardly pay attention to developmental projects. Due to all this, the common man is left to suffer. To make the public aware of this government’s inefficiency, we have launched a lantern yatra . The yatra is symbolic of the fact that even with all this extra light (from our lanterns), we can’t see any development anywhere,” said Pritam Singh while addressing a gathering at MB Inter College of Hadwani.

Congress leaders added that the state unit of the party is drafting a report card of the ruling BJP which will cover issues related to unemployment, education, medical facilities, and decisions like formation of the Devasthanam Shrine Board Act.

A day before the yatra, on Tuesday, former CM Harish Rawat uploaded a video on Twitter showing potholes on NH 309 that connects Uttar Pradesh with Kumaon region. In the video, the former CM questioned if “this is the development that has taken place during BJP rule?”

In the video, Rawat can be heard saying, “Mujhe yahan gaddhon mein road dhoondni pad rahi hai CM sahab. Kya aap thoda dhyaan denge? (I have to search for the road in the potholes. Will you pay attention, CM sir?)”

Title: Farmers to felicitate EPS for declaring delta a protected zone
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Trichy: Leaders from various farmers’ associations have met chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and thanked him for announcing the delta districts as a protected agriculture zone. They invited him for a felicitation function to be organised in Tiruvarur on March 7 to thank him for passing a resolution in this regard in the assembly.

Farmers headed by general secretary of Tamil Nadu Cauvery Delta Farmers’ Welfare Association Mannargudi S Ranganathan, president of Cauvery Irrigation Farmer’s Welfare Association Mahathanapuram V Rajaram and state organizer of the farmers’ wing of Tamil Manila Congress Puliyur A Nagarajan met the chief minister in Trichy on Wednesday, while he was on his way to Thanjavur to attend a marriage. They thanked him for his announcement made in Salem and the subsequent resolution in the assembly.

Speaking to reporters, S Ranganathan said that when the entire farming community was worried that whether the delta region would retain its status due to the ongoing hydrocarbon exploration executed by the BJP-led Union government, the chief minister has taken an excellent decision to safeguard it. “To felicitate him, the entire farming community has organised a meeting to be held at Amma Square in Tiruvarur on March 7,” he said. He appealed to the government to ban sand mining in the rivers in Tamil Nadu, which is also a grave threat to cultivation. He said that farmers would submit a memorandum to the chief minister during the meeting. Meanwhile, Puliyur A Nagarajan welcomed the chief minister at Mukkombu, while he was visiting the construction site of the new barrage across the Kollidam. He thanked him for allotting fund to execute Cauvery-Guntaru linking project. He appealed to him to include Trichy, Karur and Ariyalur within the protected agriculture zone, as thousands of acres of land in these districts are irrigated by the Cauvery.

Title: Delhi violence: As injured poured in, Al-Hind Hospital ran out of even first aid
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The hospital was overburdened with injured people for the last two days

NEW DELHI: When 21-year-old Taslim Fatima got the news of her husband’s death, she had only been a bride for 11 days. The young woman got married to Ashfaque Hussain on February 14. On Tuesday, Hussain was one of the people who succumbed to a gunshot injury at Mustafabad’s Al-Hind Hospital.

The hospital was overburdened with injured people for the last two days as rioters continued to wreak havoc in the neighbourhood.

“I didn’t even get to know him. But in the few days that we were together, I received a lifetime of love,” Fatima said. The newly wed bride kept looking at her mehndi, which had still not faded away, and the tears didn’t stop. As she spoke of her wedding day, her sobs slowly subsided into silence.

Relatives said Ashfaque went out of his home in Mustafabad with his brother to get rations when he heard people talking about a mosque being set ablaze. They rushed to check on relatives who stayed in the area. When they reached the mosque, they saw over 500 people attacking it. Bullets were being fired by the mob.

“A stray bullet hit Ashfaque. My elder son somehow managed to get him to a hospital, but he bled to death,” said his mother. Doctors at Al-Hind said there were at least 70 people, including 10 with bullet injuries, in the hospital. Three succumbed to their gunshot wounds because of lack of doctors.

Chaos in the hospital began two nights ago when the injured started to come in large numbers. There weren’t enough staff or medicines for them. After tending to the first few casualties, the hospital even ran out of first-aid. A call for help was put online and volunteers managed to crowdsource medicines through local chemists. But it was too little too late.

“We were constantly calling for ambulances, but they were stopped by police as the situation was tense near Mustafabad,” said Shahnawaz, a hospital employee.

When TOI reached the hospital on Wednesday, Mohammad Owais, who had sustained a bullet wound, was being taken to GTB Hospital for further treatment. “I was shot on my shoulder two days ago while returning from office. A mob emerged from Brijpuri and attacked me,” said the 22-year-old. Other injured at the hospital was the father-son duo of Abdul Mukeem and Muzammil. The father, a tailor, was hit on the head at Shiv Vihar while coming back with his son on a bike.

Dr Harjit Bhatti, a resident doctor at AIIMS, reached the spot after receiving an SOS. He told TOI that healthcare services were insufficient and the volatility in the area made the situation worse. “When we reached, a mob threatened to destroy our ambulance. We were initially not even allowed to go to the hospital till the high court intervened. Had we managed to get there sooner, maybe we could have saved them,” he said, adding that people were still hiding in their homes, afraid to come to hospitals because of the fear of being attacked.

Another gunshot victim was 28-year-old Zakir, who had gone to offer prayers at the mosque that was attacked. His family members said he was shot at least thrice. Zakir leaves behind his wife Muskan and two daughters aged eight and four. He was the eldest son in the family and their sole breadwinner. A welder by profession, he earned Rs 8,000 per month.

The family had not received the body sent for autopsy. They had only received photographs of the body on their phones. As Zakir’s brother passed on the phone to Muskan, her eight-year-old daughter Ayesha peered into it. She was promptly stopped by Muskan.

“I do not want my daughter to remember her father’s brutalised body,” she sobbed. She narrated the father-daughter’s daily ritual of studying together. “He taught her Urdu and she helped him with English,” she added.

Zakir’s mother, Meena, said, “My husband passed away 12 years ago. He was the only support I had at the time. He made sure that his brother finished his schooling and took the responsibility of his sister’s wedding. We have lived here for ages, but we have never felt so unsafe. We are afraid to leave our houses.”

Title: Kerala: Crime branch arrests SI in missing cartridge case
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The crime branch team probing missing ammunition of the police has arrested sub-inspector Reji Balachandran , who was found to have replaced the missing ammunition with forged ones in 2014.

Currently, a trainer sub-inspector with Kerala Armed Police battalion-3 in Adoor , Balachandran was the quarter master in special armed police (SAP) in 2014, when the shells went missing. According to crime branch officials, in July 2014, when Balachandran found that about 350 drill cartridges were missing, he replaced them with forged ones in the quarter guard. Balachandran is one of the 11 police officers accused in the case, and probe is on against the remaining officials. He has been remanded in 14-day judicial custody by first class magistrate here.

The crime branch is also probing the role of senior officers in missing cartridges case, and also if the missing cartridges have gone into terrorists or Maoists hands, crime branch director Tomin J Thachankary said.

The police had registered a case in connection with the missing cartridges on April 3, 2019, at Peroorkkada police station in the capital under sections 403, 409, 420, 424, 468 and 471 of IPC and the case was handed over to crime branch in June last year.

The crime branch team, after considering the report of the comptroller and auditor general (CAG) that cited 25 Insas rifles and over 12,000 cartridges missing, had prepared a detailed plan of action and launched a probe into the matter. The guns were verified personally after summoning them from all the units and it was found that there was no shortage as was cited by the CAG report. However, in the case of ammunitions, the crime branch team had found that the cartridges were indeed missing and a search was conducted at the SAP in the capital last week.

The crime branch team took into custody an SAP emblem weighing nearly 2.5kg and believed to be made using empty shells along with 350 dummy cartridges. After examining several registers and documents, and questioning 22 witnesses, the sub-inspector was arrested on Wednesday.

The probe team led by crimes DSP B Anil Kumar comprises 15 members from the crime branch, that is being supervised by IG (crimes) S Sreejith and SP (crimes) A Shanavas. Crime branch sources said that more arrests will be recorded in the coming days in the case.

Title: Multiple surveys amid CAA-NRC fear spook locals
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

GHMC commissioner DS Lokesh Kumar

HYDERABAD: Two door-to-door surveys launched in the city almost simultaneously, amid raging protests over the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) in the country, has left residents across Hyderabad unsettled. Questioning the timing of these surveys, they fear that this might create unnecessary panic among people, even if they are routine exercises.

Along with the Telangana Literacy Survey, the state is executing phase 1 of the central government’s National Sample Survey (NSS), too, comprising two parts — Domestic Tourism Expenditure Survey and Multiple Indicators Survey (MIS).

While the literacy survey is believed to be the first of its kind launched across Telangana, officials confirmed that the MIS component — which, among other things, collects data on availability of birth registration certificate of individuals — has also been added to the 78th NSS for the first time.

On Wednesday, some residents from Old Malakpet refused to divulge details when enumerators landed at their doorstep for the National Sample Survey (NSS). In a video widely circulated, one of them is heard saying: “Are you not aware of what is happening in the country? How can you expect people to share any details under such circumstances? People are scared. Would you have shared these details (about family members’ birth dates, recent travels etc) if asked?”

The NSS is being conducted by the Union ministry of statistics & programme implementation. “Maybe it is indeed a harmless exercise, as officials claim. But to launch it at a time when people are already reeling under the fear of CAA-NRC-NPR, is inappropriate. It is only elevating their concerns,” said S Alam, resident of an apartment complex in Somajiguda that was visited by Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) staff on Tuesday, for the literacy survey.

In other parts of the city too — right from Barkas to Gachibowli — the surveys have raised eyebrows. “Since the literacy survey was announced, people are discussing it. The fear is palpable among people across all economic strata of society,” said Zakir Hussain, board member of Salar Jung Museum who lives in Gachibowli.

Officials, however, insist there’s no reason for worry. DS Lokesh Kumar, GHMC commissioner, feels the survey will show how Telangana’s illiteracy rate has dropped significantly — maybe below 15%.

G Lakshminarayana, joint director, Directorate of Economic and Statistics (Telangana) claimed the birth certificate data (under NSS) did not entail providing hard copies. “We are only asking people if they are aware that they need to register the birth of family members with the concerned authorities. We don’t want any physical copies,” he said.

Title: 3-day strike, weekend and Holi holiday: Banks shut for 6 days
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Indore: Hundreds of bankers staged a protest on Wednesday demanding early wage settlement ahead of their proposed three-day strike in March.

Bankers’ proposed strike on March 11,12 and 13 will lead to a six-day shutdown in banks owing to Holi falling on March 10 and then extending until Sunday March 15.

The six days in a row will adversely hit banking transactions, delay cheque clearances and may leave ATMs dry.

Indore has 641 branches comprising various banks and banking business that is likely to get hit due to strike is about Rs 1.17 lakh crore, claimed bank unions.

MP Bank Employees Association’s chairman M K Shukla said, “Banks will go on a three-day strike in March and this will have a massive impact on banking business.”

Protesting bankers said that unions have decided not to engage in any extra work during the week as a mark of protest which will result in empty ATMs and delayed transactions.

United Forum of Bank Unions (UFBU), an umbrella body of nine unions in the banking sector, has called for the strike in which all public sector banks including State Bank of India will participate. Private banks like ICICI, HDFC and Axis had no participation in the strike.

Before this, bankers were on strike on January 31 and February 1 after wage revision talks with Indian Banks' Association (IBA) failed.

From April 1, 2020, the bank unions have called for an indefinite all-India bank strike if demands are not met.

Title: Kamala blaze report: 30% offices not checked
Content:
Blaze in two eateries in Kamala Mills complex that left 14 dead (File photo)

MUMBAI: In the aftermath of the December 2017 blaze in two eateries in Kamala Mills complex that left 14 dead, a civic team appointed to inspect violations at the premises has claimed it could not inspect around 30% of the offices saying they were locked.Municipal sources expressed shock at the reason cited as the BMC has powers to direct owners to unlock offices for inspection. Despite not checking 30% offices and claiming the occupiers did not furnish documents, the committee, set up in 2018, has given a clean chit to mill owners Ramesh Govani and Ravi Bhandari for change of user violations.Over a decade ago, mill owners had taken advantage of the state government’s policy to promote information technology (IT) to redevelop the entire complex. Under the policy, a mill owner could avail of double the construction rights if 80% of the floor space index (FSI) is exclusively used for IT-related purposes. Around 20% of the property was permitted to be used for non-IT purposes. It was alleged that several offices inside the complex were used for non-IT activities.In 2018, the then BMC commissioner Ajoy Mehta formed a three-member committee supervised by the then additional municipal commissioner Vijay Singhal to probe “change of user” and FSI violations in the mill complex. Singhal submitted the report to the current BMC commissioner Praveen Pardeshi earlier this month.The report stated there were FSI violations in 2.4 lakh square feet space where occupiers had illegally amalgamated common areas. It does not mention change of user violations. The report stated FSI violations can be regularized after imposing a penalty if within permissible limit under the new policy.While giving a clean chit, the team reported that non-IT activities were carried out in merely around 15% of the total premises, that is within the permissible limit.While the mill owner told the committee 83% of total built-up area was used for IT activities, the BMC team said it could inspect 54% of the 83% area; the remaining 30% offices were locked.A committee member told TOI the industries department should examine change of user violations. Committee members Jeevan Patgaonkar and R G Patgaonkar refused to comment. An IAS officer said, “The report was expected to point out change of user violations.” Architect Shirish Sukhatme said, “It is inconclusive.”

Title: Accused of assault, official transferred
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Trichy: Regional joint director of collegiate education (RJDCE), Trichy, S Usha, who was accused of physically assaulting subordinate staff two weeks ago, has been posted as the RJDCE of Thanjavur.

Higher education secretary Apoorva passed an order to this effect on Tuesday. T Arivudainambi, RJDCE of Thanjavur has been appointed as the new Trichy RJDCE.

The decision from the higher education department has come under criticism from teachers’ organisations who charged the department of ignoring the safety of its staff at workplace.

On February 13, all the 20 staff at the RJDCE office, Trichy staged a protest alleging that Usha had physically assaulted stenographer Rajeswari and office superintendent Savariyammal Brisca Mary.

Rajeswari, who was allegedly slapped by Usha, was so traumatized that she had to be admitted to a hospital for treatment.

The staff members wrote to the higher education secretary, director of collegiate education and the higher education minister about the incident seeking an inquiry. They also met governor Banwarilal Purohit and submitted a memorandum seeking an inquiry into the incident.

Usha went on forced leave the very next day, and two weeks later she has been transferred to Thanjavur, her home town.

Stating that the decision from the higher education department will set a bad precedence, general secretary of Aided College Teachers Association (ACTA) S Sahaya Sathish said Usha has been demanding a transfer to Thanjavur.

Now, she has been given transfer following the incident, which can only be construed as a reward for her act. There has not been any inquiry into the complaint lodged by the victims, he said.

AUT general secretary M S Balamurugan said that the transfer cannot be considered as punishment, as this is not the first such case against her.

Earlier, there were complaints of verbal abuse by her on staff.

However, no action was taken against her then and she was reinstated to the same post two weeks later.

Title: Five Firms To Pump In Rs 2K Cr By Marc
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Indore: An estimated Rs 2,000 crore investment is likely to come on ground from five companies getting operational between February and March in Pithampur, state’s largest industrial belt.

The industry department claims that over Rs 5,000 crore investment will materialise in financial year 2019/20 in Indore region led by pharmaceutical, packaging, automobile and food processing units.

Three pharmaceutical firms have set up manufacturing units in Special Economic Zone (SEZ) while other two companies into furniture fittings and auto parts making have come up in recently denotified areas of Pithampur.

The five companies have collectively proposed to pump in close to Rs 2,000 crore in first phase and expected to generate over 4,000 employment, claimed the industry department.

Madhya Pradesh Industry Development Corporation (MPIDC), Indore head Kumar Purushottam said, “Five big companies are getting operational in February and March. These companies have invested Rs 2,000 crore in the first phase and will expand gradually. Pharmaceutical units in SEZ are rolling on operations to take benefit of the sunset clause getting expired in March.”

Indian origin drug manufacturer Macleods Pharmaceuticals Ltd started operations on Tuesday while German furniture company Hettich started production from Sunday. The United States-based PAR Pharmaceutical has started trial run and likely to be operational before March-end.

Automotive systems suppliers ZF Group has also started trial run while Indian origin Ajanta Pharma is looking to roll into action by March-end.

Purushottam said, “It's not easy to attract industries as there are many in competition but one of the best infrastructure and favorable policies are luring industries in the state and especially in this region that has immense potential and is the most preferred land parcel amongst investors.”

Sunset clause applicable in SEZ restricts tax benefits to only those industries that gets operational before March 2020. Industry associations have been demanding to extend sunset clause as restrictions will hamper fresh investments and job creation.

According to Ministry of Commerce and Industry, companies in SEZ gets 100 per cent Income Tax exemption on export income under Section 10AA of the Income Tax Act for first 5 years, 50 per cent for next 5 years thereafter and 50 per cent on the ploughed back export profit for next 5 years.

Title: Resolution against NRC under consideration: CM
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Trichy: The issue of passing a resolution against the National Register of Citizens (NRC) was under consideration of the government, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami said. The casual remark came in response to a query from a reporter on whether Tamil Nadu will follow Bihar in passing a resolution against NRC in the assembly.

Bihar is the first NDA state to pass an unanimous resolution against NRC in the assembly on Tuesday and to decide on updating the National Population Register (NPR) according to the 2010 format.

Responding to a question on whether the TN assembly would pass a similar resolution like Bihar where the JD (U) and BJP are in coalition, the chief minister said, “It is all under the government’s consideration”. The NRC is a register of all Indian citizens, mandated by the 2003 amendment of the Citizenship Act, 1955.

CM Palaniswami was in Trichy to inspect the new barrage across Kollidam river in Mukkombu being constructed at a cost of Rs 387.6 crore after a portion of the old structure was washed away by the 2018 floods. Palaniswami had informed the state assembly on January 7 that he had made it clear to Union home minister Amit Shah during a Delhi visit that NRC was not acceptable.

Palaniswami said the Census was a routine exercise carried out once every 10 years, an exercise that began during the colonial rule. The NPR was first introduced by a BJP-led government in 2003, in which the DMK was a constituent too. “It was the UPA government that first implemented the NPR across the country in 2010. Now, the Union government has added three more requirements during the enumeration, such as mother tongue, parent's birth place and any identification card like Aadhaar, family card or voter ID. So, there is now no issue in carrying out NPR", he said.

Replying to a query on the recent legislation to protect the Cauvery basin, the CM said Trichy and Ariyalur could not be brought into the protected zone as several industries were operating in both the districts.

Replying to a question on withdrawing the cases pending against hundreds of protesters in the delta districts who held agitations against hydrocarbon projects, he said it was under consideration.

Title: Congress put family above nation: BJP on Trump banquet boycott
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

US President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump pose with President Ram Nath Kovind and his wife Savita Kovind... Read More

NEW DELHI: Congress has put "family interests above national interest" by boycotting a banquet given in the honour of US President Donald Trump on Tuesday night at the end of his two-day visit, law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said.

He said it was odd that Congress could not bring itself to appreciate that the visit of the US President has been a success and furthered India's interests. Alleging Congress boycotted the dinner as its interim president Sonia Gandhi was not extended an invitation, Prasad said BJP's presidents were also not previously invited for similar banquets to honour visiting US presidents George Bush and Barrack Obama when Congress-led UPA was in office.

BJP had not boycotted the events then, he said, noting that Rajnath Singh and Nitin Gadkari were party president in 2006 and 2010 respectively during the Bush and Obama visits.

Prasad noted that Congress leaders Ghulam Nabi Azad and Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury , besides former PM Manmohan Singh were invited for the banquet but Congress functionaries skipped the dinner. The invitation to Chowdhury was extended even though Congress is not formally recognised as the main opposition party while BJP held that status previously.

"Trump's historic visit is over. India-US relations are on a new high. Even here, Congress is doing its petty politics. This has become the party's practice that family interest comes above national interest," Prasad said. He said Congress had also kicked up a row over its then president Rahul Gandhi not being given a front row seat during the Republic Day parade.

Title: Govt signs MoU with Tata Trust to open 115 health and wellness centres in 23 districts
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Chief minister Kamal Nath, minister Prabhuram Choudhary, Tata Trust official and chief secretary SR Mohanty at... Read More

Bhopal: The state government on Wednesday signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Tata Trust to open 115 health and wellness centres in 23 districts of the state. Chief minister Kamal Nath was present at the MoU signing function.

According to the MoU, five health and wellness centres will be set up in 23 high priority districts of MP. The Tata Trust will extend technical and managerial support to 115 identified health and wellness centres to be set up in four years. The trust will also extend cooperation for 500 more health and wellness centres later.

Under the facility, electronic health record of citizens will be maintained at these centres. Moreover, the Tata Trust will support high-risk pregnant women, referral to complex cases of diabetes, hypertension and cancer and necessary follow-up treatment. The technical committee of experts will implement the scheme, said officials.

Stressing for a fresh approach and robust monitoring mechanism to ensure quality health services, chief minister Kamal Nath said that ensuring better health facilities to people in urban and rural areas is the primary goal of the state government. "Efforts in this regard were being taken for last one year. Our priority is to ensure that the benefits of state-of-the-art health facilities reach the people. We need to evolve a strong monitoring mechanism and adopt fresh approach while assuring delivery of quality health services," said Nath.

The health and wellness centres are aimed at improving primary health services in the state. The MoU was signed by chief secretary SR Mohanty and Tata Trust vice-president Vijay Singh. It was also stated that capacity building of health workers will also be taken up at the block level. The Tata Trust will also cooperate in developing health counselling practices in the state. A monitoring committee will be formed jointly by the National Health Mission and Trust for periodic monitoring of the project implementation, an official said.

Title: Man, 40, held for abusing minor
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Trichy: The Velliyanai police arrested a 40-year-old man for sexually assaulting his paramour’s minor daughter in Karur on Wednesday.

The accused, Vimalendran, from Chinnagowndanur in Karur, who is separated from his wife, had sexually assaulted the 16-year-old girl several times.

The incident came to light after the girl ‘went missing’ from her house last week. Upset over this, Vimalendran called up ChildLine helpline 1098 on February 19 and sought their help to find her. Child Line officials advised him to register a police complaint. Though he was initially reluctant to register a complaint, a few days later, he lodged a missing complaint with the Velliyanai police. Police who took up the investigation, found the girl taking shelter at her relative’s house in Trichy. Police rescued her and during inquiry it was revealed that the girl’s mother had sent her to protect her from Vimalendran. The girl also revealed that Vimalendran sexually abused her on several occasions. The girl was put through medical examination at Karur government medical college hospital. Sources in the district child protection office (DCPO) in Karur said that the girl is safe.

Police booked Vimalendran under two sections including charges of penetrative sexual assault of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act by altering the previous missing case and arrested him. He was remanded in judicial custody. TNN

Title: Corona hits drug supply leaving small firms in critical condition
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Indore: The spike in pharmaceutical ingredients amid lockdown in China has hit production of medicines from small drug manufacturers.

Local manufacturers and stockists at Dawa Bazaar have raised concerns over availability of paracetamol, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, antibiotics and medicines for hyper acidity in the market from April-May, if supply restrictions extend.

Unlike better placed and financially sound multinational players to sustain temporary supply disruptions, small-scale drug companies are the worst hit, said industry players.

Dr Subhash Rijhwani, chairman, MP Small-Scale Drug Manufacturers Association said, “Small players have dropped production and are the most-affected due to supply disruption. At present, availability of medicines is normal but if supply continues to remain troublesome, then we may see some crunch from May.”

Indore is a hub for small-scale drug manufacturers with presence of over 120 manufacturing units engaged in production of sanitizers, ointments, syrups and injectables.

Association secretary Amit Chawla said, “I am short of 6 tonne raw material in production. The situation is getting worse each passing day.”

Drug stockists Virendra Sahni said, “We are maintaining a month’s stock and so far, availability is good but if this situation prolongs then there can be some trouble because production is already less locally and transit time from China is no less than a month.”

Dawa Bazaar traders said supply disruption has triggered hoarding by large players that is further squeezing home supplies.

Vinay Bakliwal, president, Indore Chemist Association said, “We have inventories, but they are fast slipping. There is shortage of raw material from China and this has started reflecting in the trade.”

Though, carrying and forwarding agents of multinational companies claim to have sufficient stock and availability in the market.

Sanjay Budhrani, C&F agent supplying drugs to over 20 companies in Indore said, “We have sufficient stock and supplying drugs as demanded in the market. Raw material is available in India also and large companies are not affected at all. The cost factor has definitely gone up but this is not hitting multinationals unlike small drug manufacturers.”

Title: At 13,040 MW, power demand in Telangana soars to new record in five years
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Telangana set a new record in the last five years in power consumption with the demand soaring to 13,040 megawatt on Tuesday. Senior officials attribute the rise in power demand to rising temperatures across the state in the last few days and farm power requirement going up.

TSTransco officials said thanks to the free 24x7 power supply to the agriculture sector, which began two years ago, the demand had been seeing an upward trend. In Greater Hyderabad, the demand soared to 2,537 MW, which was 200 MW more than the power consumed on the same day last year.

“Of the total power demand, 1,200 MW to 1,300 MW goes into running lift irrigation projects like Kaleshwaram and Kalwakurthy. Also, there are nearly 25 lakh agriculture pumpsets in Telangana,” a senior Transco official said.

Power demand in February is around 9,500 MW. It increases slowly in March with temperatures rising and touches peak demand in mid-summer with usage of air-conditioners going up. Thanks to mercury touching 34-37 degree Celsius in the third week of February this year, the power demand touched the highest 12,780 MW recently.

While power consumption in 2017 summer was between 6,700 MW and 7,000 MW, it hit a high of 8,500 MW in March during peak agriculture season. The demand touched 10,284 MW in March 2018 with the government providing free power to farmers.

In August 2019, the power demand soared to 11,703 MW. Six months later, in January 2020, it touched 11,359 MW. Officials explained that demand for power kept rising since August last year. It may be recalled the mega Kaleshwaram project was inaugurated during this time with about 20 lifts operating.

Though the government is going all out to increase power generation by adding new thermal stations and solar power units, the consumption is equally going up.

Meanwhile, the government has asked all the discoms to ensure uninterrupted supply both for domestic and agriculture purposes. “We are taking steps to provide power without any interruption. TSSPDCL is planning to procure 200 distribution transformers to reduce the load on the existing transformers,” Telangana State Southern Power Distribution Company Limited (TSSPDCL) director (operations) J Srinivas Reddy said.

Title: Environmental norms being bypassed during all-weather road work in Uttarkashi, say activists
Content: Uttarkashi: Local environmentalists have expressed concern over the alleged negligence of environmental norms in the ongoing all-weather char dham road project in Uttarkashi. They allege that despite repetitive instructions, construction companies engaged in the project are dumping debris into Bhagirathi and Yamuna rivers and their supporting streams. They also warned that disturbing the natural course of rivers and streams can cause widespread devastation in the hill districts during monsoons.Suresh Bhai, an activist, told TOI, “Companies engaged in the all-weather road project have not developed proper dumping zones to manage the debris generated from road widening work at Gangotri and Yamunotri highways. Due to this, they are dumping debris into rivers in more than two dozen areas including Dharasu, Badethi Chungi, Matli, and Kuthnor. Further, the dumping zones developed alongside rivers are of no use as most of the retaining walls have got damaged due to over burden of debris.”“It is pity that government agencies are not taking any strict action on the companies which are breaching environmental norms. This is despite one of the companies being penalised Rs 2 crore by the National Green Tribunal in 2018 for violating norms. VK Singh, minister of state for road transport and highways, who recently visited the state, expressed his content with the ongoing works by just doing an aerial survey. This shows government's apathy towards environment,” Suresh Bhai added.Echoing a similar concern, Dwarika Semwal, social activist and secretary of NGO ‘Jadi’, emphasised on “the need for green development in hills.” He said, “Development is important but it should not be done at the cost of environment. Dumping debris in Bhagirathi and Yamuna will not only pollute rivers and affect marine eco-system but also alter the course of rivers which can cause widespread devastation during monsoons.”“Government agencies must develop sufficient dumping zones across construction sites and conduct proper monitoring. Besides, they should also plant trees in dumping zones to reverse the damage”, he added.Meanwhile, Ashish Chauhan, Uttarkashi district magistrate, said, “We have set up a monitoring committee to check that environmental norms are being followed during all-weather road construction works. Besides, we are also following the suggestions of a high-powered committee formed by the Supreme Court. We will take proper action if any company is found guilty of dumping debris directly into rivers or in forest areas.”

Title: Bor reserve guards stop fishing at night, attacked
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bor Tiger Reserve

Nagpur: Selu police have registered an FIR against 8-9 fishermen for allegedly attacking forest staffers who accosted them for fishing in Bor dam during night. The incident occurred on the intervening night of February 23-24.

The earth fill dam on Bor river is a part of the buffer zone of 138sqkm Bor tiger reserve (BTR) in Wardha district. The dam, 60 km from here, is the major source of water for wildlife and birds.

Though the dam belongs to irrigation department, city-based contractor Chandu Patil had bagged fishing rights for which tender was floated by Maharashtra Fisheries Development Corporation (MFDC). Patil has been bagging the contracts since 2016.

According to the FIR, forest guards Premdas Bhakre, Gajanan Sayam, Sunil Dakhore and driver Rahul Patil were patrolling at around 9pm on February 23 when they saw four men near Pardi tower running towards the dam. “When the guards asked them to stop, they fled in three boats. Forest guards seized 150kg nets and two boats. An hour later, the forest staffers saw two boats with at least 8-10 men approaching the dam waters. Sensing trouble, Bhakre intimated other field staff through wireless and asked them to rush to the spot,” said divisional forest officer (DFO) Rahul Gavai.

The two boats came towards the patrolling staff and stopped near the shore. One Parvez Khan countered the staff on seizure of the nets and other material. When the guards asked names of the four persons who had fled the spot earlier, this irked Khan who entered into heated arguments with the staffers and threatened them with dire consequences if they did not allow to take away the nets and other seized material.

Gavai said as the staffers did not allow Khan to take away the seized material, he manhandled forest guard Narayan Kale and tore his shirt. “Not stopping at this, these fishermen pelted stones at the staff in which forest guard Ramesh Raut and Bhakre were injured. We immediately lodged a police complaint on the basis of which an FIR was registered,” said Gavai.

Contrary to forest department’s claim, contractor Patil said, “My men were not involved in fishing at night. They were there to remove some nets which had got stuck.” Patil added, “I agree that fishing should not be done at night, but villagers sneak into the dam waters through forest areas for fishing illegally. The forest staff has no control over them.”

“Being a contractor, I have lodged at least five complaints with Selu police against illegal fishing but both police and the forest staffers have failed to stop the menace due to which I’m suffering huge losses. I’m ready to give up the contract if MFDC refunds my money,” said Patil.

MFDC divisional manager BD Garad said, “This is for the first time such an incident has happened. We will talk to the contractor as it is his responsibility to curb such practices. Night fishing is completely prohibited.”

Title: Guest faculty protest removal from service
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Trichy: Redeployment of excess teachers from Annamalai University, Chidambaram to three government colleges in Trichy and Pudukottai has created a ruckus as the guest faculty members working in the colleges have been asked to leave the institutions.

Guest faculty members in the recently-converted government arts and science colleges in Lalgudi, Orthanadu and Aranthangi staged a protest seeking reinstatement of the guest staff members who have been asked to leave the colleges.

The director of collegiate education, Chennai has ordered for the redeployment of 39 excess teaching staff from Annamalai University on Tuesday. These teachers have been redeployed in place of vacant posts in colleges, which have been presently being managed by ad hoc teachers for years together.

With the redeployment of the staff, four guest faculty members from Lalgudi college and three each from Orthanadu and Aranthangi colleges have been asked to leave.

One of the guest faculty from Orthanadu college said that she is working as a guest faculty for the last nine years and now suddenly she has been asked to leave the college despite being a qualified teacher.

UGC has mandated that not more than 20% staff members in an institution should be hired on ad hoc, but most of the constituent colleges under Bharathidasan University are run with more than 80% guest faculty members. While we have worked for the development of the college all these years we have been asked to leave all of a sudden, she said. There are more than 200 guest faculty members working in 10 constituent colleges working under Bharathidasan University, among which four have been converted into govenrment colleges recently. TNN

Title: Case closed: No road through Bharat Van
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: The over one-year-long campaign that was kicked off by a small group of city environmentalists and which fired the green imagination of several passionate citizens came to a victorious end on Wednesday. Though on expected lines as TOI had reported earlier, the case of an unnecessary road through the urban mini forest of Bharat Van got the judicial closure.

The Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court , on Wednesday, disposed of the suo motu public interest litigation (PIL) based on the letter submitted by environmental activist Jaydeep Das. Based on TOI’s reports, Das had written a letter to the court highlighting the adverse impacts of the proposed road.

The move came after the Nagpur Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) rejected MahaMetro’s application seeking felling and transplantation of around 558 trees in Bharat Van.

NMC submitted a document dated January 17 by its garden superintendent where he rejected the permission sought by MahaMetro for the 18-metre road as per city’s development plan (DP). MahaMetro had sought permission for the alternate road on February 1 last year, in view of proposed viewers gallery and tunnel on the banks of Telangkhedi Lake, which would have led to closure of existing road and diversion of traffic.

The civic body informed the court that MahaMetro came out with a revised proposal on September 13 last year, where the proposed tunnel was dropped and, therefore, the alternate road passing through the Bharat Van, which would lead to Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran’s (MJP) office near Telangkhedi Hanuman Temple, wasn’t required for the traffic diversion during construction of the viewers’ gallery.

A division bench comprising justices Ravi Deshpande and Amit Borkar disposed of the PIL after a demand was made by amicus curiae Kartik Shukul and endorsed by senior counsel SK Mishra and others who appeared for respondents like MahaMetro and others.

Soon after the court’s verdict, various groups on WhatsApp that were created for the Save Bharat Van campaign were flooded with celebratory messages. ‘It’s a victory for all of us who care for clean and liveable future. Keep the spirit alive’, ‘The efforts for protecting Bharat Van have set a benchmark about how people’s movement can be mobilized for a noble cause’ and ‘Finally victory is in favour of the environment’ were some messages which were circulated.

Speaking to TOI, Das said, “At a time when religion and caste are dividing the nation, Nagpur has shown how environment and nature can unite people. Save Bharat Van movement has been the first of its kind people's movement against unnecessary and unsustainable practices to destroy nature. It has shown how the power of urban environmentalism can change a policy decision threatening green cover.”

Title: Manuu students shut down university , protests in University of Hyderabad too
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Students of Maulana Azad National Urdu University stage a protest in front of the varsity’s main gate on Wedne... Read More

HYDERABAD: Hundreds of students boycotted classes and shut down the Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu) on Wednesday as protests against riots in Delhi that has claimed lives of 22 people so far took hold.

They boycotted internal examinations as a mark of solidarity with those protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Register of Population (NPR) across the country.

Following a ‘university lockdown’ call given by the Manuu students union, students gathered at the main gate and raised slogans of ‘Halla Bol’ and ‘Inquilab Zindabad’.

“We want action against BJP leader Kapil Mishra who is inciting communal hatred and violence in Delhi,” said an angry student even as others burnt his effigy in the evening.

They blamed the BJP and Delhi police for the riots in the capital city.
