“We will not be threatened by lathicharge, bullets or imprisonment. Action should also be taken against cops who used force on those protesting against CAA, NRC and NPR,” said Umar Faruq Quadri, president of the Manuu Students Union.

Students also demanded the Telangana government to pass a resolution against CAA, NRC and NPR at the earliest.

Students belonging to University of Hyderabad (UoH) also condemned the violence against anti-CAA protestors and Muslims in Delhi and organised a rally.

“The government is inciting fights among its own citizens in the name of religion. The violence at Delhi, where each person is running for his safety, is an undeclared war on democracy,” said Abhishek Nandan, president of UoH Students Union.

In retaliation, members of Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad, UoH unit, also protested within the campus.

Title: Will shift waste from Shishambara plant daily: DMC
Content: Dehradun: Following protests over rising stench from the Shishambara Waste Management Plant, Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) officials said on Wednesday that they are making efforts to improve the conditions at the waste management plant. They added that they have also decided to shift several tonnes of refuse-derived fuel (RDF) made from the waste on the site on a daily basis. The site holds around 1.5 lakh metric tonnes of RDF waste.The DMC has also installed a pipeline system to prevent the chemical (released from the RDF) from getting mixed with the nearby Asan river. Earlier, the chemical used to get mixed with the groundwater making it unfit for use. This caused several issues for the local residents. In a spot visit conducted by TOI earlier, it was revealed that the pollutants were getting drained into the river.“We were facing several difficulties in regards to the transportation of the RDF but it has been resolved now. Some cement factories based in Rajasthan are willing to take the RDF from us. Hundreds of tonnes of RDF will be transported to those factories daily. Also, the pipeline system will make sure that the harmful chemical doesn’t get mixed into the river or the groundwater,” said DMC’s chief health officer Kailash Joshi.Notably, the residents of the area around Shishambara plant have been protesting for about four months now. They allege that the condition of their area is getting worse with each passing day. The protesters claim that the groundwater has become so polluted that people who do not have access to RO water are getting afflicted with diseases.“The river and the groundwater have become so contaminated that those who drink tap water complain of neck pain. It will take a lot of time to clean the water. As far as the shifting of the waste to the cement factories is concerned, only time will tell whether it will help us or not,” said Satpal Dhania, a protester.

Title: Century-old government school struggles due to space constraints
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Trichy: Over a century-old Viscountess Goschen government girls ( Muslim ) higher secondary school (VGGGMHSS) in Trichy is struggling for space as students’ strength has gone up to 320 which is double the strength from last year.

Parents Teachers Association (PTA) of the school seek retrieval of half of the school land that was taken away for building minority students hostel to accommodate more number of students.

Started exclusively for girl children, the school had hundreds of children a couple of decades back after which the strength started coming down gradually. The advent of private schools has affected the school strength which came down to 10 in 2005. Finding low strength of the school, then collector of Trichy took half the land of the school to build minority hostel for girls.

Visiting the school on the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi, S Thirunavakkarasu has assured to allocate Rs 10 lakh from his MP local area development fund. Impressed with the work carried out for the education of girl children from the minority community, the MP has also promised to source an additional Rs 10 lakh for constructing of additional school building.

A total of 50 school and college students are staying in the hostel now. And there are 320 students in school now which has increased from 158 in 2018, said Indrani, headmistress of the school. Efforts taken by the HM along with the PTA has led to an increase in the strength of the school, but the existing 10 classrooms have become inadequate to accommodate these many students, said the HM.

We have decided to demolish existing four classrooms operating from over 100-year-old building, but that may not be adequate. Further lack of space has been a major hurdle in the school premises even though the MP has come forward to help with funds, she said.

V M Habibullah, president of parent-teacher association had approached the court in 2005 against taking over of the school land for hostels. But the court justified the decision as the school strength was poor. Now that the strength has increased, we are thinking about approaching the court for retrieval of the land. Students also come from far of places to the city in school vans, he said.

Speaking to TOI, backward classes and minorities welfare officer Kamaraj said that they have not received any communication from the school. "In case the school comes with the representation on retrieval of the building, we will send their request to the minority welfare department, he said.

Title: Safety onus entirely on motorists, no rules to curb jaywalking in Mumbai
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: Even as two motorists were recently acquitted by magistrate courts because the pedestrians they knocked down had been jaywalking , the city at present doesn’t have any law to penalize errant pedestrians.The situation is in stark contrast with the developed world. In California, errant pedestrians can be fined $250 for crossing a street between adjacent intersections controlled by signals. And in Singapore, jaywalking attracts a penalty of 50 dollars.In Mumbai, road safety experts say the responsibility should lie with motorists as vehicles are capable of attaining high speeds. According to experts, jaywalking cannot be discussed without taking a critical view of the existing state of pedestrian infrastructure, the aggressive attitude of motorists towards pedestrians, and the priority that police provide to movement of vehicles over the safety of pedestrians. In 2017 and 2018, pedestrians accounted for over 50% of road crash deaths in the city.In 2009, traffic police carried out an extensive campaign to curb jaywalking . Police pounced on pedestrians found jumping dividers near CSMT. Foreign tourists were not spared either. Back then, they followed the Rules of Road Regulations (RRR), notified under the Motor Vehicles Act, which mandated that a driver and every other person should obey automated signals at intersections. Police interpreted “every other person” to include pedestrians and booked jaywalkers.But in 2017, the Motor Vehicles Driving Rules (MDVR), which replaced RRR, brought in a paradigm shift, putting the entire onus on motorists and not pedestrians. “MDVR put a lot of restrictions on drivers while giving the highest priority to pedestrians and cyclists... It recognises that there isn't adequate safety infrastructure in place for pedestrians. It also recognises that pedestrians could get distracted... So, MDVR instructs drivers to practice defensive driving and always be cautious,” said Ranjit Gadgil, programme director of the non-profit, Parisar. Gadgil was among those invited by the parliamentary select committee to give inputs during the process of amending the Motor Vehicles Act.Their hands tied with the MDVR coming into effect, police turned towards the Bombay Police Act to penalize errant pedestrians. The Act empowers the police commissioner to make rules for regulating traffic of all kinds—a notification can be issued spelling out rules for pedestrians. Police did so and started fining errant pedestrians Rs 200. But now, there is no such notification in effect. "We are exploring the possibility of re-issuing such a notification,” said an official.The Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019 empowers states to regulate activities of non-motorised transport and pedestrians. But no rules have been framed for pedestrians under this clause, state transport department officers say.“I’m opposed to the idea of booking pedestrians for jaywalking until we have carefully designed our infrastructure to accommodate needs of all road users. If you really want to save lives, you have to create infrastructure that is forgiving. It stems from an understanding that people will make some mistakes but they shouldn’t have to die for it. In this case, the forgiving factor is speed,” said a transport planner. “Lower speeds in cities equals to increased road safety.”In fact at the third Global Ministerial Conference on Road Safety in Sweden recently, global leaders sought capping of speed limits at 30kmph in areas where vulnerable road users and vehicles mix frequently.

Title: Delhi violence: Failure of intelligence, poor judgment, say former top cops
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

A vandalized street following violence between pro and anti-CAA protesters in Delhi (AP photo)

NEW DELHI: On a day when the Supreme Court hauled up Delhi Police for not acting professionally while handling the communal situation in northeast Delhi, former top cops opined the force showed poor judgement about the probability of simmering tensions in the region erupting into full-scale violence.

“It was not a coincidence that the riots broke out during US president Donald Trump’s visit. A large number of well-armed people were on the streets. Where was the police during the build-up?” wondered Prakash Singh, former DGP of UP. Singh, whose report on police reforms was cited by the Supreme Court, said police had failed to gather intelligence when tensions escalated after some provocative speeches.

The retired police chief also charged the senior Delhi Police leadership with failing to take a quick call in containing the situation. “It is imperative for any police force to use arms when they are being used rampantly by rioters. I did not see a single police person armed with a service weapon,” said Singh. What stopped orders to open fire at the armed mob? A lot of lives could have been saved.”

Former Delhi Police commissioner Ajai Raj Sharma was also critical of the brass. “A DCP being beaten up is a shocking sign in policing. When prohibitory orders have been imposed, it is imperative to implement it without compromise,” Sharma said. He recalled a similar situation in UP in the early 1980s. “We aggressively resorted to all sorts of riot control measures because there should be a fear of the law. You cannot expect a rioter to back off. Delhi Police, in this case, seemed to be lacking the intent,” said Sharma.

Some former officers pointed out that the cops appeared to be underprepared to handle the crisis. Ashok Chand, who retired as Delhi Police additional commissioner, linked this with the absence of risk assessment by the cops. “The persons on the ground taking the decisions were clearly not knowledgeable about the topography of the region,” he explained. “It is expected that immediately after violence breaks out, police teams must start area-domination exercises and quick decision-making is essential for this.”

It was not simply the spot decision-making that faltered. As former Delhi Police DCP L N Rao noted, there also was a stark disconnect between the ground force and the senior officers, pointing out that at the Shaheen Bagh protests, the policemen on the ground were clueless until thing went out of control. “In northeast Delhi too, the policemen couldn’t gauge the repercussions of two antagonistic protests coming face to face,” Rao said.

In fact, felt retired additional commissioner SBS Tyagi, apart from having intel and more boots on ground, police should have acted immediately following the provocative speeches last Sunday. “It was evident to anyone that allowing two opposing groups within a stone’s throw of each other would lead to violence. What were police doing when the speeches were being made?” he said. And, the former senior cop added, as soon as the riots broke out, Delhi Police should have immediately started arresting the perpetrators to instil a fear among the rioters. This could have helped defuse the situation.

Title: Police put up signboard asking people to report harassment by money lenders
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The appeal comes in the wake of the incident in which a farmer allegedly attempted suicide by consuming pestic... Read More

KOLHAPUR: The Gandhinagar police have put a signboard outside the police station appealing people to approach them and register complaints if they are harassed by private money lenders.

The appeal comes in the wake of the incident in which a farmer allegedly attempted suicide by consuming pesticide after he was unable to clear dues of a private money lender despite attaching his agricultural land on the name of money lender. Police said that the farmer is currently admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) and is undergoing treatment.

Prashant Amruktar, deputy superintendent of police, Karveer division, said, “We have already appealed to the people to come forward and register complaints against private money lenders with us so that we can crack whip against them. As a part of our drive to reach out to people and build confidence in them about our assurance, we have put a signboard outside the Gandhinagar police station. We expect people to approach us for any help, especially if they are being harassed by private money lenders.”

Gandhinagar is a major wholesale market area. Hundreds of traders and businessmen have their outlets and shops in Gandhinagar.

“Gandhinagar is one of the regions in Kolhapur district where illegal activities like private moneylending is deep rooted, creating fear among the traders working here. Our aim is to weed out private moneylending and extortion crimes from this area. This is one of the reason that we have chosen to put board at Gandhinagar police station so that the traders will come forward and register complaints with us,” Amruktar said.

He also said that recent incidents have revealed that these private money lenders operate in gangs and resort to kidnapping and extortion to recover their interest. “We have already invoked Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA) against some gangs that were found operating as private money lenders in this region. We will take action against the remaining ones after people come forward and register complaints with us,” he added.

Title: Police writer caught while taking bribe in Karur
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representaive Image

KARUR: A police writer attached to Velayuthampalayam police station in Karur was caught red-handed by vigilance and anti-corruption (DVAC) officials, while taking a bribe of Rs 15,000 from a man in Karur on Wednesday. He had to pay the bribe for moving a file on his car that was involved in a traffic accident. The DVAC also booked the inspector of the police station for his alleged involvement in the incident.

Senthilkumar, 44, is the official caught red-handed while receiving money from Abhishek, the owner of the car. The waiting DVAC team surrounded Senthilkumar and took him into custody.

A multi utility vehicle (MUV) of Abhishek collided with another car on the bypass road on February 16. Velayuthampalayam police registered a case after booking the driver of the car as the accused in the case. As per the procedure, the car should be referred to the motor vehicle inspector (MVI) at RTO for verification. The verification can be done at the recommendation of the police officer concerned.

Initially, Senthilkumar demanded Rs 20,000 from Abhishek for moving his file. As Abhishek refused the amount, Senthilkumar settled the deal for Rs 15,000. Unwilling to bribe him, Abhishek filed a complaint with DVAC, Karur, which laid a trap.

After the arrest, Senthilkumar told police that he took the bribe at the behest of police inspector Veluchamy. Recording his statement, DVAC implicated inspector Veluchamy also in the case. Since the inspector was unavailable at the police station on Wednesday, DVAC have planned to summon him for further inquiry.

After searching Senthilkumar’s residence at the police quarters, the DVAC produced him before a court. The court remanded him in judicial custody and he is sent to Trichy central prison.

Title: Disease on the prowl: In slums, many families have two or more tuberculosis patients
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Three months ago, Shaheen Begun, who is just 32, lost her husband to tuberculosis. He was the family’s sole breadwinner. He was undergoing treatment for relapse of tuberculosis for the third time in a matter of two years at the community health centre (CHC) in Barkas.After he passed away, their 7-year-old daughter was diagnosed with tuberculosis (contact tracing was done by CHC) and is undergoing treatment.The dread of the disease has caught on her extended family as well and they remain out of touch now.“My relatives are even hesitant to meet us. They don’t invite us to any function and we stay away too. Now I fear for my daughter’s life,” said the distraught mother.Several families living in slums in the city are facing the same problem, with more than one family member being diagnosed with the disease. They also complained that government help (Rs 500 per month and free medicines) is not sufficient.In three slum areas that TOI visited, a few bylanes had 3-7 houses with a cluster of tuberculosis patients. The spread has been rapid despite many of these patients being under treatment.Another family in Bandlaguda slum area has a second member battling the disease. “Our elderly neighbour passed away because of tuberculosis. Later, I was diagnosed with tuberculosis and now my 4-year-old child has also contracted the disease,” said a 34-year-old woman, who is now on daily dosage of injections and pills to cure the multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (an aggressive form of tuberculosis).Though the government provides Rs 500 a month and free medicines to patients, the cases of patients discontinuing the treatment are hardly being followed up.“The government health officials have visited only once so far. They give medicines, but I find them useless and have stopped taking them,” said a patient.

Title: PPP trains to offer refund for delays
Content:
Operation of Tejas trains will pave the way for the PPP-model for Indian railways and improve amenities for pa... Read More

HYDERABAD: Passengers can now seek refunds for delays of eight trains which will run under the public-private partnership (PPP) model. “As per the model, a passenger will receive Rs 100 if the train is delayed by over an hour and Rs 250 if the delay is over two hours. The payment will be processed by Indian Railways Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) without passengers having to file ticket deposit receipts (TDR),” said a senior South Central Railway (SCR) official.The official added that operation of Tejas trains will pave the way for the PPP-model for Indian railways and improve amenities for passengers.While trains under the PPP model are trying to provide airline-like facilities, railway unions rue the move to hand over ticketing, parcel, catering and housekeeping services to private players.“The Railways have identified around 50 routes across its network to expand the privatisation of train services, they could have let local operators to provide the services,” said a representative of South Central Railways Mazdoor Union (SCRMU).“Not just the in-train services, but private players coming into the game will also be allowed to acquire their own rolling stock from foreign, when till now they were mostly manufactured in India,” the representative added.Under the PPP model, infrastructure such as locomotives, coaches will remain under Indian Railways along with employment of loco pilots, guards and security personnel while soft services such as catering, housekeeping among others will be contracted to private players.“It is good to see that passenger amenities are being focused on, but it is also important that they don't charge exorbitant ticket pricing otherwise it will be pointless. It will be interesting to see how they introduce the refund policy ,” said a member of the Suburban Train and Bus Travellers Association from SCR zone.

Title: In Trichy, 505 gold coins unearthed at temple
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

A treasure trove of 504 small and one big gold coins weighing 1,716g surfaced when workers were digging the ground at the Jambukeswarar Akilandeswari temple at Thiruvanaikaval in Trichy on Wednesday. Temple officials said the coins, which had letters resembling Arabic etched on them, could date back to 1000-1200 CE.

The temple workers engaged in renovation work stumbled upon a copper vessel with the coins opposite Amman Sannathi at Kottaram Vaazhai Thottam behind Prasanna Vinayagar Sannathi. On being informed, officials of the Hindu religious and charitable endowment (HR&CE) department recovered the vessel and counted the coins in the presence of a policeman.

The officials said the temple administration was clearing the bushes and digging the ground for around 7 feet when they found the vessel.

Though the coins’ period or antique value could not be determined yet, the HR&CE officials roughly estimated their value at Rs 68 lakh. TNN

Title: Life Mission: Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan to announce completion of over 2 lakh homes
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan , on Saturday, will officially announce completion of the construction of two lakh houses for homeless under Life Mission , which the government considers as an ‘unparalleled achievement’ in a short span of time.

The government, since the launch of Life Mission (bringing all existing housing schemes under one umbrella) in 2017, has spent around Rs 6,500 crore for works under the three-phased project and has so far completed construction of around 2.14 lakh houses, LSGD minister A C Moideen told reporters here on Wednesday. Thiruvananthapuram district topped in the number of houses constructed (32,388) followed by Palakkad (24,898) and Kollam (18,470).

Around 30,000 beneficiaries are expected to take part in the mega function to be held at Putharikkandam Maidan at 3pm on Saturday, said general committee chairman and cooperation minister Kadakampally Surendran. Besides the main event in the capital, panchayat-level programmes with the participation of beneficiaries are being organized across the state simultaneously.

Elaborating on the three phases of the project, Moideen said an amount of Rs 670 crore was spent to construct 52,050 houses (of total 54,173) in the first phase, which dealt with houses remaining incomplete under various government schemes during the period from 2000-01 to 2015-16.

The second phase targeted homeless people who owned land, and the government has so far spent Rs 5,851.23 crore. “Houses of 74,674 (80.97%) beneficiaries were completed. Out of the 17,475 houses for which construction began under Life-PMAY (rural), 16,640 houses have been completed,” the minister said.

The mission has also identified 1,06,925 beneficiaries under the third phase (house for landless people), which would feature construction of housing complexes using prefab technology. The government has spent Rs 31 crore besides giving administrative sanction for works estimated at Rs 448 crore for the third phase, the minister added.

Title: Telangana: Bathukamma saris for one crore women, scheme to cost Rs 320 crore
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: Despite severe financial constraints and economic slowdown, the state government will distribute Bathukamma saris to about one crore women. This will be the fourth successive year that the TRS government will be distributing Bathukamma saris to women of above 18 years having white ration cards.

Officials said the scheme would cost Rs 320 crore to the government. The officials have already placed orders with powerloom weavers, particularly those working in Sircilla, represented by TRS working president and industry minister KT Rama Rao in the assembly.

Each sari will cost about Rs 300. They will be distributed for free to women before the Bathukamma festival. Sources said one crore saris made of polyester with attractive golden and silver colour border would be distributed.

Officials consulted design experts, took feedback from rural and urban women before finalising the designs for the saris.

Over 40,000 weaver families working in the powerloom sector will benefit from the government order for these saris. Telangana State Handloom Weavers Cooperative Society Ltd managing director P Yadagiri told TOI that the government had been giving nearly Rs 500 crore worth work orders every year to the weavers for production of saris, uniforms, among others.

Upon the directions of KTR , orders for production of school uniforms for students of SC, ST and BC welfare residential schools, Ramzan and Christmas gifts comprising saris, kurta-pyjama and trouser-shirt are also being given to the powerloom weavers in the last few years, officials said.

“This is being done to give work to the weavers facilitating revival of the weaving industry,” an official said.

Title: Valuables worth Rs 1.70 lakh stolen in three house break-ins
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Three cases of house break-ins were reported in the city on Wednesday where burglars decamped with valuables worth Rs 1.70 lakh.

Of the three cases, two have been reported with Gandhinagar police while the last incident was reported under the jurisdiction of Kurundwad police station.

In the case registered with Kurundwad police station, the complainant — identified as Ravsaheb Shivram Kamble (65), a resident of Nave Danwad of Shirol taluka — had gone out of his home for some work when someone broke in.

“The burglars stole valuables worth Rs 65,000, including gold jewellery worth Rs 10,000 and building construction material kept outside his house,” a police officer said, adding that they are investigating the case.

In another incident reported at Gandhinagar police station, the suspects targeted a house belonging to Sagar Anandrao Sonawane located at Gauri Shankar Nagar in Gadmudshingi and decamped with valuables worth Rs 63,000, including gold and silver jewellery.

In the last incident, the suspects broke into a house of Mahesh Indrajeet Chohitramani and looted valuables worth Rs 39,900 from it.

Police have booked the suspects under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code, including sections 454 (lurking house-trespass or house-breaking in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment), 457 (lurking house trespass or house-breaking by night in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment) and 380 (theft in dwelling house).

Title: Delhi violence a grim reminder of the 2002 Gujarat riots: Asaduddin Owaisi
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: Accusing the BJP of inciting communal tension in Delhi, AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Wednesday said clashes in the capital city brought back memories of the 2002 Gujarat riots .

“The whole world has seen how the Delhi police were complicit in the whole communal carnage that took place. I will not call it a communal riot, but it is a deliberate programme, and it reminds the nation of what happened in 2002,” said Owaisi on Wednesday in Hyderabad.

Continuing his verbal attack on BJP and Delhi police, Owaisi said: “I want to ask the honourable Prime Minister, is this your Sab Ka Saath Sab Ka Vikas? Your chief minister says, to be in India you have to say this slogan, who are you to judge my loyalty towards nation? This very thinking has gone down to the level of police officers,” said Owaisi, referring to a video where four inured people were singing the national anthem in the presence of cops.

An angry Owaisi questioned how cops allowed a group of people to go near a place of worship and said the Army should be pressed into action as people did not have any faith in the police.

“The worst part was people clapping when the whole tyre market was burnt. Army should be brought in as Delhi police is complicit in this matter,” said the Hyderabad MP.

He took potshots at Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Union home minister Amit Shah and MoS (home) Kishan Reddy.

“Neither the PM OR HM has reacted to this, and are only holding meetings. Why can’t they condemn it an outright manner? Why can’t union home minster visit the areas (where violence erupted), why can’t his MOS go? he (MOS) sits in Hyderabad and criticises me,” said the lawmaker.

“Why can’t HM visit all these areas, when HM can camp for four days continuously and hold more 30 public meetings ahead of Delhi elections, why can’t he go now?” he added.

He also said that the responsibility of not controlling this communal riot lies with the BJP government at the centre.

“It is the failure of the BJP government. The central government is deliberately not acting, many journalists have been attacked too,” said Owaisi.

Title: Special police agency mooted to prevent accidents on national & state highways
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A mere 5% length of the total road network spanning across the country causes 55.33% road accidents and leads to 62.50% deaths. This was in 2018. In a damning report to the Bureau of Police Research and Development (BPRD), it was also said that India alone accounts for 11% of total road accident-related deaths in the world.The report titled ‘Road safety scenario and national road safety plan’ was submitted to BPRD by chairman of Telangana Road Safety Authority and DGP (road safety) T Krishna Prasad. Towards preventing road accidents on national highways (NHs) and state highways (SHs), Prasad suggested formation of special police agency for highways apart from safety plan. BPRD functions under the ministry of home affairs.“The dedicated NH and SH safety police should focus 60% of their energies on enforcement, 20% on educating commuters and awareness programmes and remaining 20% on emergency response,” Prasad told TOI on Wednesday. He said safety police and local cops should work in tandem to prevent road accidents.Prasad, who submitted his report on Tuesday, focused on strategy for road crash fatality prevention. BPRD had asked for report on road safety six months ago. “India ranks first in number of road accident deaths as per World Road Statistics, 2018, followed by China and the US,” he said.Since NHs carry more than 40% of traffic load, enforcement must be on NHs, he said. “If it is done within five years, fatalities caused by accidents on NHs will come down by at least 50%. Standard operating procedures and legal provisions should also be outlined for new police agency,” he observed.In the wake of an accident in Karimnagar where a car plunged into canal and three of a family drowned, all district collectors and SPs have been asked to identify vulnerable spots in coordination with R&B department. Prasad said instructions have also been given to engineering department to review existing safety mechanisms at such locations and provide additional measures, if required.

Title: Navi Mumbai has worst air quality in Maharashtra, reveals study
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Navi Mumbai is the most toxic city in the state and 51st most polluted in the world, reveals the latest World Air Quality Report 2019. According to it, Nagpur’s air is the second-most toxic in the state.

Track the pollution level in your city

The report is based on the latest data from government and private continuous ambient air quality monitoring stations and compiled by IQAir Air Visual – a global air quality information platform. It reveals the changing state of particulate matter 2.5 around the world last year.

Globally, India ranks fifth in the polluted countries across the world, with an annual PM2.5 concentration of 58.1 micrograms per cubic meter (mpcm). PM2.5 is a deadly pollutant which measures up to 2.5 microns. Due to its microscopic size, the particles can enter the bloodstream through the respiratory system, leading to severe health impacts.

Of the 11 cities from Maharashtra which are listed under polluted cities, annual PM2.5 levels of Navi Mumbai in 2019 are the highest at 61.6 mpcm. The pollutant’s concentration exceeded the World Health Organization’s (WHO) safe target of 10 mpcm by nearly 500%.

Nagpur, the state’s second most toxic city, breaches this standard by nearly 400%, with an annual PM2.5 average of 47.2 mpcm. Other cities from the state which recorded high PM2.5 levels include Mumbai, Aurangabad, Nashik, Solapur, Pimpi-Chinchwad, Pune, Chandrapur, Kupti (Nanded district) and Kumbhori (Pune district).

According to experts, different combustion processes are the main contributors for particulate pollution . “Thermal power plants, open burning and landfill fires of municipal solid waste, commercial food sector and vehicular emissions are some prominent sources,” said Avinash Chanchal, senior campaigner at Greenpeace India.

As reported by TOI, Maharashtra, at 18, has the highest number of non-attainment cities in the country. In the National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), the Union environment ministry categorized 102 cities as ‘non-attainment’. It meant these cities have consistently witnessed deteriorating air quality when compared to the National Ambient Air Quality Standards.

Stating that the government needs to address major sources of pollution which are prevalent throughout the year, Chanchal said, “It needs to ensure that the growing demand for energy is fuelled by sustainable and cleaner sources. The policymakers also need to introduce measures to phase out from petrol and diesel cars and build a more equipped public transport system.”

Chancal added that the city clean air action plan should include sectoral targets and policies for emission reduction with interim milestones to track half-yearly and annual progress.

Title: Barrage repair work may cost 3-4 days water cut: WRD
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The barrage was constructed twenty years ago, however, two of the 20 columns have been completely damaged

KOLHAPUR: The water resource department (WRD) officials have suggested to the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) to stop the water supply to the city for three to four days to repair the barrage at Shinganapur pumping station located along the Panchganga river.

The barrage was constructed twenty years ago, however, two of the 20 columns have been completely damaged. The KMC had earlier floated the tenders inviting the firms to take up the repair works on several occasions, however, it did not receive an adequate response. The civic body, therefore, approached the WRD officials asking them to provide the contractor from their panel to get the work done before the arrival of monsoon.

A senior WRD official on condition of anonymity said that the repair work of the barrage requires complete drying of the river site for at least three to four days. “We have visited the site recently. The ready-mix concrete foundation has to be laid. The suggestion has been made to the KMC, however, we are yet to get the response. The repairs are important and if it is neglected the rest of the structure may get damaged and then it will be hard to get the new one constructed.”

According to the WRD officials, around 50% of the water reserved for the city is lost through various leakages. The damage to the barrage has further added to the leaking woes.

Last year, the KMC had set aside Rs 40 lakh for the work but the cost for the repair work would have increased. Due to the leakages, the water level at the barrage is not maintained at the level required to operate the pumps at full capacity.

This has lead to inadequate supply to the E ward and some other areas of the city, which forms around 60% of the total population. The capacity of the pumps is around 86 million litres however the supply is just 50%.

When questioned to the recommendation made by the WRD, a senior water supply official said, “It is not practical to stop the water supply for three to four days. We are finding other ways to get the columns repaired. To cut the water supply for the longer duration we have to take the citizens, corporators into confidence.”

Title: Flash protests against CAA continue in Old City areas
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

CHARMINAR: Flash protests, candlelight vigil and demonstrations were held in parts of Old City on Wednesday night againstthe Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Protesters gathered on the streets at Tolichowki, Yakutpura, and Hussaini Alam holding the National flag, placards and candles to raise their voice against the controversial Act implemented by the central government as well as mass detention of agitators by the city police. They also condemned the violence in Delhi.

“The women are taking out a peaceful rally and yet cops are trying to push us away. They are trying to suppress public voice and the government is silent. We urge the chief minister to take a clear stand on Citizenship Amendment Act,” said a protester at Yakutpura.

Students of Nizamia Tibbi College also demanded that the government should make its stand on the contentious law clear without any delay. “We began our protest 51 days ago and will continue our agitation till our demands are met,” said a student.

Similarly, blackout demonstrations were organised by traders at Chatta Bazaar and Barkas as well as Chandrayangutta Market between 7.15pm and 7.30 pm. The traders switched off the lights in their respective shops for 15 minutes as part of the protest.

“We have been organising blackout protests regularly and the agitation will continue till the demands are met,” a shopkeeper told TOI.

Title: Directive issued for transfer of 400 govt docs
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Transfer of a large number of doctors in the health service ahead of the routine general transfer has created unrest among them. However, health minister K K Shailaja has assured them that any anomaly pointed out would be rectified at the time of general transfer.

A directive for transfer of over 400 doctors has been issued to fill up newly-created posts in the health service. This precedes general transfer, a routine process, in April and May.

Doctors serving at a place for more than three years are considered for general transfer. Priority is given to those seeking hometown placements after serving elsewhere for the last three years. With the transfer list to fill up the newly-created posts, hometown placement opportunities have been affected.

“We discussed this with the health minister and have been assured that injustices pointed out it can be rectified,” said Dr G S Vijayakrishnan, state secretary of Kerala Government Medical Officers Association.tnn

Title: Laxman: Asad modern-day Jinnah
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hyderabad: Telangana BJP president K Laxman on Wednesday compared AIMIM chief Asaddudin Owaisi to Muhammad Ali Jinnah. At a press conference here, he said Jinnah used Muslims to create Pakistan and now Owaisi was instigating Muslims in India against CAA, NPR and NRC. “When several Muslims stayed back in India, they were provided several constitutional provisions to protect them. PM Narendra Modi has made it clear that CAA is not against Muslims or any Indian citizen. Why are the attacks happening?” he sought to know. tnn

Title: VMRDA picks 7 mandals to develop 1-cent housing sites
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA) is racing against time to prepare one-cent layouts for distribution to the homeless in Vizag city starting this Ugadi. Even though the land pooling exercise is being carried out in 10 mandals in the district for nearly 6,100 acres, officials have identified about 2,867 acres in seven mandals out of the pooled land to develop the housing sites for 1.54 lakh beneficiaries.

About 58,861 beneficiaries will be given one-cent plots in Sabbavaram mandal alone, including Gollapalem village (15,108 plots), Nanginarapadu (11,936), Yerukunaidupalem (3,363), Pydiwada (9,953) and Gangavaram (18,501). Housing sites will be allocated to nearly 38,000 families in Thangudubilli, Gandigundam and Ramavaram villages in Anandapuram mandal.

About 20,187 plots will be provided to the homeless in Mudapaka mandal. Nearly 13,000 housing sites will be developed in various villages of Parawada mandal. Other layouts will come up in Gajuwaka, Anakapalli and Pedagantyada mandal.

Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority estimates that basic infrastructural development works, including jungle clearance, site levelling, total station survey and peg marking with stones for the one cent plots, would cost the exchequer about Rs 57 crore. VMRDA called for tenders for the same two days ago. Civil works at these layouts are expected to begin around March 10 after finalising bidders. Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao said VMRDA engineering officials will prepare a daily report on the ongoing works at various layouts.

“VMRDA officials were asked to work in a coordinated manner to complete the works within the stipulated deadline to facilitate distribution of the housing sites to the poor,” said Koteswara Rao. VMRDA will get nearly 900 acres as its share out of the pooled land in compensation for the development of these one-cent layouts. The farmers (assignees/encroachers) will also be provided developed plots. But the size of the plots will be based on the legitimacy of possession and tenure.

While the development of one-cent layouts is estimated to cost about Rs 2 lakh per acre, expenditure on the layout development towards farmers’ share as well as VMRDA’s share is likely to hover around Rs 50 lakh per acre.

Title: MLA Thakre demands action against Sadar cops
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Vikas Thakre

Nagpur: West Nagpur Congress MLA Vikas Thakre on Wednesday criticized the city police for non-registration of FIR in cases pertaining to women. While speaking in the state assembly on Wednesday, he also demanded strict and exemplary action against erring officials.

Referring to an incident of Sadar police station on February 16, Thakre highlighted the plight of two sisters who were turned away by night officer API Mohan Dere without initiating any proper action. The husband of one sister had thrashed both under the influence of liquor. No medical examination too was conducted.

The women, who reached the police station at midnight, were rudely turned away. They were also told to get the medical examination done on their own from any hospital of their choice.

No action was initiated until Thakre intervened the following morning. The women were then sent for a medical examination at Mayo hospital. On February 18, they were given a copy of the non-cognizable offence registered against the husband.

Thakre expressed shock how women who wanted protection and justice at such an odd hour were sent away by the police.

Speaking to TOI, Thakre asked an offence should have been registered “without his intervention”.

State home minister Anil Deshmukh, responding to Thakre, said that he would ensure strict action is initiated against the accused once a detailed complaint is submitted. “We already have crime and criminal tracking network and system (CCTNS) in place which have made it possible to register complaint online. Also, every police station across the state would be covered under surveillance of six CCTV cameras. These systems would help us keep a check on the functioning of the police stations and also ensure that there ills like non-registration of FIRs are being monitored,” he said.

PI Amol Deshmukh, who was in-charge of the Sadar police station between February 14 and 18, said he was clueless about the incident.

Senior PI Mahesh Bansod of Sadar police station said the doctor at Mayo hospital had stated in his report that there was no fracture on the women’s hand. “One of them had declined to get the medical examination done but underwent one on our insistence. Neither had any serious injuries,” he said, adding that even the husband had lodged a counter-complaint.

CP BK Upadhyay said the entire matter would be thoroughly probed now. “Action would be initiated against anyone who may have failed to act,” he said.

Title: Pedestrian has close shave as lorries collide
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hyderabad: A pedestrian had a close shave with death in Pothireddypalli in Sanga Reddy, after two lorries collided with each other in the wee hours of Wednesday. The man was crossing the road when the accident occurred.

Sanga Reddy police said that when the man who was crossing the road, a lorry which was travelling on the highway collided with another lorry. The second lorry has entered the highway from an internal road that was leading up from a village. Due to the impact of the collision, the lorry travelling on the highway was completely pushed towards the right side of the road, causing it to hit the median and tumble.

At the time, a man who had just crossed the median realised that two lorries had collided and were right behind him. Displaying presence of man, he immediately ran ahead and managed to prevent himself from being hit by both lorries. The lorries came to a standstill after got one fell to its side and another halted after its tyre struck to median. One of drivers was grievously injured.

Title: Riots in Delhi: This graveyard of cars is what remains of neighbourly living
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

More than 100 cars were torched

NEW DELHI: Six kilometres from the battle zone of Jafrabad-Maujpur lies Shiv Vihar in Karawal Nagar. The riots have so affected the locals that children showed reporters on Wednesday messages from their own friends taunting them to attack or back off. Amid smouldering houses and shops were also those that had been abandoned by frightened residents.

The magnitude of the hostility was clearly visible at the two paid parking lots near the Shiv temple. More than 100 cars there had been torched. An RAF official said, “Rioting took place throughout the night. Obviously, the mob had large amounts of arson material.” Anuj Sharma alleged that the skirmish began with stones being thrown at the temple in the area. “We pushed the mob back but they burnt the cars in the parking lot,” he claimed.

The destruction in this area abutting the Loni borde with UP is horrifying. TOI found many shops still aflame around 2.30pm on Wednesday. Sonu and his five brothers were combing the charred remains of their Radhe Radhe Confectionery Shop. “Hindus and Muslims both ate from our shop. We had no enmity with anyone. How will our families survive now with everything gone?” despaired Sonu, showing currency notes worth Rs 2,700 currency — the only remaining wealth of the family. Three fire tenders were trying to extinguish blazes in at least two locations.

The Rapid Action Force was clearly dominating the area, but unlike in Maujpur, Kabir Nagar, Jafrabad and Ghonda, no one in Shiv Vihar ventured out on the roads, which were strewn with rubble, stones and bricks. People sat at lane entrances with bamboo staves to deter anyone from going afield even as community elders sat outside places of worship trying to coax the residents into normality. As in Jafrabad, here too a canal divides the areas where the two communities have lived in harmony for decades.

Though the violence has abated, the tension hasn’t. Mohammad Azeem, an air conditioner repairman, recalled a sleepless night. “The area was quiet and we tried to sleep. But at 4am we heard a big blast. We ran to the terrace to see a ball of fire. Some women residents made frantic calls for help when their houses caught fire. We took the help of police to rescue them,” he said.

Basheer Ahmed, who works in Ghaziabad, worried about loss of income. “We are unable to go for work and I don’t know how I will sustain my family if this continues for long,” he said.

The elderly Mohammed Ikrammudin said he had experienced no disharmony in the 25 years he has lived here. “The perpetrators have come from outside, from UP. Their accents are different,” he alleged. Mohammad Umar said that rioters had used gas cylinders during the attack on homes and shops, including two mosques.

Title: Pattana Pragathi is to ensure basic amenities in towns: KT Rama Rao
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

KT Rama Rao

JANGAON: Ensuring basic amenities in towns and a plan to meet future demands is the main objective of Pattana Pragathi programme, the brainchild of chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao, municipal administration and urban development minister KT Rama Rao said on Wednesday.

During a surprise visit to Jangaon district on Wednesday, KTR inspected the progress of Pattana Pragathi programme at Dharmakancha basti . He said that the onus is on councillors and civic officials to bring a visible change in the towns, especially in regard with greenery and cleanliness. “As per the new Municipal Act, councillors will be held responsible if they fail to ensure greenery in their areas. They need to achieve at least 85% survival rate of plants,” KTR said.

The TRS working president also interacted with the sanitation workers and they told KTR about the problems they are facing. He directed district collector K Nikhila to resolve the issues faced by the sanitation workers.

Talking about garbage collection in the town, KTR told the municipal officials to procure Swachh autos and directed them to create awareness about the importance of segregating waste. The officials were also told to penalise residents if they dispose garbage on roads.

KTR further directed the officials to ensure that land owners keep their vacant plots clean or else they should be fined. The minister instructed officials to go tough on realtors who are resorting to illegal layouts.

He said that the 10-day Pattana Pragathi programme should become a platform to start construction of vegetable and non-vegetarian market yards, parks, open gyms, public toilets for women and men.

Title: Starting new courses tough, should be made easy: Official
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hyderabad: Lack of flexibility in introducing new courses in higher educational institutions is a major issue which the Telangana State Council of Higher Education has decided to focus on in its draft perspective plan of technical education (PPTE).

The decision was taken at a conference on Wednesday which was attended by several academicians and industry experts. Commissioner of technical and collegiate education Navin Mittal said the current process to approve new courses is tedious wherein permissions need to be sought at institution and government levels. “We have to streamline the process so that approvals can be granted faster and new courses can be introduced sooner,” he said.

Echoing similar views, in-charge vice-chancellor of Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad, and principal IT secretary to the state government, Jayesh Ranjan said that even if there is a will to introduce new courses, lack of flexibility to do so is a major challenge.

“Currently, if a university has to introduce a new course, it should first send a proposal to the Board of Studies following which it has to be approved by the higher education department,” Ranjan said, adding that a mechanism needs to be outlined in the draft PPTE to streamline introduction of new courses.

Stakeholders also emphasised on the need to have greater industry-academic collaborations to encourage apprenticeships. “Every institution should have two members from the industry on board who can guide students on apprenticeships,” said BVR Mohan Reddy, chairman of IIT-Hyderabad and executive chairman of Cyient Ltd.

Title: Water tax dues of government offices mounting
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has issued notices to the government establishments asking them to clear the water tax dues totalling more than Rs 17 crore.

Meanwhile, the civic body has paid Rs 2 crore to the water resources department towards the water lifted from Panchganga river. However, the total principal amount of Rs 13 crore is pending.

Recently, the Chhatrapati Pramila Raje Civil Hospital, which has total dues of Rs 7 crore, made part payment after the KMC threatened to cut its water supply. The railways have Rs 6.52 crore dues.

The total dues of the water supply department are Rs 28 crore and most of them are with the government establishments such as educational institutes, offices of government departments.

A senior KMC official said that while the government establishments pay the bills of other services such as power, bills, fuel, however they do not pay the water tax bills regularly.

Prashant Pandat, water tax superintendent of KMC, said, “We have issued show-cause notices. Soon, we are going to meet the top officers and request them to pay the dues. We have more dues with the government departments than with the citizens. The poor revenue collection has severely affected the KMC’s finances.”

Pandat said that the KMC cannot disconnect the water supply to the government offices suddenly since most of the establishments, especially the hospitals, have a number of visitors.

The KMC had sought concession in the bills issued by the water resources department. Along with the principal amount of dues and the fine, the total dues with the KMC is around Rs 35 crore. The WRD officials claimed that many other local bodies pay the bills regularly and even the farmers for using water from Panchganga river, the KMC has not been able to pay the dues.

Rohit Bandivdekar, executive engineer of WRD, said, “The demand of KMC to waive the fine amount and provide concession in the bills has been rejected by Maharashtra River Water Regulatory Authority. We have time and again told KMC to recover the dues from the consumers regularly and improve the supply system.”

Title: Road contractor JP Enterprises blacklisted for shoddy work
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has blacklisted Mumbai-based JP Enterprises for poor quality work as well as delay in completing the project under Cement Concrete Road Phase-III Project. It is for the first time in NMC’s history that a contractor has been blacklisted for this reason.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe on Wednesday issued orders for JP Enterprises to be blacklisted for a year and also slapped a fine of Rs8.11 lakhs on the firm.

JP Enterprises was to construct roads (package-8 under phase-III) covering Ekstambh Square to North Ambazari Road (road in front of Children Traffic Park) and Ekstambh Square to Zenda Chowk to Coffee House Square to Ram Nagar-Ravi Nagar Road.

Few months ago, NGO Civic Action Guild (CAG) had lodged a complaint with the then municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar alleging poor quality of works in construction of footpath and laying of paver blocks on both sides of Ekstambh Square to North Ambazari Road.

CAG claimed that the paver blocks came out immediately after they were fitted. The NGO had also said paver blocks were placed without ensuring proper curing of cement concrete.

Bangar had ordered an inquiry which found quality of paver blocks and other works not as per tender conditions.

Two days after Mundhe assumed charge as municipal commissioner, he received the inquiry report. He issued notices to the contractor, project management consultant M/s Creations Engineers Private Ltd and NMC junior engineer Gajendra Shrivastav.

After receiving replies from all, Mundhe on Wednesday took action. Earlier, the contractors would be ‘excused’ whenever such inquiries were conducted. But Mundhe decided to blacklist the contractor. What action has been taken against Creations Engineers Private Ltd and Shrivastav could not be ascertained.

Despite the deadline of March 31, the contractor is yet to complete main cement concrete works between Ekstambh Square and Zenda Chowk. Various other works too are pending. The total cost of the package is Rs32.47 crore.

The contractor will now have to complete remaining works but will not get any new work from the NMC in the next one year.

NMC sources told TOI that Mundhe blacklisted JP Enterprises to send a warning bell to all contractors engaged in road works.

The NMC’s cement concrete road phase-I of Rs133 crore, phase-II of Rs324 crore and phase-III of Rs302 crore are replete with poor quality works and inordinate delay.

Many roads concretized under first two phases have developed cracks along with scaling of surface layer. Quality of paver blocks, footpaths, road-divider too are of shoddy quality. No action has been taken against any contractor in last nine years.

Title: P Parameswaran very much like Hedgewar: Mohan Bhagwat
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat, along with various spiritual heads, hailed late P Parameshwaran in Thiruvananthapuram... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Recalling his long association with RSS ideologue P Parameswaran who passed away last week, RSS sarsangh chalak Mohan Bhagwat here, on Wednesday, said Parameswaran was a model swayam sewak who very much like Dr Hedgewar would ever continue as a living presence.

“I used to keep regular touch with him. In the last seven years I made it a point to meet him every year, once at least. As someone rightly mentioned, he was an Ajathasathru; the one who has no enemies. He never harboured enmity towards anybody. Such a simple and erudite person, he spoke in short simple sentences. He was an embodiment of all nine qualities that a swayam sewak should aspire for. He has the strength, character and knowledge. He was a fighter who pursued his goal astutely. He is an example for how each sangh member should conduct one self,” he said.

Bhagawat said Parameswaran had enlightened him about the crux of Bhagawat Gita in simple sentences. “Once I had an occasion to ask him how we can talk in brief about Gita. He explained it to me in four or five sentences. First, don’t try to avoid problems in life. Second, don’t think about how difficult the challenges are ahead. Then, whatever you do, do it with love. Don’t fight because you hate, fight because you love. Fight because you are on the right side. Then, whatever the result, learn to distance oneself away from that. Parameswarji had told me. He could practise all these,” he said.

Incidentally, Bhagawat’s reference about the gist of Bhagavad Gita prompted many to draw a connection between the riot in Delhi and the claims about the glory associated with those fighting on the right side.

Title: Kolhapur: Action committee opposes Maharashtra govt’s move of rationalising schools
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The Kolhapur city and district citizens action committee has opposed the state governments move of closing dow... Read More

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur city and district citizens’ action committee has opposed state government ’s move of rationalising schools that have less than 20 students.

According to the committee members, due to this decision as many as 58 schools in the district will be merged and students will be transferred to other schools.

Ramesh More, member of the action committee, said the state government in its government resolution on February 20 has skillfully managed to avoid the mention of closure of schools in the name of rationalisation and providing transport allowance to the affected students.

“We will not tolerate closure of any school in the district even if there are less than 10 students studying in them. Education is the right of every child and nobody should be deprived of it,” he said, adding that they met the Kolhapur zilla parishad Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Aman Mittal regarding the issue and he has promised to look into the matter.

When contacted, Mittal said, “The GR does not mention closure of any school. But this has been observed that in many places there are two-three schools that need to be rationalised.”

He added that if there are no schools in the standard vicinity — 1-km for primary and 3-km for upper primary — the schools will not be merged and students will continue their education in that school only.

“I want to assure everyone that all schools in remote areas having less than 10 or 20 students will continue to operate,” he said.

Title: Salinity threatens Kuttanad paddy yields
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Alappuzha: Saline water intrusion into Vembanad Lake from the sea is posing a threat to the paddy crops of Kuttanad which are below sea level.

The presence of salinity of more than 2PPT (a measurement to check the presence of salt in 1kg of water) will destroy the paddy and will reduce the weight and quality of the crops.

Tinto K Edayadi, a farmer said that he had conducted puncha cultivation on 35 acres and his paddy is 80 days old. “So, if salinity increases, all my plans will get derailed. My paddy will get destroyed and the salinity level in my paddy fields are nearing 2PPT. Uma seeds will not survive more than this limit. We are expecting 2,000-2,500kg paddy per acre. But if salinity level increases, it will come down to 1,500-1,800kg. The paddy crops which covers 100 days, can only survive the salinity levels of 2PPT,” he said.

According to farmers, though the shutters of Thanneermukkom bund were closed for preventing arrival of seawater to Kuttanad, the saline water keeps entering Vembanad Lake. “The water level in Kuttanad ips continuously depleting. Kollam-Kottappuram inland waterway and canals like Pookaitha that are connected to the sea though various water bodies are some of the major mediums for the arrival of saline water to Kuttanad,” the farmers said.

District Congress committee president M Liju said that the presence of salinity should be reduced in paddy fields of Kuttanad by opening the shutters of Pamba Dam. “If fresh water comes to the paddy fields, the salinity level will reduce. Liju has sent a letter in this regard to chief minister, ministers and officials concerned. The paddy crops in 270 acres is getting destroyed in Veeyapuram panchayat of upper Kuttanad due to the intrusion of saline water,” he said.

The ‘puncha’ harvesting of Kuttanad began last week. The paddy harvesting will come into full swing by March. The harvesting is getting delayed in many paddy fields as sowing in several areas was done behind the schedule due to rain and a shortage of seeds.

Kuttanad peasants of 1,217 ‘padasekhara samithi’, famous for bio saline farming, have indulged in ‘puncha’ farming in 26,268 hectares.

A farmer needs 50 to 60 kg seeds per acre for ‘puncha’ farming. The cost of one kg of seeds was Rs 32 and the state government distributed 40kg of seeds to the farmers free of cost. The remaining seeds were bought by the farmers spending their own cash.

Title: Rs 1,480-cr Technical Textiles Mission gets Cabinet nod
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

NEW DELHI: The government on Wednesday approved setting up of a National Technical Textiles Mission with a total outlay of Rs 1,480 crore. The mission will have a four-year implementation period from 2020-21 to 2023-24.

“The mission will aim at average growth rate of 15-20% per annum taking the level of domestic market size to $40-50 billion by the year 2024 through market development, market promotion, international technical collaborations, investment promotions and ‘ Make in India ’ initiatives,” an official statement said.

Technical textiles are futuristic and niche segment of textiles, which are used for various applications ranging from agriculture, roads, railway tracks, sportswear, healthcare, bullet proof jackets, fire proof jackets, high altitude combat gear and space applications.

The use of technical textiles in agriculture, aquaculture, dairy, poultry, Jal Jivan Mission, Swachch Bharat Mission, Ayushman Bharat will bring an overall improvement in cost economy, water and soil conservation, better agricultural productivity and higher income to farmers per acre of land holding in addition to promotion of manufacturing and exports activities in India, the government said.

The mission envisages export promotion of technical textiles, enhancing it from the current annual value of approximately Rs 14,000 crore to Rs 20,000 crore by 2021-22, and ensuring 10% average growth in exports per year up to 2023-24.

In India, the segment is estimated at $16 billion (about Rs 1.14 lakh crore) which is approximately 6% of the $250 billion (about Rs 17.75 lakh crore) global technical textiles market . The penetration level of technical textiles is low in India, varying between 5-10% against the level of 30-70% in developed countries.

Talking to reporters, Union textiles minister Smriti Irani said arrangements have been made under the mission for skill development of 50,000 people in the field of technical textiles. “We have mandated use of technical textiles in nine ministries and 92 products and our hope is that with convergence of efforts with the technology group we will see a new future for especially MSME and technologists in the field of technical textiles, thereby making India self sufficient specially in strategic fields like defence and aerospace,” she said.

The minister said that the trade deficit in this segment will be nullified in the next one year.

According to an official release, the mission will have four components including research, innovation and development with outlay of Rs 1,000 crore; promotion and market development; export promotion; education, training and skill development. It will also promote technical education at higher engineering and technology levels related to technical textiles and its application areas covering engineering, medical, agriculture, aquaculture and dairy segments.

Title: Loan waiver scheme: Money sent to 175 farmers accounts
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: After publishing a list of 208 farmers from the district on a pilot basis in the state government’s ambitious Mahatma Jyotirao Phule Farmer Loan Waiver Scheme , Amar Shinde, deputy registrar, finance and cooperation department said that the authentication of 175 farmers has been completed and the loan amount has been transferred to the respective banks.

Shinde said that there are more than 50,000 beneficiaries from the district who are eligible for the loan waiver scheme. He said that the list which has been published is just the preliminary list one. The list of the remaining beneficiaries will be published by February 28, said Shinde.

He also said that the farmers whose loan accounts have been cleared with this loan waiver scheme will be eligible to apply for the fresh loan.

According to Shinde, 57,141 farmers were initially identified across the district; however, the figure was reduced to around 51,000 after a few figures were found to be inflated from the nationalized banks.

Notably, as per the scheme, loan up to Rs two lakh taken between April 1, 2015, and March 31, 2019, and which has not been repaid till September 30, 2019, is eligible for the waiver.

In January 2020, the state government had issued a resolution which stated that farmers whose crop loan and restructured loan is more than Rs two lakh will not be eligible for any benefit under the scheme.

Title: Experts sound alarm over unscientific & reckless methods of fishing in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

One of the major reasons of the decline is being attributed to unscientific and reckless methods of fishing

HYDERABAD: A serious decline in fish catch across Telangana and Andhra Pradesh since last monsoon has got experts worried. Besides climate change, one of the major reasons of the decline is being attributed to unscientific and reckless methods of fishing .

M Vijay Gupta, fisheries scientist, told TOI, “In trolling, which is widely used in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh, one or more fishing lines, baited with lures are drawn through the water in small and large water bodies alike. This results in trapping a large number of unintended species.”

Experts said that wherever there is such kind of fishing, there is a by-catch, the incidental capture of non-target species such as sharks, marine turtles, sea birds, and in some areas, dolphins.

The National Fisheries Development Board (NFDB), Hyderabad has been long running schemes to encourage fishermen to switch from conventional fishing techniques (trawl fishing) to longlining in India under the Blue Revolution programme.

Under the scheme, fishermen can claim up to Rs 15 lakh to convert conventional fishing techniques to longlining fishing and avail of training from National Fisheries Development Board.

A senior executive of NFDB, said: “Longlining is a commercial fishing technique using a long line with baited hooks attached at intervals. It helps in catching the intended breeds of fishes unlike other techniques where big nets and modern-day equipment trap other species as well.”

Trawl fishing is another inadvisable technique, which involves dragging nets across the sea floor to scoop up fish. This results in disturbing the seabed, while harming marine species, said officials.

“After consulting fishermen, and with the research over the years, we have found that a number of modern fishing gears, strong and unnoticeable, are not only efficient at catching the desired fish species but also anything else coming in its path,” said a principal scientist from Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI).

Experts have cautioned that a collapse in fishing sector is imminent, but avoiding trawling and impulsive techniques alike can help the case.

“There are proven solutions to deal with the issue. Fishing gear can be modified so that either fewer non-target species are caught, or if caught they can escape,” he said.

Title: Panel enforcing agenda of liquor lobby: Activist
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Chandrapur: Anti-liquor activist Paromita Goswami has alleged that the committee formed to evaluate prohibition in Chandrapur district is enforcing the agenda of liquor lobby . She stated this following reports that memorandums submitted to the committee seeking lifting of liquor ban are 20 times more than those favouring prohibition.

A sub-inspector rank officer of the excise department had reportedly disclosed the figures to a select media within an hour of deadline for submitting memorandums to the committee ended on Tuesday evening. According to the officer, 2.61 lakh memorandums favoured revocation of the ban while only 20,585 demanded its continuation.

The officer termed it as a referendum in favour of removing liquor ban and stated that more than 1.25 lakh memorandums were received on the last day.

“The officer who revealed the figures is not part of the committee and he was not authorized to speak to the media. I have directed the superintendent of the excise department to serve him a show cause notice,” said district collector and head of the committee, Dr Kunal Khemnar.

Questioning intentions of the committee, Goswami said how can confidential figures be disclosed within an hour after the deadline ends. “Firstly, guardian minister Vijay Wadettiwar is repeatedly stating that liquor ban has failed. Secondly, figures favouring lifting of prohibition have been leaked. This shows that public opinion is being built to suit agenda of the liquor lobby,” she said and demanded immediate action against the officer who disclosed the figures.

She announced to boycott the committee and demanded that CM should institute an all inclusive community comprising social workers, women leaders, experts in subject under retired high court judge if government really wants to evaluate the outcome of prohibition in Chandrapur.

“A memorandum to this effect has been sent to chief minister Uddhav Thackeray,” she said and claimed that anti-liquor activists are soon going to meet him to press the demand.

The nine-member committee had sought opinion on the ban in writing or by e-mail between February 10 and 25. It has come to fore that those favouring removal of prohibition undertook a signature campaign on a printed format of memorandum at public places.

WhatsApp message were circulated with an ‘e-mail address’ asking people for opinion against prohibition. TOI has copy of both the printed format as well as the WhatsApp message. Those favouring removal of ban brought such printed and signed memorandums in bundles for submission.

District collector Khemnar confirmed receiving complaints regarding some people moving around seeking signatures on printed memorandums. He claimed that the number of memorandum does not matter to the committee. “It is in no way a referendum. Committee will compile all opinions, gather figures related to liquor crime, domestic violence, accidents etc and submit a report to the guardian minister,” he told TOI.

“If government wants to a referendum, then it would do it as per provision in related law,” said Khemnar.

Title: Telangana: Milk prices jump twice in 10 days, officials point at fall in supply
Content:
With production taking a hit, the rates have been witnessing an upward trend

HYDERABAD: Milk consumers are hit yet again. In the last 10 days, milk prices of private dairies have gone up by Rs 2 to Rs 6 per litre. The rate of toned milk is sold at Rs 50 now and that of whole milk Rs 68 per litre.The state-run Vijaya Dairy toned milk costs Rs 48 per litre, while private dairies like Tirumala, Arokya, Dodla, Tirumala and Heritage are selling at Rs 48 to Rs 50. The price of Amul milk, which is sold at Rs 46 a litre, is also likely to go up in the next few days, said sources.Officials attribute the spiralling effect in prices to milk production seeing a dip in Telangana . With production taking a hit, the rates have been witnessing an upward trend. Officials said this phenomenon of milk shortage happens once five years.One main reason for the shortfall in the production, officials say, could be due to dairy farmers switching over to agriculture. “With ground water levels going up and irrigated water supply increasing, many dairy farmers got into farming as they thought it is more lucrative,” an official said.While this has led to reduction in milk production, officials point out that it has also caused less procurement of milk. “We are forced to increase the rates as farmers are expecting higher returns,” a representative of a private dairy said. Traders said the farmers were supplying milk to only those who are offering them a better price.The government-owned Vijaya Dairy has also increased milk procurement rate from Rs 2 toRs 4 in this month alone.There are about two lakh farmers who sell milk to dairies run by cooperative societies in Karimnagar and Mulkanoor. Apart from these, there are 22 lakh independent dairy farmers who own cattle and sell milk.

Title: Bundi administration to urge Rajasthan government to revamp old river bridges
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The bridge where the incident took place had no railing to prevent the bus from falling off it

JAIPUR: Bundi district administration will write to the state government regarding the dismal condition of the bridges on rivers in the state. In the Bundi accident, where the bus lost control and fell into the river , the bridge had no horizontal component to prevent the vehicle from falling off it. The bridge only had small cement pillars, which barely served any purpose.

Antar Singh Nehra, district collector, Bundi said, “The bridge from which the bus fell into the river had vertical component but no horizontal ones which could prevent the vehicle from falling into the water body. The bus broke past the pillar which was completely shattered. The bridge was constructed nearly 40 years ago and since then, has been in the same condition.”

According to officials, there are many such bridges not just in Bundi but across the state which could also lead to similar incidents. “We have found that there are other bridges in the district which also have similar pillars and are dangerous. We will also look at the original plans of the bridges as to how they were planned with the pillars but no complete boundary,” added the collector.

According to the officials, the bridge was constructed by RIDCO many decades back and the collector added, “At present, no action can be taken against anyone as RIDCO had made this bridge years ago. Nowadays, they do not do this kind of construction, but we will try to get the original plans from them.”

Seeing the severity of the accident, which could have been prevented if there was a higher boundary wall, the official said, “We will be writing to the state government requesting them to ask the concerned department to review such bridges and possibly take some measures so that they can be upgraded so that such accidents can be prevented in future.”

Title: AAP leaders demand completion of canal work pending since 4 decades
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

KOLHAPUR: During a meeting with district collector Bhausaheb Galande on Wednesday, a delegation of the Aam Aadmi Party’s district unit demanded the completion of Warna dam’s canal work as well as water supply from the same for irrigation purposes.

They said that the Warna’s left irrigation canal has not been completed although the land has been handed over to the government 40 years ago. They said that the farmers who transferred part of their farmlands to the government for developing the canal have to depend on the irrigation schemes of co-operative societies which charge huge sum of money.

Sharad Patil, head of Shahuwadi tehsil unit of the party, said, “Over 150 acres of land was taken by the state government for rehabilitating the people affected by Warna dam and the construction of the canal. Then government had assured the farmers that they will get water from the canal. However, the canal has not yet been constructed and the farmers still await water supply from it. We have to depend on the lift irrigation schemes of co-operative societies for which Rs 60,000 per hectare is being charged. If the canal work would have completed, we could have got water for irrigation purposes at just Rs 4,000 per hectare.”

The members of the delegation, mostly farmers, demanded that the government should give their land back as the canal has not been constructed. They also demanded that the government should compensate for the charges that the farmers had paid to co-operative societies.
