The farmers claimed that Warna irrigation project was supposed to provide water in Shirala taluka of Sangli district as well as Hatkanangle, Shirol and Panhala talukas of Kolhapur district. The project was commissioned in 1985.

Title: ‘Floods, record temperatures clear sign of climate change’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Thrissur: The forest fires severely affect the small species in the forest areas, said former KFRI director in charge Dr P S Essa.

Addressing a workshop about climate change and forest fire at Thrissur press club on Tuesday he said the present fire prevention methods by the forest department are not capable of preventing the forest fires.

“A study found that, when a forest fire occurs in an area the temperature of that area will rise to 300 to 800 degree Celsius and it will affect the vegetation of the entire area,” he said.

“Controlled burning is also not capable of preventing the fires. In most cases, officials can’t control it and it ends up gutting more forest lands. To prevent the forest fires, a more capable system should be developed,” he said.

Climatologist Gopakumar Cholayil said that climate change is clearly visible in our state.

“During the last Christmas season there was no dip in temperature. Then we expected that cool climate would arrive in February this year,” said Cholayil.

But the mercury continues to soar and highest temperatures were recorded in many districts in February. If the same situation continues the heat waves will be recorded in the state on March, he added.

“If the temperature rose over 40 degree Celsius it will be considered as a heat wave. We are now witnessing extreme events like floods and high temperature and it is the clear indication of climate change,” he said.

KFRI principal scientist Dr T V Sajeev said that if the forest fire occurs in a region it will affect the existence of the forest and nearby people.

“The canopy fire in the forest areas are more dangerous and it will affect the vegetation of the evergreen forest areas,” said Sajeev.

Thrissur Press club president K Prabhath, Secretary M V Vineetha also attended the workshop.

Title: Burglars flee with gold as couple goes on vacation
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hyderabad: A couple’s wedding anniversary ended on a bitter note after burglars made away with 30 tola gold and a kg of silver from their Tilak Nagar residence when they were holidaying in Ooty. Shiva Kumar, a techie and his wife are residents of Nallakunta.

“On Monday the house owner informed the duo that their house window was open and it looks suspicious. The couple returned on Wednesday,” Nallakunta inspector K Muralidhar said.

The couple noticed that 30 tolas of gold , a kg of silver jewellery and other items were missing. A case was registered under Section 380 of the IPC.TNN

Title: Rajasthan: Man survived crash but lost his family in bus tragedy
Content:
Rescue operation being carried out at Mej river in Bundi on Wednesday

JAIPUR: Though it was a lucky escape for Amit Dhobi, the Bundi bus mishap claimed the lives of his 23 relatives.“We were talking and suddenly there was a loud noise and in two seconds we were in the river,” said Amit while narrating the events that transpired before the bus plunged into the river.“We were sitting and chatting with each other when the bus climbed the bridge at a slow speed when suddenly there was a very loud noise and the bus stopped. Two seconds after the noise, the bus was in the river. It went into water in such a position that everyone got trapped beneath leaving very little chance for anyone to escape.”According to Amit, it seemed that the bus gear got stuck, “We were not speeding, but the gear got stuck because of which it went over the bridge. We didn’t hear any sound of the tyre bursting.” He was the first one to get out of the bus and was lucky to have not sustained any major injuries in the accident which killed 23 members of his familyAmit suffered minor injuries and was released after treatment. The bus was pulled out from the river on Wednesday evening. “I lost everyone in the accident including my mother, sister, her children, uncles, grandmother, younger siblings, brother-in-law and other relatives. My whole family is gone suddenly in a matter of seconds.”

Title: Coronavirus: Ashwini Patil on her way to Delhi with other Indians
Content: KOLHAPUR: Ashwini Patil , the woman from Satara who had been stranded in China’s Wuhan since the coronavirus outbreak, and five others from the state will be among 90 Indians to be evacuated late on Wednesday night.At the time of filing the report on Wednesday evening, Ashwini had already reached the Wuhan-based international airport. Ashwini confirmed via WhatsApp that she was awaiting further formalities at the airport.On Wednesday morning, she had tweeted: “At least we have clearance from the Chinese government. We will be evacuated today. See you all soon.”She said all the evacuees have been informed about the quarantine period and other formalities that they have to undergo once they land in India.Ashwini had been stranded in her flat since February 7 and was managing alone with limited resources. She had moved to Wuhan in June 2019 with her Polish husband Alan Goldmann. Alan had to leave Wuhan as he had developed an ear infection and needed urgent medical attention.Apart from Ashwini, other citizens of the state stranded in Wuhan are from Latur, Jalgaon, Dhule, Ahmednagar, and Kolhapur. However, they are not willing to interact with the media.Earlier, in a series of tweets on February 17, the Indian embassy in China had stated: “GoI will send a consignment of medical supplies on a relief flight to Wuhan later this week to support China to fight the COVID-19 epidemic. On its return, the flight will have limited capacity to take on board Indians wishing to return to India from Wuhan/Hubei.”Subsequently, the embassy had attributed the delay to the Chinese government, which had not given clearance to the Indian Air Force’s biggest aircraft — C-17 Globemaster — that was to be sent with medical supplies as well as to evacuate the Indians stranded in Wuhan.

Title: Now, teachers’ association demands 5 day week for ZP schools
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Nagpur: After the state government’s decision to shift to a five-day week for its various departments, two big associations representing government schoolteachers in Maharashtra say they don’t want their members to be left out.

The Maharashtra Rajya Prathmik Shikshak Sangh (MRPSS) and Maharashtra Rajya Shikshak Parishad (MRSP) say teachers must also get benefit of the new policy as they too are, government employees.

Rajaram Warute, president of MRPSS said, “We are demanding this specifically for teachers of zilla parishad schools. There are about 2.75 lakh ZP schoolteachers who will benefit from this decision.”

Warute said he is camping in Mumbai, due to the ongoing legislature session, and has given a memorandum to senior leaders from both MVA and the opposition. “This demand is in fact coming from parents as they now have a five day week and say the same should be applicable for their children,” said Warute.

Puja Choudhari, a senior leader of MRSP said there is nothing wrong is extending the benefit to teachers. “We had been supporting this demand since 2011. Our association is of the view that if there is no detrimental effect on the quality of teaching then there is no reason why schools can’t have a five day week,” said Choudhari.

Under Right to Education Act (RTE), schools are required to remain open for over 200 days and the five day week proposal is likely to clash with that. However Warute says they have found a solution to the legal problem. “The minimum requirement for schools being open is also calculated in hours. So for primary section schools need to be open for minimum 600 hours which can be fulfilled by increasing the daily school timings.”

MRPSS proposes to add anywhere between an hour to 90 minutes to the daily schedule to cover up for the time lost. “We believe that shifting to a 10.30am to 5.30pm or beyond schedule will be an effective solution. At least students get two days off which will help them to get refreshed,” said Warute.

Title: Surrogacy bill to benefit widows & divorcees too
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Women and child development (WCD) minister Smriti Irani along with Cabinet minister Prakash Javadekar (ANI pho... Read More

NEW DELHI: Accepting key recommendations from a parliamentary select committee, the Cabinet on Wednesday approved the Surrogacy (Regulation) Bill, 2020 allowing a “willing woman” and not just a “close relative” to become a surrogate mother and proposing that widows and divorced women can also benefit from its provisions, besides infertile Indian couples.

The proposed insurance cover for a surrogate mother has also now been increased to 36 months from 16 months earlier.

The bill aims to regulate surrogacy while prohibiting commercial surrogacy and allowing altruistic ones, Cabinet minister Prakash Javadekar said after the meeting.

Women and child development (WCD) minister Smriti Irani added that only Indian couples, with both partners being of Indian origins, can opt for surrogacy in the country.

The 15 major changes suggested by the 23-member Rajya Sabha select committee, headed by Bhupendra Yadav, included omission of five-year wait period before opting for surrogacy, and allowing single women – either divorcee or widow – in the 35- to 45-year age group and Persons of Indian Origin (PIOs) to avail surrogacy.

The previous bill was passed by the Lok Sabha on August 5, 2019, but was referred to the select committee by the Upper House after members raised concerns over clauses such as allowing only altruistic surrogacy with a near relative as a surrogate and not allowing single woman or with the definition of infertility in the proposed legislation.

The Rajya Sabha select committee that examined the bill argued that restricting the surrogate mother to a “close relative” potentially affects the availability of surrogate mothers. “A willing woman shall act as a surrogate mother and be permitted to undergo surrogacy procedures as per the provisions of this Act,” the committee said in its report.

Advocating for the need to allow single woman, it said : “There are conditions under which a single person genuinely needs to avail surrogacy as an option to have a child. One such situation is a young aged widow, who is otherwise capable but cannot carry a child because of fear of social stigma attached to pregnancy of widows in our society.”

After the Cabinet meeting on Wednesday, Irani said PM Narendra Modi has led from the front with a liberal view on the issues of reproductive rights of women, be it medical termination of pregnancy, the Assisted Reproductive Technology Regulation Bill or the surrogacy bill . The Cabinet last week also approved the long pending ART Regulation Bill.

The Surrogacy Regulation Bill, , 2020 – which proposes to regulate surrogacy by setting up a National Surrogacy Board and State Surrogacy Boards along with appropriate authorities in the states and Union Territories – is likely to be tabled in the second half of the budget session beginning next month.

Title: Madras Eye Infection: ‘Madras eye’ is back, with fever, cough
Content:
Madras eye is back, with fever, cough

CHENNAI: Several people are walking into eye clinics with red, itchy eyes and opthalmologists say the season for conjunctivitis has just begun.While adults complain of watery eyes, children are showing symptoms of fever, cold and sore throat, along with conjunctivitis.“The viral disease, unlike what we saw last year, isn’t serious. Most people don’t require medication. It settles down in five days. But this time we are seeing many children with flu-like symptoms,” said opthalmologist Dr V Vasumathi of Radhatri Nethralaya. “They may need no medication for the eye, unless there is an associated bacterial infection causing eye inflammation or vision disruption,” she said.Childcare specialists call the condition pharyngoconjunctival fever. “We see this often in school children. It is caused by a virus, usually the adenovirus, and is contagious,” said Dr S Balasubramanian, medical director of Kanchi Kamakoti Childs Trust. This type of fever peaks in summer, particularly when children are in camps and swimming pools, he said. Some children may also complain of fatigue and and upset stomach.Most patients are treated as outpatient and advised to stay athome. They are askedto come back if they notice photophobia (unable to see light), swelling of the eye, vision disruption or a cloudy cornea. “The viral disease is contagious and can spread quickly in classrooms or closed office spaces,” said Dr S Soundari, head of medical services, Agarwal Eye Hospital. “We are commonly seeing at least seven to eight people a day, compared to the usual one or two, or none,” she said.However, unlike last year when most patients had bleeding and severe swelling of the eye, symptoms were milder. “The best thing to do is prevention. And if you are infected, see a doctor and stay in isolation,” she said.

Title: Gunman kills 5 at Milwaukee brewery before taking own life
Content:
Police and emergency officials work at an active shooting scene at the Molson Coors headquarters in Milwaukee ... Read More

MILWAUKEE: An employee opened fire Wednesday at one of the nation's largest breweries in Milwaukee, killing five fellow workers before taking his own life, police said.The assailant who attacked the Molson Coors complex was identified as a 51-year-old Milwaukee man who died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, police said.``There were five individuals who went to work today, just like everybody goes to work, and they thought they were going to go to work, finish their day and return to their families. They didn't _ and tragically they never will,'' Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett said.Authorities offered no immediate motive for the attack and did not release details about the shooter or how the shooting unfolded.None of the victims was identified. Police, who were still contacting relatives, said identities would not be released for at least 24 hours. No one was wounded beyond those who were killed, authorities said.Officers worked for hours to clear the more than 20 buildings in the complex where more than 1,000 people work. They announced at a late evening news conference that the work was done and all employees had been allowed to go home. Police Chief Alfonso Morales said authorities believe the shooter operated alone.President Donald Trump addressed the shooting before speaking at the White House about his administration's efforts to combat the coronavirus.``Our hearts break for them and their loved ones,'' the president said. ``We send our condolences. We'll be with them, and it's a terrible thing, a terrible thing.''The attack occurred at a sprawling complex that includes a mix of corporate offices and brewing facilities. The complex is widely known in the Milwaukee area as ``Miller Valley,`` a reference to the Miller Brewing Co . that is now part of Molson Coors.Molson Coors CEO Gavin Hattersley called the shooter ``an active brewery employee.''``Unfortunately, I am devastated to share that we lost five other members of our family in this tragic incident,'' he said in an email sent to employees. ``There are no words to express the deep sadness many of us are feeling right now.''He said the office would be closed the rest of the week and the brewery shuttered ``for the time being'' to give people time to cope.A group of brewery employees gathered at a nearby bar to talk about what had happened.``We are all a family. We work a lot of hours together, so we're all very sad,'' said Selena Curka, a brewery employee who was about to start her shift when the complex went on lockdown and she was turned away.``It's just weird, because nine times out of 10 you're going to know the shooter,`` said another employee Thomas Milner. ``It's a tight-knit family. Within the brewery we all interact with each other.''Milner was also on his way to work when the shooting happened, and he was turned away too.James Boyles told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel that his wife, Lasonya Ragdales, works at Molson Coors in the claims department. She was texting from inside the facility and told her husband that there was an active shooter and she was locked in a room with a bunch of co-workers, the Journal Sentinel newspaper reported.``Miller Valley'' features a 160-year-old brewery, with a packaging center that fills thousands of cans and bottles every minute and a distribution center the size of five football fields. A massive red Miller sign towers over the complex and is a well-known symbol in Milwaukee, where beer and brewing are intertwined in the city's history.The facility is also home to corporate customer service, finance, human resources and engineering departments. Tours take people to underground caves where beer was once stored, a saloon with intricate woodwork, a stein hall with stained-glass windows, a champagne room meeting hall with leaded-glass windows, and an outdoor beer garden that can hold 300 people.Molson Coors announced in October that it planned to close a Denver office as part of a restructuring to eliminate 400 to 500 jobs. The reorganization was to benefit Milwaukee, which was expected to see hundreds of corporate and support jobs relocated there.Before Wednesday's shooting, there had been three mass killings nationwide in 2020, with 12 total victims. All have been shootings. In 2019, there were 44 mass killings, with 224 total victims. The Associated Press/USA TODAY/Northeastern University Mass Killings database tracks all U.S. homicides since 2006 involving four or more people killed, not including the offender, over 24 hours regardless of weapon, location, victim-offender relationship or motive.The last mass shooting in the Milwaukee area was in August 2012, when white supremacist Wade Michael Page fatally shot six people and wounded four others at a Sikh temple in suburban Oak Creek. Page killed himself after being wounded in a shootout with police. The worst mass shooting in the area in the past 20 years was in 2005, when seven people were killed and four wounded at a church service in Brookfield, a Milwaukee suburb. The shooter killed himself.Shortly before word of the brewery shooting broke, Republican Senate Majority Leader Scott Fitzgerald told reporters in suburban Franklin that state gun laws would not be changing despite a push by Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat, to do so, according to a report in the Journal Sentinel.Evers called lawmakers into special session late last year to consider expanding background checks and allowing guns to be taken from people deemed a threat. But the Republican-controlled Legislature adjourned without action. Fitzgerald later called the shootings ``an act of evil,'' the Journal Sentinel reported.At a news conference outside Molson Coors, Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes said, ``We shouldn't accept this.'' He took up the issue later on social media, tweeting: ``Another avoidable uniquely American tragedy. It's not normal, we should never accept it, and we should never relent when 'leaders' offer hollow thoughts and prayers but choose inaction.``In Video: Gunman kills 5, self at Milwaukee brewery

Title: 505 ancient gold coins unearthed in Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Temple officials said the coins, which had letters resembling Arabic etched on them, could date back to 1000-1... Read More

TRICHY: A treasure trove of 505 gold coins weighing 1,716 grams surfaced when workers were digging the ground at the Akilandeswari Jambukeswarar temple at Thiruvanaikaval in Trichy on Wednesday. Temple officials said the coins, which had letters resembling Arabic etched on them, could date back to 1000-1200CE.

The temple workers engaged in renovation work stumbled upon a copper vessel with the coins near the Amman Sannathi. On being informed, officials of the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowment (HR&CE) recovered the vessel and counted the coins in the presence of a policeman.

The officials said the temple administration was clearing the bushes and digging the ground for around 7 feet when they found the vessel.

Though the coins' period or antique value could not be determined yet, the HR&CE officials roughly estimated their value at 68 lakh.

"I have informed the state archaeology department to assess the coins and ascertain the period the coins belong to. Till then, they will be kept in the district treasury," collector Sivarasu told ToI.

Though the coins were found around 1 pm, the temple officials had kept it under wraps until 7pm. As soon as he was informed, the collector ordered the temple officials to immediately hand over the treasure to the tahsildar of the Srirangam taluk office.

Despite repeated attempts, executive officer of the temple Mariappan could not be contacted.

Title: Delhi violence latest news: Houses burnt, many Muslims find shelter in Hindu homes
Content: NEW DELHI: Their homes are gone, their livelihoods destroyed. But the 40-odd Muslim residents of northeast Delhi's Ashok Nagar found brotherhood and hope amid the smouldering ruins.When a mob burnt down their homes and shops on Tuesday, the Hindu neighbours gave them more than succour -they opened their homes to the victims.A 1,000-strong mob had entered the colony near Badi Masjid around 1pm. They barged into the mosque where at least 20 people were offering prayers. "I was at the mosque when suddenly a huge group of people entered and started shouting slogans. We ran to save our lives," recalled Khursheer Alam, standing outside the remains of his house, which was among six ransacked and set ablaze by the rioters.Delhi violence: Live updatesThe mob also vandalised the mosque and set it ablaze. Mohammad Tayyab, a local, said the mob reached the terrace of the building around 1.30pm, and hoisted the tricolour and a saffron flag. These were removed by locals on Wednesday morning.Locals in the area kept asking the rioters not to damage any property, but they didn't listen. All of them were outsiders. "Most of the men in the group had covered their faces and were armed with iron rods. Soon, they started burning down the shops in the area. We were afraid that we would be killed," said Rajesh Khatri, a resident of Ashok Nagar.After targeting the shops, the men headed towards the six houses. "There are just six Muslim families living in the neighbourhood and these men knew about us for sure because they did not target any other house. They didn't leave a thing, looted everything. Now we are homeless," said Mohammed Rashid."However, when we thought we would be reduced to living on the streets, we were helped by our Hindu friends in the neighbourhood. They have been with us throughout, and have put us up in their homes. We have been living here for the past 25 years and never in these years have we had a single discord with any of our Hindu neighbours. We all co-exist here like a family," said Rashid.Said Pintu, their neighbour: "We will stand by them no matter what. We are also Hindus but can never even think of harming people or their property. Some of the shops that have been set on fire were owned by these families only. Now their homes and livelihoods both are destroyed. We will not let them be alone in their misery," he said.Neeraj Kumar, another resident of Ashok Nagar's gali number five, said people in the area were helping each other in the aftermath of the violence. "We did not recognise any of the rioters. People who stay here won't hurt each other as we have lived peacefully for years. There were two waves of attacks. One around 1 pm and another around 4 pm," said Kumar.Danish, whose home was one of the six which was burnt down, said they were helpless before the mob. "We called the police several times but they came an hour late. By that time, much of the damage had been done and they had ransacked most of the houses. The police then took our family to the police station for safety, where we spent the night," he said.It was not just the Muslims who suffered. Raj Kumar, who sold slippers from a shop directly underneath the masjid, had his establishment looted and burnt. "They spared no one. While my shop had been shut for the last few days, I had no idea this would happen in Ashok Nagar. I only came to inspect the shop on Wednesday morning and found it had been reduced to ashes," said Kumar.

Title: Kerala: Student outfits have no right to hold strikes on educational campuses, rules high court
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

KOCHI: Reiterating that student organizations do not have the right to compel students to participate in strikes nor do they have the right to conduct strikes on school or college campuses, the high court on Wednesday ordered heads of all educational institutions to promptly report such disturbances to police and asked the state police chief to direct police officers to take prompt action.

Justice P B Suresh Kumar issued the order after considering a total of 26 petitions filed by schools and colleges, with the lead case being a plea by Raju Kuruvilla, manager of MS Higher Secondary School at Ranni in Pathanamthitta, through advocate Jacob P Alex.

In the judgment, the court referred to a 2017 decision (Antony Thomas vs Muhammed Rafique) in which it was held that it is the obligation of police to ensure that academic atmosphere in educational institutions are not disturbed and that educational institutions cannot be hijacked or converted into a political battle field. The court also cited a 2003 decision (Vijayakumar V vs State of Kerala ), which held that police can enter campuses to prevent or take action against students engaging in criminal activities.

The court order said: “…organizations of students do not have the right to disrupt or disturb the academic and other activities of students who do not want to partake in their strikes and agitations, or any right to compel such students to forego the aforesaid activities in their campuses. Similarly, it is also declared that organizations of students do not have any right to convene any meetings and resort to the modes of agitations like strike, dharna, gherao, processions, etc in the school or college campuses… It is also declared that it is the obligation of the police to ensure that the fundamental rights of the students to pursue their academics in the campuses are not thwarted by anyone...”

However, the judgment does not mean that students cannot voice their opinions on political issues and redress their grievances by recourse to various forums allowed by statutes and executive orders.

The court said educational institutions are forced to approach the HC for police protection despite several judicial pronouncements regarding the rights of students. The position of government and quasi-government institutions is that students have to forego studies until disturbances and disruptions settle down naturally, the court said. It is the students who become victims of student unrest in campuses, the court said.

Noticing that judicial pronouncements alone won’t suffice, the court ordered, “…I deem it appropriate to direct the director of collegiate education, director of higher secondary education, director of public instruction and also the registrars of the universities in the state to bring this judgment to the notice of the heads of the educational institutions under them, and direct them to bring external and internal disturbances affecting the conduct of the classes forthwith to the notice of the police... There will also be a direction to the DGP to bring this judgment to the notice of the police officers...”

Title: North Karnataka hopes for a bonanza from Yediyurappa’s budget
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hubballi: Hopes are riding high on chief minister BS Yediyurappa ’s budget , slated to be presented in the next week. The people of Dharwad, and North Karnataka , who were instrumental in steering the BJP to power both during the assembly elections in 2018 and in the bypolls held late last year, are hoping for a veritable bonanza from the BJP government.

Former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy, who led the JD(S)-Congress coalition government for 14 months, had drawn flak for neglecting North Karnataka in his maiden budget speech in 2018. Now, with Yediyurappa set to present the budget after the collapse of the Kumaraswamy-led coalition government, expectations of a large corpus of funds being allocated in all sectors, particularly for infrastructure.

Among the longstanding demands of the people of North Karnataka is for the setting up of a special economic zone (SEZ), which they are convinced will give a fillip to industrial development in the region and help solve the problem of unemployment. The failure of successive governments to earmark funds towards this initiative has been a source of discontent among the people. Now, people are hoping for allocation of funds for an SEZ in Hubballi-Dharwad, in addition to announcement of three or four industrial parks in the rest of North Karnataka.

The lack of a visionary document such as the comprehensive development plan (CDP) for Hubballi-Dharwad, among the urban centres chosen for the Smart Cities project, highlights the ironical situation that the twin cities find themselves in. Stakeholders have reportedly appealed to Yediyurappa to make an allocation for a new CDP in this year’s budget. The CM has also been requested to divert funds to ensure an efficient solid waste management (SWM) mechanism is in place in Hubballi-Dharwad. Civic groups and stakeholders in the industrial sector are hoping that the mechanism emulates the one in Dubai and thereby serves as a model for the other cities of the region. There is also a demand for upgrading of all roads connecting Hubballi-Dharwad with other urban centres of the state. Pressure is also being exerted on the state government to ensure sufficient funds for the truck terminal proposed to be built in Hubballi. Those keen on the project pointed to Hubballi’s strategic location on the road network – it is a nodal point on five national highways – as the rationale for setting up such a terminal in the city.

President of the Karnataka Chamber of Commerce and Industry , Hubballi Mahendra Ladhad told TOI that allocation of funds for infrastructure, speedy internet connectivity and uninterrupted power supply would inspire confidence in the IT/BT sector to invest in the twin cities. “There is also a need to upgrade the bypass road to a four-lane road, and funds need to be earmarked towards this,” he added.

Ladhad also expressed the need for the state government to set the wheels in motion for the setting up of skill development centres for aerospace industries, and silk production in the region. “This will help many youngsters, including those enrolled in ITI courses to hone their skills. Also, the CM must announce the setting up of a Food Safety and Standards of India centre in Hubballi-Dharwad, which will eliminate the need for local manufacturers to go to Pune and Bengaluru to get their products certified,” said Ladhad, asking the CM to take note of the scope for growth of the food processing industry in North Karnataka.

Calling for reforms in agro-based industries, Ladhad added, “All agriculture produce market committee (APMC) units must be upgraded, and all facilities provided at these plants. Cess levied on agricultural produce must be reduced from 1.5% to 0.5%, and rules passed mandating holding a review meeting of the APMC once every three months.”

Pointing to the central government’s approval for setting up the Central Institute of Plastic Engineering and Technology in Hubballi-Dharwad, Ladhad said that the CM’s budget should ensure sufficient allocation for the centre. Setting up of solar parks in North Karnataka and establishing a maize processing centre in Ranebennur in Haveri district, in addition to pumping funds to boost tourism in the region are among the other demands.

Ladhad also highlighted the need for the state government to clear the decks for the implementation of the Dr Nanjundappa Report. “We are hopeful of the CM honouring our demands,” he added.

Title: Man found dead in KSRTC bus
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Mangaluru: An unidentified person who was travelling in a KSRTC bus was found dead near Bantwal, on Wednesday. According to police, the person had reserved a ticket to Mudigere in Chikkamagaluru district.

Police said that the incident took place on the bus plying to Chikkamagaluru from Mangaluru. On reaching Bantwal, the bus conductor noticed that pthe assenger aged about 45 to 50, did not respond, and it was found that he was dead. The body was shifted to a government hospital in Bantwal. Police said that the deceased had two stitches on his chest, which is suspected to be due to some operation. A case has been registered at the Bantwal town police station.

Title: Officials’ errors have deprived flood victims of rightful compensation, says Vinay Kulkarni
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Dharwad: Growing frustration with mistakes committed by officials in assessing damage to property during the floods that ravaged North Karnataka last year prompted victims of the natural calamity, and Congress workers to take out a rally to protest the inefficiency of the administrative machinery in Dharwad on Thursday. Former minister and senior Congress member Vinay Kulkarni was among those at the head of the protesters.

The rally, which started at Kadapa Maidan proceeded through several thoroughfares of Dharwad before concluding at the deputy commissioner’s office, where the protesters sat in a dharna.

Kulkarni said that the government had classified properties under three categories based on the extent of damage (A, B and C). “However, the surveyors have committed several mistakes and some victims who have suffered extensive damage have been denied their rightful compensation,” he added.

Pointing to the extensive loss of crops and property that North Karnataka had suffered owing to the spate, the former minister said, “Roads in various villages have been washed away nearly entirely. But the officials, instead of conducting a survey using strict scientific guidelines, appear to have succumbed to political pressure. They have disbursed funds meant for the victims to relatives of political leaders.”

Kulkarni alleged that Manjula Kallur, a flood victim, had taken the extreme step of ending her life a few days ago after she failed in getting the compensation rightly due to her. “The government must ensure that her bereaved family is duly compensated,” he added.

Kulkarni also expressed outrage with nationalised banks issuing notices to flood victims seeking repayment of loans. He questioned the rationale behind asking farmers, busy trying to rebuild their life after the floods, could be expected to repay their debts. “The banks must stop issuance of such orders immediately,” he said.

The senior Congress member, who submitted a memorandum addressed to chief minister BS Yediyurappa to the deputy commissioner seeking redressal for the flood victims’ grievances, also called on the central government to turn its attention to generation of employment.

Title: Heritage HDMC office to turn smart and green
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hubballi: The civic corporation office on Lamington Road, which is a heritage building, and Lamington School are set to get a green makeover soon, replete with solar panels and plantation on campus. The facelift will come at a cost of Rs 5 crore under the Smart City Project.

The park in front of Chittagupi Hospital will also be redeveloped.

“The buildings will have solar panels to generate electricity which will reduce their dependence on power companies. The Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation office and other buildings on the campus have set up rainwater harvesting systems already,” said SH Naregal, special officer of the Hubballi-Dharwad Smart City Limited (HDSCL). “We also plan to grow native vegetation in these locations. The makeover will be in keeping with Indian Green Building Council regulations.

“The campuses will be lit with solar-powered piezoelectric crystals. Smart dustbins will be placed and a smart waste disposal system will be adopted in these buildings,” Naregal said. “The HDMC main building, which is a major landmark in the city, and the park near it, will become must-visit spots.”

An HDSCL officer on condition of anonymity said the project has been in the pipeline for long. Tenders were invited thrice but vendors failed to meet the criteria in the technical bid, he said.

Title: KPSC applicants in a fix as Aadhaar not allowed for ID proof
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Hubballi: Applicants to the post of gazetted probationers are facing a hurdle in the very first step – the Karnataka Public Service Commission has not included Aadhaar as an eligible identity proof. Graduates from rural and rurban areas, who make up a majority of the applicants, say Aadhaar is the most commonly available document and this is not being accepted for submission of forms.

KPSC has listed voter ID, driving licence, passport and PAN card as admissible ID proofs. The last date for submission of applications is March 6.

Earlier this month, KPSC issued the notification for 106 gazetted probationers’ posts for 2017-18. These include the posts of deputy SP of police; assistant commissioner for labour and commercial taxes, tahsildar, and assistant director in several departments. Graduation is the minimum required qualification.

While applicants said they had called the helpline number and complained and would submit a memorandum, KPSC authorities said they had heard no opposition. “We have not received any complaint in this regard. We feel candidates will have a voter ID or driving licence for sure by the time they complete their degree. We cannot make Aadhaar card mandatory for recruitment because that might create a legal issue. We will check with the Union government and decide,” said KPSC secretary G Sathyavathi.

“Most graduates never get around to applying for a passport. They get a PAN card when they need to share it with the employer. By asking for these documents, KPSC is indirectly excluding rural youths and candidates from the middle and lower middle classes,” said Renuka Kanakammanavar, another applicant. “Arts and commerce graduates generally don’t apply for a passport or PAN card immediately after their degree,” said Rajeshwari.

Ambarish Bannikoppa from Gadag district said he got his bachelors degree from KKS College in Hubballi. “Students like me who have studied outside home have not got a passport, PAN card, voter ID or driving licence made. But we have had to provide Aadhaar number for admission and scholarship even at the school level. We will not be able to apply if KPSC does not allow Aadhaar,” he said.

“I cannot get a passport or PAN card done before March 6. I’m losing all hope of submitting my application,” said Santosh Naikwadi of Vijayapura.

Savita, Geetakka, Poornima, Venkatesh and Sanjeev said they had been to a cybercafe to submit their application but Aadhaar was not being accepted. “The KPSC helpline numbers are either switched off or they failed to address our grievance,” Poornima said.

Title: Gram panchayat chief arrested in suicide case
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Udupi: Shirva police on Wednesday arrested president of Mudarangadi gram panchayat David D’Souza in connection with the suicide case of Fr Mahesh D’Souza, principal of Don Bosco English Medium School.

According to police, the accused was arrested at around 2pm on charges of abetting the suicide of Fr Mahesh D’Souza. The court sent him to judicial custody for 14 days.

On October 11, 2019, Fr Mahesh D’Souza was found dead in the school chamber in Shirva. Though it was suicide, a case of unnatural death was registered at Shirva police station.

Title: Desi flyers asked to avoid travel to South Korea, Iran, Italy
Content:
Workers spray disinfectant as a precaution against the coronavirus at a bus garage in Seoul, South Korea, on W... Read More

NEW DELHI: With a spike in coronavirus cases, mainly in countries outside China, India has once again revised its travel advisory asking citizens to avoid non-essential travel to Republic of Korea, Iran and Italy Meanwhile, a flight from Wuhan carrying around 120 passengers including some foreign nationals is expected to reach Delhi airport at 4 am on Thursday, sources in ITBP said.The ITBP quarantine facility has been kept ready to receive Indians and friendly nations’ citizens from Wuhan - the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak in China.While immigration process will take around an hour, the evacuees will be screened at the airport isolation bay by a team of doctors from ITBP. After this, these people will be taken to ITBP’s Chhawla Camp – which also housed over 400 evacuees earlier and released them after 17 days of isolation when all cases tested negative of coronavirus infection.The new batch of evacuees will also be kept at the ITBP quarantine facility for the required period, the official said.Besides, travellers from Republic of Korea, Iran and Italy or having such travel history since February 10 may be quarantined for 14 days on arrival to India, the health ministry’s fresh advisory said.The new travel advisory, issued on 26 February will be applicable along with the existing advisories against travel to China. The last one issued on February 22 advised citizens to avoid all non-essential travel to Singapore.The update comes in view of the evolving situation related to coronavirus being reported from these countries.Currently, passengers from China, Hong Kong, Thailand, South Korea , Singapore, Japan, Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia and Nepal are screened at 21 designated airports in the country for possible exposure to the virus infection.The WHO has declared the recent outbreak as epidemic affecting 30 countries as public health emergency of international concern.

Title: System to help keep real-time tabs on veggies
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

File image used for representation

NEW DELHI: The Centre on Wednesday launched a newly designed Market Intelligence and Early Warning System (MIEWS) which is a ‘first-of-its-kind’ platform for ‘real time monitoring’ of prices of tomatoes, onions and potatoes (TOP) and generating alerts for intervention simultaneously.

The system will forecast wholesale prices of these three key vegetables for three months and alert the government to take timely intervention in case of price crash due to a production glut.

The portal, launched by Union minister for food processing industries Harsimrat Kaur Badal , will disseminate all relevant information related to TOP crops such as prices and arrivals, area, yield and production, imports and exports, crop calendars and crop agronomy in an easy to use visual format.

The MIEWS is launched under the ‘Operation Greens’ scheme which was announced in the Budget 2018-19, with an outlay of Rs 500 crore, to stabilise supply of TOP crops and to ensure their availability throughout the country round the year without price volatility. The ‘Operation Greens’ is also meant to promote Farmer Producers Organisations (FPOs), agri-logistics , processing facilities and professional management.

The alerts under the system will be triggered when prices of these three perishable commodities fall to a three-year low level at the time of harvest or when the price fall is more than 50% from the year ago or when the fall in rates is lower than the benchmark fixed by Centre/state government for a specified period.

The portal will show wholesale prices of these three commodities from 128 markets, monitored by private firm Agriwatch, and data of 1,200 ‘mandis’ tracked by Agmark. It will show prices of both producing and consuming centres.

Under the ‘Operation Greens’ scheme, Badal said the government has approved a grant of Rs 161 crore for creation of five clusters in these three crops at producing centres. The total cost of these five clusters is Rs 425 crore and will benefit 15,000 farmers, she added.

Three onion clusters will come up in Maharashtra and Gujarat, one each cluster of potato and tomato will be developed in Gujarat and Andhra Pradesh, respectively. A storage capacity of 90,000 tonnes and processing capacity of 3.36 lakh tonne will come up in these five clusters.

Title: CBSE schools wary of mandatory Marathi rule
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Nagpur: The bill to make Marathi a compulsory subject in all schools is all set to become a law on Thursday as it will be tabled in the state legislature’s lower house where the government has sufficient numbers to pass it.

On Wednesday, the bill cleared the upper house without any hitch, making it clear that no party would be opposing it. Once the bill is passed, Marathi will be compulsory from Std I to X in all schools operating in the state.

In Nagpur, CBSE, ICSE and international board schools are, however, unhappy with the ‘mandatory’ tag citing ground realities.

Not wanting to speak openly considering the political sensitivity, a school’s trustee said, “What happens if a student comes from Kerala in Std IX or X due to the transfer of a parent? Do we expect the child to cope with Marathi at that level even though the language is alien to it?.”

Another CBSE school principal said “I have Marathi till Std VIII in my school and now I have to plan properly on how to proceed with the higher classes. I am sure CBSE will inform us about the curriculum well in advance.”

State education minister Varsha Gaikwad told the state legislature that the new policy will be implemented in a phased manner. Her short statement suggested that in the first phase, it will be only the primary section in which Marathi as a mandatory subject will be implemented. And going by the same statement, it seemed that the implementation of the policy in totality, till Std X, might take a couple of years.

A senior CBSE school principal said this seemed more of a game of one upmanship. “It’s almost like the state government wants to show who’s the boss. I’m sure they also know that it’s going to be chaotic for those getting transferred,” said the principal.

Another trustee of a school said this could even lead to people avoiding admissions in the state. “If an army officer is moving from Jaipur to Nagpur when his son is in Std IX, he would prefer to keep his family back there for a couple of years,” she said.

For all schools, the ball is now in CBSE’s court. “If it’s mandatory in Std X then CBSE comes into play immediately. They have to intimate us with all the details as it will affect the grade sheet with an additional mandatory subject,” said a principal.

Title: NIT sanctions Rs 33cr to develop 100 playgrounds
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Nagpur: Sheetal Ugale, chairperson of Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT), on Wednesday presented its budget for 2020-21. The outlay of the budget has reduced from Rs 388 crore this fiscal to Rs 311 crore as most Gunthewari layouts have been transferred to Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC). NIT’s seven street schemes in the city have also been transferred to NMC.

On expenditure side, NIT has sanctioned Rs 33 crore for development of 100 playgrounds in the city. This is the dream project of Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari.

NIT will spend Rs 17 crore on tarring of roads and other development works. Around Rs 4 crore will be spent on plantations in NIT gardens and development of gardens. NIT has received Rs 36.68 crore from local area development (LAD) funds of local MP and MLAs for development of e-library, Islamic cultural centre and other works in Manewada.

NIT will implement seventh pay commission for its employees and retired staffers. This will lead to an additional expenditure of Rs 87 crore. The civic agency expects Rs 2 crore from Gunthewari layouts that are still with NIT but it will have to spend Rs 30.45 crore on provision of civic amenities in these areas.

A source in NIT said that Nagpur Metropolitan Region Development Authority (NMRDA) will execute Koradi temple development, Futala multimedia show, Tajbagh dargah beautification, Chicholi museum, Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar convention centre etc. Houses under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (PMAY) will also be constructed by NMRDA.

According to the budget document, Rs 2.36 crore is the carry forward from 2019-20. NIT expects an income of Rs 311.30 crore in 2020-21 of which Rs 118.57 crore is capital receipts, Rs 80.66 crore is revenue receipts and advances and deposits will give Rs 29.70 crore.

The capital expenditure in 2020-21 is expected to be Rs 147.09 crore, revenue expenditure will be Rs 106.70 crore, advances and deposits will be Rs 54.68 crore. Total Rs 308.47 crore will be spent next fiscal.

Title: City homeopaths seek recruitment as govt docs
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Nagpur: Homeopathy practitioners from the city have demanded that they should get opportunity to work on government posts as doctors at health and wellness centres, 108 ambulances and in rural hospitals. Presently, only graduates of modern medicines (MBBS) and ayurveda (BAMS) can be recruited for the government jobs.

More than 900 homeopathy practitioners from Vidarbha had a meeting at Antarbharti Homeopathic Medical College (AHMC) in Dabha recently. Dr Dhanaji Bagal, dean of homeopathy at Maharashtra University of Health Sciences (MUHS) presided over the meet. Founder of AHMC Dr Madhukar Zite was felicitated on the occasion. Practising homeopaths also demanded that AIIMS Nagpur should have a separate homeopathy section.

“Nagpur is emerging as a medical hub of Central India, but we don’t have a government homeopathic college in city. AIIMS is now functioning and it has a separate AYUSH unit. We want homeopathy to get prominence in this unit,” said Dr Manish Patil of Orange City Homeopaths Association (OCHA).

“India has over 250 homeopathic medical institutes and around 2,50,000 homeopathic doctors. AHMC is one of the pioneering institutes in homeopathy. In last 45 years, it has trained more than 2,000 doctors. Unfortunately, such old institution in Nagpur still don’t have master’s degree (MD) course. This college should get 100 seat intake of BHMS and permission for MD course,” he added.

Title: West Bengal: Body in suitcase found on train
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

MECHEDA: The body of a man in his 30s was found inside an abandoned suitcase in a compartment of a Howrah-Mecheda Local that reached its destination of East Midnapore's Mecheda around 10.30pm on Tuesday. The body bore multiple injury marks. The victim is yet to be identified.

After all passengers got off the train, one of the cleaners spotted the suitcase wrapped in polythene lying under one of the seats of a general compartment. Finding it very heavy, they informed the GRP. The train was taken to the car shed with the suitcase in it. GRP men opened the suitcase and found the body. The man was dressed in a pair of grey trousers and a white shirt. The body was sent for post-mortem.

South Eastern Railway's senior divisional commercial manager Aditya Kumar Chowdhury said, "The body has been handed over to the GRP and state police."

GRP SP Kharagpur, A Pathak, said: "The body has been sent for post-mortem and a case has been lodged. All railway stations from Howrah to Mecheda has been alerted and with their help we are trying to identify the victim."

Title: Senior citizens to help the elderly at Mumbai police stations
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Wrinkled faces with grey hair will soon man dedicated help desks for the elderly at police stations in Mumbai. In a first, the police department will handpick senior citizens and train them to help individuals their age tackle common grievances.

The volunteers may mediate in squabbles or offer counseling, but they will have to direct the aggrieved to police officers if it is a serious issue involving law. The volunteers can meet senior citizens at public places to hear them out. Activists working for the welfare of the elderly have welcomed the move.

As a pilot project, help desks will come up at Malabar Hill and Vile Parle police stations next month. The volunteers will be selected after taking physical and mental fitness into account. They will be trained on what questions to ask and how best to resolve issues. They will work in shifts at the police stations.

Over the years, Mumbai Police have been following a system where beat constables keep a record of senior citizens living in their jurisdiction and visit their homes once a month to check on them. Police have also been running a helpline (1090) for senior citizens in distress. This system will be supplemented with a force of trained elderly volunteers who can be approached by any senior citizen having a grievance.

"This is a good move and will provide meaningful engagement to elders, particularly those in their 60s, many of whom are active. Senior citizens are an unused asset and trained elderly volunteers can bridge the gap between police and public," said Sailesh Mishra of the NGO, Silver Innings. He added that there are more than 100 associations for senior citizens registered in the city. "Members of these associations usually come together for yoga or spiritual discussions. They would be enthused to do social work," Mishra added.

Police are also contemplating creation of WhatsApp groups for volunteers from every locality, with one policeman added to the group in case assistance is required.

Title: Kerala: Ex-minister P Sankaran to be laid to rest today
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

People offer tribute to Congress leader P Sankaran when the body was brought to Kozhikode Town Hall on Wednesd... Read More

KOZHIKODE: P Sankaran , former minister and Congress leader who died on Tuesday night, will be laid to rest on the premises of his ancestral house at Perambra on Thursday.

Sankaran was admitted to the M V R Cancer Centre here a few months ago.

The body was taken to his house at Kadiyangad on Wednesday evening. Earlier, the body was placed at the house at Karikkamkulam , DCC office, Kozhikode Town Hall, Koyilandi Town Hall and the Congress office at Perambra for the public to offer tributes.

People from various walks of life offered tributes to the Congress leader who was active in Kozhikode's political circles for decades.

A member of the A K Antony cabinet in 2001, Sankaran was the minister of health and tourism. He became member of Parliament in 1998 by defeating M P Veerendrakumar.

He was also the general secretary of KPCC, president of the DCC, chairman of the district UDF, district president of the Youth Congress and member of the Calicut University Syndicate. Entering politics during the student days, Sankaran was a staunch follower of Congress stalwart K Karunakaran. It was the 'Leader' who persuaded him from joining police as sub-inspector and to continue in politics. Karunakaran was instrumental in getting him elected from the Koyilandi assembly constituency.

Title: 12 cities to get new air quality monitoring stations
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

NEW DELHI: State-run generation utility NTPC will help Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) set up 25 continuous ambient air quality monitoring stations (CAAQMS) across six states and three Union Territories, the company said on Wednesday.

The company will provide financial support of Rs 80 crore for installation of the air quality monitoring stations in Gwalior (Madhya Pradesh), Ranchi (Jharkhand), Patna (Bihar), Varanasi, Lucknow, Kanpur and Allahabad (all in Uttar Pradesh), Pimpri-Chinchwad (Maharashtra) and Madurai ( Tamil Nadu ).

CAAQMS will also be installed at Port Blair in Andaman & Nicobar Islands, Silvassa in Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman in UT of Daman & Diu. Data collected from these stations will be used for evaluation of air quality index for these cities.

Title: Chicken Price in Mumbai: Chicken prices drop over false virus scare in Mumbai
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: India may be insulated from the spread of coronavirus , but the myths and fears surrounding the disease are taking a toll. A few people are shying away from consuming chicken, causing prices to drop by 20%, though there is no established link between the disease and chickenAcross Bandra, Kurla, Andheri and Chembur, poultry shops reported that fear of the virus is driving down sales, forcing them to reduce rates. In Bandra, a family that bought chicken legs for Rs 200/kg not so long ago, purchased for Rs 160 on Monday.The owner of Aziz Broiler in Bandra said poultry farmers are suffering losses by disposing of birds at a 20% lower rate. Another shop Yaadgaar has dropped retail prices 'marginally' to Rs 90 per kg to lure consumers. Abdul Hafeez Qureshi, who owns Mumbai Mutton and Chicken Shop in Goregaon, said: "Even the WHO has not hinted at any link between the outbreak of coronavirus and chicken. Yet people are affected by baseless forwards on social media."

Title: Tamil Nadu: Mount-Poonamallee Road could turn into OMR 2.0 for IT firms
Content:
Housing Projects Being Dropped For Tech Parks Along Stretch

Poonamallee, the western gateway to Chennai, could soon emerge as the city’s second IT highway. The arterial road is attracting several realtors interested in developing IT parks.Interestingly, a new trend of housing projects being transformed into office spaces for IT firms is shaping up, with metro rail connectivity being the key driver to spark interest in real estate along the Mount-Poonamallee Road .At least two residential projects on land parcels at Porur and Poonamallee, which had applied for planning permission with the Chennai Metropolitan Development Authority (CMDA) for housing projects, were withdrawn to build multi-storeyed buildings to accommodate IT companies.R Murugesan, MD of ARAM Realty, said plans are afoot to convert a 15-acre plot at Poonamallee into an IT special economic zone. “We are developing an IT SEZ spread over 1.3 million square feet on the land parcel, which was earmarked for a residential- cum-mall complex three years ago,” he said.In fact, the developer had applied for planning approval to construct apartments, but changed his plans in the wake of the state government announcing a metro rail corridor linking Poonamallee with the rest of the city. “This has transformed the dynamics of utilising it for office space to house IT companies,” he said.A study conducted to explore the commercial potential of Mount-Poonamallee Road said that the metro rail line has made Poonamallee accessible for city residents as the travel time will be reduced. “Even rentals would be 50% lesser than IT parks on OMR and the core city that could attract mid-level multinational companies, BPOs, IT and ITES firms,” Murugesan, former CEO of Shriram IT SEZ said.The 15km stretch between St Thomas Mount and Poonamallee is witnessing an expansion of office space, with three IT parks offering 3.5 million square foot office space under construction at Porur.While the Mount-Poonamallee stretch has better groundwater availability as compared to OMR that depends on tankers for water supply, the proposed bus mofussil terminus for west-bound buses at Thirumazhisaiand the second airport at Parandur off Chennai - Bengaluru highway could prove to be the icing on the cake.Aslam Mohamed, joint managing director of Allied Investments and Housing Pvt Limited, who is executing a joint venture IT park project at Porur, said that their facility will be coming up in an area of 7,00,000 sq ft.“We sought planning permission from CMDA to construct an apartment complex in 2017. We switched over to building an IT park after the declaration of metro rail link to Porur,” he said. The development comes against the backdrop of the city recording high absorptions of commercial space in recent years -- more than 60 lakh square feet in 2019. Sanjay Chugh, city head, ANAROCK Property Consultants, said the rental yield at Poonamallee was 3.15% last year.“As long as connectivity via metro rail improves, there are higher chances of more projects coming up beyond Poonamallee,” he said.Another real estate consultant, Savills, said that there has also been a rising interest from co-living operators for this micro market given the sheer size of the workforce in the locality.“We are witnessing upcoming residential developments around these large IT parks, primarily to cater to the workforce, extending beyond Porur junction,” said Anup Vasanth, the firm’s Chennai managing director.With realtors showing preference for setting up IT parks in the suburbs, software companies could soon have a new address – OMR 2.0

Title: Impersonator hired by Chennai medical student wrote NEET in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

The father of the arrested student being escorted away by police

CHENNAI: A second-year student of Madras Medical College , who was arrested along with his father on Wednesday in connection with the NEET scam , had used an impersonator who took the entrance exam at a centre in Bihar, investigators have found.

The student was expelled from the college last October, but could not be booked till now because of delay in establishing mismatch of fingerprints on the NEET answer sheet and other documents submitted to the college during admission.

Police said K Deivendran, 53, a businessman who hails from Hosur, had paid 20 lakh to a Bengaluru-based broker to arrange an impersonator for his son. The broker is yet to be apprehended.

Deivendran told police that he met the mediator in Bengaluru through a common friend. A police officer said, "Once we arrest the mediator we may be able to get to many impersonators who wrote NEET on behalf of students from Tamil Nadu," said a police officer.

According to a press release, police arrested Deivendran and his son (name withheld) after scrutinizing documents submitted by the student to the Madras Medical College and the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE). A magistrate court in the city on Wednesday remanded them in judicial custody.

Police said the student enrolled in MMC in 2018 claiming that he had appeared for NEET at a centre in Gaya, Bihar, though he was born and brought up in Hosur. After the scrutiny found the papers suspicious, the college filed a police complaint which was forwarded to the CB-CID.

In October last year, news about a case of impersonation of a second year medical student in the Madras Medical College came up. College dean Dr R Jayanthi filed a police complaint at the Flower Bazaar police station, which was later transferred to CB-CID. There was so far no other complaint against anyone of the 2018 batch, said director of medical education Dr R Narayana Babu. Earlier he had asked all medical college deans to verify the credentials of first year students in MBBS and PG courses.

CB-CID police personnel have so far arrested 16 people including seven medical students, six parents and three middlemen.

Title: Mahie Gill: Don't want to do sensuous roles anymore
Content: Actor Mahie Gill has much more to offer as an artiste than just playing "sensuous" characters and the actor says her upcoming film, family comedy is her first step in the new direction.The film, directed by Gagan Puri , was a breath of fresh air for Mahie, who has made a name for herself by delivering powerful performances in movies such as 'Gulaal', ' Dev D ' and 'Sahib Biwi Aur Gangster'."When Gagan came to me, I really liked the script, I loved it. It was a breath of fresh air because the kind of films that I did earlier were very serious and sensuous. I needed a break from these roles and this is a comedy which I haven't explored much," the actor told in an interview.Mahie said she has been looking for opportunities to explore the alternate side of her personality for a long while, but film producers and directors still offer her similar characters."The kind of roles that were being offered to me, I was saying no to a lot of them. I don't want to continue doing sensuous roles. I did three parts of 'Sahib Biwi and Gangster' but after that I was continuously offered similar parts."I would love to do a part four of 'Sahib...' but not a similar film. If I want to try something in this genre, then I prefer to continue working on this franchise. But it becomes boring for an actor to do similar roles. Somewhere you have to take a stand for yourself."Mahie said she liked the film for two reasons -- her character was a Punjabi like her real self and the film was trip down memory lane."This character is so much like me. After 'Dev D', this is the first movie where I'm able to speak the way I'm do real life. Since I'm from Chandigarh, the character also has a Punjabi touch to it," she said."I miss the serials of that time, especially the sitcoms 'Dekh Bhai Dekh' and 'Yeh Jo Hai Zindagi'. Today, you turn on the TV and you're bombarded with the choices. You really don't know what to watch. But in the 80s, it was only Doordarshan and I now realise that most of their shows were ahead of their time," Mahie added.
