Title: You can't miss Mouni Roy's punjabi kurta look!
Content: Bollywood actress Mouni Roy never fails to impress us with her sartorial picks. The 34-year-old actress is known for her feminine fashion. While she's mostly spotted in modern silhouettes, currently the actress is trending for her latest ethnic look.Recently, the actress was spotted wearing a punjabi kurta set for a song shoot. For the song, Mouni wore a pastel-coloured short kurta, which she wore with patiala salwar. She accessorised the pink kurta with silver jewels. She was also seen wearing ethnic jhumka earrings and a statement bangle. For her hairdo, she opted for straight hair with a centre parting. Keeping her look comfy, she completed the look with mojari flats.While the actress teamed up her look with a simple dupatta, you can style such kurtas with festive and heavy dupattas to amp up the look. This kurta-set is the perfect pick for wedding festivities like haldi and mehendi. Just like Mouni, you can make a statement with ethnic jewellery and footwear.What do you think of Mouni's latest look? Let us know in the comment section below.

Title: Didi pens poem against violence, prays for peace
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Chief minister Mamata Banerjee has lamented over “…so many lives lost, not to return again” in a poem she wrote called ‘Hell’ that gave vent to her anguish over the Delhi communal violence. The poem also refers to a “storm raging the country at gunpoint” and a “search for an address getting lost”.

Banerjee, who is in Odisha on a four-day visit, earlier on Wednesday offered prayers at the Jagannath Temple in Puri seeking harmony and peace in the country.

Responding to a media query in Puri on the Delhi violence, the CM iterated her earlier statement. “We don’t want bloodshed, we want peace. I prayed for the same before Lord Jagannath.”

Banerjee is expected to meet her Odisha counterpart Naveen Patnaik at the latter’s home, Naveen Niwas, on Friday before the two attend the Eastern Zonal Council meeting here to be chaired by Union home minister Amit Shah later the same day.

Bihar and Jharkhand CMs Nitish Kumar and Hemant Soren respectively are also scheduled to attend the Shah-led meeting. Banerjee will come face to face with Shah and Naveen for the first time since the enactment of CAA, which the Odisha CM supports.

In the poem that she posted on her Facebook page, Banerjee wrote: “So much bloodshed, so many deaths, anger burning like fire, a Holi of blood, before the Holi of colours! Humanity a worst sufferer.”

“A peaceful country, turned violent, is it the end of democracy,” she asks in the poem and concludes by saying “The sacred land turns into hell”.

Before leaving Kolkata on Tuesday evening, Banerjee had told reporters: “Ours is a country where we need to stay together. I am deeply disturbed. I am deeply concerned. I do not know what is going on there. We, the people of India, want peace. I appeal to all, please restore peace.”

In Odisha, speculations are rife on the discussion points between Banerjee and Naveen since they are on the opposite ends of the CAA divide. “Mamata ji will pay a courtesy call to the Odisha CM. There is no fixed agenda in the one-on-one meeting,” said sources in the CMO in Bhubaneswar.

The sources added that the current political situations in the wake of violence in Delhi over CAA may figure in the brief meeting.

The same day, Shah is scheduled to address a pro-CAA rally at Janata Maidan in Bhubaneswar, the first such rally to be addressed by the home minister after the latest CAA violence in New Delhi.

(With inputs from Kolkata)

Title: Barcoded invitation cards for Trinamool programme on March 2
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Midnapore/Kolkata: From the man on the street to audiences in swanky auditoriums, Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee is comfortable with all. She connects with them at ease. But TMC this time has come up with a stunt that has sprung a surprise on party ranks.

TMC has issued a barcoded invitation card bearing the invitee’s name for the party programme at Netaji Indoor Stadium on March 2. Issued by name to party organisers from block party president to MLAs, MPs and ministers, it looks like a corporate card.

Captioned ‘AITC event launch’, the card bears Banerjee’s photograph and a barcode, and mentions the invitee’s name and organisational post. It also specifies the gate through which s/he should enter and the gallery where s/he should take the seat. An advisory, printed overleaf, says the invitee has to enter through the designated gate 15 minutes ahead of the 10am programme, collect the food coupon against the card and keep the counterfoil while taking a seat.

Banerjee is likely to present the civic campaign’s salient features to party organisers at the programme.

TMC seniors suggest the card was designed to ensure the invitees were in attendance. “There have been instances of the card being transferred to others. This should not happen,” said party spokesperson Partha Chatterjee.

TMC sources said party leaders are doing their best to tackle TMC-Yuva Trinamool squabbles that have hit the streets in several parts of Bengal. Party seniors don’t want any trouble during the March 2 programme. One of them said the barcode has been introduced to track the distribution of cards and quickly spot the zone and person in charge during an exigency.

Title: Yechury seeks to meet Prez, present views of opposition
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Kolkata: CPM and other Left parties hit the city’s streets on Wednesday evening, raising slogans against the “divisive politics of religion” in keeping with the tradition of secular politics in West Bengal.

The rally was taken out against the communal conflagration in northeast Delhi that has triggered tension in certain areas of Kolkata and its suburbs. Left Front chairman Biman Bose led the march from Entally market to Park Circus Maidan, an area with a strong presence of the minority community.

Left functionaries sent out a word of caution against the Modi-Shah regime and its attempt to provide citizenship based on religious identity (CAA) followed by National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). They said CAA-NPR-NRC are all part of a sinister design to drive a wedge between communities with the aim to polarise people on the lines of “us and them”.

CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury has sought an appointment with President Ram Nath Kovind to apprise him of the opposition’s views on the “very disturbing situation prevailing in the country’s capital”. CPI, SP, DMK and NCP functionaries are likely to accompany Yechury to Rashtrapati Bhavan.

Title: BJP workers protest in front of Babul’s house
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Asansol: Disgruntled BJP members protested at junior Union minister Babul Supriyo’s doorstep in Asansol on Wednesday morning to vent their anger against the former Asansol-Durgapur BJP district president.

The demonstrators, from various mandals, were demanding division of the district into two based on the Asansol and Durgapur Lok Sabha seats.

They alleged that the former district president was trying to pack the district committee with his handpicked men while the deserving ones were left out.

Supriyo found it “nothing unusual” in politics. He asked the demonstrators to send him their complaints to let him try to resolve the issue.

Title: Mumbai: Mahim to get back 25,000 sq ft ground 'misused' as parking lot for a decade
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Work on developing Ram Gawande Udyan is on, say civic officials

MUMBAI: Soon, Mahim residents will be able to play volleyball , practise yoga and go for walks on a 25,000-sq-ft recreation ground that was earlier being 'misused' as a parking lot by locals for almost a decade.

Recently, the BMC took over Ram Gawande Udyan in Bhandar gully, which is marked as a recreation ground in the revised draft Development Plan-2034, and placed signboards asking locals not to park there. Work has started on developing the recreation ground, which will be ready in a few months, said a civic official.

The amenity plot was to be handed over to the BMC by the developer after completion of a Slum Rehabilitation Project (SRA) project nearly 10 years ago, but it never happened. "Unfortunately, the location of the amenity plot is such that it provides the sole access path to a building. So, when drawing up the plan to develop the recreation ground, we had to keep in mind the convenience of the residents of this building," said the officer.

Kiran Dighavar, ward officer of G-North which covers Mahim area, said: "We found that many local youths would play volleyball on the open space even when vehicles were parked there. So, we decided to incorporate a space for them in the garden plan. We are also working out a way for emergency services, like ambulance and fire engines, to reach the building that has access only from the ground."

Local corporator Sheetal Gambhir from the BJP said she had been pushing to reclaim this space for public use since a long time. "There is no recreation ground in the area, therefore reclaiming this plot to benefit the locals is important. We plan to create a designated space for walkers and joggers, a seating area for senior citizens and yoga lawns," she added.

Title: Coronavirus update: 119 Indians, 5 foreigners from coronavirus-hit Japan cruise ship land in Delhi on Air India flight
Content:
Indian nationals on special Air India flight sent to Japan for their repatriation to India.

Air India flight has just landed in Delhi from Tokyo,carrying 119 Indians & 5 nationals from Sri Lanka,Nepal, South… https://t.co/sbIQUNUO8W — Dr. S. Jaishankar (@DrSJaishankar) 1582759207000 NEW DELHI: A special Air India flight carrying 119 Indians and five nationals from Sri Lanka, Nepal, South Africa and Peru, who were on board the coronavirus-hit quarantined cruise ship Diamond Princess, landed in New Delhi on Thursday morning.covidIndia thanked Japanese authorities for facilitating the evacuation of people."Air India flight has just landed in Delhi from Tokyo, carrying 119 Indians & 5 nationals from Sri Lanka, Nepal, South Africa and Peru who were quarantined onboard the #DiamondPrincess due to #COVID19. Appreciate the facilitation of Japanese authorities. Thank you @airindiain once again," tweeted external affairs minister S Jaishankar.As many as 138 Indians including 132 crew and six passengers were among the 3,711 people on board the luxury cruise ship, which was quarantined off Japan on February 5 after it emerged that a former passenger had tested positive for the virus.Of these, 16 were tested positive for coronavirus and will stay in Japan for treatment, while the remaining will be repatriated to India.The repatriation is being facilitated by the Indian government.Coronavirus has infected more than 80,000 people in 37 countries, causing more than 2,600 deaths in the past few months.Earlier this month, India had evacuated as many as 640 of its nationals from Wuhan - the capital of the Chinese province of Hubei which has been the epicentre of the novel coronavirus.In Video: Covid-19: 119 Indians, 5 foreigners from quarantined cruise ship land in Delhi on Air India flight

Title: Delhi: Parking lot at Sadar Bazar to unclog roads
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

File photo of Sadar Bazar MCD parking in Delhi

NEW DELHI: Taking a cue from a similar project in Chandni Chowk, north corporation has initiated work on a multilevel-parking-cum-commercial complex at Qutab Road in Sadar Bazar . The concessionaire engaged for the job had begun excavation work at the site, a corporation official said, adding that the project was key to decongesting the Old Delhi area.

"The structure will have seven floors, including two basements and five upper floors. The ground and the first floors will be used by the concessionaire to develop a commercial complex. The remaining floors will have parking space for 174 vehicles," the official said.

Jai Prakash, north corporation standing committee chairman, said the project had been conceived on a public-private partnership basis and the civic agency would not have to spend a single penny on it. "On the one hand, it will help reduce congestion on roads and, on the other, generate revenue for us. We have provided 1,300 sqm of land to the company that is developing the facility. It will pay Rs 30 crore in three instalments to the corporation by October 2020. In addition, we expect to get Rs 75 lakh annually as lease rent," he said.

As per the terms and conditions of the project, space for 130 vehicles will be transferred to the corporation after five years. "We will arrange for running this parking lot on our own after five years. But the shops will be used entirely by the concessionaire," Prakash said.

A civic official said after the traders' association recently moved high court over the parking problems in the area, a meeting was called by MoHUA secretary where it was decided that the civic agency take up the project immediately.

The traders, however, have now pursued the civic agency to increase the height of the structure from the proposed 15 metres for the project to be successful. Dev Raj Baweja, general secretary of Confederation of Sadar Bazar Traders' Association, said: "Parking is a major issue in Sadar Bazaar. The plan is good, but we need more space. When over 1,000 cars are parked on the road daily, how will making space for 174 vehicles help?"

Title: Kolkata: Chitpore level crossing may open on March 1; to ease Tallah traffic
Content:
Once operational, the new alignment will provide relief to goods vehicles, who are currently not being allowed... Read More

KOLKATA: The level crossing at the Chitpore railway yard is likely to be thrown open on the first day of the next month. In case there is a sudden delay, the administration said it should be ready before the higher secondary exams that are scheduled towards the end of the second week of March.Once operational, the new alignment will provide relief to goods vehicles, who are currently not being allowed in the area for most part of the day. Though a detailed plan is awaited, good vehicles are expected to use the Strand Bank Road-Sarbamangala Ghat-Cossipore alignment.The cops and transport department are also planning an alternative auto route from Cossipore to Bagbazar using this alignment for maximum use of the new link in the day time. The move will also help decongest the highways and its approaches, where trucks are getting stuck after not being able to enter the city due to various prevailing restrictions on their movement.While the lane widening and strengthening, alongside concretization, which was required immediately near the railway tracks is mostly over, parallel work by railways on the tracks is almost reaching an end. The all-important rail gate and the necessary gateman’s room, too, have come up.While the railways concretized around 200m of the road around the railway tracks in order to allow movement of heavy trucks, the KMC has created around 300m of new road besides the widening of the existing road. Two shops and a couple of godowns, too, were pulled down to complete the work, claimed local sources.The proposed level-crossing will connect the Braja Dayal Shah Road located next to the Cossipore Bridge with Sethpukur Road and Pranakrishna Mukherjee Road on the Bagbazar side. Cops are making some last moment changes on the K C Chatterjee Road, which is expected to handle heavy traffic at night.Police said the road will be crucial for traffic flow in the morning as it allows two-way movements. “While trucks can use this to enter the Chitpur terminal, smaller vehicles can use it if the Belgachhia bridge witnesses too much jam,” said an officer.The state government had earlier consulted the railway to ensure there were no operational glitches and that necessary clearances were made available from the railway board before the level crossing was built across the tracks.The cops said they are also trying to see if the Khagen Chatterjee Road can continue handling the extra pressure. “Using this road has eased the traffic. Any new plan will involve a peak-hour traffic study. Every option is being studied in detail,” said a cop.

Title: Docu film to focus on city Jews’ ‘identity crisis’
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Kolkata: Identity crisis plaguing Kolkata’s Jewish community is the subject of Ilmaz Syed’s forthcoming documentary. This is one of the smallest communities of the city, with just around 20 members.

Titled ‘Beginning of an End’, the documentary bypasses nostalgic references to the Nahoums bakery and the beauty of stained glass synagogues to focus on the untold story of questioned identities and what it takes to be or not to be a Jew in today’s Kolkata.

Through interviews of prominent members of the community, Syed has explored the dynamics involving identity issues, motives of converts, ambitions of community leaders and conspiracy theories. “In the teaser, the city Jews have spoken about how identity issues based on prehistoric religious practices are being raked up inside the micro-community to get some elderly members of the community disqualified as authentic Jews. Some alleged that non-Jewish people are claiming false Jewish lineage expressing their claim over the Jewish property. While making this documentary, I came across the friction within the community, which is basically related to power and property issues.”

The teaser of the documentary has already created a stir. At the centre of this identity crisis is 74-year-old A M Cohen, the general secretary of the Jewish Community Affairs and secretary of the Board of the Jewish Girls’ School. According to the Jewish religious laws, a person is a Jew if the mother is Jewish. “My husband was Jewish and I converted to Judaism after my marriage in 1970. My conversion was accepted by all members of my community down the years. Recently, questions have been raised because I have become a thorn in the efforts to sell assets,” said Cohen.

Complexities regarding conversion add layers to the movie’s content. “Once you renounce the Jewish faith, you can no longer be considered Jewish. Interestingly, those supporting that these people now be recognised as Jews are doubting my conversion. But, they haven’t even seen my conversion papers,” she added. In her opinion, the current identity crisis is a “tool” being used by some to “remove” her from the position she holds.

The teaser has video recordings of Ian Zachariah, a prominent community member who has “resigned” from all posts because he “didn’t endorse the way things were moving on the question of assets”. “Her conversion is now being brought up since she is coming in the way for many,” Zachariah told TOI.

Also lending his voice in the teaser is Shillong’s David R Ashkenazy. The honorary secretary of the Maghen David Synagogue and the president and trustee of Beth El Synagogue, Ashkenazy told TOI: “Earlier, those who were half-Jewish in origin were all working as a part of the community. The identity issue has weakened us further when the community members starting using arguments like who is Jew and who is not and who is a Kolkata Jew and who isn’t one. By doing this, we have created the opportunity for others to cease something that they can gain from us. I hope the frictions we have faced will be sorted out and apprehensions over Jewish identity issues will soon be laid to rest.”

Title: How cops in Ghaziabad stopped mob in its tracks
Content:
This story is from February 27, 2020

Ghaziabad SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun

GHAZIABAD: Just 100 metres from police barricades at the border, a slogan-shouting mob of 10 went from house to house in Delhi's Karawal Nagar on Tuesday afternoon, knocking on doors.

Moments before this group had turned into the alley, the police team stationed on the other side of the border - in Ghaziabad 's Lal Bagh - had seen a family secure themselves inside one of the Karawal Nagar houses.

In a sudden burst of violence, the mob set on fire like expert arsonists a bike and a Scooty, a car and an e-rickshaw parked in the alley.

When they got no response from the houses, they decided to hit back by smashing glass bottles filled with fuel into the walls. It didn't take long for the UP Police team to realise Molotov cocktails would be next. They only had a few seconds to save whoever was within those walls.

Ghaziabad's SP (rural) Neeraj Kumar Jadaun , who held charge at the border checkpoint set up to stop any movement between Delhi and UP, made the decision. He crossed the border and dashed towards the mob. Subdivisional magistrate (Loni) Khalid Anjum, circle officer Rajkumar Pandey and around 30 other policemen followed. They were in anti-riot gear. The mob retreated after cops threatened a lathi charge.

"We couldn't just stand and see a group of rioters come and set fire to houses before our eyes," Jadaun told TOI on Wednesday. "When no one in the houses opened the doors, the mob was preparing to throw a bottle of petrol. Seeing this, we immediately made the decision to cross the border. I didn't think whether the house was in Delhi or Ghaziabad at the time or whether I have the jurisdiction to protect or not. As a police officer, it is my duty to protect every citizen of the country," he added.

Once the mob had retreated, the Ghaziabad police team went back to its post and did what protocol demanded: report the incident to Delhi Police. "We called Delhi Police but they didn't respond to the situation. That was most surprising," Jadaun said.

Anjum said the Ghaziabad team got pelted with stones by the mob. "But when police and the administration displayed unity to save the houses, the mob stopped and retreated. For the last two days, not a single cop from Delhi was deployed at the border to maintain law and order. When we called Delhi Police, they told us they were busy with security arrangements for the visit of (US President) Donald Trump. It was only on Tuesday night that senior Delhi policemen came to the Karawal Nagar-Lal Bagh border and appreciated the work done by Ghaziabad police and the administration," Anjum said.

But even after that, a fresh security threat cropped us as mobs from Delhi made multiple attempts to breach the barricades and create trouble in Lal Bagh. The first attempt was made around 10pm on Tuesday by a group of around 40. They were thwarted. Around midnight and 3am, two more mobs made similar attempts but were foiled both times. UP Police had increased deployment by then.

Ghaziabad SSP Kalanidhi Naithani told TOI, "There are 10 major border points between Ghaziabad and Delhi. The sensitive areas are Tulsiniketan, Shalimar Garden, Loni and Lal Bagh." No violence was reported in Ghaziabad where vigil has been stepped up in light of the Delhi riots.
